column2: Reviewing Jane Ziegelman's "97 Orchard" in today's Arts section, Dwight Garner talks entertainingly about the recent fad for "food historicism," predicting it will eventually yield titles like "1897: The Year the Oysters Tasted a Bit Dubious."

After a week in St. Andrews, Scotland, followed by a week in Ontario, Canada, some touring pros at the Greenbrier's Old White Course for this week's Greenbrier Classic may feel they have been transported back to a more elegant time and place.
Updated: Fixed a typo in the second paragraph

I unfortunately do not have the time today for a full post, but I wanted to follow up on my post on Tuesday about the dispute between Lions Gate Entertainment and Carl C. Icahn and my promise to comment on the British Columbia lawsuit as soon as I obtained the papers. Set forth below is a copy of the amended petition that Mr. Icahn's funds filed on with the Supreme Court of British Columbia, where the movie studio has its headquarters. This is the equivalent of a complaint filed in an American court.

With no more oil flowing into the Gulf of Mexico from the the blown-out BP well, the surface oil slick seems to be breaking down rapidly, as Campbell Robertson and I report in Wednesday's paper. That the surface oil would fade away is no surprise: scientists have long understood how oil weathers and dissipates in the environment.

A Brooklyn photographer is suing the producers of the Broadway musical "Fela!" in federal court for copyright and trademark infringement, seeking at least $150,000 in damages for their use of her 1977 photograph of the legendary Nigerian nightclub of the Afrobeat musician Fela Kuti.

This week, in conjunction with Math for America, we're providing math problems based on Times articles. Today's question was written by Patrick Honner at MfA, based on a Times article by Justin Gillis about the Gulf oil spill.

Updated, 11:36 a.m. Thursday | The $104 monthly MetroCard moved one step closer to reality on Wednesday as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted to start the process of implementing a sprawling set of fare increases on the region's buses, trains and bridges.

From the porch of my cabin here at the Palmyra Atoll National Wildlife Refuge in the Central Pacific my eyes take in an iconic tropical island paradise - white, sandy beaches; palm trees swaying in the gentle breeze; sea birds diving into the water and big fish jumping out of the water ... and I know just around the corner are gorgeous coral reefs teeming with brightly colored fish in the crystal blue sea. We are smack in the middle of nowhere, just above the equator in the Pacific - about a thousand miles south of Hawaii.

Perhaps if I had been able to fix this image in my mind a month ago, I would have survived the dog days of July with a little more ... well, cool. When Judy and Ted Goldsmith approached Madderlake Designs to design a pool at their house on the Long Island shore about a decade ago, the brief was as follows: Include a lap pool for Ted and a wading pool for Judy and the grandchildren, and make it all invisible from the house. "All they wanted to see was waving grasses," said Tom Pritchard, a partner in Madderlake, which started out in 1971 as an elegant plant store with an architectural practice on the side, and which is now a thriving architecture and landscape design firm, with projects from Connecticut to Colorado.

Jason and Justin Sablich, The Times's in-house fantasy football experts, are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Brothers Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season and are now on Twitter.

I was about to post a hail-and-farewell to the veteran journalist Daniel Schorr, who died last week, not only because of his long and distinguished broadcast career, but also because I'd heard him capably analyzing the news on NPR's "Weekend Edition" just a couple of weeks ago. He was about to turn 94.
Today, oil on the Gulf's surface is clearing up faster than expected, a Russian policeman uses YouTube to battle corruption and New York City begins a grading system to keep restaurants in check.

They may be only the paintings and other artworks created by a well-known rock 'n' roll guitarist, but the Butler Institute of American Art likes them -- enough to give Ronnie Wood of the Rolling Stones an eight-week exhibition there that the museum says is the first American show of Mr. Wood's art.
If New York's state budget passes, tourists could wind up paying more for hotels booked through third parties like Liberty Travel, Globus Tours and Travelocity.

I've seen a lot of new point-and-shoot cameras over the past couple of weeks as camera makers announce their new summer lineups. A few have demonstrated solid new improvements that should deliver better photos. But one feature that I had been hoping to see -- a built-in GPS receiver for geo-tagging photos -- wasn't offered on a single new camera.
For years, chess players have bemoaned that chess is not as popular as poker, particularly when it comes to attracting television coverage.
Here's where the tech reporters and editors of the New York Times paused on the Web:
Ever get overwhelmed trying to keep up with all the information available online about stocks and what that information could mean for your investments?

New Delhi -- PayPal's business in India has hit another barrier. This week the company told customers here, which include thousands of small Internet businesses with foreign clients, that beginning Aug. 1 they will no longer be able to transfer cash electronically from the online payment network into their local bank accounts. Instead, PayPal will send them a check.

Yale Repertory Theater is on a fund-raising hot streak. After announcing last week that it had received a $950,000 donation from the Robina Foundation, the theater said on Tuesday that it had received a $1 million gift from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation aimed at supporting new commissions and productions under the auspices of the Yale Center for New Theater.
-The Coco & Igor star, Anna Mouglalis, questions whether Coco Chanel would have approved of the film. At least she doesn't have to question how disappointed Karl Lagerfeld was.

In his latest Political Times column, The Times's Matt Bai considers how recent efforts from Peter Orszag, the outgoing budget director, and other White House officials appear to have "signaled that an administration populated from the top down by Capitol Hill alumni is intent on altering the balance of power between the branches of government." Post a Comment

Updated, 1:28 p.m. | The retired judge investigating Gov. David A. Paterson's intervention in a domestic violence case involving a former top aide will not recommend any charges against the governor, according to a report released on Wednesday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission apparently no longer has to comply with requests for information from the public, including those filed under the Freedom of Information Act, because of a little-noticed provision in the new financial regulations that became law last week, the Fox Business Network reports.

Perhaps lies loom larger in the open air. I have rarely been as conscious of the levels of duplicity in the "Henry IV" plays as I was on Sunday at Shakespeare's Globe, where I saw a double header of Dominic Dromgoole's productions of Parts I and II. It was a good day for theater al fresco: sunny, breezy, achingly clear. Only man - that great pretender -- was vile, at least as embodied on the stage, which of course made the six hours it takes to perform "Henry IV: Parts I and II" pass all the faster.
Nearly a half-century after little Mini took on the mighty of automobile rally racing, and beat them, the brand is about to get down in the mud - and gravel and wet -- once again.
Last night, I fell into a deep sleep almost as soon as my head hit the pillow.
She didn’t hit her stride until her mid-30s. Can her new role  in a dark TV comedy make her a middle-aged success?

With a cap on carbon dioxide an apparent nonstarter in the Senate these days, some clean energy and climate advocates have shifted their sights to a scaled-back but still ambitious goal: passage of a national renewable electricity standard.
Co-vocabularists have noted that some recent comments have disappeared. Technical boffins are ascertaining why. Normal service will be resumed as soon as possible.

Data drives policy. Or, at least, it should. In recent months there have been several studies suggesting that children raised by same-sex couples are certainly no worse off (and in some ways are arguably better off) than children raised by heterosexual couples.

"Having one foot firmly placed in the fashion world with the other in the world of technology is my biggest asset at this point," says Tarik Malak, the Parisian-born owner of digital media's freshest face, Swell NY. Malak has already made a name for himself with La Boutique, the company he co-founded and brought to the forefront of the photo retouching world, working with clients like Diane von Furstenberg, Redken and Swarovski. With the switch from still photography to moving images being one of the most relevant topics of discussion in the fashion world today, this new agency finds itself in a fantastic position.
The sunsetting of a 2002 agreement on community gardens has some advocates and bloggers feeling like Paul Revere.
Tightening skin, stiffening joints, digestive difficulties and shortness of breath — six people with scleroderma speak.
Since Laurent Blanc was named coach of France, he has introduced a sense of accountability lacking under his predecessor, Raymond Domenech.
Social relationships are just as important to health as other common risk factors like smoking, lack of exercise or obesity, new research shows.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

In a moment of cultural bipartisanship that political wags (i.e., the anchors on ABC's "Good Morning America") are already referring to as "the Diva and the Diplomat," Aretha Franklin and Condoleezza Rice teamed up on Tuesday night at the Mann Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia for a concert to benefit inner-city youth programs and education initiatives. A review of the concert by Steve Smith will follow; in the meantime, The Associated Press has posted the above video package which features Ms. Franklin and Ms. Rice's duet on "I Say a Little Prayer." (Only one performer sings, and it's the one you're expecting.)
Whatever the antique vessel was, and whenever in the 18th century it arrived on the Lower Manhattan waterfront, one thing can be said almost certainly: Its journey in was easier than its journey out.

More than 800,000 gallons of oil spill from a ruptured pipeline into the waterways of southwest Michigan -- the largest oil spill ever in the Midwest, Environmental Protection Agency officials say. [WBEZ]
For the second time, Cheyenne Jackson has been cast in a key role on "Glee." And he says he's really looking forward to making his first appearance on the show.

President's Itinerary: Mr. Obama is traveling today to Edison, N.J., to have lunch with small-business owners and discuss the economy and small-business legislation in Congress. Afterward, the president will attend two Democratic Party fund-raisers in New York City. The Wall Street Journal estimates that about 50 people are expected to attend each fund-raiser, each paying $30,400, which is the maximum individual contribution permissible in a two-year election cycle. Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue Magazine, is hosting one event at her home. The guests will have a chance to meet one-on-one with Mr. Obama, who, as the Journal noted, is up to "a tough task given the many Wall Street executives who are put off by his rhetoric and policies."  On his quick trip, the president will also sit down for an interview on ABC's "The View."

Just a quick note: I thought it might be worth doing an Irons-Bivens plot for Japan (and, to be honest, I wanted to see if I had finally managed to trick a spreadsheet into labeling the data points!). So here it is (data from IMF WEO database):
David Cameron's description of Britain's relationship with the United States.

The number of prekindergarten students acing the city's gifted and talented test spiked this year, with 1,000 4- and 5-year-olds reaching the 99th percentile, the highest possible, on the nationally scaled exam, the Department of Education said on Tuesday.

12:12 p.m. | Updated with Couche-Tard statement Casey's General Stores said on Wednesday that it has rejected the latest hostile offer by Alimentation Couche-Tard and will instead buy back up to 25 percent of its outstanding shares.
What we're reading this morning:
Sigmund Bloom writes for Footballguys.com and hosts a podcast there with Cecil Lammey. You can follow him on Twitter.

Updated | 10:14 a.m. As my colleague Adam Ellick reports, a Pakistani passenger plane "crashed atop the hills near the capital, Islamabad, amid thick fog and intense rain on Wednesday morning, killing all 152 people on board."
The National Council on Aging has released a poll showing that a majority of senior citizens are uninformed about the impact of the federal health care law on Medicare and Medicaid benefits.
Be forewarned, Al Pacino - it looks as if there's another Academy Award-winner who's trying to out-Shylock your Shylock.

On Sunday night, my wife and I settled in to watch "Mad Men" and we realized that it had been weeks since we had sat on our sofa. Our living room is an island without air-conditioning, and the July heat wave has forced us to abandon this room completely for cooler climes. (It was either that or prowl the streets before dawn.)

It's one of the hottest concepts to emerge from the discussions about how best to overhaul the nation's health care system: accountable care organizations. The idea is to encourage groups of doctors or hospitals to work together to oversee medical care so quality improves and costs go down. Having captured the fancy of Washington, the organizations are even a part of the new health care law.
Hard on the heels of the Senate Democratic leadership's decision to put aside climate legislation intended to cap carbon dioxide emissions, another carbon-capping precinct was heard from this week.

It's all about semantics. On a conference call Tuesday, BP said it was planning to "high-grade" its assets -- newspeak for selling off whatever it must to keep its balance sheet in balance. That's just one of the steps the oil giant will take as it embarks on what one hopes will be a safer chapter in its history. The full blueprint is here.

Those of us who say that the stimulus was too small are often accused of after-the-fact rationalization: you said this would work, but now that it hasn't, you're just saying it wasn't big enough. The quick answer to that accusation is that people like me said that the stimulus was too small in advance. But the longer answer is that it's all in the math: Keynesian analysis provides numbers as well as qualitative predictions, and given reasonable projections of the economy's path in January 2009, the proposed stimulus just wasn't big enough. Let's go back to the tape, January 9, 2009:

On Wednesday, as the New York City health department begins letter-grading restaurant inspections, designating an A, B or C to rate the cleanliness of more than 24,000 restaurants in the five boroughs, it is also activating a new Web site that will "offer much more information and be more user-friendly," said Daniel Kass, a deputy commissioner.
Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is the darling of United States millionaires, or at least those in Tiger 21, a peer investment group, Bloomberg News reports.

UnitedHealth Group is nearing an agreement to buy Executive Health Resources, a medical services firm backed by Abry Partners, for about $1.5 billion, three people with knowledge of the talks told Bloomberg News.

Hong Kong on Wednesday auctioned a plot of land for 10.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1.3 billion) in its third-most expensive land sale, beating forecasts and adding to fears of a bubble in one of the world's hottest property markets, Reuters reported.
UCI International, a supplier of replacement parts for light and heavy-duty vehicles, is looking to raise as much as $200 million in an initial public offering, Renaissance Capital reported.

The Roots' daily gig as the house band for “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” doesn't keep them from playing huge shows in Prospect Park or DJ-ing in Williamsburg.  Melena Ryzik reports.

Thai Union Frozen Products, a seafood exporter, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy MW Brands, a tuna canner, from Trilantic Capital Partners to form one of the world's largest seafood companies. The deal values MW Brands at 680 million euros, or $884 million.

RAB Capital, the London-based hedge fund, reported a pretax loss which widened from last year as clients continued to pull out cash after a volatile summer for equity markets, and warned that asset gathering remains tough, Reuters reported.

Citigroup may move a team of proprietary traders into its hedge-fund unit, one of at least three alternatives the bank is studying to comply with the Dodd-Frank Act, Bloomberg News reported, citing people briefed on the matter.
Bank of Moscow said Tuesday that it had raised up to 21.7 billion rubles ($718 million) in a share issue whose buyers included Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse.

The parent company of United Airlines won unconditional regulatory approval from the European Union on Tuesday for its $3.17 billion buy of Continental Airlines that will create the world's largest carrier, Reuters reported.

Housing officials at colleges and universities are finding that roommates are having difficulties resolving their differences because they feel uncomfortable having face-to-face conversations. Do you find it easier to converse with friends via text or instant message instead of in person?

Telefónica of Spain won full control of the mobile phone joint venture it had with Portugal Telecom in Brazil after raising its bid for a third time, to 7.5 billion euros, thereby overcoming opposition from the Portuguese government, Raphael Minder reports in The New York Times.

Hess Corporation, a United States energy company, said Tuesday that it would acquire the independent American Oil & Gas in an all-stock deal worth about $445 million as it expands its holdings in the Bakken oil play of North Dakota by around 85,000 acres.

A botched share swap last month in which 10 times more U.S. Bancorp shares were issued than planned, angering and confusing investors, led the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday to cancel three days of trades in the stock.

Athletes are a notoriously superstitious lot. For years, Michael Jordan wore the shorts from his national-championship-winning University of North Carolina days under his Chicago Bulls uniform. Serena Williams won't change her socks at tournaments she's winning. Other professional athletes carry lucky charms or perform rituals, like bouncing a basketball in elaborate sequences before a free throw or kissing the golf ball before a putt. Jason Giambi (the former Yankee and current Colorado Rockies first baseman) has said that he slips on a pair of "lucky" thong underwear when his batting average falls. The thong's reputation is so potent that slumping teammates reportedly beg to borrow it.

ULLMAN--Frank L.,b. October 25, 1913, passed away peacefully on July 26, 2010 at the age of 96. Frank, his wife Emily, who pre-deceased him on October 25, 2000, survived the Holocaust in hiding in Amsterdam, Holland and immigrated to the U.S. with their two sons in 1947. Shortly thereafter, he helped establish the Nassau Stores, a chain of five and ten cent stores on Long Island which closed in the 1980s. Frank then worked for 23 years at the Manhasset (New York) Public Library, where he became the oldest paid library employee in the country prior to his retirement in 2009. He loved music, books, language and his family. He owed much in a long wonderful life to the Unitarian Universalist Congregation, to the Manhasset Public Library, and to many community organizations in Port Washington. He is survived by sons Leo and Henry, six grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren.

HUNTINGTON--Robert H. Jr.,a retired advertising and investment banking executive, died Monday, July 26 at Greenwich Hospital, after a long illness. He was 73. Mr. Huntington was born in New York, New York. He grew up in Wayne, Pennsylvania, outside of Philadelphia, and graduated from the Haverford School in 1955. He was received a B.S. degree from Cornell University in 1959, and an M.B.A. from the Wharton School of Business in 1961. After serving on active duty in the U.S. Army Reserves, he joined Compton Advertising in New York in 1962. He began his career in account management on the Procter and Gamble account. He later became chief financial officer and chief operating officer. After negotiating the sale of Compton to Saatchi and Saatchi, a large publicly traded holding company based in London, he became chairman and chief executive officer of the Saatchi and Saatchi Compton Group, a group of specialized advertising agencies and marketing services. In 1988, he was named Vice Chairman and Chief Operating Officer of DDB Needham Worldwide. He was actively involved in the agency's acquisition program worldwide and was a member of its board of directors. He also was a director of Omnicom, the parent company of DDB Needham. In 1992, he became a partner in AdMedia Partners in New York, a boutique investment bank working for marketing, advertising and publishing companies. Until his retirement in 2005, he was the principal advisor on mergers and acquisitions to a number of advertising agencies. Bob and his family were long time residents of Rye, New York. He was an active golfer and board member at the Apawamis Club. He was also a member of the University Club in New York. Mr. Huntington also served on the Board of Advisors at the Wharton School of Business. He is survived and will be missed by his loving wife, Ellie, and their children: Robert H. Huntington III and his wife Katherine of New York City; Thomas Andrew Huntington and his wife Melissa of Oakland, California; and Betsy Gallagher and her husband Jim of Rye, along with five grandchildren, Amanda and John Huntington, Ben Huntington, and Emma and Georgia Gallagher. Mr. Huntington's brother, Stephen and his wife Susan reside in Philadelphia. Bob was loved and respected by all who knew him, both personally and professionally. His enthusiasm and ready laugh will be sorely missed. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 on Thursday from 3pm to 6pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Friday, July 30 at 10:30am at The Church of the Resurrection in Rye. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to POTS Soup Kitchen or the Alzheimer's Foundation of America.

CAPE TOWN -- It was another picture-perfect wedding at the foot of Table Mountain, recalled the Rev. Daniel Brits. Inside the chapel, a female vocalist sang ''Wind Beneath My Wings'' before he led the nervous couple through their vows surrounded by family and friends a few weeks ago. That the betrothed were two men gave few of the guests pause. For Mr. Brits, it was all in a day's work. After all, he says, he has married more than 500 gay couples in the four years since South Africa became the first country in the Southern Hemisphere to legalize same-sex marriage, a distinction that ended only this month when Argentina did the same.

An article on July 12 about the New York Police Department's tactic known as ''Stop, Question, Frisk'' and its application in eight blocks of Brownsville, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to the legal standard that governs when police officers are permitted to frisk someone. The United States Supreme Court has held that in order for the police to frisk someone they must have a reasonable belief that the person is armed and dangerous. The standard cited in the article -- reasonable suspicion of a crime -- is enough to justify a stop, but not enough to make a legal frisk.

An article on Monday about the upcoming wedding of Chelsea Clinton in Rhinebeck, N.Y., misstated the occupation and gender of one of the two Norwegian journalists accused of trespassing on the Astor Courts estate, which is assumed to be the location of the wedding. Kjersti Sortland, a woman, is a newspaper editor -- not a photographer. (The other Norwegian journalist is a photographer.)

A headline on Tuesday about the stock market's performance on Monday attributed an erroneous distinction to the closing prices of the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq exchange. At the close on Monday, the Dow index and Nasdaq were higher than they were at the start of the year, but not at their highest points of the year. (The Dow reached 11,205.03, its highest point so far this year, on April 26, the same day that the Nasdaq closed at 2,531.51, its highest so far this year.)

ROSE--Clare F. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors, volunteers, medical staff and employees of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center mourn the passing or our long time friend and benefactor, Clare F. Rose. Clare's vision, generosity and dedication to the growth and future of our Hospital was immeasurable and greatly appreciated. Clare was the father of Board of Directors member Ric Rose, and grandfather of Board of Directors member Lisa Rose. We extend our heart-felt condolences to the entire Rose family. Clare F. Rose will be sorely missed by his friends at Brookhaven. Thomas Ockers, President and CEO Sharon Norton Remmer, Chairwoman of the Board of Directors

NOYES--Molly. Mary Duncan Weed Noyes (Molly) died on July 25, 2010 in New Canaan, CT. She was born on September 23, 1915 in Boston MA. Molly Noyes trained as an architect at the Cambridge School of Architecture in Cambridge, MA. She worked in close association with her husband, architect and industrial designer Eliot Noyes of the Harvard Five, and was largely responsible for interior design for their multiple clients which included many leading American corporations such as IBM, Xerox, Mobil, and Westinghouse, but extended to libraries, schools and residences. She was known for her unerring eye for quality, and intuitive spatial awareness, and for making warm, comfortable spaces. Her husband predeceased her. She is survived by her four children: Mary Duncan Brust (Meridee): Eliot, Jr., (Eli): Frederick; and Margaret Noyes Craig (Derry). She is also survived by ten grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. She will be interred at the family burial plot in Abel's Hill Cemetery in Chilmark, MA.

WASHINGTON -- The House of Representatives agreed on Tuesday to provide $59 billion to continue financing America's two wars, but the vote showed deepening divisions and anxiety among Democrats over the course of the nearly nine-year-old conflict in Afghanistan. The 308-to-114 vote, with strong Republican support, came after the leak of an archive of classified battlefield reports from Afghanistan that fueled new debate over the course of the war and whether President Obama's counterinsurgency strategy could work.

MORRIS--Eugene J.,died peacefully on July 24, 2010 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Born in Manhattan on October 14, 1910, he was the beloved father of Dick Morris. Gene was married to the late Terry Morris for 59 years and to the late Blanche Morris for 14 years. He graduated from City College (1931) and St. John's University School of Law (1934). During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army. After the war, Gene was a founding partner of Demov and Morris, where he practiced real estate law for more than 54 years. He was a pioneer in urban renewal and instrumental in the development of many New York City projects, including Lincoln Center. He was a prolific writer of books and articles, including 26 volumes of Real Property practice books for Matthew Bender and a weekly real estate Column for the New York Law Journal for twenty-five years. He served as a Special Master for N.Y. State Supreme Court Justice Bea Shainswit. He was active in the New York City, New York State, and American Bar Associations. From 1990-2007, he taught real estate Law at N.Y.U. A native New Yorker, he lived in the city he loved and help build all of his life. Gene was an inspiration to everyone who knew him. He was much loved and is already sorely missed. In addition to his son, Dick, he is survived by his daughter-in-law, Eileen McGann, and one granddaughter. Friends and family may call at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan on Thursday July 29, 2010 from 6-9 and for the funeral service at 11:30am on Friday, July 30, 2010. In lieu of flowers, contributions to City College will be welcomed.

Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, Chancellor Julius Berman, Chair RIETS Board of Trustees Michael Jesselson, Co-Chair Yeshiva University Museum

Nearly all day laborers who gather for work in the Ironbound neighborhood of Newark have had employers who have either paid them less than promised or not paid them at all, according to a Seton Hall University report on wage theft and workplace conditions among day laborers. In addition, despite New Jersey state laws that grant day laborers the same legal protections that apply to all workers, the vast majority of day laborers in the Ironbound say that employers have failed to provide them with safety equipment, and at least 20 percent say they have been injured on the job, said the report (pdf), which is scheduled to be released Tuesday.
The system, from your first day at work, requires you to go out and obtain bribes. ALEKSEI DYMOVSKY, a former Russian policeman, in a video posted on YouTube. [A1]

The Bloomberg administration's years-long attempt to force the city's cab owners to switch from gas guzzlers to hybrid vehicles was rejected by a federal appeals court Tuesday morning. The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld a judge's 2009 ruling, in a suit brought by taxi fleet owners, that the city's rules amounted to an effort to mandate fuel economy and emissions standards, something that only the federal government is allowed to do.

We came expecting a picnic; we left knowing how to card wool and spin yarn. On Monday night, the High Line in Chelsea was the site of the Hipnic, an offbeat alfresco party held every two weeks at which some picnic while others dance to the jam of oddball instruments - the buzz of kazoos and the scritch-scratch syncopation of a washboard. And at 8 p.m., there the Hipnickers were - in a kink of the elevated railroad-turned-park around 17th Street - some hula hooping, others seated in a circle of slatted chairs.

PEABODY--Judy. The patients and staff of the Center for Special Studies at New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our remarkable friend, Judy Peabody. Judy was one of the heroes of the AIDS epidemic. Outraged by the discrimination against people suffering with AIDS, Judy stayed at the bedside of many whose families had abandoned them, and rallied her friends to support programming intended to help restore dignity as well as health. An elegant, soft-spoken person, Judy found a very powerful voice to advocate for the marginalized and vulnerable. She touched the lives of countless people around the nation through her work and example. Our program was founded with her determination and sustained by her love. We will miss her guidance, inspiration, and, above all, friendship. Our thoughts are with Sam, Elizabeth, and the other members of her family. Jonathan L. Jacobs M.D. Executive Director Samuel T. Merrick M.D. Medical Director

LEWIS--Mirjana, born Mirjana Vrbanic in Zagreb, Croatia, on February 20, 1936, died on Tuesday, July 20, 2010. A pianist and harpsichordist, she studied at the Zagreb Conservatory of Music, with Walda Aveling at Trinity College in London and, after moving to the U.S. in 1962, with Albert Fuller in New York City. She issued a solo recording of Scarlatti Sonatas in 1990 and made duo recordings with her late husband of 39 years, jazz pianist and composer John Lewis. She is survived by a sister, Lela; two children, Alexander and Nina; and five grandchildren.

ENDICO--Michael, Sr. died on July 26 at Greenwich Hospital from natural causes. He was the husband of the late Mary Endico of Rye, NY, father of William A. Endico of Armonk, NY, Michael Endico Jr. of Yonkers, NY, Frances Endico-Neubig of New Rochelle, NY and Felix W. Endico of Darien, CT. He is survived by six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. After serving in the Army during WWII at Fort Leonardwood, MO, he married his teenage sweetheart Mary LaRocco and helped his father expand a produce business which was established in 1934. The business grew exponentially after WWII when Mr. Endico and his brothers entered the business which morphed into one of the largest independent food processing company in the Eastern United States. Mr. Endico pioneered the French fry as we know it today. He built his own machines which are still used today. Originally setting up shop in the Bronx, Mr. Endico and his brothers expanded into farming and salad processing (Sally Sherman Salads). In 1951 Michael was the first Italian-American to buy a seat on the New York Mercantile Exchange where his brother Felix traded commodities for the company. Michael was a self made man who related to the man in the street as easily as he did in the board rooms of Del Monte where he was Vice President in 1967. Headquartered in Mount Vernon, Mr. Endico now has food processing operations in four states, employing over 300 in West- chester County. Michael served in the American Legion, Scarsdale, NY and was a member of Westchester Country Club where he resided for over 20 years. He will be missed for his good sense of humor that charmed the hearts of all that knew him. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580, on Wednesday from 1-5pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye on Thursday 10am

The Bronx isn't Kansas, but yes, Dorothy, that was a tornado that sent trees flying and utility poles crashing on Sunday afternoon. The National Weather Service says the twister churned through a half-mile slice of Riverdale with winds of 100 miles an hour for 10 minutes. By Tuesday, the weather historians were poring over the record books. Seven tornadoes have been confirmed in New York City since 1974. There were none in the city in the 24 years before that, according to the Weather Service's list of tornadoes since 1950 in the territory from Long Island to Orange and Putnam Counties.

CROCKETT--Todd H.,passed on July 25, 2010. He is survived by his loving wife, Rebecca; his sister, Alyssa; his mother, Karen K. Schwalm, and her husband, William; his father Bruce K. Crockett, and his wife Christine. He is also survived by his father-in-law, Bruce J. White, his sister and brother-in-law, Sarah and Brian Meisenzahl. Calling hours at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. will be Thursday 6-9pm. Funeral service to be held Friday at 9:30am.

SHEEBER--Edward. November 16, 1938 - July 26, 2010. A beloved father, grandfather, brother and friend. He gave us love and laughter. He will be missed everyday. Services Thursday, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

COYLE--Charles T. Of Greenwich, Connecticut passed away of natural causes on Monday, July 26, 2010. Charlie, as his friends called him, is survived by his beloved wife of 59 1/2 years, Julia Bruce Coyle and his four children Charles Thomas Coyle III, Christopher Bruce Coyle, Andrews Johnson Coyle, Julia Andrews Coyle, and eight grandchildren. Born in New York in 1927, Charlie graduated from Princeton University and Wharton School of Business. Charlie served as a Lt. (j.g.) in the US Navy during the Korean War. He had a distinguished career in senior business capacities with leading companies including Johnson & Johnson, American Home Products, RCA and most recently the New York Times, from which he retired in 1993. Charlie was an active and regular contributor around Greenwich. He served on Town committees for years including the Executive Committee and the Fire & Police Committee, and was a Director of the Round Hill Association. More recently, he was a volunteer at the Greenwich Hospital. Charlie was a member of the Union Club of New York, the Stanwich Club and the Johns Island Club in Indian River Shores, Florida. Charlie's friends and family will always warmly remember his creativity, wit and kindness. Charlie's love for his wife Julia and his passion for life are inspirations for all who were blessed to know him. A memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, July 31 at 10:00am at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church, in Greenwich, Connecticut.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about appearances by older movie stars at the Comic-Con International convention in San Diego misstated the number of years the event has been held. This was its 41st year, not its 40th.

KISSELOFF--Samuel J.,83, the loving husband of Judith Kayloe Kisseloff, died Sunday, July 25, in Lake Worth, FL. He is survived by his sons Alan S. Kisseloff (Nancy) of Ormond Beach, FL and Jeff Kisseloff (Susan) of New Paltz, NY and his four loving grandchildren. Mr. Kisseloff served as President of City and Suburban Federal Savings Bank, as well as its General Counsel. He was also counsel in the law firm of Rosenberg and Estes, P. C. Mr. Kisseloff was a community leader, having served on the Board of his beloved Cold Spring Country Club in every capacity, including President. Other offices he has held include the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Temple Emanuel in East Meadow, NY where he was a founding member and was later honored as a lifetime trustee. Mr. Kisseloff was an amateur thespian with a fondness for the theater as well as an avid golfer, jogger, and traveler. At the time of his death, he maintained residences in Lake Worth and Vonore, TN.

MIRVIS--Rabbi Allan. The Yeshiva University/Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) family is saddened by the passing of Rabbi Allan Mirvis in Jerusalem. He was an outstanding, loyal, rabbinic alumnus who served successfully for many years as the rabbi in Hampton, Virgina. He was then the Chaplain at the VA Hospital in Miami and after going on Aliyah--first worked at Shaare Zedek Hospital, and was then a successful and beloved teacher at a Geirut Program in Jerusalem. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his children, Dr. David M. (and Arlynn, a former Stern College for Women Board member) Mirvis, and YU Guardians, Theodore N. (and Ruth) Mirvis, who is Co-Chair of the Yeshiva University Museum and was a past member of the Yeshiva University High School Board, and established a scholarship in the High School in memory of his mother, Lena Sear Mirvis, and also to his second wife, Naomi Patinkin, and her children, the grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University and RIETS Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, Chancellor Julius Berman, Chair RIETS Board of Trustees Michael Jesselson, Co-Chair Yeshiva University Museum

GELB--Sally. The Trustees, management and staff of Jewish Home Lifecare extend their deepest sympathies to Lisa Feiner, Board Chair of Sarah Neuman Center, Jewish Home's Westchester Division, on the passing of her mother Sally Gelb. Sally was committed to the level of care and quality of life provided to the elders at Sarah Neuman and was personally involved in many programs and events. She will be missed by all who had the pleasure to know her. Our thoughts will be with Lisa and her family during their time of loss. Stanley H. Pantowich Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO

An article on July 19 about the Chinese government's new effort to censor television programming deemed salacious and materialistic referred incorrectly to a female contestant on a recent episode of the popular dating show ''If You Are the One,'' who gained notoriety by telling a possible date that she would rather cry in the back of a BMW than go on a bicycle ride with him. Subsequent references to the contestant, Ma Nuo, should have been Ms. Ma, not Ms. Nuo. (Chinese family names are usually written first.)

An article on July 13 about a newly published memoir by Peter Mandelson, a powerful adviser in Britain's Labour Party, misstated the number of seats separating Labour and the Conservative Party after the general elections on May 6. Labour finished 48 seats behind the Conservatives, not ''nearly 100 seats.'' (The Conservatives won 306 and Labour 258.)

Democrats attempting to wrap up work on a small business jobs bill were stymied Thursday morning when they were unable to break a Republican filibuster. In calling for a vote to end debate on the bill, Harry Reid, the majority leader, said that he had won the support of one Republican -- enough to reach the 60-vote threshold. But when the vote was counted, all the Republicans held together. The final tally was 58 to 42 - Mr. Reid switched his vote to no in a procedural maneuver that allows him to call for another vote and try again.

I don't know whether it's the lingering influence of a long era of conservative dominance (which forced liberals to grapple seriously with their critics on the right) or a consequence of the internet age (which places endless studies and PDFs and policy documents at the fingertips of every columnist and blogger), but I feel like there's been a definite drop-off in what you might call "sentimental liberal" arguments for policy measures, in which the good intentions of a given piece of legislation are treated as the only argument necessary to justify its passage. Even when liberals are making the contemporary equivalent of Robert Fulghum's sententious claim that "it will be a great day when our schools have all the money they need, and our air force has to have a bake-sale to buy a bombers," they usually have a Congressional Budget Office report to back it up.

This is a tale of two climate forecasts -- one successful, the other not. The successful forecast is described in a nice post on Realclimate.org commemorating the approaching 35th anniversary of "Climatic Change: Are We on the Bring of a Pronounced Global warming?" This pivotal paper was written by Wallace Broecker, one of the deans of modern climate science. This morning I woke up to a huge splash just offshore. I don't even look any more as I know it is a large predator, either a jack or a shark, feeding in the lagoon. You get used to them here. You have to. The six scientists from the American Museum of Natural History, at this field station for two weeks to study sea turtles, regularly see at least 10 sharks, and sometimes we see 40 to 50 in a day if we concentrate. I am particularly fond of the shark pups - the size of my forearm or so - but the often-curious larger sharks (black tips in the shallow flats as well as Galapagos sharks on the deeper dives) can be a bit disconcerting, especially if you are concentrating on something else and only notice them as they swim past for a closer look. Other scientists have had close encounters with tiger sharks, but I have not yet seen them. I just see evidence of them on the turtles. When we are checking turtles over in the health analyses, we see healed wounds that make me crazy trying to figure out how the turtles survived. In some, the shell looks like a cookie with a bite out of it.

The Motion Picture Association of America said it ended negotiations with Bob Kerrey, the former United States senator who for months has been in talks to become the association's chief executive. Bob Pisano, the group's president, has been serving as its interim chief executive since Dan Glickman left in April to become the president of Refugees International. The M.P.A.A. said in a statement that its search for a new chief executive would continue. When asked for comment, Mr. Kerrey said, "We simply could not reach agreement."

Summertime is tote time. Totes for the fresh corn from the farmer's market. Totes for the towel and suntan lotion at the beach. Totes for lugging around all that reading you meant to catch up on. You get the picture. Now the students at the Polo Fashion School, a collaboration between the Hetrick-Martin Institute and Polo Ralph Lauren, have designed paint-splattered tote bags that proudly declare "I Kiss Boys" or "I Kiss Girls." Proceeds benefit the institute, the nation's oldest social service organization supporting lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender youth. Whatever your preference, you can totes tell it like it is while carting around your summer essentials. Available for $20 at Maison 24 - in Bridgehampton and the Fire Island Pines, or online.

As talks continue about a possible merger between the downtown presenter Dance Theater Workshop and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, the theater on Thursday announced a full 2010-11 season featuring the work of choreographers from Europe, Africa and of course the United States. The lineup includes a collaboration between the German dance maker and performer Raimund Hoghe and Faustin Linyekula of Congo; new work by Richard Move, who will recreate a 1963 interview with Martha Graham; and the French choreographer Alain Buffard's "Les Inconsolés," a work set to Schubert and Throbbing Gristle. Also on the schedule will be revivals from the Trisha Brown Dance Company, the first time that troupe will appear at the theater. Complete information is at dancetheaterworkshop.org. Representatives for the theater said merger talks would probably conclude late in the fall.

A recent road trip across northern Spain also had a hand in her creative process. Several readers of the Consults blog had questions about migraines and patent foramen ovale, a fairly common condition that causes blood to flow through a hole between the heart's chambers. "Like many people, I had believed that hospice care hastens death, because patients forgo hospital treatments and are allowed high-dose narcotics to combat pain. But studies suggest otherwise. In one, researchers followed 4,493 Medicare patients with either terminal cancer or congestive heart failure. They found no difference in survival time between hospice and non-hospice patients with breast cancer, prostate cancer, and colon cancer. Curiously, hospice care seemed to extend survival for some patients; those with pancreatic cancer gained an average of three weeks, those with lung cancer gained six weeks, and those with congestive heart failure gained three months. The lesson seems almost Zen: you live longer only when you stop trying to live longer."

Bedbugs, the seed-size insects that have invaded mattresses, couches and laundry baskets everywhere, are now officially on New York City's hit list. With the bravado of military commandos, city officials on Wednesday declared war on bedbugs (see battle plan, also below), known in scientific parlance as Cimex lectularius, which have exploded in number in New York and major cities across the world over the past several decades.

An article on Monday about a decision by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America to welcome back into its fold seven openly gay pastors who had been barred from the church's ministry referred incorrectly to the ceremony that was used to mark the occasion at St. Mark's Lutheran Church in San Francisco. It was a ''rite of reception,'' not a ''rite of reconciliation.''

VERVILLE--Frank, on July 27, 2010 of Douglaston, NY. Beloved husband of Irene. Loving father of Matthew (Christine) Verville and Diane (Mauro) Brattoli. Cherished grandfather of Ava, Jason, Ariana, Darcy and the late Austin. Visitation, Friday 3-5pm and 7-9pm at the Fair- child Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

Because of an editing error, the Big City column in some editions on Tuesday, about the deaths of a woman and her four children in a Staten Island fire last week, overstated investigators' certainty about their initial theory on the case, and misidentified the official who spoke about it. A police official -- not fire officials -- said that evidence suggested that the eldest child, known as C.J. Jones, had slit his sisters' throats and his own, but cautioned that the investigation was continuing; the official did not say that investigators had concluded that the young man indeed slit their throats. (The authorities shifted the focus of their investigation after autopsies suggested that the mother was responsible for the killings.)

The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about the deficiency of vitamin D in much of the population, referred imprecisely to the publisher of a book by Dr. Michael Holick of Boston University, who said low levels of the vitamin could be contributing to high rates of some chronic diseases. While Penguin did not publish Dr. Holick's book, ''The Vitamin D Solution,'' it owns the imprint that did, Hudson Street Press.

ELLIOTT--Glenn J. The Board of Directors, the District Management Association and the staff of the Grand Central Partnership mourn the loss of our friend and former Board member Glenn Elliott. Glenn leaves behind an exceptional legacy of professional accomplishment and civic involvement. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the Elliott family and all of Glenn's loved ones during this time of great sadness. Peter S. Kalikow, Chairman Alfred C. Cerullo, III, President/CEO

You can make a movie with a phone, so why not with a doll? The Barbie Video Girl Doll ($50, Mattel, for ages 6 and up) looks just like a regular Barbie, but a closer look reveals a camera in her pendant, and a postage-sized color screen on her back, peeking through her blouse.

An article on Tuesday about the anger and dissatisfaction of many Khmer Rouge survivors at the sentencing of the first major figure convicted in connection with the deaths of 1.7 million Cambodians from 1975 to 1979 misstated, in some editions, the age of Sopheap Pich, a sculptor, who said he was uncertain about how he felt at the sentence. He is 39, not 29.

HALPERIN--Clara, July 26, 2010. Passed away peacefully at home at age 94. Beloved daughter of the late I.C. and Tess Herman. Clara is preceded in death by her husbands Sidney Frankel and Harry Halperin, and her nephew Peter Kenner. She is survived by family members Alan and Giselle Frankel of Waterville, Maine; Barbara, Nick, and Kate Kenner of New York; Robert, Marguerite, Zach, and Tess Kenner of Los Angeles, California; and Martin, Camilla, and Mark Kenner of New York. Clara lived an enchanted and exciting life to the end. Her quick wit and kindness will be missed by all. The family thanks Rita Keeffe and Denise Codrington for the loving care they provided Clara in her final years.

An article on Wednesday about the House's approval of financing for the military's efforts in Iraq, Afghanistan and Pakistan, as well as for various other programs, referred incorrectly to the bill's scope and cost. The bill provides about $37 billion in military funding and related foreign aid, and $22 billion for other purposes; the total of $59 billion is not solely for the cost of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. (The error also appeared in an Op-Ed column on Wednesday.)

MORRIS--Eugene J. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the passing of Gene Morris. A giant in the field of real estate law. Gene, and his firm Demov and Morris were instrumental in helping the Hebrew Home develop leading edge buildings for the elderly on our Riverdale campus. His wise counsel, keen intellect and deep knowledge of the intricacies of New York City real estate law were applied in creative and unique ways to help the Hebrew Home fulfill its mission of caring for the elderly with respect and dignity. We extend our condolences to Dick, daughter in law Eileen and his beloved granddaughter. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine announced Wednesday that she would vote to confirm Solicitor General Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court, making her the fourth Senate Republican to back Ms. Kagan, President Obama's nominee. ''Throughout my tenure in the Senate, I have applied a uniform standard for evaluating nominees for the United States Supreme Court, under both Republican and Democratic administrations,'' Ms. Snowe said in a statement. ''I find that Ms. Kagan has met that standard with the strong intellect, respect for the rule of law, and understanding of the important but limited role of the Supreme Court that I believe is required of any justice.''
An article last Thursday about a fashion movement to wear the same six items for 31 consecutive days misspelled the name of a product used to eliminate odors from fabrics. It is Febreze, not Fabreze.

MORRIS--Eugene J.,died peacefully on July 24, 2010 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Born in Manhattan on October 14, 1910, he was the beloved father of Dick Morris. Gene was married to the late Terry Morris for 59 years and to the late Blanche Morris for 14 years. He graduated from City College (1931) and St. John's University School of Law (1934). During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army. After the war, Gene was a founding partner of Demov and Morris, where he practiced real estate law for more than 54 years. He was a pioneer in urban renewal and instrumental in the development of many New York City projects, including Lincoln Center. He was a prolific writer of books and articles, including 26 volumes of Real Property practice books for Matthew Bender and a weekly real estate Column for the New York Law Journal for twenty-five years. He served as a Special Master for N.Y. State Supreme Court Justice Bea Shainswit. He was active in the New York City, New York State, and American Bar Associations. From 1990-2007, he taught real estate Law at N.Y.U. A native New Yorker, he lived in the city he loved and help build all of his life. Gene was an inspiration to everyone who knew him. He was much loved and is already sorely missed. In addition to his son, Dick, he is survived by his daughter-in-law, Eileen McGann, and one granddaughter. Friends and family may call at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan on Thursday July 29, 2010 from 6-9 and for the funeral service at 11:30am on Friday, July 30, 2010. In lieu of flowers, contributions to City College will be welcomed.

Many Republicans have been very eager to associate themselves with Tea Party followers, hoping to tap into the movement's deep enthusiasm. Now Democrats say they are more than willing to help Republicans do so. Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, a Florida Democrat, said it is hard to tell where the Republican Party ended and the Tea Party began. ''Or vice versa.'' And in a gibe at the agenda House Republicans intend to unveil later this fall, the Democrats helpfully provided a full-blown ''Republican Tea Party Contract on America.''
SLIDE SHOW An artist's compound in Lyme, Conn., that features an 18th-century farmhouse, greenhouse, and assorted other buildings. nytimes.com/homes

HARRIS--Charles W. (Chuck), of Manhattan, on July 16, 2010, in Isalo National Park, Madagascar. Beloved husband of Elizabeth and father of Spencer (Spike); son of Leah and the late Marvin; brother of Robert (Wynn) and Donald; uncle of Mitchell (Kate) and Rebecca; grand-uncle of Ryan. A memorial service will be held at 7pm on Friday, July 30, at The Church of St. Luke in the Fields in Greenwich Village. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Children's Aid Society or Mercy Corps.

LEVIN--Cornelia Rose, February 7, 1932 July 25, 2010. Born New York, New York. Died Calais, Vermont. Daughter of Sophie K. and Alfred Oscar Rose. Graduate of Scarborough School; Radcliffe College, '53, A.B., magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa, Ford Foundation Fellow in political theory; Harvard, M.Ed. Taught and tutored in Concord, MA, Arlington, VA, Taichung, Taipei, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Dar-es-Salaam, Colombo, New Delhi and remedial math at the Math Center in Washington, DC. Upon her husband's retirement after 34 years in the Foreign Service, Cornelia drew on her Chinese language and painting skills and became a devoted docent, supporter and participant in the museum family at the Smithsonian Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery of Asian Art. Cornelia divided her time between Washington, DC, New York and Calais where she took particular pride in her showplace gardens. Cornelia was diagnosed with non-treatable stomach cancer on July 9, 2010. In accord with her wishes, she died at home with truly caring hospice nursing, surrounded by her family. She is survived by her husband of 56 years, Herbert Levin, of New York City, daughter Martha Levin, of Hong Kong, son Jonathan C. Levin, of South Burlington, VT, sister, Nancy Rose Wadhams of Goshen, CT, and loving nieces and nephews in Tyrone and Sharpsburg, GA, Minneapolis, MN and Bala Cynwyd, PA. Her last days in Calais were comforted and supported by the loving efforts of long time friends and neighbors who maintained her vegetable and flower gardens which she viewed with joy and appreciation. The many messages and cards received in July from her friends from the Outer Hebrides to Australia and throughout the U.S., were all read to her and were of great comfort. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Central Vermont Home Health and Hospice, Inc., 600 Granger Road, Barre, VT, 05641. Private interment at the family plot in Robinson Cemetery in Calais, VT.

HILBERG--John Victor, 70, of Laconia, NH and Sedona, AZ, died from cancer in Concord, NH on July 26, 2010. The son of Victor and Rosemary Hilberg, he graduated from Regis High School (NYC) and Fordham University. John also attended the Graduate School of International Studies (Denver) and the Free University of Berlin. He is survived by his wife Ingeborg (Stein) Hilberg of Laconia, NH and Sedona, AZ, son Eric Victor Hilberg of Newton, MA, and daughter Lisa Rosemary Craig of Saratoga Springs, NY. After teaching four years at the University of Connecticut, he founded StockCross, the pioneer discount stock brokerage firm in Boston and later Calcogen, an alternate energy and cogeneration developer in California. Himself an Eagle Scout, John was an ardent supporter of the Boy Scouts, of numerous libertarian organizations, and of Enfield Shaker Museum (New Hampshire), for which he served as a trustee. There will be no calling hours. A private Celebration of Life will be held at a later date.

RICH--Florence (nee Blumenson) widow of Morris H.,survived by loving children Harlan and Beverly, Jonathan and Mindy and dearest grandchildren, Max, Samantha, Sarah, Ilan and Cole. Services to be held at Sharon Gardens 273 Lakeview Ave, Valhalla, NY 10595 at 1pm.

An article on Tuesday about physicists' hunt for the ''God particle'' misstated the affiliation of one of the scientists, Ben Kilminster. He is a researcher with the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, not with Ohio State.

LANSING--Gerrit L. The Institute of Fine Arts community mourns the loss of our friend and alumnus, Gerrit Lansing. He served loyally as President of the IFA Alumni Association and as a long-time member of the Connoisseurs Circle Executive Committee. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Sydie, and his entire family. Judy Steinhardt, Chairman Patricia Rubin, Director Institute of Fine Arts, NYU

4:39 p.m. | Updated with information about where the projector is available. When I was a kid I used to camp out in my backyard with friends, as we sat around telling ghost stories and eating junk food. I remember fantasizing that one day we would be able to watch a horror movie on the wall of our my tent - almost like our own private movie theater. And now, a new travel projector from Tumi can make that possible.

LANSING--Gerrit. Gerrit was a man easily admired. He had a wonderfully joyous and lively spirit that was evidenced in his love for art. Gerrit was an astute art historian who specialized in American Surrealism. He was the long-time, gifted president and then chairman of iCI and also a member of several other art boards and committees including MoMA's International Council. Gerrit and his wife, Sydie, were a dynamic couple, supporting both art and artists alike. On behalf of the MoMA PS1 Board of Trustees, Klaus Biesenbach, director, and Agnes Gund, chairman, we send our very sincere condolences to his wonderful family: his wife Sydie, sons Gerrit, Jr. and Sims, daughter-in-law Patricia, and three grandchildren, Carolina, Gerrit III, and Magnus.

PEABODY--Judy. The patients and staff of the Center for Special Studies at New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our remarkable friend, Judy Peabody. Judy was one of the heroes of the AIDS epidemic. Outraged by the discrimination against people suffering with AIDS, Judy stayed at the bedside of many whose families had abandoned them, and rallied her friends to support programming intended to help restore dignity as well as health. An elegant, soft-spoken person, Judy found a very powerful voice to advocate for the marginalized and vulnerable. She touched the lives of countless people around the nation through her work and example. Our program was founded with her determination and sustained by her love. We will miss her guidance, inspiration, and, above all, friendship. Our thoughts are with Sam, Elizabeth, and the other members of her family. Jonathan L. Jacobs M.D. Executive Director Samuel T. Merrick M.D. Medical Director

Less than a month after the conclusion of a successful World Cup tournament in South Africa, the Brazilian sports minister touted the promise of the 2014 tournament in Brazil and responded to familiar concerns over the readiness of stadiums. ''I believe the world will be surprised by the country it will be discovering in 2014,'' Orlando Silva Jr., the country's minister of sports, said in a conference call Wednesday. ''Infrastructure investments are important not only for the event, but for our people. We are particularly interested in improving our public transportation infrastructure.''
GELB--Sally. We will never forget you. You were not only a fantastic wife and mother, you and Harold were the greatest one two punch through all our years in dentistry. Lucia and Irwin Smigel

PEABODY--Judith. The Board of Directors and entire staff of Argus Community mourn the passing of Judith Peabody, wife, partner and inspiration of our esteemed Board member and vice-chairman, Samuel Peabody. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sam and to their daughter Elizabeth and to the community of service providers who will deeply feel her loss. Argus Community, Inc.

Swarms of photographers, reporters and plain old curious folk are expected to descend on the upstate New York town of Rhinebeck when Chelsea Clinton gets married there on Saturday. Now it appears they will have to make do with whatever they can see through the hedges - if they can even get that close. The Federal Aviation Administration said late Wednesday that it would enforce a temporary ban on flights below 2,000 feet for the area surrounding the estate on the Hudson River where Ms. Clinton is to be married.

8 P.M. (TCM) TCM SPOTLIGHT: TEEN MOVIES Turner Classic Movies closes out its 28-film festival for young viewers with a frenzied celebration of rock 'n' roll, the term widely associated with the disc jockey Alan Freed, who gets things started in ''Rock, Rock, Rock!'' (1956), starring Tuesday Weld in her breakout role as a teenager who will stop at nothing to get the perfect dress for the school dance. The 85-minute film averages a song every four and a half minutes, with Connie Francis dubbing Ms. Weld's songs. Freed shows up again in ''Rock Around the Clock'' (1956), at 9:30, with a beat set by Bill Haley and His Comets, the Platters, the Ernie Freeman Combo and Tony Martinez and His Band. The film cost $200,000 and earned around $1 million. In ''Bye Bye Birdie'' (1963), at 11, adapted from the Broadway musical inspired by Elvis Presley's induction into the Army in 1958, Jesse Pearson plays a pop idol who is drafted and plans to bestow a farewell kiss on a small-town girl (Ann-Margret). At 1 a.m. Presley shakes and shimmies in ''Jailhouse Rock'' (1957), above, as a musical sensation who practices his guitar skills in prison. Freed, this time portraying a rock 'n' roll promoter in search of a talent contest's mysterious winner, makes a third appearance in ''Go, Johnny, Go!'' (1959), at 2:45. And Chubby Checker gyrates to end the night in ''Don't Knock the Twist'' (1962), about a television executive who tries to create a musical to save his network, at 4:15. 8:40 P.M. (Sundance) MONTEREY POP (1968) D. A. Pennebaker -- with cinematography assistance from James Desmond, Richard Leacock, Albert Maysles, Roger Murphy and Barry Feinstein -- captures three days of the 1967 International Pop Festival in Monterey, Calif., in what was to become the fabled Summer of Love. Captured onstage and off: the Mamas and the Papas, Jefferson Airplane, the Who, Jimi Hendrix, Simon & Garfunkel, Ravi Shankar and Janis Joplin.

RUTMAN--Henry, passed away from lymphoma in New York City on July 27, 2010 at age 84. Survived by his loving and devoted wife of nearly 60 years Sherry Berg Rutman; he will be missed by his adoring children, Howard Rutman and Lori Fife, their spouses Shereen Gertel Rutman and Mark Fife, as well as his grandchildren, Elizabeth Fife and Melissa and Stephen Rutman. Throughout his life he always maintained his warm smile, abundant kindness and gentlemanly appearance. After surviving the Holocaust, he immigrated to New York where he spent most of his career as a principal and executive of Gallery, a woman's apparel firm. He was prominent in the woman's apparel industry as a designer, innovator and importer; he was also a highly regarded teacher and served as a mentor to many in the industry. His kind heart, warmth, creativity and integrity in all aspects of his life serve as an inspiration to all who knew him. Funeral services will be on Thursday, July 29 at 9:30am at Park Avenue Synagogue, Madison Avenue at 87th Street and shiva will be at the Fife home. Contributions in memory of Henry Rutman are welcome to be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage - A Living Memorial to the Holocaust.

FABRIKANT--Elaine, 89, wife of late Bernard Fabrikant, mother of Charles (Sara), Jane (Peter) Strasser, loving grandmother of Scott, Harlan and Eric, great-grandmother of Sammi, Aaron and Lizzie, beloved Aunt of Cathy Fetell. She will be greatly missed by her cherished companion, Reese.

On a narrow 0.051-acre patch of Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon, Maury Tannenbaum leaned back in his chair. The brakes on the M11 bus to his left squealed. Cabbies honked to his right. Construction vehicles rumbled by. But Mr. Tannenbaum, 73, is a retired surgeon who grew up in the Bronx, which is another way of saying he has learned a thing or two about drowning out distraction and focusing on what matters.He sat in the shade of London Plane trees in a 138-year-old park off Broadway, listening to a classical guitarist from Japan play songs written in Spain to a small crowd of New Yorkers and tourists that included an unemployed librarian from Queens, a West African newspaper vendor, tattooed construction workers, bearded homeless men and a businesswoman wearing a pearl necklace. His wife, Gloria, sat next to him as the bronze bust of Richard Tucker, the Brooklyn-born opera star for whom the park is named, looked on - a great tenor, setting the tenor.

LANSING--Gerrit L. It is with profound sadness that we learn of the passing of Gerrit L. Lansing. Gerrit was a member of The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art since 1983, serving on our Program Committee. With his wife, Sydie, he was a brilliant contributor to our travels and programs. He made significant contributions to the study of American Surrealism, and was a beloved member of our Museum family. His wisdom and gentle intelligence will be missed by his many friends from all over the world. We extend our deepest sympathy to Sydie, his sons Gerrit and Sims, daughter-in-law Patricia, and grandchildren Carolina, Gerrit III, and Magnus. HRH Duke Franz von Bayern, Chair Emeritus Brian Urquhart, Chair Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chair Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President Jo Carole Lauder, President Emerita Joanne M. Stern, President Emerita Beth Straus, President Emerita Jeanne C. Thayer, President Emerita Beatrix Medinger, Treasurer William L. Bernhard, Secretary The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

KELLNER--Emil. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with deep sorrow the passing of Emil Kellner, beloved father and father-in-law of our dear friends and Benefactors Marcia and Ronald Lissak. The Lissaks are generous supporters of biomedical research at the College of Medicine and Mr. Lissak serves on Einstein's Board of Overseers. To Marcia and Ron, and to the entire family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, Chairperson, Board of Overseers

Fujifilm has reprised last year's well-reviewed FinePix F200EXR camera with a tempting new model that has a versatile 15X zoom shoe-horned into a compact chassis. The new $330 FinePix F300EXR uses a 12-megapixel EXR sensor, which is designed to improve low-light performance and boost dynamic range. It also employs a new hybrid auto-focus system that selects phase detection auto-focus (the AF technology used by most D.S.L.R. cameras) in bright light and contrast detection auto-focus in low light. Fujifilm says this technology enables the camera to focus as fast as 0.16 second. You would have a tough time measuring that, though.

SILVER--Marcia, age 83, daughter of Rose and Jacob Branower, long time resident of Scarsdale and Rye, NY, St. Petersburg, FL and most recently of Norfolk, Virginia, died on July 26, 2010. She was preceded in death by Norman Silver, her husband of fifty six years and her sister Joan Levy. Marcia was an accomplished pianist, oboist, and flautist. As graduates of Music and Art high school, Bronx, NY, Marcia and Norman shared a life long love of music, travel, friends and family. Over the years, she sold real estate and volunteered her time with numerous organizations. She delighted in building and renovating homes. She especially enjoyed hand making rugs and socializing with neighbors. Throughout her long battle with Alzheimer's disease, she maintained her warmth, charm, sense of humor, and dignity. She will be missed by her children Nancy and her husband Steve of Norfolk, VA, Jack of Norwalk, CT, and Tom and his wife Diane of New Rochelle, NY. Grandchildren Eric, Marc, Matthew, Timothy, Catherine and Benjamin have only fondest memories of their grandma Marcia. The funeral will be held on Friday, July 30, 10am, Mount Pleasant Cemetery chapel, Hawthorne, NY. Donations may be made to Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, NY, NY., www.crt.org.

ORIFICI--Salvatore J.,of Hobe Sound, FL passed away peacefully on July 27, 2010 at the age of 80. He was born in the Bronx, NY on April 12, 1930. He was a life-member of the New York Athletic Club and served on the Board of Governors from 1994-1997. He was President of Construction Associates until he retired in 1995 and Site Works Plus, Inc. He is survived by his loving wife, Andrea (Gettings) Orifici. He will be greatly missed by his children, grandchildren and great- grandchildren. Visitation will be Friday, July 30 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY. Funeral Mass on Saturday, July 31 at 10am at St. Mary's Church, Katonah, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the NYAC Athlete's Fund, 180 Central Park South, NY, NY 10019.

An article on Tuesday about the time performances of the New York region's three major commuter railroads referred imprecisely to one of the slowest routes on the Long Island Rail Road, the trip from Port Jefferson to Penn Station. While only one train on that route leaves during the morning rush -- defined as 6 a.m. to 9 a.m. for the analysis in the article -- that is not the only train that makes the trip on weekdays. A train leaves Port Jefferson for Penn Station at 5:44 a.m.

PFORZHEIMER--Carol K. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Carol K. Pforzheimer, their beloved friend, Honorary Trustee, and the mother of the Library's esteemed Trustee, Carl Pforzheimer III. Over the past four decades, Carol and her family have shown great devotion to the Library and enormous generosity, with gifts including the extraordinary Carl H. Pforzheimer Collection of Shelley and His Circle, one of the world's leading resources for the study of English Romanticism. We offer our deepest sympathy to all of her family and friends. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Paul LeClerc, President Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti

FABRIKANT--Elaine. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Elaine Fabrikant and extend sincerest condolences to her family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

MORGAN--Edward. The Board of Directors and the staff of Martin dePorres Services for Children mourns the death of Edward Morgan on July 27, 2010. Edward Morgan was a founding member of the Board of Directors. He served for 38 years. Edward Morgan gave up his time and personal resources to bring Martin dePorres Services for Children into existence.

The Books of The Times review last Thursday about ''The Korean War'' by Bruce Cumings, in noting that Mr. Cumings mistakenly described the nonfiction Vietnam War book ''Dispatches'' by Michael Herr as a novel, misstated the year ''Dispatches'' was published. It was 1977, not 1970.
Audience members share their thoughts on the Broadway production of “Top Girls.”

FARLEY--James H. We mourn the passing of our beloved friend, colleague, and partner, Jim Farley. Anything we have accomplished over the last twenty years would have been impossible without the intelligence, good judgment, and integrity that he brought to every project. These qualities, and his warmth and concern for others, enriched every day we had the privilege of working with him, so much more so during the last three years when, with faith and courage, he battled cancer. Above all, he was dedicated to his family, which was such a source of strength and deserved pride to him. Our hearts go out to Eileen, Hilary, Brendan, Julia, Neil, his mother Cate, and his brothers and sisters. The Stahl Organization Cauldwell Wingate Company LLC The Chanin Building

PETSCHEK--Stephen Ronald, beloved father, grandfather, brother, and friend, died on July 24, 2010, in New York. He was 79. Born on June 28, 1931, in Prague, Czechoslovakia, the son of Walter and Franziska (Urbach) Petschek, Stephen came to the U.S. in 1941. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy before graduating magna cum laude from Harvard University and earning his JD, cum laude, from Harvard Law School. He practiced law at Cravath, Swaine and Moore, served for some time as Assistant to the United States Ambassador to Belgium and then entered investment banking, first as a partner at Loeb Rhoades and Co. and next as president of the J. Henry Schroder Corporation. His working life cut short by an accident, Stephen lived for many years in Seal Harbor, Maine. He was a Life Trustee and former Chairman of the Board of the Jackson Laboratory, a Trustee and past President of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and a Trustee of the Institute for Defense Analyses in Washington, DC. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the New York Yacht Club and the Knickerbocker Club. Stephen always had a passion for music, a keen interest in world events, and was an avid sailor. The way he maintained his wit despite the enormous challenges he faced in the latter part of his life was a true inspiration. His wisdom and generosity benefited many. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by daughters Jennifer Petschek and Alexandra Robson Petschek, their mother Danielle Tubiana, grandson William Robson, brother Alfred Petschek, and sister Susan Petschek. Contributions in Stephen's memory may be made to the Jackson Laboratory, P.O. Box 254, Bar Harbor, ME 04609-0254 or to the MDI YMCA, 21 Park Street, Bar Harbor, ME 04609. A small private memorial service will be held.

YOHAI--Morrie, July 27, 2010. Born March 4, 1920. Graduated University of Pennsylvania. Wharton School, 1941. US Marines Pilot 1942-1945. Married 1947. President of Old London Foods: 1949 (invented the Cheez Doodle 1960). Sr. Vice President of Borden Inc. Professor of Marketing and Management - New York Institute of Technology. With his hopes of playing in the world championships dashed because of the Knicks' inability to insure his nearly $100 million contract, Amar'e Stoudemire has apparently embarked on another intriguing international adventure. Several reports out of Israel along with messages on Stoudemire's Twitter account said he was visiting the country. The Israeli newspaper Haaretz said Stoudemire, the Knicks' new power forward, decided to go after recently learning that he had Jewish roots on his mother's side.

PFORZHEIMER--Carol K. The Pace University community mourns the death and celebrates the life of Carol Pforzheimer, a trustee from 1973 to 1979 and an honorary trustee thereafter; a counselor to Presidents Edward J. Mortola, William G. Sharwell, and Patricia D. Ewers; a moving force in several fundraising efforts; and, with her husband, Carl H. Pforzheimer Jr., a significant financial supporter of Pace programs and students. A former director of nurse's aides at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, D.C., during World War II, she took a particular interest in creating and sustaining the University's Lienhard School of Nursing, the first collegiate school of nursing in Westchester County. Her work with Pace made her a champion of helping students who aspire to a better life.

GOODMAN--Alfred, on July 27, at the age of 95, in West Orange, NJ. Survived by Beatrice (nee Goldberg), his wife of 63 years; sons Jonathan (Bonnie), and Andrew (Terry); and grandchildren Adam, Joshua, Rachel, Sarah, and Daniel. An Army captain in intelligence during WWII, he landed with an Army Ranger unit at Omaha Beach on D Day. A native of Bayonne, NJ, he was an active Rutgers alumnus who served as president of the Class of 1937. He was an executive for the family business, Goodman Warehouse Corporation, and past president of Congregation B'nai Shalom of West Orange. Services will be held at 11:30am, Friday, July 30, at Menorah Chapels, Millburn, NJ.
