Before Jeff Bridges was a famous actor, his father, Lloyd, churned the seas as Mike Nelson, the main character in the 1950s television series, ''Sea Hunt.'' In the show, large sealed, waterproof film cameras captured the elder Bridges under water, rescuing hapless individuals and fighting crooks. If you fancy yourself a modern version of Mike Nelson, you can now record your exploits more easily than Mr. Bridges' crew could. Using Liquid Image's Underwater Digital Camera Mask, you can shoot both still images and moving video as you troll your swimming pool or local reef.

A report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about the effect of warming temperatures on yellow-bellied marmots in Colorado left the incorrect impression that researchers had observed the marmots going back into hibernation later in the fall. The scientists who made a long-term study observed only the marmots' coming out of hibernation earlier in the spring.

As I said in a previous post, scientists have noted a pattern of a higher ratio of "standing" predator to prey biomass on the atoll, which contrasts with most other marine and terrestrial ecosystems (for example, think about the small ratios of top mammalian predators to grazers on the African savanna). They hypothesize that extremely high rates of production in the prey, including algae; corals, clams and other invertebrates; and smaller fish, supports the predators. This is coupled with high rates at which prey are eaten or otherwise die (called "turnover"). Another possibility is that the larger-bodied fish can live on relatively low amounts of food for many years, even decades, when protected from fishing.

In this Sunday's Book Review, Thomas Mallon reviews Geoffrey O'Brien's "Fall of the House of Walworth," about a sensational parricide in an old and influential family in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., in 1873 - sensational enough, in fact, to merit O'Brien's subtitle: "A Tale of Madness and Murder in Gilded Age America." In the case, the deranged novelist Mansfield Tracy Walworth, largely forgotten now, but of some note in his own day, was shot to death by his son, Frank, in a Manhattan hotel room; Frank's motivation, it seems, was his father's brutal treatment of his mother, Ellen Walworth, one of the founders of the Daughters of the American Revolution. Mallon has high praise for O'Brien's "crackerjack new history," and you should certainly read his elegant review first. But if we do say so, The New York Times's anonymous account on June 4, 1873, the day after the killing, is a surprisingly moving piece of journalism as well, full of passion and personal interest, a crackerjack little melodrama; such is the startling story, headlined "A Terrible Parricide":

Sometimes an idea comes along that's so elementally brilliant I feel no compunction about stealing it outright. That's what I thought I was doing with this recipe when a friend told me he'd read it in the new "River Cottage Preserves Handbook," written by Pam Corbin. It's called bachelor's jam, or sometimes officer's jam, and it isn't jam at all but rather a whip-smart method of both preserving the overflow of ripening summer fruit and infusing spirits with the same in a manner befitting, well, a bachelor and/or an officer. This makes for a "preserve" that comes into its own just in time to bring a welcome hit of summer fruit to the holidays. Once I started digging and found that the chef Roger Vergé has written on what is known as confiture de vieux garçon, and that it is also an old and well-loved treat in Germany (known as rumtopf, or "rum pot"), I felt a bit less guilty about my plagiarism.

5:45 p.m. | Updated The programmers at MTV must have pumped their fists when the overnight ratings for "Jersey Shore" arrived on Friday. (Although they might not have been so thrilled Friday afternoon after seeing reports that one of the show's stars, Nicole Polizzi, known as Snooki, had been arrested in Seaside Heights, N.J., and accused of disorderly conduct.) The premiere of the second season of "Jersey Shore" attracted 5.3 million viewers on Thursday night, according to Nielsen, the network's biggest season premiere in more than seven years. The series about young people partying at the beach - it's really that simple - was a sensation last winter for MTV, peaking at 4.8 million viewers for the finale. But Thursday night's ratings indicate that the show has legs, even in the summer. Among MTV's core demographic of viewers 12 to 34 years old, the season premiere is the No. 1 cable telecast of the year. The series will follow the cast's exploits in South Beach, last spring in Florida; it is now filming their return to Seaside Heights this summer.

I have a review in this weekend's Book Review of "Four Fish: The Future of the Last Wild Food," by Paul Greenberg. The book is a good and important read, I think, that boils down to a discussion of the push and pull of our desire to eat wild fish, and the promise and the fear of consuming the wild variety. "Four Fish" raises important questions for people interested in food, about what fish we should be eating, what fish we should be farming, what fish we should (not) be catching in the sea. It is a book to change minds.

A brave new reworking of Shakespeare's "The Tempest" directed by Julie Taymor will be the centerpiece film of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Friday. Ms. Taymor's cinematic adaptation of "The Tempest" - her first filmed version of Shakespeare since "Titus," her stylized 1999 take on "Titus Andronicus" - will be shown in the festival on Oct. 2 at Alice Tully Hall. In a gender-bending twist on the play, Ms. Taymor's "Tempest" stars Helen Mirren as the sorceress Prospera. It also features Felicity Jones as her daughter, Miranda; Ben Whishaw as Ariel; Djimon Hounsou as Caliban; Alfred Molina as Stephano; Alan Cumming as Sebastian; Chris Cooper as Antonio; David Strathairn as Alonso; and Russell Brand as Trinculo. Ms. Taymor's directing credits include the film "Across the Universe" as well as the Broadway musical "The Lion King" and - maybe, just maybe - "Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark." The festival runs from Sept. 24 through Oct. 10 and will open with David Fincher's "The Social Network."

Jennifer Egan is the author of five works of fiction, most recently "A Visit From the Goon Squad."In your new book, the term "Goon Squad" refers to the passage of time. When Ringo Starr turned 70 recently, he told The Times that he still feels 24 inside. How old do you feel inside, and how do you think the passage of time affects our core identities?My mom used to say that if someone woke her up in the middle of the night and asked how old she was, she'd answer 27. Hearing her, I'd think: That's ridiculous; your job as my mom is to be old. Now, in my mid-40s, I find that I identify with people even younger than that - teenagers! If I had to pick one age, it would probably be 17: that period of looking like an adult but not quite being one, of pretending to be "yourself" (whoever that is) and praying that people will believe you; of having wild hopes about what kind of life you might have but also fearing you'll never make it out of the house - all of that still feels so immediate. Sometimes I'll watch teenagers and find myself not quite believing I'm older than they are - even wondering, delusionally, if they can see any difference between us. And yet my own kids will be teenagers soon, and when I talk to actual teens I'm vividly aware, of course, that they're children.

A followup on the question of deflation risks: it's worth bearing in mind that the last year and a half has been a fairly clean test of alternative views about how the economy works. When the economy slumped, budget deficits skyrocketed, and the Fed began large-scale asset purchases, there were two kinds of people: people who divide people into two kinds, and people who don't On one side were people who said that deficits would drive interest rates way up, crowding out private investment, and that all that money printing would lead to high inflation. On the other were those who said that we'd entered a Japan-type liquidity trap, which meant that (a) there was a savings glut, so deficits would not crowd out private investment and interest rates would stay low (b) increases in the monetary base would just sit there, (c) the risk was deflation, not inflation.

Deflation -- it sounds like fun. Things get cheaper, right, so what's the big deal? Sadly, a widespread slide in prices has more nefarious effects than that other bugbear, inflation, first because it signals a retreat in demand and, second, because people quickly understand that if they wait longer, they will have to pay even less -- a vicious cycle spurred by a seemingly harmless virtue, thrift. Well, James Bullard, head of the St. Louis Fed, is worried about it. You can read his full essay here, or a quick summary.

You can control the music player software right from the Windows 7 taskbar on your computer. Just hover the mouse cursor over the minimized icon for the Windows Media Player in the taskbar to get a thumbnail version of the playback controls that lets you pause, play or jump to the next or previous track in your playlist. The Windows version of iTunes offers similar taskbar controls. Mac users can right- or control-click on the iTunes icon in the Dock to get a menu of playback controls to control the music - without having to bring the iTunes window to the front of the screen.

I'm always skeptical of statements like these because the mind often grabs on to a few unusual events as being commonplace and typically no context is given relative to other teams in the league. It may just be that every team struggles against starters making their major league debut.

LANSING--Gerrit. It is with profound sadness that the members and former members of the Board of Trustees, the staff, and loyal friends of Independent Curators International (ICI) mourn the death of our longtime President and Chairman, Gerrit Lansing. With his devoted wife and fellow ICI Trustee Sydie Lansing constantly at his side, Gerrit's caring leadership, passion for and knowledge of art, and extraordinary generosity have provided the foundation upon which ICI has thrived. For thirty years Gerrit has been at the heart of ICI. His unswerving commitment and wisdom will be an inspiration for years to come. Our condolences to his wife and sons, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren, of whom he was so proud and loved so deeply.

LANSING--Gerrit. Gerrit was a man easily admired. He had a wonderfully joyous and lively spirit that was evidenced in his love for art. Gerrit was an astute art historian who specialized in American Surrealism. He was the long-time, gifted president and then chairman of iCI and also a member of several other art boards and committees including MoMA's International Council. Gerrit and his wife, Sydie, were a dynamic couple, supporting both art and artists alike. On behalf of the MoMA PS1 Board of Trustees, Klaus Biesenbach, director, and Agnes Gund, chairman, we send our very sincere condolences to his wonderful family: his wife Sydie, sons Gerrit, Jr. and Sims, daughter-in-law Patricia, and three grandchildren, Carolina, Gerrit III, and Magnus.

The Cape Town Journal article and a picture caption on Wednesday about gay marriage in South Africa misstated, in some editions, the surname of a man shown with his partner before their wedding in Cape Town. He is Albert Marton, not Morton.

RUTMAN--Henry. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Henry Rutman, beloved father of Lori Fife and father-in-law of Mark Fife, who are greatly admired for their extraordinary generosity in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our sympathies to Henry's beloved wife, Sherry; to Lori and Mark; and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

An article on July 21 about David Cameron, Britain's new prime minister, and his austerity measures to slash the national budget, misstated the number of unemployed people in the country. It is 2.5 million, not 8 million. The article also misstated the government portion of the total work force in Britain. It is 21.1 percent, not ''about half.''

Until last week, Christian Jurinka had never heard complaints about the stenciled advertisements his agency sprays on the sidewalks of major cities. But when neon pink-and-yellow ads for a Brazilian brand of flip-flops landed on the North Side of Chicago, they immediately drew the ire of a Lincoln Park stroller. The pedestrian, Bruce Beavis, 51, complained to the police, his alderman, Vi Daley of the 43rd Ward, the news media and Mr. Jurinka's business partner, who promised to send a cleaning crew to remove the advertisements the next day.

An article on June 29 about a decision by the Supreme Court on state and local gun control laws, using information from a dissenting opinion, misstated the year that Chicago enacted the ban on handguns that was challenged in the case. It was enacted in 1982, not in 1983.

ROMANOFF--David. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved on the passing of David Romanoff an ardent devotee of Israel, Israeli Archeology and Israel Studies, and an active member of the Elizabeth, NJ Jewish community. He was the son of the late Rabbi Gershon (and Freda Zemel) Romanoff. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Syndi, and their children: Gershon Ari, Chi Ilana, Akiva, Elchanan, Gila Dalia, Gedalia, Yehuda and Chaim, his sister, Dr. Roberta A., a former member of the Stern College for Women Board of Overseers (and Dr. Irving) Strauchler, his brother, Dr. Elihu (and Libby) Romanoff, and his uncle, YU Guardian, Rabbi Nathan (and Marion) Zemel, and aunts, Mildred (and Milton) Klein, and Blanche Herberg. May the entire Romanoff family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

The ''On Soccer'' column on Wednesday, about the former soccer player Mick Channon's new career as a trainer of racehorses, misidentified the breed of one of his horses, Youmzain. It is a thoroughbred, not an Arabian horse.

SAFFER--Rhona. The Board, staff, members and friends of the Association for Energy Affordability mourn the passing of Rhona Saffer, a dedicated AEA employee for 14 years and recipient of AEA's Enduring Commitment to Weatherization award, a staunch and faithful friend and the loving wife of Amos and mother of Jonathan, Gabrielle and Jordan. Her spirit inspired us to live fully, and to be better human beings.

An Indian company with rich American backers is about to raise up to $350 million in a stock offering closely watched by philanthropists around the world, showing that big profits can be made from small helping-hand loans to poor cowherds and basket weavers. The company, SKS Microfinance, is one of the biggest players in the field known as microfinance, which involves loans, often as small as $20, that banks might consider too tiny and risky to bother with.

An article on Thursday about the increasing number of illegal immigrants found dead in the Arizona desert this year referred incorrectly to the backlog of more than 150 unidentified remains being handled by the Pima County medical examiner's office in Tucson. The oldest case still under active investigation dates to 2003; the backlog does not include a case ''going back as far as 1993.''
ROSENZWEIG--Elsa, passed away on July 28, 2010 at age 94. She was a beloved mother, grandmother, aunt and friend who will be missed by all who knew and loved her.

LANSING--Gerritt L. We were saddened to learn of the passing of our good friend Gerritt L. Lansing. Gerritt was a childhood friend of mine and remained a friend throughout our lives. My wife Jean Minskoff Grant serves on his Board at ICI and they formed a true friendship over the years. Gerritt was a gentleman in the truest sense of the word and deeply passionate for the Arts. He will be sorely missed by his colleagues and friends. Our deepest sympathy to Sydie, Gerrity, Sims and the Family. Jeannie & T Grant

(Nickelodeon) GLENN MARTIN, DDS The title character (voiced by Kevin Nealon) in this stop-motion-animated series starts taking karate lessons because he fears the growing strength of Conor, his 13-year-old son (Peter Oldring). Then the two hit the streets of San Francisco to fight crime. Martin's wife, Jackie (Catherine O'Hara), takes their daughter, Courtney (Jackie Clarke), and her assistant, Wendy (Judy Greer), to the San Francisco Mint, where Courtney is met with a big surprise. A variety of celebrity guest voices are being employed in this series's second season, which began in June, including those of Bret Michaels, Betty White, M C Hammer, George Takei and Gabourey Sidibe. This week Sean Hayes lends his voice to the role of the mint's tour guide, who turns out to be more than meets the eye. Viewers can interact live on Twitter with the fictional Martin during the show at twitter.com/glennmartindds. 8 P.M. (AMC) JFK (1991) Oliver Stone's drama, driven by conspiracy theories, about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, with Kevin Costner as Jim Garrison, the New Orleans district attorney who was involved in the subsequent investigation, is full of name actors turning in singular performances. They include Kevin Bacon as a male hustler, and a surprise turn by John Candy in a dramatic role. This is one of the 10 movies in which Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau appear together, but not as a comedic duo.

The 18th-century vessel unearthed two weeks ago in Lower Manhattan has begun to emerge from the mist of history. She was most likely a brigantine; the two-masted workhorse of the coastal trade, ranging perhaps from New England (where she might have picked up lumber needed by an ever-growing New York City) as far south as Barbados (from which she would have carried sugar and molasses to feed a growing population).

PEABODY--Judith. The Board of Trustees, artists, and staff of The Public Theater mourn the passing of our dear friend and long-time Board member, Judith Peabody. Judith was a key player in the creation of The Public and instrumental to all of The Public's fundraising endeavors. Her incredible spirit and enthusiasm for both The Public and the people of New York were cherished by everyone who had the privilege to know her, and admired by all. We offer our deepest sympathies to Sam and the entire Peabody family. Oskar Eustis, Artistic Director, Andrew D. Hamingson, Executive Director, Warren Spector, Chairman

MICHAELS--Jane Tierman, passed away on Wednesday, July 28th at her home in Rockville Centre, NY, after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by her devoted and loving husband of over 40 years, Joseph Michaels IV, loving and adored children, Joseph Michaels V, M.D. and Jess (Michaels) Bernstein, and their wonderful spouses, Heather and Michael, adored grandchildren, Jake Dalton Michaels, Parker Shane Michaels and Cameron Juliet Michaels, and loving sister and brother-in-law, Susan Tierman Kroll, M.D. and Mark Kroll. Jane was an Honors graduate of Baldwin High School, Baldwin, NY, an Editor of her high school year book and newspaper, a Phi Beta Kappa, cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, College for Women, one of 16 participants in the Princeton University eight month long Scholar Abroad Program her junior year at Penn, a Sigma Delta Tau sorority sister at Penn, a computer educator and teacher for over 20 years, and a lifetime lover of reading, journalistic writing, and continual learning. Jane was very active and enjoyed swimming, tennis, biking, skiing and taking long walks on the beach. She was dedicated to her husband, children, grandchildren, family and long-time friends who will forever miss her kindness, generosity, joy, love of life, sense of humor and beautiful and continual smile. Her memories will live forever in the hearts of those who loved her. In lieu of flowers, please consider a contribution to the NYU Langone Cancer Institute, 160 East 34th Street, New York, NY 10016 or the Rockville Centre Public Library Endowment Lecture Fund, 221 N. Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY 11570. Graveside service will be held at Beth Olam Fields/Shearith Israel Cemetery, 2 Cypress Hills St., Ridgewood, Queens.

SAVETH--Edward N.,of Amherst, NY, and formerly of New York City, died on July 29, 2010 at the age of 95. He was predeceased by both his first wife Betty Norr Saveth and by his second wife Harriet Obstler Saveth. He is survived by his son, Henry, of New York City. He was born on February 16, 1915, received his BSS from CCNY in 1935 and his Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1946. He wrote numerous articles in periodicals, including "The New York Times Book Review," and "Commentary." He also published several books, perhaps being best known for editing "American History and the Social Sciences," which was reviewed in "The New York Times Book Review" on January 24, 1965. In 1985 he retired from the State University of New York Fredonia, where he had been a Distinguished Professor of American History since 1967. During his career he also served as a Fulbright Professor at both Kyoto University, Kyoto Japan, and Hebrew University, Jerusalem. A special academic interest of his was the role played by patricians in American politics.

Alex Rodriguez is owed a lot of money, and he wants to make sure he gets it all. That is the focus of the objection he filed in a bankruptcy court in Texas on Wednesday. Rodriguez is owed $24.9 million in deferred compensation by the Texas Rangers, who traded him to the Yankees six years ago. When the Rangers voluntarily pushed themselves into bankruptcy in May to help speed the sale of the club, Rodriguez was listed as the largest unsecured creditor.

A famous professional bridge player, he was sought out by international players to join their tournament teams. He is survived by nephews Ronald and Jeffrey, niece Jane, his best friend Margaret Suran, and his grand niece and nephews, Ines, Adam, and Joshua. Services Friday, July 30th, 10:30am at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson.

The digital mailbag spilled forth questions from bros today, from yet more people with dietary restrictions, from birthday celebrators and nice if narrow-minded people looking for good food, decently priced. I have done my best answering. Expand on the responses in the comments below. And of course: Send me your questions! Q. A new challenge: boys' night out. We are a group of four to six high-school friends in our mid-40s who get together every couple of months to recapture a little of our glory years. The typical plan is to find a restaurant that is fun but not too crazy, nice but not too expensive, has good beer, spirits and wine options and most important food that will appeal to a bunch of guys who don't have their significant others with them. Past choices have included Char No. 4 (this hit all the right notes between the bourbon, bacon and interesting cuts of meat), Resto (pretty good, especially the burgers, but not quite lively enough), Cafe Katja (a real hit with our crowd who liked the beers, wines and wurst), 5 Napkin Burger (not such a hit - felt mass produced), Markt (a plus for the Belgian beer and mussels but not quite at the level of some of the other places), Bond St (the wrong vibe entirely). We typically get together on a weeknight fairly early so getting into most places should not be impossible. Most of us are based in Manhattan but one of our group lives on Long Island so if the place is reasonably accessible to subway lines that go to the LIRR (either Penn or Brooklyn) that is a plus.

WASHINGTON -- When President Obama steps into a General Motors plant on Friday morning -- as the majority shareholder surveying the government's investment in a company the White House called ''moribund'' just 18 months ago -- he will be doing more than just examining the first models of the all-electric Volt that began rolling off the production line this week. Mr. Obama will be delivering the opening salvo in a White House effort to argue that government bailouts, now the most charged phrase in the political lexicon, actually worked in the case of the auto industry -- much as they did in the banking industry, but with broader benefits for workers and consumers.

Despite facing a $42 million shortfall in patient revenue, the Cook County Health and Hospitals System has laid off only 100 workers out of the 1,350 positions that administrators promised to eliminate this fiscal year. A six-month status report shows 665 vacant positions and 335 filled positions that have been eliminated. But of the filled positions, only about 100 workers were actually laid off.

LANSING--Gerrit L. It is with profound sadness that we learn of the passing of Gerrit L. Lansing. With his wife, Sydie, he was a brilliant contributor to our travels and programs. He made significant contributions to the study of American Surrealism, and was a beloved member of our Museum family. His wisdom and gentle intelligence will be missed by his many friends from all over the world. We extend our deepest sympathy to Sydie, his sons Gerrit and Sims, daughter-in-law Patricia, and grandchildren Carolina, Gerrit III, and Magnus. ZUCKERMAN--Lynn, a retired accountant, passed away on July 27, 2010, at age 85. Raised in Allentown, PA and Brooklyn, NY, she graduated 2nd in her class at Franklin K. Lane High School. She married Harold Zuckerman in 1945, with whom she had two children. Widowed at age 38, Lynn went to work as a bookkeeper for a CPA in NYC. She went to school at night and graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Accounting from Brooklyn College in 1981. Lynn is survived by daughters Susan Zuckerman, of Manhattan, Mindy Zuckerman Hedley, of Oakland, CA, and; her son-in-laws Ron Kopitowsky and Jeffrey Hedley. Lynn had a beautiful spirit. All who knew her loved her and she will always be remembered.

HOUMA, La. -- Loulan Pitre Sr. was born on the Gulf Coast in 1921, the son of an oysterman. Nearly all his life, he worked on the water, abiding by the widely shared faith that the resources of the Gulf of Mexico were limitless. As a young Marine staff sergeant, back home after fighting in the South Pacific, he stood on barges in the gulf and watched as surplus mines, bombs and ammunition were pushed over the side.

My Sunday column is about pharmaceutical breakthroughs -- particularly misoprostol -- in the provision of safe abortion. In the United States and Europe, abortion is safe, but five-sixths of abortions take place in the developing world where the procedure is often highly unsafe. As I write in the column, misoprostol may change that, and it'll be very difficult for governments to prevent this revolution.

A key member of the team that won Super Bowl XLII, Strahan gets his sports fix now as a co-host of "Pros vs. Joes" on Spike TV. The reality show pits amateurs against professionals in various sports. If the high and low temperatures in Central Park on Saturday average at least 77.5, July 2010 will rank as the hottest month in New York since records began in 1869. Stephen Fybish, a weather historian, has delved into the numbers, from the National Weather Service, for these other highs and lows: July 6 was the hottest day this month, hitting 103 (and 97 in Mr. Fybish's Upper West Side kitchen). The highs on July 6 from 1999 to 2009: 101, 79, 72, 82, 89, 81, 82, 77, 83, 79, 83. The only years that have had temperatures topping 103 are 1918 (Aug. 7), 1936 (July 9) and 1977 (July 21).

HELLER--Anita Louise Cloutier de la Garza, Ph.D.,of Naples, FL, 1938-2010, passed away peacefully at her vacation home in Sag Harbor, NY, this past Sunday, July 25th, after a five month battle with pancreatic cancer. Born in Lewiston, Maine, Anita graduated from St. Dominic's High School as the Valedictorian and the Class President. She attended Manhattanville College, transferred and received her Bachelor Degree from Georgetown University and her Master's and Doctor of Philosophy in Linguistics from Columbia University. Anita's accomplishments include: Partnership with late husband where they lobbied for ground breaking medical malpractice reform and were intimately involved with the Queens County Medical Society and the MSSNY from 1970's through early 1990's. She was a champion for the mentally retarded through OMRDD. Later, she continued her passion for linguistics and education fighting for "English as a common language" as a leader with US English. Anita is survived by her husband, Peter E. Heller, her four children Luis, Ana Luisa, Julia and Andree de la Garza and her grandchildren Alexandra and Madeleine Walsh. She was beloved wife to the late Alexander M. de la Garza, M.D., and mother to the late Alexander M. de la Garza II. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Saturday, July 31st, 1pm, at the Most Holy Trinity Church, 57 Buell Lane, East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Heartshare Human Services, Memo: Cuite Residence, C/O Ana Luisa de la Garza, 535 Dean Street #

An article on Friday about President Obama's impending visit to a General Motors plant contained several errors, including two related to the design and operation of the Chevrolet Volt, which went into production this week. It is a plug-in hybrid, with a gasoline engine as well as a battery pack that is externally rechargeable; it is not an all-electric vehicle. (The error was repeated in a caption in some copies.) The Volt can be driven with its gasoline engine powering the electric motor; it need not be plugged in overnight. The article also misstated Chrysler's plans for repayment of its government loans. At a news conference last November on the company's business plans, Chrysler executives said that the automaker would repay the loans by 2014; it is not the case that it has ''not indicated how fast it plans to do so.''

LANSING--Gerrit Livingston, of Greenwich, CT and Northeast Harbor, ME died peacefully on Tuesday, July 27th at the age of 68 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Born in New York City on May 12th, 1942, he leaves his wife of 40 years, Suydam (Sydie); sons Gerrit Jr. and Sims; daughter in law Patricia; three grandchildren: Carolina, Gerrit III and Magnus; and his brothers David and Evan. Mr. Lansing was raised in New York City. He attended the Allen-Stevenson School, the Lawrenceville School, Columbia University and New York University for undergraduate studies, as well as New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, where he received his Doctorate in Art History. A lifelong patron of the arts and extensive art collector, he was an expert in American Surrealism; an author of numerous papers; a teacher of art history; the curator of many exhibitions, including "Surrealism USA: Between 1930 and 1950" at the National Academy of Design. He was current Chairman of the Board of Independent Curators International (ICI) in New York City for 30 years; President of the Alumni Association of the Institute of Fine Arts in New York City; President of the Pot and Kettle Club on Mount Desert Island, Maine; as well as actively involved for over 40 years on varied committees at the Museum of Modern Art, including the International Council. He spent his summers in Northeast Harbor, ME where he thoroughly enjoyed the outdoors, and was an avid tennis and golf player. An intellectual, lifelong philanthropist, athlete and art collector, he was a deeply beloved father, grandfather, husband, brother, colleague and friend to all. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to ICI, 799 Broadway, Ste 205, New York, NY 10003.

GEORGE--Allan. July 31, 1914 - August 28, 1979 Dear Dad, how I wish you could have been with me, right here, to share the ups, downs and sideways of life for the past 31 years. I still don't understand why you had to leave us - so abruptly and so prematurely. How do you measure an absence? Please know that I miss you still, and always will. COHEN--Stanley, on July 30, 2010 at age 87. Beloved husband for 63 years of Cecilia. Loving and devoted father of Robert (Marsha), Richard (Suzanne), and Leslie (Steven) Gordon. Adored grandfather of David, Matthew, and Joshua. A graduate of NYU, he was a CPA and successful real estate developer. A World War II veteran and recipient pf the Purple Heart, although unable to swim, during 1943 he survived the sinking of his transport ship the HMT "Rohna" in the Mediterranean Sea. For many years he served on the Board of Trustees and as a member of numerous committees for Temple Judea in Manhasset. He was very proud of his ability to donate and support those doctors at Memorial Sloan-Kettering and North Shore University Hospitals who were so helpful to him. Services Sunday, August 1, 2010, 12 Noon at Temple Judea of Manhasset, 333 Searingtown Rd., Manhasset, NY.

One of my jobs as a teacher of bright, mostly Catholic undergraduates is to get them thinking about why they hold their religious beliefs.  It's easy enough to spark discussion about the problem of evil ("Can you really read the newspaper every day and continue to believe in an all-perfect God?") or about the diversity of religious beliefs ("If you'd been born in Saudi Arabia, don't you think you'd be a Muslim?").  Inevitably, however, the discussion starts to fizzle when someone raises a hand and says (sometimes ardently, sometimes smugly) "But aren't you forgetting about faith?"

Last week, I wrote a post about the adoption of our core values. I explained that we created awards that honor employees who best demonstrate those values and give us extra incentive to deliver great service. I also explained that I'd asked everyone to rate their team members -- on a scale of 1 to 10 -- on how well they align with our values, a process that helped me identify a couple of employees who really weren't a good fit. I think it's fair to say that some readers reacted negatively to this post.

NOTTINGHAM, ENGLAND -- So what do you do as a teenager who is the newest hero of a nation badly in need of good news, already a world champion and the fastest-rising star in a sport offering previously undreamt of wealth? Obviously, you register for a college course in accounting.

The island-loving jet set of Europe now has a new Mallorca hideaway. Cap Rocat, on a protected promontory on the southern flank of the Bay of Palma, is a 19th-century military fortress that has been converted into one of the region's more remarkable hotels. Twenty minutes from Palma, the sprawling structure is almost completely buried and all but imperceptible from both land and sea. Only the canopies of the lounges on the terrace are visible on the horizon. The local architect Antonio Obrador - who did the seaside retreats of, among others, Claudia Schiffer and Michael Douglas - let the structure's past set the design tone. The 24 rooms and suites are fashioned from old munitions stores and connected by a series of sunlit ramps and alleyways to the many vaulted public spaces. The old gunpowder depot is now a dimly lit space for private parties, with gun carriages serving as cocktail tables and stylized bullets as door handles. There are two restaurants, including one waterside, and an infinity pool created from one of the ramparts. Soon to be completed will be a wooden jetty, from which guests can sail, dive and water-ski the aquamarine Mediterranean.

KIERNAN--Bernard W. of Plainview and Southold, NY peacefully at home on July 30, 2010 in his 80th year. Predeceased a year ago by his wife of 50 years, Carole, he was survived by his six children, Bernard Jr. (Mary), Matthew (Cheryl), John (Kate), James, (Jill), Patricia (Scott Paskewitz), and Stephen (Tricia), 20 adoring grandchildren and his sisters, Mary and Kac Leavy. A veteran of the Korean War, he was a graduate of Hofstra University and an accountant by trade. He enjoyed a successful business career as the president of Whitney Communications Corporation and as a member of the Board of Directors of the International Herald Tribune, when it was jointly owned by Whitney Communications Corporation, the New York Times and the Washington Post, and the Vocational Foundation, a training and placement agency for underprivileged youth. A former member of the North Fork Country Club in Cutch- ogue, Bernie's passion for golf was only exceeded by his love of family and the Yankees. He will be remembered as a great father, successful businessman and a true gentleman who always lived by his credo "Remember who you are, what you are and where you came from!" Family and friends will be received 2-5pm and 7-9:30pm on Sunday, August 1st at the Wagner Funeral Home, 125 Old Country Road, Hicksville, NY 11801, 516-935-7100. Funeral Mass on Monday, August 2nd at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 500 South Oyster Bay Road, Hicksville, at 9:30am. Interment to follow at CalvertonNational Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation at www.liaf.org.

''I AM NOT going in there,'' said the trembling teenage girl standing at the shallow end of the pool. With her were a half-dozen other girls equally embarrassed to be paraded out in bathing suits and threatened with a swimming lesson. Down in the water was a hopelessly cheery woman, more than 50 years their senior, flipping around as fluidly as a porpoise. She was Jane Katz, 67, who has been teaching New Yorkers how to swim since the bobby socks era. Ignoring the protestations of the group, who were inmates incarcerated under the city's juvenile justice system, she urged them into the pool at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan.

If there's one thing that male models and the new wave of European first ladies can agree on, it's the importance of tattoos. This year, men's fashion shows in Paris and Milan have resembled prison rec yards with their grim-faced parades of inked young men. Breakout runway stars of the season Parker Hurley (Red) and Wes Phillips (DNA) poured Marlon Brando's celebrated swagger into Angelina Jolie's decorated skin. Marc Jacobs even recruited his personal tattoo artist, Scott Campbell, to stamp models with the Louis Vuitton logo and inspire a matching range of (exorbitantly expensive) leather bags. This season, tattoos are the last word in corporate counterculture.

It is hardly a secret that New York's much-maligned waterfront has come a long way. Treated for centuries like a conveniently located industrial latrine, valued largely for its shipping access, walled off from the city's residents with highways and bulkheads and metal gates, the waterfront -- 578 astonishingly varied miles of beach and marsh, river and bay, bluff and cove and pier -- has been showered with affection and money in recent years. The new ribbons of green lining the west coasts of Manhattan and Brooklyn are but part of the 308 acres of waterfront parkland the city has added since 1992.

A series in which writers from around the world describe the view from their windows. Most of my writing time is spent forming the next sentence in my imagination. When my mind is busy with words, all by itself my eye moves away from the page and the tip of the fountain pen.This is the landscape I have gazed upon through my Istanbul window for the last 15 years. On the left side is Asia and in the middle the Bosphorus and its opening to the Sea of Marmara, as well as the islands I have been going to each summer for 58 years. To the right is the entrance to the Golden Horn and the part of the city that Istanbul residents refer to as the Old Town, home of the Ottoman dynasty for four centuries, including Topkapi Palace, the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque.

PETSCHEK--Stephen Ronald, beloved father, grandfather, brother, and friend, died on July 24, 2010, in New York. He was 79. Born on June 28, 1931, in Prague, Czechoslovakia, the son of Walter and Franziska (Urbach) Petschek, Stephen came to the U.S. in 1941. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy before graduating magna cum laude from Harvard University and earning his JD, cum laude, from Harvard Law School. He practiced law at Cravath, Swaine and Moore, served for some time as Assistant to the United States Ambassador to Belgium and then entered investment banking, first as a partner at Loeb Rhoades and Co. and next as president of the J. Henry Schroder Corporation. His working life cut short by an accident, Stephen lived for many years in Seal Harbor, Maine. He was a Life Trustee and former Chairman of the Board of the Jackson Laboratory, a Trustee and past President of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and a Trustee of the Institute for Defense Analyses in Washington, DC. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the New York Yacht Club and the Knickerbocker Club. Stephen always had a passion for music, a keen interest in world events, and was an avid sailor. The way he maintained his wit despite the enormous challenges he faced in the latter part of his life was a true inspiration. His wisdom and generosity benefited many. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by daughters Jennifer Petschek and Alexandra Robson Petschek, their mother Danielle Tubiana, grandson William Robson, brother Alfred Petschek, and sister Susan Petschek. Contributions in Stephen's memory may be made to the Jackson Laboratory, P.O. Box 254, Bar Harbor, ME 04609-0254 or to the MDI YMCA, 21 Park Street, Bar Harbor, ME 04609. A small private memorial service will be held.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

A review on June 13 about ''Burmese Lessons,'' a memoir by Karen Connelly, misstated the date and circumstances of Burma's being renamed Myanmar. The name was changed in 1989, the year after a coup d'état by Gen. Saw Maung, not after the 1962 coup led by Gen. Ne Win. A reader recently brought the error to editors' attention.

RITTER--George Joseph, 90, a veteran Connecticut lawmaker and pioneering advocate for human and civil rights, died peacefully of pneumonia on July 18, 2010. Mr. Ritter was a prodigious and creative force in a life-long pursuit of social justice, establishing national non-profit models for integrated, affordable housing in the early 1960's with his wife, Patricia Ritter, Jackie Robinson and Eleanor Roosevelt. He was an attorney for Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. at the beginning of Dr. King's career. Mr. Ritter's great talent was forging public policy for the disenfranchised. He was key in establishing a 40-hour work week, collective bargaining and "last best offer" binding arbitration for Connecticut government employees. In the 1950's, he organized some of Connecticut's first municipal unions. From the 1950's through the 1970's he served as Hartford Corporation Counsel, a Democratic member of the Hartford City Council and then a Connecticut State Representative. He practiced law in Hartford for more than 50 years. His big heart, courage, originality, frankness and optimism will be sorely missed. He was born in New York City on March 26, 1920 to Charles and Gertrude Ritter. For 58 years he was married to Patricia Kingsley Ritter, his partner in social activism and life, who died in 2004. He leaves his children, Martha, Scott, Thomas, Penn and John and eight grandchildren. More at courant.com/obituaries

Over a five-decade career, Dennis Hopper earned the well-deserved mantle of the rebellious auteur, actor and all-around American artist. Whether it was post-Depression-era angst, the Beat generation's age of exploration, Vietnam War resistance or 1980s venomous debauchery, Hopper's performances reflected the shifting psyche of America's cultural landscape. On screen he appeared unafraid, even fiercely entrenched in the zeitgeist. Now the late actor's art, much of which is unknown to a large public, is the focus of an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles entitled ''Dennis Hopper Double Standard.'' To heighten the drama of the occasion, this exhibition - which had been bumped up on the schedule due to Hopper's failing health - is the first for the museum's newly installed director, Jeffrey Deitch. Wearing his trademark New York pinstripes, Deitch was in full swing. (Consider the old story about how the pinstripes of the Yankees' uniforms were designed to distract the competition.) While the show largely under-delivers in depth of content, it is regardless, if not regrettably, a timely exhibition, one that is ideally suited to L.A. and that marks precisely the kind of quick command that Deitch has in his new role.

General Motors, after announcing on Tuesday that the Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid car would cost $41,000, was unfazed by inevitable comparisons to the Nissan Leaf, a battery electric car that will arrive in select markets at the end of the year, around the same time as the Volt. At $32,780, the Leaf is far less expensive. ''Honestly, they're two different vehicles,'' said Dave Darovitz, a G.M. spokesman. ''One is range limited, and the other one offers 40 miles of gas-free driving and then a further 300 miles of travel.''

WILKINSON--William. Who brought style and humor and exacting standards to hotels and restaurants and the food business in the Bay Area for over 25 years, died on July 19 at his home in San Francisco. He was 68. Bill was born in The Bronx and raised in Yonkers. After graduating from hotel school at Paul Smiths College he began his career at Restaurant Associates. He left Restaurant Associates for a stint in the Navy, returning to civilian life as the assistant food and beverage manager at the Waldorf-Astoria. He left the Waldorf for a corporate job at Intercontinental Hotels. He traveled the world for Intercon before he went to Maui in 1975 to open the Intercon at Wailea as resident manager. In 1976 he came to San Francisco to become the general manager of the Stanford Court Hotel. During his five years there the property was one of the best hotels in the country and a center of the emerging American food scene. In 1981 he left to develop and operate the Campton Place Hotel. Both the hotel and its eponymous restaurant were immediate hits as were his cooks who included Jan Birnbaum, Bradley Ogden, George Marrone, Craig Stoll and Charlie Trotter. In 1989 he recreated Campton Place in downtown Los Angeles with the Checkers Hotel, where Jerry Comfort and later Thomas Keller served as chefs. After his business partners sold the hotels he bought Greenleaf Produce in 1993, building that business into the largest company on the San Francisco Produce Market. Bill was an active member of the community as well as a successful businessman. He served twice as the chairman of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce and also served on the boards of the Ft. Mason Center, the Hotel Council, the local Salvation Army, and the Produce Market. He was known for his stories, his compassion, and most of all the grace with which he treated his employees and customers. He is survived by his partner of 33 years, Tom Given; his brother Tom Wilkinson of Albuquerque, NM; and his sisters Isabel Kimmel of Hawthorn, NY, Alice Soto of San Juan, PR and Julie Francis of Scottsdale AZ. Contributions to the National Parkinsons Foundation or Food Runners of San Francisco.

LANSING--Gerrit Livingston, of Greenwich, CT and Northeast Harbor, ME died peacefully on Tuesday, July 27th at the age of 68 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Born in New York City on May 12th, 1942, he leaves his wife of 40 years, Suydam (Sydie); sons Gerrit Jr. and Sims; daughter in law Patricia; three grandchildren: Carolina, Gerrit III and Magnus; and his brothers David and Evan. Mr. Lansing was raised in New York City. He attended the Allen-Stevenson School, the Lawrenceville School, Columbia University and New York University for undergraduate studies, as well as New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, where he received his Doctorate in Art History. A lifelong patron of the arts and extensive art collector, he was an expert in American Surrealism; an author of numerous papers; a teacher of art history; the curator of many exhibitions, including "Surrealism USA: Between 1930 and 1950" at the National Academy of Design. He was current Chairman of the Board of Independent Curators International (ICI) in New York City for 30 years; President of the Alumni Association of the Institute of Fine Arts in New York City; President of the Pot and Kettle Club on Mount Desert Island, Maine; as well as actively involved for over 40 years on varied committees at the Museum of Modern Art, including the International Council. He spent his summers in Northeast Harbor, ME where he thoroughly enjoyed the outdoors, and was an avid tennis and golf player. An intellectual, lifelong philanthropist, athlete and art collector, he was a deeply beloved father, grandfather, husband, brother, colleague and friend to all. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to ICI, 799 Broadway, Ste 205, New York, NY 10003.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the battle over the estate of the chess player Bobby Fischer incorrectly attributed the statement that he wanted to ''pass on his genes.'' Einar Einarsson, a friend of Mr. Fischer's, heard it from other friends of his in the Philippines, not from Mr. Fischer himself.

If the proliferation of men's-wear blogs and dapper new clothing lines are any indication, the boys are beginning to preen again. But the real peacock of fashion has always been the dandy. Though Beau Brummell would get his cravat in a knot at the idea being the poster boy for male frippery - he actually advocated a restrained, gentlemanly glamour - he has become the poster boy for flamboyant dressing and a life devoted to aesthetics. It is to this perception of Beau and Co. that a whimsical new book, ''Four Famous Dandies,'' pays tribute, albeit in paper-doll form.

KAVKEWITZ--Abraham, was born in Brooklyn, NY on November 22, 1926 and died in Scottsdale on July 24, 2010. He attended Brooklyn College, CCNY and NYU. He became a Civil Engineer and earned a P.E. in New York and Arizona. He was married to his wife Elaine for 50 years. They have one daughter Amy and three grandchildren Jacob, Shana and Lily who live in California. Abraham served in the US Army in World War II and Korea, where he was stationed in Germany and Japan. Graveside services with military honors will be held Thursday, July 29th at 9:30am at The National Memorial Cemetery of Arizona, 23029 N. Cave Creek Rd. in Phoenix. Services entrusted to Messinger Indian School Mortuary.

An article last Sunday about the transition to college misidentified the location of the University of Puget Sound, whose chief psychologist commented on making the adjustment. It is in Tacoma, Wash., not Seattle.

FEYEREISEN--Paul A.,Major General, US Army, ret. Paul Feyereisen died on July 25, 2010 after a long and full life. Paul began his military career in the Signal Corps in 1939. After assignments in the China/Burma/India Theatre, Office of the Chief of Staff of the Army, and Staff of the Comptroller, Tokyo, Japan, he received an MBA with distinction from Harvard University in 1954. He later served on the staff of the Under Secretary of the Army and attended the National War College in Washington, DC. He received his first star 1963 in recognition of his work with reorganizing the Army Material Command in Washington, DC. He received his second star for developing communication technologies with our allies. In 1973, after retiring to the private sector he joined ITT and subsequently worked for Catholic Relief Services in NYC. During this time, he was especially proud of his service as President of the Monmouth County Council, of The Boy Scouts of America. He is preceded in death by his devoted wife, Leona Stock. Survived by his son, Paul (Atlanta, GA), Nancy Studer (Vashon Island, WA) , Larry (Little Silver, NJ) and James (Marina Del Rey, CA). Memorial services and Internment at Arlington National Cemetery will be scheduled at a later date.
POLLACK--Susan. With sadness we mourn her loss. With joy we remember her courage, humor, energy, and friendship. Our deepest sympathies to Stanley and Jane. Trish and Arthur Toback
PFORZHEIMER--Carol K. There will be a Memorial Service for family and friends on September 1, 2010 at 2pm at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St.

COHEN--Stanley, on July 30, 2010 at age 87. Beloved husband for 63 years of Cecilia. Loving and devoted father of Robert (Marsha), Richard (Suzanne), and Leslie (Steven) Gordon. Adored grandfather of David, Matthew, and Joshua. A graduate of NYU, he was a CPA and successful real estate developer. A World War II veteran and recipient of the Purple Heart, although unable to swim, during 1943 he survived the sinking of his transport ship the HMT "Rohna" in the Mediterranean Sea. For many years he served on the Board of Trustees and as a member of numerous committees for Temple Judea in Manhasset. He was very proud of his ability to donate and support those doctors at Memorial Sloan-Kettering and North Shore University Hospitals who were so helpful to him. Services Sunday, August 1, 2010, 12 Noon at Temple Judea of Manhasset, 333 Searingtown Rd., Manhasset, NY.

SULLIVAN--Dennis, on July 25, 2010 of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved son of Anne and the late Lee Sullivan. Devoted brother of the late Kevin Sullivan. Memorial Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills, NY 11375, Wednesday, August 4 at 10:30am. Donations to Calvary Hospital 1740-70 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461 appreciated.

BOGUSLAV--Raphael, of Newport, RI, died July 18, 2010 at Rhode Island Hospital as a result of a motor vehicle accident. He is survived by his former wife, Donna Boguslav of Manhattan and by Mary Ann Kesson of Portsmouth, RI, his partner of 14 years. He was born in New York City July 24, 1929 to the late Isaac and Mary Boguslav. He attended the Art Students League from the age of nine, later the High School of Music and Art and graduated from Cooper Union in 1951. He worked as a graphic designer after apprenticing with Milton Glaser. In the sixties he joined Lippincott and Margulies where he produced package designs, trademarks, and logotypes including iconic images for PPG, New York Life Insurance, Chrysler. In the late sixties he and his wife had their own graphic design firm in Manhattan. His graphic work and pen and brush lettering earned him a prominent place in the world of calligraphy and type design. He gave many workshops in calligraphy and lettering nationally and taught at Cooper Union and RISD. Equally talented musically, he was a skillful classical pianist and a distinguished guitarist and singer. He toured extensively with Harry Belafonte and with Theo Bikel, gave a solo recital at Carnegie Hall, and released two solo recordings. In the seventies he moved to Newport, RI, to pursue painting and continued work as a graphic designer. He was an ardent tennis player, a devoted reader, a brilliant conversationalist, a gourmet cook. He was a valued friend to all who knew him. He is sorely missed by all. A memorial service is planned in Newport in September. Condolences, information at: memorialfuneralhome.com.

MATHERS--William Harris. Bill Mathers passed away July 27, 2010 in Wallingford, CT. Bill graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth College and from Yale Law School with honors. He worked as a corporate attorney with Milbank Tweed and later became a Senior Partner with Chadbourne Parke Whiteside & Wolff in New York City. During WWII, he served with distinction as a Major in Army Air Intelligence. He was a member of Piping Rock Golf Club in Locust Valley, NY and the Seminole Club in Florida. Bill was also a member of the Downtown Club, New York Yacht Club, Yale Club, and the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club. During his retirement in northeastern Vermont, Bill volunteered for SCORE (Service Corps of Retired Executives). Bill leaves behind Myra, his wife of 68 years, and six children: Bill, Michael, John, Myra, Ursula, and Ann. Beecher & Bennett Funeral Home, 2300 Whitney Ave., Hamden, CT in care of services. To send a condolence please see obituary at www.beecherandbennett.com

Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Sunday with an article about spies and other bearers of secrets who defect and then return home omitted the given name of a son-in-law of Saddam Hussein, a general with knowledge of Iraq's weapons programs who defected, returned and was shot. As the article noted, he was Hussein Kamel, not Kamel Hassan. (Hassan was part of his formal name, Hussein Kamel Hassan al-Majid. He was also referred to at times as Hussein Kamel al-Majid.).

What is amazing and seems painfully obvious is if someone walks in with a band of hair missing around the entire circumference of their head, you would ask the question: have you had a CT scan? Not, 'what did you eat for breakfast yesterday that would cause your hair to fall out today?' RICHARD A. PATTERSON, a Los Angeles lawyer who represents patients exposed to radiation overdoses. [12]

PECKAR--Paul, 92, of Edgewater, formerly of Bergenfield, on July 31, 2010. He was a Professional Engineer and Master builder of major New York landmarks. Beloved husband of Pearl. Devoted father of Robert Peckar (Maxine) and Elaine Kinder (Jay). Loving grandfather of Gabriel, Jeremy (Landa), and Leah Kinder, Simara Bruhim (Ilan), and Marissa Silleg (Adam). Great-grandfather of Orli and Abigail Bruhim and Ryder Silleg. Funeral services will be private.

ROSENZWEIG--Elsa. The Law Firm of McAloon & Friedman, P.C. sadly notes the passing, at age 94, of Elsa Rosenzweig, the mother of our esteemed senior partner Theodore Rosenzweig. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire family and know that she will be missed by all who knew her.

BOGARD--Solomon, 91, died peacefully on July 14, 2010. Born and raised in the Bronx, Sol attended Evander Childs High School and graduated from City College of New York with a degree in business administration. Sol was a veteran of World War II, attaining the rank of sergeant while serving in campaigns throughout North Africa and Italy. He completed 30 years of federal civil service as a procurement officer for the Departments of the Army and Navy, and for nine years also taught English and citizenship to foreign-born adults in night school. After a brief tenure with the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, in 1978 Sol began his 28-year career with the New York State Office of Court Administration at the Bronx Family Court. He went on to become the oldest serving civil servant in New York State's history before his retirement in 2006 at the age of 87. During his retirement, Sol began to divest his extensive collection of documents and photographs relating to World War II by donating them to museums, universities, embassies, and consulates throughout the world. He spent as much time and effort organizing this project as he did performing his job at the court. His administrative skills served him well until the end. Sol Bogard was married to Gloria Sloan Bogard for 60 years before her death in 2009. He is survived by their daughter Jill of Washington, DC and son Mitchell of New York. Contributions may be made in his memory to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington, DC 20024-2126.

ANDERSON--Eugene R.,82, July 30 at NY Hospital. Survived by his loving wife, Jenny Morgenthau, son Matthew from a previous marriage, grandchildren Javier, Andres and Miguel, sister-in-law Bridget, and nieces. Funeral at 4pm, Monday, August 2, Frank Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. Reception following at 25 East 86th Street. Donations in lieu of flowers to Police Athletic League or The Fresh Air Fund.

Near Paleochora, Crete, Aug. 26, 2009. ''My brother Hamish Williams was working in Budapest and lost his job last year when the economy crashed. He had nothing to do and nowhere to go, so he bought an old Volkswagen bus, nicknamed Piglet, and headed south for Greece. I joined him for a week in Crete, and we spent our time camping and traveling and meeting people from all over the world like we did in our 20s. Keep in mind we are both in our 40s now and are supposed to have settled down. Travel is freedom, and the smallest things become an adventure. It's a departure from the everyday that reminds you that there is a huge world out there worth exploring.'' Timothy Williams, Indianapolis

ON THE BUS To the Editor: Regarding ''The Humble Bus Takes Off'' (July 25), I'm a longtime BoltBus veteran, having taken it once a month between Boston and New York for years. When it was great, it was great -- a quiet ride, four hours flat, Wi-Fi all the way. When it was bad, though, it was the worst: packed buses, balky Internet and, worst, no way to know when you'd arrive.

ANDERSON--Eugene R. The Trustees and Staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage - A Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of Eugene Anderson, son-in-law of Chairman Robert Morgenthau. A true champion of the underdog and a man of great wisdom, he will be missed deeply by all who knew him. Our condolences go to his wife Jenny and family, and to the staff of Anderson Kill & Olick. David G. Marwell, Director

An entry in the Pulse column on July 11 about the stationery brand Mrs. John L. Strong referred incorrectly to its status. The company has been purchased and is still operating; it is not out of business.

The About New York column in some editions last Sunday, about the plight of Representative Charles B. Rangel as he deals with ethics charges, gave an outdated amount for a donation by a company and one of its executives to the Charles B. Rangel Center for Public Service at City College. As of July 23, the company, Nabors Industries, and its chief executive officer had donated $800,000 -- not $500,000 -- of a $1 million pledge to the center.

She will be greatly missed by her cherished companion, Reese. Contributions to Central Synagogue, 123 E. 55 St., New York City 10021 would be appreciated.

PARIS -- Nadjib Sirat is well aware of the risks he will face during his attempt to scale Everest, a mountain that researchers say claims at least one life for every 10 expeditions. But Sirat, an Afghan mountaineer, is undaunted, fired by a drive to dispel pejorative myths about Afghanistan and to promote Alpine sports in his homeland.

This summer's sandals echo those seen on the statues in the Egyptian, Greek and Roman sculpture galleries of museums. The sandals have multiple straps and flat soles or the cork platforms that were worn in Greek tragedies to give majesty to the gods. New this season is the ankle boot-sandal with multiple exposures, worn with painted toenails that might have surprised Cleopatra.
An article last Sunday about prep clothing for men misidentified the designer for the Woolrich Woolen Mills spring 2011 collection. He is Daiki Suzuki, not Tokihito Yoshida.

DUBOVSKY--Anne. July 27, 2010. A rare heroic woman who fought cancer for years. She won many battles but lost the war. Her husband Steven, daughters Amelia and Elizabeth, sister Jean, nephews Michael and Robert, niece Kayla, brothers-in-law Dan and Lester, and Nana will miss her terribly as will many friends and relatives. We shall not see her like again.
Classical Vivien Schweitzer

An article last Sunday about human rights groups' strongly criticizing the harsh prison sentence imposed by the Chinese government on an ethnic Uighur journalist, Gheyret Niyaz, who gave an interview to a Hong Kong news publication, misstated the length of the sentence imposed last December on another Chinese intellectual, Liu Xiaobo. He got up to 11 years in prison, not 15. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated part of the name of the group whose executive director, Sharon Hom, issued a statement criticizing the sentence. Ms. Hom heads Human Rights in China, not Human Rights Watch in China.

An illustration credit on July 18 with a review about ''The German Genius,'' by Peter Watson, misstated the positions of two of the illustration's composite elements. The image of Nietzsche, from Brown Brothers, appeared at the bottom of the illustration, and that of Freud, from The Associated Press, was at the center.

HACKSHAW--Eugenia, passed away peacefully at the age of 85 on July 12, 2010. As a resident of Lakeview, NY for over 40 years, she was involved in numerous educational and community service issues. Born in Cleveland, OH, she received the Stella Berkeley Award in Sociology upon graduating from Flora Stone Mather College. After graduation, she worked in various social service agencies based in Pittsburgh, Detroit and Philadelphia. Upon completion of a doctoral degree in Public Administration from New York University, she received appointments as an Assistant Professor of Social Work at Hunter College and as a Visiting Professor at Waterloo Lutheran University in Ontario, Canada. Eugenia Hackshaw is survived by her loving husband of 59 years, Dr. James Hackshaw, her son, Dr. Reg Hackshaw and his wife, Kathleen as well as nieces and nephews residing in Cleveland.
Pop Nate Chinen

PETRUCELLI--Anthony J. July 24th, 2010. Tony Petrucelli surrounded by his daughter, Jennifer, and her dear husband Rob, his first wife, Nina, and his second wife, Nora, his step-son Sam, as well as a loving support group left this life with amazing grace. Like all of his photographs this last picture was perfect in detail and emotion, a moment captured in all our hearts to be held forever. He did it all so uniquely with style, class and humor to the end. A life of intensity, creativity and a giant thrust for love. We miss him now and forever. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a contribution to the Anthony J. Petrucelli Memorial Scholarship Fund at Rochester Institute of Technology. A memorial will be held this Fall in Newport Beach, CA.

HALPERIN--Clara, July 26, 2010. Passed away peacefully at home at age 94. Beloved daughter of the late I.C. and Tess Herman. Clara is preceded in death by her sister Irene Kenner, her husbands Sidney Frankel and Harry Halperin, and her nephew Peter Kenner. She is survived by family members Alan and Giselle Frankel of Waterville, Maine, Barbara, Nick and Kate Kenner of New York, Robert, Marguerite, Zack, and Tess Kenner of Los Angeles, California, and Martin, Camilla and Max Kenner of New York. Clara lived an enchanted and exciting life to the end. Her quick wit and kindness will be missed by all. The family thanks Rita Keeffe and Denise Codrington for the loving care they provided Clara in her final years.

N.F.L. training camps are opening, and Michael Strahan says he is happy that he will be in a comfortable television studio. Those wilting two-a-day workouts are one of the few football rituals that Strahan, a former All-Pro defensive end for the Giants, says he does not miss since he retired in 2008. A key member of the team that won Super Bowl XLII, Strahan gets his sports fix now as a co-host of ''Pros vs. Joes'' on Spike TV. The reality show pits amateurs against professionals in various sports. He is also an analyst for ''Fox NFL Sunday.'' Q. Terrell Owens and Donovan McNabb have been feuding since they shared a huddle with the Philadelphia Eagles. In an episode of ''Pros vs. Joes,'' they play on the same team. How did you manage that?A. We didn't know what to expect when they got together. But in the locker room before the show, they were cool. They got there and played well together. The show is so competitive, you put aside all your little issues because you want to win. There were more confrontations with the regular Joes.

Eurostar, the high-speed rail service that connects London with the rest of Europe through the English Channel Tunnel, has started a new Web site touting its leisure-focused service. The site, called Europe by Eurostar, offers the usual timetable and ticket booking options, but adds a layer of art, food, fashion and music listings available via the rail service, mostly focusing on hidden gems instead of the usual tourist spots. In addition, a nifty interactive map integrates several countries' national rail services with Eurostar lines, allowing travelers to book multi-destination journeys without having to brave an array of foreign-language Web sites. A warning: ticket prices displayed on the itinerary map are at the cheapest possible rate and can become unavailable very quickly. The actual price, found further along the booking process, can be significantly more expensive than the one initially displayed. Also, as the Web site is still under construction, some content is out of date and some destinations do not have content yet.

LIEB--Cynthia Jo, of Manhattan passed away from cardiac disease in her home on the morning of July 29th. Ms Lieb was born in Newark New Jersey. Her parents were the late Sylvia Sass Lieb and David Paul Lieb. Cynthia Lieb received her Bachelors Degree from New York University, a Masters in Education from the University of Pittsburgh, and studied business at Temple University. She went from the classroom to the New Jersey Council on Economic Education. As the latter's Associate Director, she conducted seminars for school personnel and business leaders and raised funds for this private, non-profit organization. She also authored a national curriculum guide for elementary school teachers. After a career in education, Ms Lieb made the transition from an active lay leader to a professional fundraiser. At the time of her death she was President and founder of CL Consulting, a management firm that provided fundraising services to private and non-profit institutions. Ms Lieb raised millions of dollars for organizations through major donor cultivation, corporate sponsorship, and special events. Ms. Lieb through out her life has been active in the Jewish community. She worked as a Regional Director for B'nai Brith International, as Somerset Division Director for the Jewish Federation of Central New Jersey, and for a large number of American Friends of Israeli organizations. Cynthia is survived by her daughter Allyson Samuel, siblings Irwin Lieb, Carin and Paul Feldman, and Hilarie Lieb and Morrie Goldman. The funeral will be held on Sunday August 1st at 11am, at Riverside Funeral Home 333 Amsterdam Ave., New York City, New York, 10023. The internment will follow at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge. Donations in her memory can be made to Women at Risk, New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University Medical Center 601 West 168th Street suite #

The Los Angeles-based jeweler Irene Neuwirth decided to go bold with her fall collection, which she designed around this striking pendant, made of chrysoprase, moonstone, aquamarine, rose of France and onyx. ''With everyone designing really safe pieces of late, I thought it was a good time to be over the top and vivid,'' Neuwirth says. A recent road trip across northern Spain also had a hand in her creative process. ''I found a lot of big, colorful jewelry in the thrift stores there, which inspired me to make a costume line that was precious.'' The necklace is $38,580 at Barneys New York. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The July issue Vogue tried to tap into the mood of the hour with ''Magnificent Obsession,'' a fashion feature styled as a 1950s Technicolor melodrama, one replete with period-like headbands, swing skirts and skinny men's ties. Vogue followed up in its current issue with ''Classic Revival, a spread that showed off the sort of tightly structured handbags Grace Kelly favored in ''Rear Window.'' The bland expressions, hyper-fastidious grooming and starchy frocks of the models were vividly in keeping with tirelessly calculated efforts by the fashion community to resurrect the decorum, apparent tidiness - and subterranean naughtiness - of Cheever country in the early 1960s.
Theater Ben Brantley

''This may seem a bit obvious, but the mood of the nation is not exactly attuned right now to introspective music. After all, we're in a recession, unemployment is high, and there are simply too many pressures affecting people's moods to sit in the heat and weep or swell with nuances of reflection worthy of a Wordsworth poem. (P.S. I like Sarah McLachlan's music.) I would suggest moving Lilith Fair's tour dates to the fall, or into concert halls around the winter holidays, when people are more attuned to relating to one another. Lady Gaga is like the Busby Berkeley of pop music, and we're in a 1930s kind of mood.'' The elite sport of polo has become increasingly accessible to travelers as hotels and resorts have started highlighting lessons and matches as one of their main attractions. One of the newest polo destinations is the 12-room Estancia Vik Jose Ignacio, near Punta del Este, Uruguay, which opened last year. It offers lessons to all levels on its polo field for $150 an hour. Guests can also catch matches held on the house turf in December and January.

For the fourth time in a week, I woke up to the sound of a pigeon pecking my window screen, trying to nibble its way into my bedroom in the early morning. In just a few months, a community of city birds had established itself in the gap between my building and the one to the west, jeopardizing the quality of the little light and air that the Tenement House Act of 1901 guarantees me. It was April, I think, when I noticed a nest on top of my neighbors' air-conditioner. Inside, two little eggs received full-time attention from a couple of pigeons. It was like having a private National Geographic show. I pointed it out to guests and even texted my roommate when the babies were born. I had expected the feathered family to leave after that, but no. Another egg was laid. And another. By the time it got warm, the dynasty had developed a full sense of proprietorship of the airshaft.

MATTIS--Louis P.,"Lou," 68, of Carbondale, CO passed away on Wednesday July 14, 2010 following a courageous battle with cancer. He was 68. He will be remembered for his compassion, generosity, integrity and the difference he made in many lives. He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. Mattis retired in 1994 as Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Sterling Winthrop Inc., a worldwide developer, manufacturer and marketer of pharmaceuticals and consumer health products. He was also Co-Chairman of Sanofi Winthrop, a global pharmaceutical joint venture. He participated in the design and implementation of major corporate mergers, led several international joint ventures and the conceptualization and execution of a Four billion multinational alliance between Sterling and Sanofi, which was the first of its kind in the industry. In 1993 "Pharmaceutical Executive" magazine named him "Pharmaceutical Executive of the Year" and The A.B. Freeman School of Business at Tulane University voted him "Outstanding Alumnus". He served as a director of Salomon Brothers Asset Management and on a number of corporate, association, non-profit and philanthropic boards including chairing The Advisory Board of the A.B. Freeman School of Business at Tulane University; Governor of The Center For Creative Leadership; Honorary Chairman of the Special Olympics; Partner in the New York City Partnership; and member of The National Council for Health Education, The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association and The Non-Prescription Drug Manufacturers Association. Following his retirement, he found joy in raising and riding his horses on his ranch in Carbondale, CO and in diving in Belize but he found his greatest joy in the company of his family. He is survived by his wife of six years, Judy, his children Ted Mattis (Sally), Debbie Collier (Bill), his seven grandchildren, his sister Salli White (David) his nephews, and former wife, Patsy Cuthbert. A service celebrating his life was held at his home in Carbondale on July 16, 2010. The family has requested that in light of Lou's dedication to the health and welfare of children, memorials may be sent to Children's Tumor Foundation 95 Pine Street, 16th Floor New York, NY 10005 or Holy Cross Anglican School, San Pedro, Ambergris Cay, Belize, Central America.

RUTMAN--Henry, passed away from lymphoma in New York City on July 27, 2010 at age 84. Survived by his loving and devoted wife of nearly 60 years Sherry Berg Rutman; he will be missed by his adoring children, Howard Rutman and Lori Fife, their spouses Shereen Gertel Rutman and Mark Fife, as well as his grandchildren, Elizabeth Fife and Melissa and Stephen Rutman. Throughout his life he always maintained his warm smile, abundant kindness and gentlemanly appearance. After surviving the Holocaust, he immigrated to New York where he spent most of his career as a principal and executive of Gallery, a woman's apparel firm. He was prominent in the woman's apparel industry as a designer, innovator and importer; he was also a highly regarded teacher and served as a mentor to many in the industry. His kind heart, warmth, creativity and integrity in all aspects of his life serve as an inspiration to all who knew him. Contributions in memory of Henry Rutman are welcome to be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage - A Living Memorial to the Holocaust.

McCLELLAN--Linda Lawrence. Linda passed away peacefully on Tuesday, July 27th with her husband of 50 years at her side in Vero Beach, FL, following a long struggle with a respiratory illness. Linda was born on April 23rd, 1939 in Bronxville, NY. She attended Emma Willard School and went on to Wellesley College, later earning her degree from Sarah Lawrence College. Linda is survived by her husband S. Griffin McClellan, III, and her four adult children, Elaine M. Niemann, Leigh M. Weed, S. Griffin McClellan, IV (Mike) and Linda M. Lane, their spouses, and grandchildren Tom, Alex, Erik, Sam, Max, JT, and Ali. Linda is also survived by her sisters Mary Clifford and Hope Cole, a host of nephews and nieces, and mother-in-law Mary Jane McClellan. She is predeceased by her father, Dudley B. Lawrence, Jr., her mother Hope R. Lawrence, and her brother Hugh Lawrence. Linda lived her life with a great passion for family, friends, and animals, always putting their needs before her own. Memories of Linda's irrepressible good humor and joy in life will forever warm the hearts of all who knew her. She will never leave us. A celebration of Linda's life will take place on Wednesday, August 11th, 2010, at 11:00am at St. Joseph of Arimathea Church in White Plains, NY. A reception will follow at the church. Interment will take place at Kensico Cemetery at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Hilton Head Humane Association, P.O. Box 21790, Hilton Head Island, 29925, or to the Salvation Army.
