LIVING ROOMS Many architects trained in the 1960s and '70s moved into old houses or prewar apartments themselves. Their renovations showed that it was possible to be creative, modern and historically respectful at the same time. These projects showed up in magazines, creating a taste for inventively remodeled old buildings. Exposed brick interior walls became common, along with decorative moldings, daring color combinations and exposed columns. Despite the rising crime rates and urban riots of the 1960s, a growing number of middle- and upper-middle-class residents began to move into urban areas in the 1970s and '80s, at least partly because of their cheap, historic housing stock. But the trendiness of the old embraced by the early postmodernists likely had something to do with it as well. Urban streets developed such cachet that they turned up in television programs like ''Sesame Street,'' which premiered in 1969, and ''The Cosby Show,'' which ran from 1984 to 1992.

LATSHAW--John, 88 known as "Big John", a beloved friend, and father, passed away on July 18, 2010, in Naples, Florida. Born in Kansas City on December 10, 1921 to a prominent family in the area since the early 1800's. His family fortune was wiped out in the Depression and still only a boy; John found five jobs while going to school when most men couldn't find one. As a young man, he started out as a cashier for the securities firm of Harris, Upham. One day, he was asked to fill in for a stock trader who was sick. Though shy, he quickly showed he was a natural born trader "not a charts and research" trader but a visceral trader whose great instinct would benefit many people, for decades to come. In 1954, Big John was a managing partner of Uhlmann & Latshaw, which then merged with EF Hutton & Co. making him the youngest partner in Hutton's history. He rose to become Executive Vice President, managing director, member of the executive committee and director of E.F. Hutton Inc., the E.F. Hutton Group and E.F. Hutton International and his opinions on the economy have been widely quoted, and he was an oft-requested speaker. When most men retire, he did and became the Chairman of the Board, and Chief Executive Officer of B.C. Christopher & Company. Later, he left the brokerage business to become Chief Executive Officer, Chairman and owner of what he named Latshaw Enterprises, Inc., which included Latshaw Tools, Wescon Products Company, Anderson & Forrester, Coast Wire & Plastic Tech, Inc., and MC Electronics, and held positions at numerous other ventures. Civic duty ran in his family and President Harry Truman, who was friends with his uncle, Judge Latshaw, befriended him as a young man so John was always involved in politics not just as a contributor for local, state and national races but by devoting his time for his friends who ran for state office or working on national campaigns such as: running the Re-elect Nixon campaign for Missouri and Kansas for the landslide victory in 1972. Later, he was National Chairman of Democrats for Ford as he was, in fact, a life-long Democrat, which illustrates his independent spirit and preference for people not adherence to rigid ideas and he was a great supporter on both sides of the aisle. He was appointed His Majesties' Royal Thai Consul to the United States by His Majesty the King of Thailand. Years later, in 1983, at Saranrom Palace, Bangkok, Thailand, Mr. Latshaw was decorated by the Prime Minister of Thailand with the Chaturathabhorn of the Most Exalted Order of the White Elephant Award, the highest award given to a civilian, in honor of their contributions to Thailand. A decade later, he was decorated with The Knight Commander of the Most Noble Order of the Crown of Thailand at the Thai Embassy in Washington, D.C. He was also honored and made a Knight Hospitalier of Malta by the Sovereign Order of St. John of Jerusalem. He received the Citation of Merit for Outstanding Achievement and Meritorious Service in Business and Public Administration in 1957, the first year such an award was given by the University of Missouri. On April 30, 1970, in the U.S. Senate, he was given the Golden Eagle Award for "defending the principles of capital formation, achievements in business and civic action, and full dedication of economic freedom in all its broad humanity". His interests were not limited to finances or politics so with his friend, Lamar Hunt, he helped bring the unknown sport of soccer to the United Sates, forming the North American Soccer League and his team, the Kansas City Spurs, won the first championship. He was part of the introduction of cable television to the United States and as chairman, formed a coalition of civic leaders to create the fifth largest cable operation in the United States, American Cablevision. His exceptional dynamism and talent enabled him to serve on an unusual number of organizations and charitable causes among which: the NASA Advisory Board to the President of the United States, 1983-1986; He was member of the Exec. Board of the Religious Heritage of America Executive Board, Invest-in-America A member of the Society of Fellows- the Nelson Gallery of Art; and the Chairman- Board of Trustees the Conservatory of Music. He was truly "larger than life". When asked how tall he was, he would wryly reply "five foot-twenty". Yet it was not due to his stature but because of the kind person he was that everyone called him "Big John". He was a loyal friend, an inspiration to his co-workers, and was a mentor to many. He was an innovative thinker who refused to quit. He loved life and lived by his motto of "making money and having fun - but not one without the other" and made life, frankly, just more fun. A gentleman with a delightful sense of humor, and an impish grin, he always had a twinkle in his eye. In his teens, he could clear the dance floor but even at the end of his life, he could still make women swoon as they fondly recalled, "he was the best dancer". He was well known throughout the world but always proud to be from Kansas City - a city he loved so much and supported, and his adopted home of Naples, Florida. He was preceded in death by his parents, Edna Parker Latshaw and Ross W. Latshaw; his son, Henry John Latshaw III; his brothers, Parker Latshaw, Robert Latshaw, and sister, Mercedes Anderson. He leaves behind his two daughters: Lady Jaffray, Constance, and Elizabeth Albright Latshaw.

My childhood home broke in half during the autumn of 1973, when my twin sister and I were 10 years old. Our parents called us together one evening to announce that they were splitting up, and just like that we became "products of a broken home." The scene still flickers in my mind: my sister and I sat between our two parents on a monstrous neo-Victorian couch upholstered in a weird, synthetic shade of pink. Everybody cried.

Nothing personal. But now that Dick Wolf's "Law & Order" has called it a day - or rather a 20-year run - it is time to notice what may be its most remarkable feature; not the brilliant formula that offers both the comfort of predictability and the promise of constant surprise (an episode almost never ends up where it seems to be going at the beginning), not the ability of the show to survive major cast changes without missing a beat, not the considerable accomplishment of making the arcane vocabulary of the law ( "fruit of the poisonous tree," "asked and answered," "prejudicial," "allocute," "goes to relevance") as familiar to TV viewers as the jargon of sports, but the extraordinarily long list of professions, classes and category of persons it doesn't like.

That's the subject taken up in an American Spectator symposium, which is divided, roughly speaking, between writers who think the Republicans have become serious about limited government again and writers who think they haven't. Not surprisingly, I incline toward the latter camp: There may be specific Republicans (a Paul Ryan, a Chris Christie, a Mitch Daniels) who are committed to spending restraint in practice as well as theory, but the party as a whole is still more eager to posture about earmarks than to wrestle with entitlements. Most Republicans talk a good game about America's looming fiscal crisis, but then dance away when the subjects turns to what, specifically, they want to do about it.

"... does everyone take for granted now that science sites are where graduate students, researchers, doctors and the 'skeptical community' go not to interpret data or review experiments but to chip off one-liners, promote their books and jeer at smokers, fat people and churchgoers? And can anyone who still enjoys this class-inflected bloodsport tell me why it has to happen under the banner of science? Hammering away at an ideology, substituting stridency for contemplation, pummeling its enemies in absentia: ScienceBlogs has become Fox News for the religion-baiting, peak-oil crowd. Though [P.Z.] Myers and other science bloggers boast that they can be jerky in the service of anti-charlatanism, that's not what's bothersome about them. What's bothersome is that the site is misleading. It's not science by scientists, not even remotely; it's science blogging by science bloggers. And science blogging, apparently, is a form of redundant and effortfully incendiary rhetoric that draws bad-faith moral authority from the word 'science' and from occasional invocations of 'peer-reviewed' thises and thats. Under cover of intellectual rigor, the science bloggers - or many of the most visible ones, anyway - prosecute agendas so charged with bigotry that it doesn't take a pun-happy French critic or a rapier-witted Cambridge atheist to call this whole ScienceBlogs enterprise what it is, or has become: class-war claptrap."

I often wonder what life was like for military personnel who served on Palmyra Atoll during World War II. We see ghosts of their activities - whether abandoned buildings and ancient, odd-shaped light bulbs or structural changes to the islets and the lagoon. The military occupation there was brief, but the effects, like causeways built across the waterways, are long lasting. Some of the modifications cut off the flow of water and turned the lagoons into warm, silty bathwater, which influences what can grow and live there.

Oscilloscope Laboratories said it planned to appeal an R rating assigned by the Classification and Rating Administration to the Holocaust documentary "A Film Unfinished." The documentary, which screened at the Sundance Film Festival this year, dissects a Nazi propaganda film that was shot in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1942. In assigning an R rating, which requires viewers under the age of 17 to be accompanied by an adult, the ratings board cited "disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities including graphic nudity." Adam Yauch, an owner of Oscilloscope and its Oscilloscope Pictures operation, said the proposed rating would block use of the film as an educational tool. "This is too important of a historical document to ban from classrooms," Mr. Yauch said in a statement on Monday. "A Film Unfinished" is to open in New York on Aug. 18, and two days later in Los Angeles, before a planned national release.

No story today, just a question: what is the proper kind of relationship to have with one's accountant? I see my bookkeeper twice a week, so I know where the money is going, but I've never actually met the accountant (she was hired by my ex-partner). As far as I know, there's nothing wrong with her work. We ship her the ledgers at the end of the year and get back the tax returns in March, and that's it. That can't possibly be the best arrangement, but I'm curious as to what the alternatives are. And while I'm at it, a few more queries:

Some cynics regard Philippe Starck as merely a master of self-promotion. But they don't know that the French design superstar has always championed the work of talented newcomers. Last year, Starck was the mentor for a competition -- organized by the British Web site mydeco.com and MGX, the Belgian rapid-prototyping pioneer -- that invited students aged 18 to 25 to design a domestic object. Starck was so impressed by the work of the German student, Roland Kreiter, that he telephoned Alberto Alessi, the C.E.O. of the Italian manufacturer Alessi, and urged him to produce it. (Starck also hired Kreiter as an intern in his office.) By coincidence, Kreiter's design, My Squeeze, is a juicer. And one of the products that made Starck famous is the now-iconic Juicy Salif, the gangly three-legged objet that celebrates its 20th anniversary this year. Perfect timing.

The Los Angeles financier Eli Broad may get millions of dollars back on the $100 million museum he is planning to build as part of the Grand Avenue Project, a development of condominiums, cultural sites, stores, offices and a hotel in downtown Los Angeles. According to The Los Angeles Times, a deal approved last month by the Community Redevelopment Agency of Los Angeles calls for Mr. Broad's museum to receive millions of dollars as the Grand Avenue Project moves forward. The redevelopment agency requires developers - in this case Related Companies - to pay one percent of their project's design and construction costs to create public artworks or to support cultural sites in the neighborhood where they build. The deal, which was approved on July 15, includes the Broad Collection at Grand Avenue and 2nd Street as the cultural facility that will fulfill a large amount of Related Company's percent-for-art obligation.

Here's an exercise: Read Sam Anderson's profile of James Franco for New York Magazine. Then go back and read Andrew Corsello's 1996 profile of Mira Sorvino for GQ. Both are essays about highly-cerebral, possibly-overeducated celebrity actors whose peculiar personae are more interesting than any of the movies they've made. Both are the work of extremely skillful and engaging writers. But Anderson's profile is an exercise in rueful wonderment, whereas Corsello's profile is a brutal takedown. Franco's intellectual pretentions are celebrated and his eccentricities are smiled upon; Sorvino's intellectual ambitions are used against her and her eccentricities mercilessly mocked. Anderson goes out of his way to insist that Franco's academic work is legitimate; Corsello makes fun of Sorvino for talking about her honors thesis. Anderson takes a rueful attitude toward the gulf between Franco's ambitions and his actual body of work; Corsello has a good time making fun of "Romy and Michelle's High School Reunion." And so forth.

One of the interesting findings of a recent study conducted on amateur golfers by Neil Wolkodoff, the director of the Center for Health and Sport Science at the Rose Medical Center in Denver, is that golfers generally score lower while walking with a pushcart or a caddie as opposed to riding in a golf cart. There could be a multitude of reasons for this, but one proposed by Wolkodoff centered on the idea that walking golfers have more time - and a built-in, physical, stress-reducing response to a poor shot. ''If you've just hit a really bad shot and it sends you into a tizzy,'' Wolkodoff said, ''from a psycho-physiological standpoint, I can't think of a worse thing to do than hop into a cart that whisks you to your next shot in seconds.''

I have noticed that nearly every week, one or two strange things happen on golf courses around the world. I'm talking about things that have nothing to do with playing the game. Last week, for example, there was an altercation on the 18th green at the Franconia Golf Course in Springfield, Mass. (Sadly, I frequently read about altercations, most connected to accusations of slow play.) In this case, a 46-year-old man said he was head-butted by a man in the foursome playing behind him as he finished his round. The man also told the Springfield police that another man in the foursome threw a golf ball at his girlfriend. The police last week were still searching for the attackers.

Ever wonder if you play better golf riding in a cart or walking? Ever wonder how many calories you burn in a typical round? Or if you would play better if you were in better shape? Ever wonder if golf is truly a sport? Neil Wolkodoff wondered all those things, too. And as the director of the Center for Health and Sport Science at the Rose Medical Center in Denver, he knew how to find the answers. Two years ago, he bought $27,000 worth of equipment to conduct a painstaking set of tests on amateur golfers. When he was done, he had some findings that could settle a lot of barroom arguments.

WILKINSON--William. Who brought style and humor and exacting standards to hotels and restaurants and the food business in the Bay Area for over 25 years, died on July 19 at his home in San Francisco. He was 68. Bill was born in The Bronx and raised in Yonkers. After graduating from hotel school at Paul Smiths College he began his career at Restaurant Associates. He left Restaurant Associates for a stint in the Navy, returning to civilian life as the assistant food and beverage manager at the Waldorf-Astoria. He left the Waldorf for a corporate job at Intercontinental Hotels. He traveled the world for Intercon before he went to Maui in 1975 to open the Intercon at Wailea as resident manager. In 1976 he came to San Francisco to become the general manager of the Stanford Court Hotel. During his five years there the property was one of the best hotels in the country and a center of the emerging American food scene. In 1981 he left to develop and operate the Campton Place Hotel. Both the hotel and its eponymous restaurant were immediate hits as were his cooks who included Jan Birnbaum, Bradley Ogden, George Marrone, Craig Stoll and Charlie Trotter. In 1989 he recreated Campton Place in downtown Los Angeles with the Checkers Hotel, where Jerry Comfort and later Thomas Keller served as chefs. After his business partners sold the hotels he bought Greenleaf Produce in 1993, building that business into the largest company on the San Francisco Produce Market. Bill was an active member of the community as well as a successful businessman. He served twice as the chairman of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce and also served on the boards of the Ft. Mason Center, the Hotel Council, the local Salvation Army, and the Produce Market. He was known for his stories, his compassion, and most of all the grace with which he treated his employees and customers. He is survived by his partner of 33 years, Tom Given; his brother Tom Wilkinson of Albuquerque, NM; and his sisters Isabel Kimmel of Hawthorn, NY, Alice Soto of San Juan, PR and Julie Francis of Scottsdale AZ. Contributions to the National Parkinsons Foundation or Food Runners of San Francisco.

In an extreme case of camel coat envy, a frustrated New York socialite who had long fetishized the trench coat Ali MacGraw wore in ‘‘Love Story’’ engaged a patternmaker last year to copy it in caramel cashmere, down to the patch pockets and double-wide lapel and collar (which, like MacGraw’s character, Jenny, you gotta wear popped). From Paris to New York, from Kate Moss to Blake Lively (who seem to be as attached to their fawn-colored coats as Grace Kelly and Katharine Hepburn were to theirs), camel is dans l’air this fall. Céline’s Phoebe Philo jump-started the trend last spring with the ultimate boyfriend coat, a honey-toned Crombie. Jean Paul Gaultier — in his penultimate, fall collection for Hermès — showed a three-quarter camel coat pinched from the guys, saving his most luxurious discursion for duffel coats like the ones once worn by the British Royal Navy. Michael Kors imagined a gender mix-up at the coat check, or maybe that blushingly erotic moment when a gentleman slips his camel coat over his date’s chilly shoulders. If it’s all beginning to sound like a male conspiracy, well, a lot of women’s outerwear in the buff register does lead back to the blokes. Think of the peacoat — and the polo coat. Around 1900, polo players began wrapping themselves in camel ‘‘wait coats’’ — patterned, essentially, on a dressing gown — to keep warm between chukkers. Later, women borrowed freely of the details: half belt, full cut, chest pocket. In 1949 the camel coat was the American coed’s favorite. Kors made winking reference to all that history, pairing a great big muff of a fur skirt with a camel knit tee. Among the other camel offerings were satin blouses and high-waisted slacks (Chloé), even a strapless dress (Gianfranco Ferré). But in the end, it was the camel coat that scored, whether sable-trimmed at Carolina Herrera or sleeveless at Alexander Wang. A real love story.

The notion that more mothers of young children have dropped out of the labor force in recent years has been a hotly debated topic. But I think the facts are clear -- more mothers are not working, compared with the mid- and late 1990s -- even if the causes and implications are open to debate. This Bureau of Labor Statistics report from 2007, which I mentioned in my column this week, offers a good overview.

President Obama marked the coming end of the combat mission in Iraq "as promised and on schedule" in a speech to veterans in Atlanta on Monday. As Mr. Obama outlined the drawdown of United States forces in Iraq and the changing nature of the engagement in Iraq from military to diplomatic, he noted that this new chapter in the conflict will get a new name. Operation Iraqi Freedom will become Operation New Dawn. The change is meant to be symbolic of the new, more tacit role the United States will play in Iraq's evolving internal affairs.

I wasn't around for the coronation of Elizabeth II, and it seems unlikely I'll be invited to the crowning of her successor, should that day ever arrive. So I was delighted to be able to attend the ceremonies celebrating the ascension of one Anne Boleyn as the Queen of England. Such pomp, such circumstance. The gold canopy, the procession of ecclesiastics, the charming boys' choir. And as for young Anne herself, well, that ultimate royal fashion plate Diana, Princess of Wales, might have envied the sumptuous, megatrain-bearing dress with which the second wife of King Henry VIII has been outfitted.

Oleg V. Deripaska, the chief executive of the big aluminum producer Rusal, said on Tuesday that his company's 25 percent stake in Norilsk Nickel was not for sale and denied reports that the Russian government was trying to push him to sell it to resolve a dispute with a fellow Russian billionaire.

One might think that rock bands are fed like kings backstage, but the reality is more like a tuna wrap and a bowl of M&M's. This weekend at the Osheaga Festival in Montreal, however, the National, Arcade Fire, Beach House, Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros et al. were treated to a feast: the artists' area was catered by Chuck Hughes, the chef at the city's Garde Manger restaurant and host of the Cooking Channel's "Chuck's Day Off." Highlights on the menu - which I sampled as the guest of my husband, the Walkmen's Walter Martin - included pulled-pork tacos, jerk crab, smoked chicken (cooked in a 50-foot smoker) and a poutine bar where guests could customize the classic Québécois dish. Salads were made to order, with options including pea shoots snipped from the plant, golden beets, prosciutto and poached asparagus. Bands took advantage of the full raw bar with oysters shucked on the spot and scallops on the half shell. Beach House dug the smoothie station, and fried Mars bars were a hit as Arcade Fire was getting ready to play Saturday night. Meals are usually a to-be-avoided part of backstage life, but these bands lingered at picnic tables under twinkling lanterns. The vote was unanimous that this was the best catering ever.

Forget about that unpublished, almost-finished fourth manuscript. The next Stieg Larsson volume is a collection that includes essays about Mr. Larsson and e-mails between Mr. Larsson and his publisher, Eva Gedin. The volume, called "On Stieg Larsson," will be released by Knopf as part of a boxed set including the best-selling "Millennium" trilogy, which began with "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo," then was followed by "The Girl Who Played With Fire" and "The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest." According to Knopf, the new book will include an essay by John-Henri Holmberg, a member of the Swedish Crime Fiction Academy, "placing Stieg Larsson in the context of the resurgence of Scandinavian crime writing," and an essay by Svante Weyler, the publishing director from Mr. Larsson's publisher in Sweden, about the phenomenon surrounding Mr. Larsson. The boxed set, priced at $99, will go on sale the day after Thanksgiving -- also known as the start of the holiday shopping season.

Frank Wildhorn is about to take another leap down the rabbit hole of Broadway. Whenever I point out that bond markets are not, in fact, demanding immediate fiscal austerity, I get comments along the lines of "So now you believe markets are perfect?" That's missing the point. The starting point for the argument people like me make is that markets shouldn't be demanding immediate austerity, because the long-run fiscal effects of short-run deficits are relatively small; the burden of proof is therefore on the other side to show that markets will demand something they shouldn't.

Having topped the United Space box office list, burned out brain cells and tied up Twitter feeds for the past three weeks, the Christopher Nolan mind caper "Inception" has earned another rare distinction: it will be one of only 20 foreign-made blockbusters that China will allow to be shown at its movie theaters this year, The Associated Press reported. The government-owned China Film Group told The A.P. that "Inception" will be one of the few non-domestically produced films that it annually imports and for which it shares ticket revenues with the studio that produced it. (The company also buys smaller foreign films for flat fees.)

In 1913, the provocateur Marcel Duchamp created a ruckus at the New York Armory Show with his ''Nude Descending a Staircase (No. 2).'' The painting didn't go down well; apparently nudes don't use staircases, they're busy lolling on divans or dancing with seven veils. Looking at ''Nude'' today (in the Philadelphia Museum of Art), the Samurai Shopper sees nothing R-rated, just a fractured maze of lines and planes. What's naked is Duchamp's ambition to shock the stuffed shirts.

The BMW CS, produced from 1968 to 1975 and known internally as the E9 (or to its many ardent admirers, simply "the coupe") is often mentioned among the most beautiful BMWs ever built. It also ranks among the most delicate. Rust goblins gorged on its lithe body and undercarriage even in dry climates. Engines powered by carburetors protested violently under cold starts. Even so, the CS's cult, next to that of the 2002 coupe, is fiercely dedicated.

CRANE--Sarah. The Board of Directors of Planned Parenthood of New York City notes with profound sadness the passing of Honorary Board Member Sarah Crane. Sally joined our Board in 1981, provided extraordinary leadership and dedication to countless committees, and raised significant support to strengthen our mission. We are grateful for her incredible kindness, passion for life, and dedication to New York's women and families. Our deepest condolences to Ben, her children Michael, Elizabeth, and Susan, and their families. Diane Max, Chair Joan Malin, President & CEO

Although July fell just short of being the hottest month in New York City history, it did set a record for energy consumption. Consolidated Edison, which supplies electricity throughout the city and in Westchester County, said Monday that it distributed 6.96 million megawatt hours of power last month. That surpassed the previous high, 6.7 million megawatt hours, set in July 2008, the company said.

ANDERSON--Gene. The staff, faculty and Advisory Board of the Mount Sinai Adolescent Health Center mourn the passing of Gene Anderson and we send our sincerest condolences to his spouse, Jenny Morgenthau, and to his family and friends. Our thoughts are with you.

FRIEDMAN--Sol, 99. Adored husband of the late Emma, father of Victor (Rachel) and Nansi (Steve Pearlman), grandfather of Sam Friedman (Carolina Patlis), Bryan Becker, Juliet Cohen (Jeffrey), Alex Pearlman, Amy Pearlman and Kaila Pearlman and great-grandfather of Leon, Jacob, Joaquin, Lucia and Violet. Sol died peacefully on July 28, 2010, at home in New York City after a long and generous life. Shiva minyan at the home of Nansi and Steve, Tuesday August 3, 6pm. Charitable contributions may be made to Hadassah or Teach For America.

LEVINE--Arnold, on August 2nd, 2010 at 87, survived by his wife, Diane, his sister, Gloria, his three children, Anne, Melanie, and Michael, and six grandchildren, Dara, Jeffrey, Alison, Trevor, Randy, and Carly. Arnold was a decorated World War II hero, having received the Silver Star, the Bronze Star, and two Purple Hearts. He was discharged from the Army having achieved the rank of Captain. Thereafter, he entered the men's dresswear business, and ultimately owned Cambridge Shirt Manufacturing, Co. He was a member of North Shore Country Club, and the Sands Point Village Club. He loved his Friday steak lunches at the Palm Restaurant, his Saturday and Sunday morning golf games, and his Beefeater martinis. More than anything else, he was a true family man. RIP, Arn. Services will be held Wednesday, August 4th at the Community Synagogue, 160 Middle Neck Road, Port Washington, NY.

LEVINSON--Harry, 74, of Monsey, NY. Renowned real estate attorney (graduate of Columbia Law School), brilliant Talmudic scholar. Survived the Holocaust with the famed Mirrer Yeshiva in Shanghai, China, together with his parents, Rabbi Pinchas and Freeda Levinson. Married to the former Deborah Rokowsky from 1962 until her untimely passing in 2008. Survived by his wife, Vicky; children Aviva (Andrew) Feinman, Tova (Uri) Wolfson, Dina (Ronnie) Wilheim, and Sam (Raisy) Levinson.

BERGMAN--Irene W. Died August 2, 2010 peacefully, after a year-long battle with cancer. Loved and adored wife of Philip for 46 years. Devoted mother of sons Michael and Jason. Loving mother-in-law and friend to Jodi and Jill. Cherished grandmother to Hailey, Shari, Jordan and Jared. Loving sister to brother Philip, and sister-in-law to Cheri. Daughter of late parents Harry and Sylvia Wolff. Burial and service at Cedar Park Cemetery Paramus, NJ, 201-262-1100.

9 P.M. (ABC) SHAQ VSShaquille O'Neal tries once again to prove that his athletic prowess extends beyond the basketball court by tackling a succession of different sports and, new to this series's second season, nonathletic activities. Each episode follows Mr. O'Neal as he goes through pre-event machinations, including news conferences and interviews; trains with a coach for one week before each challenge; and negotiates a handicap with his opponent. The games begin as Mr. O'Neal swaps his jersey for a fire-retardant suit to take on the Nascar racer Dale Earnhardt Jr. (above left, with Mr. O'Neal). Later he tests his erudition by going word to word against Kavya Shivashankar, winner of the 2009 Scripps National Spelling Bee. 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: STEVE McQUEEN A 12-film tribute to the King of Cool begins with ''Le Mans'' (1971), in which a driver in the 24-hour French car race is haunted by a fatal accident. It begins drawing to a close with ''The Great Escape'' (1963), at 2:45 p.m.; ''The Magnificent Seven'' (1960), at 8; and ''Bullitt'' (1968), at 10:15, before ending at 4 a.m. with ''The Cincinnati Kid'' (1965), about stud poker players, including Mr. McQueen, above, and their women during a big game in New Orleans.

Nobody ever succeeded in making a monkey out of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia. But the reason there are no organ grinders in New York is that neighborhood bullies in Arizona tried to, during an earlier episode of ethnic conflict in that state. La Guardia's mother was from Trieste, Italy, his father from Foggia. Though born in Manhattan, La Guardia grew up partly in Prescott, Ariz., where his father was an Army bandmaster. His memories of life there in the late 19th-century were mostly good, until an organ grinder came to town.

POLLACK--Susan. Rosenthal & Rosenthal, Inc. and the entire Rosenthal family mourn the loss of Susan Pollack. Beloved wife of Stanley Pollack, Rosenthal's former general counsel and a current senior executive of the firm, Susan was a warm, intelligent and kind woman and a wonderful mother to their daughter, Jane. Over the years that Stanley has worked at Rosenthal, many had gotten to know Susan, and we will all miss her dearly. Her strength and generosity of spirit made an indelible mark on all who had the privilege to know her.

The Advertising column on Friday, about Barnes & Noble's marketing plans for its Nook e-reader, referred incorrectly to the wireless capabilities of the version sold for $149. It is not lacking both wireless services.

COLEMAN--Judith Hurley Stanley, 75, of Middletown, NJ died on Sunday at home. Visitation will be from 6-8pm, Wednesday, August 4th and 5-7pm, Thursday, August 5th, at her home on 578 Navesink River Road, Middletown Twp., NJ. The funeral will be held Friday, August 6th, 11am at the First Presbyterian Church at Red Bank Tower Hill. A private burial will follow. A reception celebrating Judith Stanley Coleman's life will be held afterwards at her home. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the VNA of Central Jersey, the Monmouth Conservation Foundation, the Monmouth Medical Center Foundation and the Monmouth County Historical Association.

EMMET--Barton Hepburn, died peacefully in his sleep on August 1, 2010. The son of the late Admiral R.R.M. Emmet and Beulah Hepburn Emmet. He was born in New York on October 18, 1918. He attended the Edgewood School in Greenwich, CT, Columbia University and Tamara Daykarhanova's School for the Stage. After four and a half years in the Army during WWII, he returned to the theatre. He owned and operated the Westchester Playhouse, a summer stock company, in Mt. Kisco, New York for 11 years. He went on to the Tyrone Guthrie Theatre in Minneapolis, The American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, CT, The Melody Tent in Hyannis, MA and the Trinity Square Repertory theatre in Providence, RI. He moved to California in 1970 to teach Drama at the Cate School in Carpinteria, CA. Barton is survived by his wife of 59 years, Cynthia Slosson, of San Rafael, CA. He leaves two daughters, Cindy Emmet-Smith and Lydia Emmet Winkeller, and his grandchildren: Emrys, Gareth and Caitlyn Smith, Ricky, Peter, Emily and Betsy Winkeller and Briana and Tommy Alexander. Contributions may be made in Barton's name to the Laguna Cottages for Seniors in Santa Barbara, CA. A celebration of Barton's life will be held on August 14, 2010 at 3pm at AlmaVia of San Rafael, located on 515 Northgate Dr., San Rafel, CA.

The threat by the United Arab Emirates to shut down mobile services on BlackBerrys like e-mail and text messaging underscores a growing tension between communications companies and governments over how to balance privacy with national security. While communications companies want to be able to ensure that their customers' messages are shielded from prying eyes, governments increasingly insist on gaining access to electronic messages to track down criminals or uncover terrorist plots.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the end of Bob Kerrey's negotiations to become chief executive of the Motion Picture Association of America misstated Mr. Kerrey's current post. He is president of the New School -- not the New School for Social Research, which is its graduate social sciences division.

For most people, donating blood is as simple as rolling up a sleeve. But not for gay men. Since 1983, the Food and Drug Administration has barred them from donating. The F.D.A. has re-examined the ban over the years, but maintains that the restriction is necessary to keep the blood supply safe and untainted by H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Critics say the ban is scientifically and medically unjustified and that it unfairly singles out gay men.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the author Buzz Bissinger's turnabout from foe to fan of Twitter, misstated, in some editions, the maximum length of the service's messages. They can be no more than 140 characters, not 140 words.

Little League World Series officials announced Monday that their instant replay system -- in place for the past two years to cover mostly home runs or other close outfield-fence calls -- would be expanded this year and managers would be allowed to challenge calls on forceouts, tags, missed bases and hit batsmen. Under the old system, only umpires could call for the replays. Now, if umpires do not request a replay, managers can. They are allowed one challenge in the first six innings, although they would retain the challenge if successful. They would be granted another challenge in extra innings.

ATHENS -- Panagiotis became an anarchist at 15, a middle-class Athenian kid attracted to anti-authoritarianism and the gritty central Exarcheia neighborhood, where Greece's activists came of age. Over the last 26 years, he says he has thrown stones, bottles and Molotov cocktails during hundreds of anti-government demonstrations. His identity is often hidden behind a mask and hood and layers of black clothing, the dress code of koukouloforoi, the ''hooded ones'' that Greek police say regularly turn peaceful protests here violent.

Alex Rodriguez has become the seventh player and the youngest member of the 600 Club. A-Rod joins Barry Bonds (762), Hank Aaron (755), Babe Ruth (714), Willie Mays (660), Ken Griffey Jr. (630) and Sammy Sosa (609). Ruth had been the youngest to hit 600, reaching the mark in 1931 at 36 years, 196 days. Rodriguez is just eight days past his 35th birthday. Both Ruth and Rodriguez hit No. 600 wearing a Yankee uniform.

But in baseball, it is a milestone - though for a while, as one of the Yankees' YES Network commentators said on Wednesday, it seemed to be a millstone around Alex Rodriguez's neck. And then he passed it. On to 700.

Ravi Coltrane, the highly regarded tenor and soprano saxophonist, is the newest addition to the roster of Blue Note Records, with an album due out next spring. His signing unites the most storied label in jazz, one of the last majors standing, with a saxophonist-bandleader from an imposing lineage: Mr. Coltrane's father was John Coltrane, who similarly played tenor and soprano, reshaping the language of jazz improvisation from the mid-1950s up to his death in 1967.

Most makeup artists consider the skin their canvas, but William Lemon III takes the idea more literally. Lemon, who is also a musician and painter, created a water-based acrylic body painting technique called skin printing, and he has used it to cover Marc Jacobs's naked body with hot pink Stephen Sprouse/Louis Vuitton logos, and to transform Chloë Sevigny into a tattooed-lady-slash-clown for Beck's trippy "Gamma Ray" video. (Look close: Lemon is the dancing mime.) In N.E.R.D.'s new "Hot and Fun" video, directed by Jonas Akerlund, he trussed up a tribe of apocalyptic party girls with animal prints, mystical symbols and ash. "He let me go a little bit far out," Lemon said of the director - not surprising since Akerlund is also the man behind Lady Gaga's "Telephone."

Massimiliano Giornetti planned to spend his summer vacation in Puglia, a popular Italian getaway several hours from his home in Florence. ''I'm not entirely a free spirit on holiday,'' says the 38-year-old designer, who was recently named Ferragamo's creative director. ''I like some structure, with a little room to be adventurous.'' A perfect metaphor for his design mantra at Ferragamo, where he has helmed the men's-wear divison for the last decade. Any question as to whether Giornetti could translate his masculine sensibilities to the more mercurial closets of women was answered in his much lauded fall collection. He managed to channel the independent spirit of Salvatore Ferragamo's devoted customer, Greta Garbo, while creating sharp, assertive glamour: fur-lined capes, cuffed leather shorts, thick cable knits and a three-piece pinstriped suit that seemed like a 21st-century version of ''Annie Hall.''

Julien David apprenticed with Narciso Rodriguez and Ralph Lauren in New York, but when the 31-year-old French designer ventured out on his own, he went back to Square 1: the scarf. His collection, which he started in Tokyo in 2007, uses the finest Japanese silks and cashmere - to wildly irreverent effect. Artificial growth, for example, is his theme for this fall. This plays itself out in something as unusual as a pill motif, which the designer blows up into a giant two-toned capsule, whose colorful geometry drapes around the neck. ''I tend to like gigantism,'' David says. ''I thought I could make the silk scarves look very different and interesting [by] changing prints and proportions.'' This September, David will add coats and bags to the mix. Artificial growth? More likely, natural progression.

A study published late last month in The New England Journal of Medicine is raising provocative questions about how best to treat a torn anterior cruciate ligament. For the study, researchers from Lund University in Sweden recruited 121 young adults who had injured their A.C.L.'s. The volunteers, between 18 and 35, were physically active, and many were competitive athletes. They agreed, rather bravely, to be randomly assigned to one of two groups and accept radically different treatments for their torn A.C.L.'s. The first group began physical therapy and then underwent surgical reconstruction of the ligament, considered by many people to be the best option for injured athletes. The second group received only physical therapy, with the option to have the operation later. Twenty-three subjects of that group did eventually have the operation. (For those fortunate enough not to be personally familiar with A.C.L. surgery, reconstruction involves replacing the injured ligament with tissue from elsewhere in your own leg or from a cadaver.)

(Science) WONDERS OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM Brian Cox, a professor of particle physics at the University of Manchester in England, hosts this series, which explains how the laws of nature have created spectacular landscapes in the solar system -- from ice fountains that erupt thousands of miles into space; to the liquid methane seas on Titan, a moon of Saturn; and the Valles Marineris on Mars, an immense canyon system that extends a quarter of the way around the planet at its equator. In ''Empire of the Sun,'' the first installment, Mr. Cox examines the ''beating heart'' of our celestial neighborhood. Above, the sky over the Mojave Desert in California. 11 A.M. MIGLIORE--Ferdinand "Fred", 76, of Avon Park, FL on Saturday, July 31, 2010. Beloved husband of Lorraine (nee Deininger) and his former wife Dolores I. (nee Klepacki). Loving father of Gregory and David Migliore. Dear brother of Carrie Nesser and Madelyn Fuhro. Cherished uncle of Brian Fuhro, Marylin Koziol and Janet DeSantis. Mr. Migliore was the owner of Valentino's Restaurant in Park Ridge for over 15 years. He had worked for Flamingo, Thunderbird and MGM Grand Resort. He was also a buyer in E.J. Korvettes. Funeral Saturday at 9am from the Ippolito-Stellato Funeral Home, 425 Ridge Road, Lyndhurst, NJ. Funeral Mass 10am Sacred Heart R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Friends will be received Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the charity of your choice. Send condolences to stellatofuneralhomes.com

LYONS--Marilyn Gersten, 87, passed away on August 2 at her home in New York. She was predeceased by her loving husband of 52 years, Herbert, and survived by her children Judy, David, their spouses Seth and Phyllis, eight grandchildren and nine great- grandchildren. She retired as an associate professor from Pratt Institute last September, where she was the founding coordinator of the Graduate Communications Department, and where the Marilyn Lyons Gallery was dedicated to her for "Unselfishly managing and guiding our students and faculty with her integrity, hard work, guidance, and day-by-day example of unfaltering commitment." Her memories will always live with us and be a presence in the things we do. In lieu of flowers, please take a moment and do something you might have or did enjoy doing with her, and think of her. Services: Thursday at 10am at Riverside Chapels, West 79th Street, New York.

DERFNER--Harold. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale note with profound sadness the loss of Harold Derfner, a stalwart member of the Home's Board of Directors for more than fifty years. Through his generosity and that of his beloved late wife, Helen, the Derfner Judaica Museum, known world-wide for its art program, was created. They also graciously provided the lead gift to create a spectacular 25,000 square foot outdoor space at the Home, known as "Helen's Terrace" providing numerous opportunities for residents to relax and reflect. We will sorely miss his warmth and friendship. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children Peter and Leslie and granddaughter Rachel. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

Soon, grave sites at the Canarsie Cemetery will be for sale again. They have not been since 1993, when the city stopped selling dirt three feet under - the law in New York requires that bodies be buried at least three and not six feet deep - because the cemetery's fate was uncertain. The city inherited the cemetery, which it did not want, when the five boroughs merged in 1898.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Monday about Tumblr, a blogging service based in New York, misstated the estimated number of readers drawn to Newsweek's site through Twitter and Facebook. It is 200,000 to 300,000 a month, not each day. (The draw from Tumblr was correctly reported as 1,000 a day.) The article also erroneously included one media outlet on a list of new users of Tumblr. While there is an interns' NPR account at Tumblr, there is no account for NPR itself.

MILLER--Charles J.,age 87. Manhattan. Charles Miller died of complications from cancer surgery on July 22, 2010. Charles grew up on the Upper West Side during the 1920s and 30s. He graduated from the Horace Mann School and New York University. He was a World War II combat veteran who served with distinction in Europe. After the War, Charles returned to a top position at the family business, I. Miller & Sons, maker of "beautiful" women's shoes. He was involved in all aspects of the business, especially shoe design and U.S. sales. Following the sale of the company in 1959, Charles and his late brother, Robert Miller, acquired D.H. Blair & Co., a Wall Street securities firm, where Charles was the managing partner into the early 1970s. In the mid-1970s, Charles' career began a third phase. He returned to school and obtained advanced training at Columbia and the Postgraduate Center for Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy. He had practiced as a psychoanalyst continuously since the early 1980s. Charles is survived by his wife, Madelyne Bailey of Manhattan, his daughter and son-in-law, Patricia Miller-Katz and Gordon Katz of Newton, Massachusetts, his son, Burton Miller of Huntington, New York, daughter, Rebecca Miller of Newark, New York, stepson and stepdaughter-in-law, Mark Bailey and Rory Kennedy of Los Angeles, California, stepson, Paul Bailey of Belmont, Massachusetts, special godson, Scott Carlin of Los Angeles, California, grandchildren, Emily Tess Katz, Michelle Miller, Georgia Kennedy-Bailey, Bridget Kennedy-Bailey, and Zachery Kennedy-Bailey, many nieces and nephews and their children, and numerous cherished friends. Charles was preceded in death by his first wife, Thelma Levine Miller. Funeral services and burial were privately held on July 25, 2010. A celebration of Charles' life will be held on Sunday, August 8, 2010, at 2-5pm at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC.

LEBENGER--Seymour, 85, passed on August 2, 2010 in his sleep. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sylvia, children Joshua, Stacy and Aaron, grandchildren Dara, David, Rachel, Daniel and Raena, sister Necia and brother Calvert, and their families. Born, raised and educated in Brooklyn, he served as a combat medic in World War II before beginning a lifetime career as an educator, ultimately serving as principal of I.S. 59 in Queens, New York. He was also the founding director of Timber Lake Camp and served in various capacities, including Dean, as he helped build the Hofstra University day camp and its School of Continuing Education, for which he was still on staff when he died. In lieu of flowers or gifts the family requests that mourners and friends make a charitable contribution to a scholarship fund being set up in his name at Hofstra University or to Reach Out for Youth with Crohn's and Colitis, and to always fight the good fight.

OBITUARIES An obituary on July 16 about the statistician and mathematician David Blackwell gave an incorrect account of Mr. Blackwell's time spent as a member of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., in 1941 and 1942. He was denied the right to attend lectures or do research at Princeton University; the university did not refuse to grant him the courtesy title of assistant professor, as Mr. Blackwell recalled in an interview in the 1980s. The obituary also referred incorrectly to his tenure at the institute. He completed a one-year fellowship; he did not leave early. And the obituary referred imprecisely to the institute's connection to Princeton University. While the Institute for Advanced Study is located in Princeton, it is not part the university.

CRANE--Sarah Ann Molloy, "Sally," 75, passed away peacefully in her sleep in her home in Santa Fe, NM, on August 1. Sally was born in Rockville Center, NY, and raised in an extended family in Haverstraw, NY. She lived with her beloved Aunt Anne McCabe after both of her parents died. After graduating from Simmons College in 1956, Sally spent a year in Vienna, Austria, helping to resettle refugees from the Hungarian Revolution. After returning to New York City, she worked for a short time in the Personnel Department of The New York Times. She married Benjamin F. Crane (now a retired partner of the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP) on February 8, 1959, after a whirlwind courtship. They celebrated their 50th anniversary in 2009 surrounded by family and many friends from their years together. They settled in Brooklyn Heights, and eventually had a home in Cold Spring, NY, as well as in Santa Fe. Sally was actively involved on the boards of many charitable institutions, getting her start as the President of the Junior League of Brooklyn. She went on to serve for many years on the boards of Planned Parenthood of New York City (including one term as President), the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, Trinity School in Manhattan (which her children attended), the Brooklyn Heights Association, Colony-South Brooklyn Houses, the New York Women's Foundation, and Simmons College, her alma mater, where from 2000-2004 she co-chaired a hugely successful fundraising campaign. Simmons granted her an honorary doctorate in public service, and she established a scholarship fund at the college for students in need. Sally had an exceptional gift for making friends and for helping others through her work and philanthropy. She was also the organizing force for keeping together the extended McCabe-Molloy clan. Everywhere she spent time and lived, Sally gathered new and old friends together and participated actively in the local scene. With her radiant smile and beautiful blue eyes, Sally was a force of nature, combining fun, humor, vigor, intellect, inspiration, warmth, and a passionate love for life. Her passing leaves a gaping hole in many interconnected worlds and in so many hearts. In addition to the love of her life, Ben, she is survived by her sister, Catherine Molloy, CND, of Kumbo, Cameroon, her son Michael and wife Kate of London, England, her daughter Betsy of Denver, Colorado, her daughter Susan and partner Karen Newman, also of London, and seven grandchildren, all of whom cherished her and loved her dearly. In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions may be made in Sally's honor to Planned Parenthood of New York City or the Sarah Molloy Crane '56 Scholarship Fund at Simmons College in Boston. The family is planning to hold a memorial service in New York City in the fall to celebrate Sally's life; please check www.memorialebook.com (Sarah Ann Molloy Crane) for details as they become available.

In the latest attempt to revive the crumbling Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, the New York State Lottery recommended Tuesday that Gov. David A. Paterson strike a deal with the largest gambling company in Southeast Asia to install and operate 4,500 video slot machines at the track. Through a subsidiary, the company, Genting Group, has promised to provide the state, which is in desperate need of cash to cover a multibillion-dollar budget shortfall, with $380 million for the licensing fee as soon as a final agreement is reached. It has also promised to install 1,600 slots within six months. It says it will have the remaining 2,900 operating at the track in Queens by next summer.

The R-rating for the Holocaust documentary "A Film Unfinished" will stand, an appeals board ruled on Thursday, according to Oscilloscope Laboratories, which is releasing the movie. Oscilloscope had appealed the rating by the Classification and Rating Administration, which cited "disturbing images of Holocaust atrocities including graphic nudity." The film, directed by Yael Hersonski, dissects a Nazi propaganda film that purported to depict life among Jews in the Warsaw ghetto during World War II but actually manipulated its portrayal to reinforce anti-Jewish policies. The rating bars those under 17 from seeing the film without an accompanying parent or guardian. Oscilloscope argued that a similar film, "The Last Days," on which Steven Spielberg was an executive producer, had been rated PG-13. Spokesmen for the ratings administration did not immediately respond to a query. Oscilloscope said the board ruled 12 to 3 against changing the rating. "A Film Unfinished" won a film editing award at the Sundance Film Festival earlier this year.

Three books due out this fall find fashion in a retrospective mood. ''Yohji Yamamoto: My Dear Bomb'' (Ludion), the first-ever biography of the designer, fittingly ditches an orthodox chronology for a series of short fictions written by Yamamoto interspersed with vivid reminiscences. (For those looking for something a little more linear, the book concludes with a timeline featuring never-before-seen personal images.) Anna Sui's eponymous biography (Chronicle Books), on the other hand, is a more visual feast. Written by Andrew Bolton, a curator at the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this book will showcase 400 photographs from the Sui archives and include text by the White Stripes frontman Jack White and her longtime collaborator Steven Meisel. Finally, two photographers put the art in Rodarte in a new book from JRP Ringier. ''Rodarte, Catherine Opie, Alec Soth'' (above) is an off-the-cuff collaboration with Kate and Laura Mulleavy that delves into the design duo's myriad obsessions.

Passengers who have checked in can swipe their boarding passes at gates reminiscent of turnstiles and then proceed to their departing flight.

Charles Guislain was just 15 when he crashed his first Paris runway show, Gareth Pugh in 2008. For a petit écolier, he cuts an unusual image, clad in an apocalyptic Rad Hourani chain mail sheath or a princely Martin Margiela cape with hooflike Rick Owens wedge boots. The fashion commentariat thinks of him as the goth counterpoint to the kooky, hat-loving Tavi, but Guislain is no blogger. He was discovered by the raspy-voiced cult fashion journalist Diane Pernet and became something of a flaxen-haired YouTube curiosity, and he was recently the subject of a spread in Italian Vogue. He's still in school, studying Rimbaud, Barthes, Proust - serious reading for a serious boy.

Reliance Industries of India continues to pay top dollar to tap into the natural gas market in the United States, pushing up what some people in the energy industry think are exorbitant prices to obtain unconventional shale gas. Reliance's $392 million deal with Carrizo Oil and Gas is just one of several shale transactions that are expected by energy bankers.

At a recent Chanel party, a little-known D.J. took the stage to a remix of ''Carmina Burana'' and spun the crowd - which included Tim Burton, Vanessa Paradis and Johnny Depp - into a frenzy. This mix master wasn't a model or a downtown doyenne: it was Ruth Flowers, a k a Mamy Rock, a grandmother well into her 70s who has put in appearances at Cannes, Glastonbury and Paris, where her ''factotum'' is based. ''I thought, What are they going to think of this old biddy who gets up there to play records?'' she says from her home in southwest England. Inspired to become a D.J. when she attended her grandson's birthday party, Flowers has worked with a French producer on mixing, as well as on her ''stage persona,'' which includes a hairstyle that ''looks as if I've been plugged into an electricity cord.'' Spinning has eclipsed some of her other hobbies, like giving historical talks about Henry VIII, but she's happy to be busy. ''When you get to 60, that's when you just go to bingo, I suppose,'' she says, adding unnecessarily, ''That's not my scene.''

Israel's border police force insisted in a statement on Thursday that video of a 5-year-old Palestinian boy reacting with dismay to the arrest of his father this week in the West Bank, which has been broadcast internationally, was staged.

As my colleagues Campbell Robertson, Justin Gillis and I reported on reaction, scientific and otherwise, to a government report on the fate of the oil in the gulf, it emerged that the Obama administration faced something of a credibility gap in conveying its findings to some gulf residents, environmental groups and even scientists.

A 30-year-old man who confessed to the 2008 baseball-bat murder of a 31-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant by saying, "So I killed someone - that makes me a bad guy?" was sentenced on Thursday to more than 30 years in prison.

Jellies and jelly molds seem to be wiggling into the picture. Their structured yet bosomy shapes provide a flourish of Victoriana, and their wobbly weirdness seems to prefigure molecular cuisine. I store my hair elastics in upended enamel molds, and turned out my third summer pudding in a rabbit-shaped one from a tag sale. They're remarkably pretty, and they satisfy the current food-geist of homemade and arcane.

The Japanese speed-eating powerhouse Takeru Kobayashi was given a pass Thursday morning on charges of trespassing and resisting arrest after he rushed the stage at last month's Nathan's Hot Dog Eating Contest in Coney Island.

From the start, postures in the lawsuit challenging California's same-sex marriage ban have been unpredictable. There was the David Boies-Ted Olson alliance arguing for the plaintiffs. The defendant in the case, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, a Republican, said, essentially, that he was glad he lost.

Earlier this year, we asked students and teachers to name the books they love to read and teach. Books like "The Catcher in the Rye" and "To Kill a Mockingbird" were favorites among teachers and students alike.

Senator Scott Brown, the Massachusetts Republican, said on Thursday that he would not support Solicitor General Elena Kagan's nomination to the Supreme Court, denying her a Republican vote that many had expected to be in her corner.

In an article on Wednesday and a followup on Thursday, my colleague Leslie Kaufman and I wrote about a new government report that says that about three-quarters of the oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill has effectively been dealt with through capture, skimming, burning, dispersion or dissolution. The implication is that the oil poses little additional risk to shorelines or at the ocean's surface.
Staff members at Camp Mohawk, a girls' sleep-away camp in northwestern Connecticut, are admonished to leave all Yankee gear home. Read the post on City Room.

Because of the new overdraft law fully going into effect on Aug. 15, new and existing bank customers will be able to withdraw more than is in their checking accounts only if they opt in to pay for overdraft protection from their banks. Previously, banks had automatically signed up consumers for the service and then charged customers hefty fees whenever they covered an overdraft.

In reports issued on Thursday, the long-term outlook for Medicare remained gloomy unless further reforms are put in place. But the financial picture for both Medicare and Social Security has improved because of changes mandated by the new health care law, according to a new article by The Times's Jackie Calmes.
Baseball fans throughout the Northeast are eagerly anticipating the return of the Boston Red Sox to the Bronx this weekend to face their archrivals, the New York Yankees.

Stuart Appleby had just birdied the last three holes. It was the final round of the Greenbrier Classic, and he had birdied nine holes and eagled another to shoot a historic 59. He had bogeyed only one of 72 holes during the tournament. He was on fire, playing almost as precisely -- 22-under par for the four days -- as any golfer could reasonably expect.

The 18 men and women slowly climbing the steps to their yoga class at RAIN Inwood Senior Center the other day hardly resembled the young, lithe exemplars of America's yoga boom. You won't find the likes of Sylvia Guzman, 81, on the covers of yoga magazines or Francisco Batista, 88, on the proliferating Web sites hawking trendy yoga clothing.

Oh, the trials of being a supermodel. Naomi Campbell testified in the war crimes trial against former Liberian President Charles Taylor this morning in The Hague. La Campbell, who had been subpoenaed about whether Taylor had gifted her blood diamonds, was asked why she didn't find being given a small pouch of "dirty-looking stones" by two men in the middle of the night strange. Her reply? She responded, "It's not abnormal for me to get gifts, I get gifts all the time." She also claimed she didn't even know the stones, which she subsequently donated to charity, were diamonds: "I'm used to seeing diamonds shiny and in a box, that's the kind of diamonds I'm used to seeing." At least she had the common sense not to wear diamonds with her Azzedine Alaïa knit dress and matching cardigan.
Our children are overweight. Experts blame everything from high fructose corn syrup and too much computer time to too little sleep and insidious advertising.

CORTLAND, N.Y. - The Hall of Fame quarterback Joe Namath met with reporters Thursday morning in the media room of the Jets' training facility. He labeled the Jets' Super Bowl aspirations "justified," claimed he was not concerned with the stalled contract negotiations for Darrelle Revis and repeatedly expressed concern about the team's opening at left guard.

I'm not the man to write about climate change, but I can say that I was a little surprised last week to see triggerfish at our local farmers' market, caught off the Hamptons. Members of this pretty large family are not unheard of around here, but I've always thought of them as warmer-water fish. I look to readers to set me straight on this, especially if they're anglers by profession or avocation. Anyway, never having tasted triggerfish, my wife, Jackie, and I bought a couple of five-ounce fillets to slot into the previously designed template for dinner that night.
Readers of The Choice enrolled at for-profit colleges, or considering doing so, would do well to read two articles by my colleague Tamar Lewin in The Times on Thursday and Wednesday.

After Chevrolet's announcement last week that its 2011 Volt plug-in hybrid would sell for $41,000, it seemed that only President Obama could muster an unequivocal assessment of the car. "Pretty smooth," he said, grinning, after a brief test drive on the Volt's factory floor in Hamtramck, Mich. Others criticized Chevrolet's parent company, General Motors, for pricing the car beyond the reach of many taxpayers who buoyed the corporation before its June 2009 bankruptcy filing.
The former Mets first baseman Carlos Delgado, recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his right hip, seems to be on the verge of a major league return.

The city and state announced an agreement Thursday morning that paves the way for the city to start cleaning up 7,000 acres of brownfields around the city - contaminated areas that are not toxic enough to qualify for Superfund designation. The program offers developers financial incentives to offset some of the cost of cleanup. Read more on The Times's Green blog.

This week on Popcast, The Times's music podcast, Jon Pareles discusses "The Suburbs" by Arcade Fire, the indie-rock band from Montreal that went gold with "whoa-oh-oh" choruses and meditations on death and family.

Add this to the growing list of reasons to visit (or relocate to) Portland, Ore.: the city's food-focused happy hour tradition. While other towns - notably Seattle, Los Angeles, Atlanta and Charleston, S.C. - also serve cheap eats in the late afternoon, Portland has been doing it since the last recession. If you ask restaurant owners, they'll tell you the back story: a state liquor law forbids businesses from promoting discounted alcohol, so it made sense to lure in diners with at-cost food. (Though this law has recently changed, $5 plates are more ubiquitous than ever.) And this being Portland, you're more likely to find charcuterie plates or pig heart with quince jam on the menu than sliders and fries.

My parents, who are in their 70s, are coming to visit Savannah this summer. They are from New York, and Savannah is on their list of possible places to retire to. Do you have any sights you'd recommend?
The Department of Education announced winners in a $650 million federal grant competition known as Investing in Innovation. About 1,700 groups applied for grants.

Usually in situations like these, we'd begin with a tongue-in-cheek gloss on one of Don Henley's songs - "Dirty Laundry," maybe? - but under the circumstances, we'll just play it straight: Mr. Henley, the once and future Eagle and solo singer-songwriter, has reached a settlement with and received an apology from Chuck DeVore, the California politician, and Justin Hart, a worker for Mr. DeVore's 2010 United States Senate campaign, who were found to have violated the copyrights to two of Mr. Henley's best-known tracks.

Bloomberg and Pete Grannis, the commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, announced an agreement Thursday morning that paved the way for the city to start cleaning up "brownfields," or light-to-moderately contaminated areas that are not toxic enough to qualify for federal or state Superfund cleanup programs. About 7,000 vacant or underused acres around the city could be readied for new development under the program, city officials said.

In Politco, Darren Samuelsohn has a solid roundup of reflections by environmental campaigners on why, despite spending tens of millions of dollars, they failed to gain the votes for any climate action in the Senate. But the entire discussion is about tactics, not ideas. There are scant signs, yet, that anyone within the Beltway is willing to shift toward attacking the entwined energy and climate challenges as less a 20th-century-style pollution problem and more a 21st-century-style technology and innovation opportunity.

BAYREUTH, Germany - There is a general and mostly well-founded perception of the Bayreuth Festival as an elitist stronghold for opera, as much a shrine to Wagner as a festival of his works. And there is no ticket harder to come by. Wagner-lovers wait an average of 10 years to get a coveted ticket to the Festspielhaus, which seats only about 2,000.
Jan Benzel is an editor at The Times who is being reassigned to Paris. Before she leaves, she is attempting to do all the things in the city that every New Yorker should do, at least once.
I.B.M. has been quietly saying for months that it planned to enter the market for electronic health records, a business being primed with hefty government subsidies.

If you put Martha Stewart and Rhoda Morgenstern together, you might just get Cathy Callahan. As Cathy of California, Callahan creates whimsical shop windows and styles merchandise for Los Angeles shops like Heath Ceramics; the fashion boutique Market; Stripes, an upscale shoe store in Bel Air; and Yolk, a purveyor of groovy gifts and housewares in Silver Lake. The garland of bright yellow marshmallow Peeps that graced Yolk's window around Easter time was Cathy of California's handiwork. Callahan's displays blend elegance, whimsy and humor; her windows often include cheeky one-liners. Her current window for Market, which features hanging embroidery hoops festooned with paper price tags, declares, "Tag, you're it!" She's also an avid crafter and often makes the props for her displays. When a client wanted to buy the props from a display that was coming down, Callahan added a handmade craft business to her repertory. Her colorful vintage-inspired creations - like plump toadstool pincushions and bright butterfly brooches - sell out quickly at West Coast indie craft fairs like Renegade and Felt Club. Callahan once appeared on Martha Stewart's TV show, kindly but firmly demonstrating to the design maven herself how to make straw flowers from a vintage kit.

As I write in Thursday's issue of The Times, the Dead Sea and its depleted waters have become a rare symbol of regional cooperation among the people that share its shores, which stretch across Israel, Jordan and the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Officials and activists in Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian Authority have joined forces in trying to find solutions to a drop in the water level of the salt lake even as diplomatic progress on other fronts has stalled.

David Rockefeller, Ronald Perelman, Larry Ellison, Sanford Weill, Ted Turner and Paul Allen joined a pledge started by Warren Buffett for billionaires to give more than half their wealth to charity, Bloomberg News reported.

It's not just in the United States that classic single-screen movie theaters have become an endangered species, steadily replaced by nearly interchangeable multiplexes. Most of the legendary cinema halls where Mumbaikars of a certain age first fell in love with movies have either ceased operations, been subdivided into smaller rooms, or primarily screen B-movies or regional films. But one of these celebrated halls, Edward Cinema, seems to be trapped in time. And an ongoing film festival is a great reason to visit.

The China Investment Corporation, the sovereign wealth fund represented by Kenny Huang, has lined up the cash needed to purchase Liverpool Football Club in Britain, The Guardian reports.

The Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, the sovereign wealth fund known as G.I.C., has added three banks as joint bookrunners for the upcoming initial public offering of its logistics unit that could raise as much as $3 billion, Reuters reported, citing two sources familiar with the deal.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Bain Capital, which earned billions of dollars buying and selling companies, are facing a 25 percent discount in the initial public offering of NXP Semiconductors after three years of losses, Bloomberg News reports.

The European Commission, International Monetary Fund and European Central Bank will outline the results of an inspection Thursday that will determine whether debt-ridden Greece will receive the second installment of rescue loans to keep it from bankruptcy, The Associated Press reported.

Commerzbank, the second-largest lender in Germany after Deutsche Bank, said Thursday that it had earned 352 million euros, or $463 million, in the second quarter as loan loss provisions shrunk, the German economy recovered and it booked a tax credit. The bank also raised its outlook, saying it expected to turn a profit for the year.

Dima Gavrysh, who was born in Ukraine, is a New York-based photographer. For his most recent project, he spent last summer with the United States Army in Afghanistan for The Associated Press.

Warner Brothers is set to buy the British television production company Shed Media, maker of such programs as Supernanny and The Choir, for around £100 million ($158 million) to boost its presence in the key market, Reuters reported.
Shares in Motorola rose 6 percent on Wednesday after the billionaire investor,  Carl C. Icahn,  said he had raised his stake in the company to 9.9 percent from 8.75 percent, Reuters reported.

The hedge fund manager, J. Ezra Merkin, asked a United States judge to dismiss a class-action lawsuit accusing him of recklessly funneling millions of dollars in client funds to the now-imprisoned Ponzi schemer Bernard Madoff, Reuters reported.

China's banking regulator told lenders last month to conduct a new round of stress tests to gauge the impact of residential property prices falling as much as 60 percent in the hardest-hit markets, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.
