An article on Saturday about the Boy Scouts' trying to rebuild their image and their membership misidentified the home state of a scout who attended the organization's National Scout Jamboree last week at Fort A.P. Hill, Va., and said that ''women deserve the same stuff as men do.'' The scout, Ben Rosenbaum, is from California, not Utah.

When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appointed Ranji Nagaswami as the administration's first chief investment adviser this week, city officials acknowledged that she had been granted a residency waiver so she could continue to live in Greenwich, Conn. Which raises the question: How many other waivers have been allowed since Mr. Bloomberg became mayor in 2002?

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about some filmmakers' reservations about 3-D technology misstated Joss Whedon's role in the coming horror film ''The Cabin in the Woods.'' He is the producer of the film, not its director. The article also misstated the name of a planned 3-D release in the ''Saw'' series. It will be called ''Saw 3-D,'' not ''Saw VII.''

In the years I've been using computers, monitors have grown thinner and more vivid in their picture displays, and the technology that runs them has grown faster and less expensive. But two things have remained relatively constant: my keyboard and mouse. Yet that's about to change. I'm pretty certain I will never own a traditional mouse again, at least when I use an Apple computer. Instead I will own a trackpad -- a Magic Trackpad.

A subheading with an article on Tuesday about a growing dispute between communications companies and governments on the monitoring of e-mail and text messages misstated, in some copies, the name of the nation that recently threatened to shut down mobile services on BlackBerrys. It is the United Arab Emirates -- not the United Arab Republic, which no longer exists.

The federal judge overseeing a discrimination lawsuit against the city's Fire Department ruled on Wednesday that the hiring test being used by the department was unfair to minority applicants and issued an injunction that will prevent the city from offering positions to 300 applicants who had already taken the exam. Two previous hiring tests have been ruled discriminatory by the judge, who has accused the city of using obstructionist tactics to avoid court-ordered reforms aimed at increasing the number of black and Hispanic firefighters in a department that has long been disproportionately white.

Two new portable camcorders from Panasonic and Samsung are vying with the market leader Flip for a place in your pocket. Both shoot video in full 1080p high definition using the H.264 format. The $170 Panasonic HM-TA1 doubles as a Webcam when connected to a computer via U.S.B., a nifty feature that allows you to use video chat applications. It's a compact, straightforward camcorder whose design is very similar to that of the Flip family. Just below its 2-inch LCD are intuitive single-function buttons for power, play, record, still photo, and delete.

SWAN--Thomas F.,84 died peacefully, after a short illness, on July 31, 2010, with his wife, Barbara H. Swan by his side. Tom is survived by his sister, Betty Kuntz, two children from a previous marriage, Sally and Gregory Swan, and two step daughters, Jacqueline Van Cleve Hinshaw and Kathryn Van Cleve Kuhns. Tom's son Steven predeceased him. After a long career in advertising, Tom became a published author of four mystery novels dealing with art crime. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, August 10th at 11 am at Basking Ridge Presbyterian Church, 1 East Oak Street, Basking Ridge, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a charity of your choice. For more information please contact the Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home at 908-766-0250 or visit our website www.gcfuneralhome.com.

In a city forever stretching skyward, a local landlord has been ordered to do an unusual thing: tear part of his building down. The Board of Standards and Appeals ruled this week that Benjamin Shaoul must remove four seventh-story cabinlike structures he built atop two of his adjoining tenement buildings at 514-516 East Sixth Street in the East Village in Manhattan. The decision was greeted as a partial victory by the landlord, and a mixed blessing by longtime tenants who have long fought the expansion.
FISHMAN--Harry. Adored husband, best friend, thank you for 61 wonderful years, it was too short, I miss you already. Your forever wife

The next player to join Alex Rodriguez in the 600 home run club, if he keeps playing, should be Jim Thome of the Minnesota Twins. Thome, who turns 40 this month, has 577 career homers, including 13 in 227 plate appearances this season. Thome ranks 10th on the career list for home runs, and according to baseball-reference.com, these are the six most similar players in baseball history to Thome: Harmon Killebrew, Frank Thomas, Mike Schmidt, Willie McCovey, Mickey Mantle and Willie Stargell. All are Hall of Famers except Thomas, a two-time most valuable player who retired in 2008 and seems to be a Cooperstown lock.

WESTERMANN--Helge, a modernist Danish-born architect designing urban buildings such as the Juilliard School in New York and a Performing Arts Center at Smith College, died on August 4, 2010 in Washington, DC. He was 94.

In gadget terms, the progression of the U.S.B. flash drive is a contradiction: the bigger it gets, the smaller it gets. That's because size, in this particular device, has two meanings. One refers to the storage capacity, as measured in bytes and the amount of data in the form of photos, music, etc. that a flash drive has. They now have the ability to store some rather amazing sizes, up to 256 gigabytes. I still use a U.S.B. stick that holds a modest 64 megabytes, but I don't show it off.

ZELNER--Barbara, of New York, NY, died on August 4, 2010. Devoted wife of Martin, cherished sister of Myra, loving mother of Emily and Bennet. Adored grandmother of Harry and Lily, beloved mother-in-law of Joel and Elizabeth. Selfless to the end, she died as she lived, making plans to bring her loved ones together, as she did so often for family celebrations and holidays, to help ease the pain of their loss. Her love and friendship will always be with us. Services private. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for the purpose of lung cancer research.
GARTENBERG--Max J. May 12, 1926-August 5, 2009 Dearest and best of men. Loved forever. Pat, Annie, Dirk, Will & Paul

SAVAGE--William Halsted, 91, of Westwood, MA formerly of New York City on August 3, 2010. Predeceased by wife, Carolyn Mackie Savage. Survived by sons, William and Frederick, and grandsons, Jonathan and Christopher. Memorial service at a future date. In lieu of flowers, family would appreciate contributions to Protect the Adirondacks, 897 St. David's Lane, Niskayuna, NY 12309.
An article on Monday about scientific research in golf misstated the surname of the senior vice president for membership at the National Golf Foundation. He is Greg Nathan, not Nation.

Bicycling or skateboarding with headphones is fun, but it's dangerous. Blocking out the sound of approaching cars and other riders can result in road rash or worse. So now there is the Tunebug Shake, which turns a helmet into a speaker, allowing riders to wear safety gear and listen to music without blocking out other sounds.

Excerpts from the ruling by a federal judge in San Francisco that struck down California's Proposition 8, the voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage, follow. The full text is at nytimes.com/national: ''Marriage in the United States has always been a civil matter. Civil authorities may permit religious leaders to solemnize marriages but not to determine who may enter or leave a civil marriage. Religious leaders may determine independently whether to recognize a civil marriage or divorce, but that recognition or lack thereof has no effect on the relationship under state law. ...

BUCK--Marilyn, December 13, 1947-August 3, 2010, died at home in Brooklyn. Recently released from prison, she was extraordinary, beautiful and brilliant. Poet, translator and revolutionary; she is survived by loving family and a world-wide community in solidarity for justice.
PREISS--Al. Visionary Adman, Phenomenal Husband, Father and Grandpa. Died August 2nd. Forever loved.

WOLFSOHN--Vera, 92, owner of the Shack in the Back Antiques in Forest Hills, Queens, for 30 years, and a Past President of the Long Island Antique Dealer's Association, died August 3rd at the home of her son, Brian Wolfsohn and daughter-in-law, Ellen Bukstel in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Preceded in death by her husband, Edward B. Wolfsohn, Mrs. Wolfsohn is survived by her son Brian, sister Beatrice Baron, niece Ann Floch, nephew Bill Baron, three great-nephews and daughter-in-law Ellen Bukstel. Graveside service Thursday 1pm at Beth David in Elmont, NY. For Florida information: Star of David in North Lauderdale. A celebration of Vera's life will be held September 5th at the home of Brian and Ellen.

DERFNER--Harold. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale note with profound sadness the loss of Harold Derfner, a stalwart member of the Home's Board of Directors for more than fifty years. Through his generosity and that of his beloved late wife, Helen, the Derfner Judaica Museum, known world-wide for its art program, was created. They also graciously provided the lead gift to create a spectacular 25,000 square foot outdoor space at the Home, known as "Helen's Terrace" providing numerous opportunities for residents to relax and reflect. We will sorely miss his warmth and friendship. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children Peter and Leslie, granddaughter Rachel White (Christopher) and devoted friend Jay Lieberman. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

John Aylesworth, co-creator of the long-running television hit ''Hee Haw,'' a blend of cornball humor and country music, died July 28 in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Palm Desert, Calif. The cause was pneumonia, his wife, Anita Rufus, said.

WORMSER--Eva. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of its long time member, Eva Wormser, wife of Stephen Wormser. Condolences are extended to the entire family. Rabbi Jordan Millstein Jack Reich & Howard Simon, Presidents

An article on Tuesday about Mets players' reaction to Ozzie Guillen's comments about bias against Latin American baseball players misstated the name of the city where the Mets have a minor league affiliate. It is Kingsport, Tenn., not Kingston.

Proposition 8 cannot withstand any level of scrutiny under the Equal Protection Clause. Excluding same-sex couples from marriage is simply not rationally related to a legitimate state interest. VAUGHN R. WALKER, the chief judge of the Federal District Court in San Francisco. [A1]

An article on Wednesday about the interfaith wedding of Chelsea Clinton and Marc Mezvinsky misidentified the state in which Mr. Mezvinsky's grandfather had a grocery store. Abe Mezvinsky's store was in Iowa, not Ohio.

FISHMAN--Harry, died peacefully August 2 at the age of 88. Loving and devoted husband to Gloria, adoring father to Michael and Laurie, proud grandfather to Sam, Anna and Joshua, loving brother to Patty and Lila and loving father-in- law to Pam. Born in Philadelphia, one of 12 children, Harry was a self-made man with a passion for business. A giant of a man to those whose lives he touched, he had a charismatic presence, a radiant smile, amazing blue eyes and most of all a huge heart with so much love to give. He loved golf, gin games, vodka, telling jokes and singing old war songs, especially "A Wing and a Prayer". Most of all, he loved his family. Service Thursday 11:30am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, NY.

An article and a picture caption on Tuesday about a federal rule that bars the donation of blood by gay men misspelled the surname of a project manager in St. Paul who was first turned away as a blood donor in college. He is Brad Baso, not Basso.

FELIX--Arthur, M.D.,on July 31. Survived by his loving wife Marilyn of 58 years, children Laurel (Abe), Lisa (Alan), and Alan (Allyson), and sister Joan. Devoted "Papa" to seven grandchildren. Dedicated physician for more than 40 years.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- Under the watchful eye of a male instructor, a teenage boy is deep in focus, trying to trace and copy from a postcard as accurately as possible. For years, this has been the art scene in Afghanistan: stale, and dominated by men. Realism has long ruled as the only accepted style.

All the editors in my department want to talk about the New York shows. Already? It was more than I could take, and I decided to go shopping. I love the lull before the storm - the arrival of runway clothes in stores. The expected arrival of runway clothes. They are coming, aren't they? Stores now want more deliveries than a squirrel wants nuts. I saw Alexander Wang the other day over lunch at ABC Kitchen, and he said he's up to nine deliveries a year.

Hart Schaffner Marx, the 123-year-old Chicago-based clothier best known for its sartorial style (and for suiting up President Obama), has been rediscovered, and in the process has made its own exciting discovery. After a tumultuous 2009 - which included a bankruptcy filing and new overseas owners - Joseph Abboud, a master of soft tailoring, has been placed at the helm as creative director to oversee the redesign of its roster of well-known brands, which include Hickey Freeman, Austin Reed and Bobby Jones. While mining the company archives for inspiration, he and his colleagues discovered a cache of valuable Maxfield Parrish paintings that had been used for Hickey Freeman advertisements.

A seaside promenade notwithstanding, Tel Aviv is not known for its open spaces. But this concrete condition has improved considerably with the gleaming transformation of HaTachana, the Hebrew name for the old Jaffa railway station, into the city's newest marketplace. Constructed in 1892 as the terminus for the Jaffa-Jerusalem railway, it's become an instant hit with locals who, like Manhattanites, never say no to a piece of the sky or a new hipster nook. HaTachana offers both, and the location couldn't be better: between the beach and Neve Tzedek, the city's first Jewish settlement outside Jaffa and now a lively district of renovated pastel houses and designer boutiques, especially along Shabazi Street, which ends where the HaTachana complex begins.

Movies haunt culture like starlit ghosts, circling our collective unconscious. Some insinuate themselves because they are comforting and friendly, which is not the case with ''Last Year at Marienbad,'' a famously impenetrable monument to the avant-garde directed by Alain Resnais. But the discovery of six reels of behind-the-scenes footage from 1960 forever fractures the movie's cool, calculated surface. With a Super-8 camera, Françoise Spira, a young cast member with a bit part, produced what seems like an amateur version of the film itself, her relationship to its protagonist, played by Delphine Seyrig, as intimate as Resnais's. Spira committed suicide a few years later, and her celluloid diary languished until 2008. The movie's second assistant director, Volker Schlöndorff, later turned it into the documentary ''The Making of 'Last Year at Marienbad,' '' which Diane von Furstenberg toasted at her studio in June after a screening at New York University. Schlöndorff was there, as well as Jean-Luc Godard's biographer Richard Brody, the photographer Steven Klein, Ahn Duong, Daphne Guinness and the documentary's principal promoter, Bernard-Henri Lévy.

Microsoft Office 2010 came out this summer, and users who made the leap from Office 2003 or earlier may find the "ribbon" that replaces the on-screen toolbars to be confusing. To help newcomers get used to the ribbon, Microsoft has made a game of it. Ribbon Hero, released this year, is a tool that combines casual gaming with interactive software training to teach users how to find commands in the ribbon for Word, Excel, PowerPoint and OneNote. While the experimental game may not be for everyone (or for those who wish the ribbon were more intuitive in the first place), it may help ease some frustration for others. Ribbon Hero is free to download.

METRICK--Richard L. "Richie" of Lloyd Neck, NY on August 3, 2010. Richie was a friend, anchor, mentor, and teacher to his friends and business associates. He was kind, brilliant, generous, honest and possessed an unconditional love and immense selflessness for his friends and family. He is survived by his beloved wife Cheryl. Loving father of Andrew Metrick, Sara Gewirtz, and Marc Metrick. Caring brother of Neil (Carroll) Metrick and Allan (Eleanor) Metrick. Devoted uncle of Kym Dawson, Kristen (Jeremy) Dean, and Kory Happ. Cherished grandfather of 13. Also survived by his sister in-law Terry (Joel) Happ and ex-wife Barbara Ross. A family service was held on Thursday at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home. A memorial service for friends and family will be held at a later date. www.jacobsenfuneral.com

NAPCHEN--Minnie, 94 died on August 5, 2010. Predeceased by beloved husband Leon. Survived by her children Deanna and Edwin Weinfeld, Audrey and Joel Napchen, grandchildren Lindsay and Mathew, Scott, Ilene, Steven, Tammy, Andrew, Cynthia, Sheri, Bill and Michael, and great-grandchildren Danny, Jack, Ross, Cory, Leah, Joshua, Rebecca, Anna and Paul. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, August 8, 2010 at 9am at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY. The family would like to thank all the staff at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, Goldfine 2, for their warm and loving care, especially Myrtie McFarlane, who loved her like her own mother. Donations may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, 5901 Palisade Ave. Riverdale, NY 10471.

DVORKIN--Louis, 88, passed away on Wednesday August 4th. He was a graduate of City College of New York where he received his degree in Accounting. He was an Accountant for many years most recently for New York City retiring at the age of 76. He was a Chairman of the Liberal Party of Queens. He was predeceased by his wife the late Naomi Dvorkin nee Zakim. Surviving are his son Sid Dvorkin wife Jan of Florham Park, NJ, daughter Janice Dvorkin of San Antonio, TX, sister Aida Reinbolt of Pleasant Hill, CA and a granddaughter Danielle. Services at Sharon Gardens Memorial Park Valhalla NY today at 12 Noon. Services by Jewish Memorial Chapel Clifton NJ.

A 30-year-old man who confessed to the 2008 baseball-bat murder of a 31-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant by saying, ''So I killed someone - that makes me a bad guy?'' was sentenced on Thursday to more than 30 years in prison. The defendant, Keith Phoenix, was convicted in May of attacking Jose O. Sucuzhanay on a street corner in Bushwick, Brooklyn, after Mr. Phoenix and another man, Hakim Scott, 27, jumped out of their sport utility vehicle, yelling slurs at Mr. Sucuzhanay and his brother, Romel Sucuzhanay.

METRICK--Richard L. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of Richard L. Metrick, a distinguished member of the evening class of 1968. He was a generous benefactor and beloved friend. Generations of students have benefited from his philanthropy through the Metrick Family Scholarship Fund, which provides support to evening students who have family obligations. Although his presence will be missed, his legacy will be long enduring. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Cheryl, and his entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, President Michael A. Gerber, Dean

ZEAVIN--Robert, died on the evening of Thursday, July 29 in Salt Lake City following a heart attack. He was 59. A fanatically devoted father, and an equally dedicated friend, Bob was also a renowned advocate: As a partner at Manatt, Phelps & Phillips, he co-chaired the national trial group, and co-led the trial team that won the country's largest verdict of 2008. Still, Bob's real loves were his late wife, Yadi, his daughters, Hadley and Georgia, World Cup soccer, wine, food, friends and fun. Survived by his daughters, his brother, Michael, and sister, Lynne, he will be lovingly remembered at a Memorial Celebration at Elings Park, Santa Barbara, on August 15 at 1pm. No black clothing, please. (Hat and comfortable shoes suggested.) In lieu of flowers, remembrance contributions are welcome at Susan G. Komen for the Cure, PO Box 650309, Dallas, Texas 75265.
FEIT--Alvin. Sweetest father and grandfather, Eagle Scout, inventor, decorated sailor. My adorable husband and best friend, thank you for 63 wonderful years. It was too short, we miss you already.

COLEMAN--Fran, 67, died Wednesday August 4th after a valiant battle with brain cancer. Fran was a pioneer in the children's apparel industry. More importantly she was a beloved wife, mother, grandmother of five, and sister. Mom, our hearts are broken. We will miss you forever. Love, Your David, Alyssa and Steven, Hillary and Danny, Austin, Caroline, Eliza, Jillian, Andrew and Jeff.

Teach for America, the nonprofit group that recruits elite college students to teach in public schools, and the KIPP Foundation, which runs a nationwide network of charter schools, were big winners in a $650 million federal grant competition known as Investing in Innovation, the Department of Education said Wednesday. Each group won $50 million. Two others won large awards for proposals the department said were backed by significant evidence of success with students.

WASHINGTON -- The Senate confirmed Elena Kagan to a seat on the Supreme Court on Thursday, giving President Obama his second appointment to the court in a year and a victory over Republicans who sharply challenged her credentials and record. Ms. Kagan, who is set to be sworn in Saturday as the newest member of the court, was approved by a vote of 63 to 37 after hearings and floor debate that showcased the competing views of Democrats and Republicans about the court but exposed no significant stumbling blocks to her confirmation.

Baseball fans throughout the Northeast are eagerly anticipating the return of the Boston Red Sox to the Bronx this weekend to face their archrivals, the New York Yankees. Patrick Marchand has always lived, physically, somewhat in the middle of the two teams. Yet, spiritually, he is firmly in the Red Sox camp - and does not mind letting people know that in the other camp that is a big part of his life: Camp Mohawk, a girls' sleep-away camp in Cornwall, Conn., where he is the director.

In the spring of 2008, the Denver public school system needed to plug a $400 million hole in its pension fund. Bankers at JPMorgan Chase offered what seemed to be a perfect solution. The bankers said that the school system could raise $750 million in an exotic transaction that would eliminate the pension gap and save tens of millions of dollars annually in debt costs -- money that could be plowed back into Denver's classrooms, starved in recent years for funds.

EPSTEIN--Daniel, on August 4, 2010. Former Director of Musical Operations for Sesame Street. He is survived by his beloved wife Shelley, loving daughter Ivy Austin, and grandchildren Oliver and Nolan Marsh. Services Sunday, 2pm at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ISTANBUL -- Israeli business executives here like to point out that most of the angry Turks who protested Israel's deadly raid on a Turkish-led flotilla to Gaza this past spring do not know that their cellphones, personal computers and plasma televisions were made using parts and technology from Tel Aviv. For Menashe Carmon, chairman of the Israel Turkey Business Council, such ignorance is a blessing for Israelis and Turks.

An article on July 29 about the appointment of a new director for the troubled internal watchdog agency at the United Nations misstated the job of Bea Edwards, an advocate for whistle-blowers, who said that the United Nations may not be making good use of its resources to pursue corruption and fraud. She is the director of international reform for the Government Accountability Project, not a lawyer for the group.

6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: INGRID BERGMAN Fans of this Swedish actress (1915-1982) will find some old favorites among the classics in this daylong retrospective. It begins with ''Saratoga Trunk'' (1945), based on the Edna Ferber novel and also starring Flora Robson and Gary Cooper, who plays a gambler the Bergman character falls for. At 4 p.m. Bergman portrays a psychiatrist in the Alfred Hitchcock thriller ''Spellbound'' (1945), with Gregory Peck (above, with Bergman), Rhonda Fleming and a dream sequence designed by Salvador Dalí. No survey would be complete without ''Casablanca'' (1942), at 9:30 p.m., when Ilsa Lund (Bergman), Rick Blaine (Humphrey Bogart), Victor Laszlo (Paul Henreid) and Ugarte (Peter Lorre), among others, get together at Rick's Cafe in Morocco during World War II, under the direction of Michael Curtiz. At 11:30 p.m. Bergman and Hitchcock are collaborators again in ''Notorious'' (1946), in which she stars with Cary Grant and Claude Rains, who also appears with her in ''Casablanca.'' 7 P.M. (National Geographic) NAT GEO AMAZING! This week on the documentary series: sword swallowing and baboons with a knack for stealing.

BERNARD--Pamela. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the passing of Pamela M. Bernard, daughter of the late Helen and Meyer Morris, beloved wife of Martin, adoring mother of Elisabeth, Jeffrey and Jill, sister of Stanley and Renay Morris. BERNARD--Pam. A dear, caring, loving friend, our hearts are broken. We will cherish the wonderful times we shared together. You never had to say a word, your beautiful smile said it all. You loved your friends and your friends loved you back. We will miss you very much. Love, BIC

An article on Thursday about newly emerging accounts of an oil spill on the coast of the northern Chinese city of Dalian referred incorrectly to dimethylbenzene, a flammable, poisonous chemical that, according to a report by the environmental advocacy group Greenpeace and two people with detailed knowledge of the accident, was in a storage tank at the facility where the leak originated and where a fire was raging. The chemical is a liquid, not a gas.

An article on the Small Business page on Thursday about using crowd-sourcing to guide business development misidentified the source of a cash investment received by Trada, a crowd-sourcing firm in Boulder, Colo. WASHINGTON -- Nearly a dozen current or former lawmakers have been honored by university endowments financed in part by corporations with business before Congress, posing some potential conflicts like that attributed to Representative Charles B. Rangel in an House ethics complaint. The donations from businesses to the endowments ranged from modest amounts to millions of dollars, federal records show. And the lawmakers, who include powerful committee chairmen or party leaders, often pushed legislation or special appropriations sought by the corporations.

On Friday, the Boston Red Sox will arrive at Yankee Stadium for a four-game series. When Boston came to New York last August, they were only two and a half games out of first place. In 2008, they were four and a half out of first when they made the August trip. And in 2007, the Red Sox were in first place, by seven and a half games, when they traveled to Yankee Stadium in August. This year, though, it is a different story. The Red Sox are further behind the Yankees - six and a half games going into Thursday's games.

MARLIN--William M.,(85), died on August 2, 2010 after a brief illness. He served in the US Army Aircorp (483rd) 17th Squad during World War II. His aircraft was shot down over Germany during the Memmingen air battle. He was a POW interned at Stalag Luft IV, Luft I. Awarded the Purple Heart and Bronze star. He spent thirty years on Wall Street retiring as Vice Chairman of the board at Prudential-Bache Securities. Survived by wife Suzanne, children Scott, Dennis, and Kristy Ann. Brothers John, Lawrence, and James. Stepchildren Michael and Bryan. Six grandchildren.

The summer holiday period has existed for a few years now in Formula One. It used to be there was no break, but as teams took more and more mechanics and crew to races and there were more and more races in the season, the series decided to create a three week break in August to give everyone a rest. That three-week break is sometimes four weeks, as it is this year, but even a four-week break for F1 people is a three week break, since they usually leave a day or two after the preceding race and they arrive at the next race several days in advance.

What Mark Thoma said: Ned Phelps's declaration that "There are no symptoms of deficient demand, like deflation" is bizarre. Disinflation has been proceeding steadily in the face of high unemployment:

Why would a temporary extension of the high-end Bush tax cuts be a highly ineffective form of stimulus? Coming into this economic crisis, I thought every macroeconomist understood why temporary tax cuts do little to boost demand, especially if those tax cuts are for people with high incomes. But as with so much else, this seems to be one of these economic insights that has been lost in our intellectual Dark Age. So what I thought I'd do is lay out, briefly, the basic logic.

An article on Friday about the financing of centers established by universities to honor lawmakers referred incorrectly to assertions in a report by the House Ethics Committee on the practices of Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, who was criticized by the panel for practices involving a program honoring him at the City College of New York. The committee's report said that Mr. Rangel and his staff had discussed both legislative matters and potential donations to the program with the same lobbyists; the report did not say he discussed legislative matters at the same meetings where he was soliciting donations. (The Times was told by participants at a gathering in February 2007 that both legislation and donations were discussed there, but Mr. Rangel disputed that.)

You might call it the college student's first lesson in exploitation: paying $100 for a textbook, then getting a mere $12 when reselling to the campus bookstore at the end of the semester. College textbook prices rose about 6 percent, on average, every year -- that's twice the rate of inflation -- from 1986 to 2004. And there's nothing more infuriating then paying the sticker price on textbooks (well, with the exception of tuition itself), when many other books are available at a discount. The cost of buying the textbooks can easily add up to $1,000 a year or more.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE BOX (2009) A stranger (Frank Langella) bearing a gift worth a million dollars arrives on the doorstep of Norma and Arthur (James Marsden and Cameron Diaz, above), a Virginia couple living somewhat beyond their means. All they have to do is push a red button -- after which someone will die. ''The actors are fine, and to watch Norma trying to persuade Arthur that they need to push the button is to realize that Ms. Diaz should go dark more often,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of Richard Matheson's short story ''Button, Button,'' by the director Richard Kelly. '' 'The Box' is alternately fluid and inspired, and rarely dull (though it is a little, on occasion),'' she added. ''There are, as with his previous films, various visual gifts, like the spooky image of an airplane hangar glowing in the night and the odd image of Norma's little toe waving like a finger. But Mr. Kelly is so busy sampling genres and confusing the issue that he rarely gives you time or space to enjoy them. In the end, he often seems as lost as his characters, trapped in a Pandora's box of his own making.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Burt Neuborne, the legal director of the Brennan Center for Justice at the New York University School of Law, concludes his analysis of the First Amendment and the ruling by the United States Supreme Court that the government may not ban political spending by corporations in candidate elections.

According to a recent post on Consumer Reports' Money Blog, banks have reported a sharp rise in recent months of crime related to thefts of bank account data from tampered gas pumps. Reports of the thefts are popping up in states like Arizona, Florida, Utah and Colorado. In fact, according to the post, the governor of Arizona recently ordered inspections of gas pumps to find the skimmer devices.

JAKARTA -- After years of being known for inefficiency, corruption and instability, Indonesia is emerging from the global financial crisis with a surprising new reputation -- economic golden child. The country's economy, the largest in Southeast Asia, grew at an annual rate of 6.2 percent in the second quarter of this year, data released Thursday showed. That is an acceleration from 2009, when gross domestic product expanded 4.5 percent.

GORDON--Hattie (nee Cohen), 95, "a voracious reader" of Teaneck, NJ on August 5, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Nason. Devoted mother of Suzan. Loving grandmother of Lauri Benton and Gregory Benton. Great-grandmother of Angela and Mabel Benton. Graveside service Sunday August 8, 2010, 11:30am at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Hattie and Nason Gordon Therapeutic Nursery Foundation, care of JCC on the Palisades, Tenafly, NJ 07670. Services Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.

OLTARSH--Kenneth S.,on August 5, 2010. Darling husband of Naomi (nee Daniels), beloved father of Valerie (McCarthy) and Frederic, adored grandfather of Alex. Lawyer to his last day, sweetheart, tennis player, avid Fig Newton eater. Died quickly, courageously, sparing his survivors the torture of seeing him go. We love you always and forever, Naomi, Valerie, Frederic and families. Service Sunday, 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

ALFENITO--Diana S.,of New Rochelle, passed away peacefully on August 5, 2010 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Dr. Joseph Alfenito. Loving mother of Dianne Hackney (Thomas), Lisa Monsen (Craig) and Joseph Jr. (Pam). Dear sister of Virginia Christiana. Adoring grandmother of seven grandchildren. Visiting Sunday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. in Larchmont, NY (914)834-0144. Mass Monday 11am at Holy Name of Jesus Church in New Rochelle, NY.

The Knicks continued their roster overhaul on Friday by reaching an agreement with the shooting guard Roger Mason Jr., who played for the San Antonio Spurs the last two seasons. Mason, 29, is expected to sign a one-year contract and compete for a starting position. He has bounced around the league; the Knicks will be his fifth team in seven seasons. He carved a niche with the Spurs in 2008-09 by averaging a career-high 11.8 points and hitting a number of game-winning shots. But Mason's role diminished last season when a healthy Manu Ginobili returned.

SLATER--Jack. August 7, 2007. Remembered with love. Miss your wit, politics, cigars. You were one of a kind.

SIMON--Stanley, a man of extraordinary talent, who had the respect of business people the world over for his integrity, brilliant strategic analyses of complex problems, his sense of humor and loyalty to his friends that will never be forgotten. He lived a long and successful life, was a dedicated arborist and he will be missed by generations to come. A. Robert Towbin

LAUDY--William R.,Jr. died peacefully on August 2, 2010. He was 80 years old. He is survived by his wife Mary Lou, his sister Barbara, his son Mark, daughter-in-law Janet, and grandchildren Kate and Sam. Mr. Laudy was born in Tarrytown, New York, on June 30, 1930, to William R. Laudy, Sr., and Eleanor (McBride) Laudy. He received a BA from Yale University in 1952. After two years of service with the US Army, Mr. Laudy worked for 35 years at the Bankers Trust Company of New York. He enjoyed a steak with a nice Bordeaux, his hapless Mets, reading about obscure topics, and, most of all, his friends and family. He will be remembered for his dry humor, his encyclopedic knowledge, and the example he set as a loving husband and father. Visiting hours 3-6pm Sunday at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 North Broadway in Tarrytown, with a funeral service in the same location at 11 am Monday. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

An article on Page 28 this weekend about the writer Daphne Merkin's lifelong experience with psychotherapy misstates the status of a medical condition of a therapist of hers who died suddenly. It was a recurrence of leukemia, not a remission.

Somewhat hidden in a New Jersey suburb is a treasure trove of golf history. The United States Golf Association Museum in Far Hills, N.J., is more than a collection of golf memorabilia, though it is an impressive gathering of artifacts, clubs, garments, trophies, works of golf art and hundreds of other meaningful and memorable objects associated with the game. The museum, however, does more than show you important pieces of golf history; it puts them together to tell you the story of golf in America.

CHICAGO -- Perry Farrell of Jane's Addiction was the original visionary behind Lollapalooza, which began in 1991 as a package tour of alternative rock, stocked with side stages, art installations and freak-show diversions, and it became the model for all everything-but-the-kitchen sink American music festivals, from H.O.R.D.E. to Coachella. It ran for seven years and had a brief, troubled return in the early 2000s before an ambitious group of independent concert promoters in Austin, Tex., revived it in 2005 as a single weekend event Chicago.

Surfing the Web while eating lunch at your desk is a good way to catch up on the news, but it can get messy trying to juggle forks, spoons and the mouse all at once. If you'd rather just sit back and dine while the headlines and news from your favorite blogs and Web sites automatically roll by on screen, try the ScrollyFox add-on for the Mozilla Firefox browser. Once installed and turned on, ScrollyFox gently scrolls down an open page and then back up again for each selected site. The add-on works on most Web pages, although it may get stymied occasionally by certain sites, and the scrolling speed is adjustable.

Watching flamenco performed outdoors has be one of the most sublime experiences in dance. Though often associated with smoky cafes, the art form becomes all the more electrifying when the sounds of strumming guitars, pounding feet and plaintive voices fill the fresh evening air. That's why every summer in Spain the greatest flamenco artists work their magic on stages under the stars. But even among all those superb festivals, the flamenco-related portion of the Veranos de la Villa festival in Madrid, which runs from Aug. 10 to 21, stands out.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Cyclists Said to Back Claims Armstrong Doped,'' Aug. 5: Assume for the sake of argument that Lance Armstrong is guilty of systematic doping. Who cares? He has done a lot of good. Armstrong has raised money for cancer research, and stands as an inspiration for many cancer survivors. He will continue to do good unless he falls victim to an inquisition.Lee Fineman

My parents and I arrived promptly for our 7 p.m. reservation late last month in what was almost certainly the lone white-tablecloth dining establishment in Los Zorros, a seaside fishing village on the Pacific coast of Nicaragua. As the only guests, we were seated without delay and were soon digging into three whole fried sea bass smothered in chopped tomatoes alongside rice, salad and gooey, sweet fried plantains. My mother paused to sip her drink. ''I'm really enjoying this fine orange wine,'' she said. ''What an aroma.''
STONE COLONIAL $1,175,000

GANZ--Leonora, nee Alton. Died April 28, 2010 in New York City, where she was born on February 19, 1910. Late of Hollywood, Florida, Leonora was the daughter of Minnie and Maurice Alton, sister of William Alton, widow of Samuel Evans Ganz, MD, who she missed for the rest of her life and mother of Maurice Cory, who survives her. Always cheerful, always understanding, always caring, your loving son will miss you every day of his life.
Film Neil Genzlinger

My husband and I spent a year looking for our first home. Every Sunday, we'd jump in the car with driving directions and hope, the latter often dashed before we even got out of the car. The open houses were often short stories unto themselves: what exactly - or who - was behind that padlocked door in the hall? Who thought to put the kitchen next to the master bedroom? What sort of people suspend a suit of armor over their bed? One constant behind all the front doors was the fast and cheap kitchen renovation. Done no doubt at the urging of the real estate agent, who warned that no one would ever buy a house without an updated kitchen, these cookie-cutter remodels featured identical green granite countertops, frosted glass cabinet doors (revealing a hint of the Italian pasta boxes inside), black and white checkerboard floor tile and wannabe Viking ranges.

BERMAN--Lawrence "Larry", of New York passed away on August 5, 2010, after a long and unforgiving illness at age 73. He is survived by his best friend and adoring wife Gina, his cherished children Wendy, David, and Sarah, and his precious granddaughter Zoe. Larry was a kind, generous, loving and respected man. He dedicated himself to his family, his career and his friends. Larry was truly a gift to all whose lives he touched and leaves us with a lifetime of wonderful and beautiful memories. Services Sunday, August 8, 11 am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, corner West 91st NY, NY.

A safari camp with political pedigree recently opened in South Africa.The 30,000-acre Shambala Game Reserve in the Waterberg Mountains of Limpopo Province, home to Africa's Big Five and the center where Nelson Mandela hosts world leaders, has opened to the public with a new camp. The seven-room Zulu Camp on the property offers access to the game reserve, home to Africa's ''big five'' wild animals, as well as rare Cape hunting dogs (also known as wild dogs) and cheetahs. Each suite is decorated in a mix of French antiques and African art; an outdoor patio and shower supplement indoor facilities. Nightly all-inclusive rates are 18,500 South African rand for singles and 25,000 rand per couple, or about $2,600 and $3,500, at 7.10 rand to the dollar.

He is survived by daughters Helaine Cohen and Jodi Hartman, son-in-law Alan Cohen, grandchildren Jeremy, Brad, Melanie, Brandon and Jessica, and brother Alan Hartman. Services private. Contributions to Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

MARLIN--William M.,(85), died on August 2, 2010 after a brief illness. He served in the US Army Aircorp (483rd) 17th Squad during World War II. His aircraft was shot down over Germany during the Memmingen air battle. He was a POW interned at Stalag Luft IV, Luft I. Awarded the Purple Heart and Bronze star. He spent thirty years on Wall Street retiring as Vice Chairman of the board at Prudential-Bache Securities. Survived by wife Suzanne, children Scott, Dennis, and Kristy Ann. Brothers John, Lawrence, and James. Stepchildren Michael and Bryan. Six grandchildren.

MERRILL--Beverly. Born March 17, 1928 in Los Angeles, CA. Died in Menlo Park, CA on Saturday, July 24, 2010. Survived by her brother Hugh A. Merrill, his family and friends she cherishes. Prayers have been offered for the repose of her soul. Her ashes have been scattered at sea as she requested. Contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.

VAN OSS--Hendrik (Hank): July 26, 1917-July 21, 2010. Born in Mount Pleasant, PA, raised in Plainfield, NJ, graduated from Princeton University (1939). A career diplomat with Foreign Service posts in China, Indochina, Malaya, Austria, Uganda, Congo-Brazzaville, New Zealand, Mozambique. Active volunteer with Princeton University and Recording for Blind after retiring to Lawrenceville, NJ (1974); moved to Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA (1996), served on their Board. Noted at International Swimming Hall of Fame for achievements as freestyle swimmer. Married (1947) to Anne Burnett of Louisville, KY (d. 1998); survived by their children Alex van Oss (Washington, DC), Hendrik van Oss (Reston, VA), Elise van Oss (New York, NY). Contributions to Recording for Blind & Dyslexic, 69 Mapleton Road, Princeton, NJ 08540 or www.rfbd.org.

PAPE--Paul Frederick Jr. "Fred," died on August 2nd at his home, Misty Hilltop, in Moretown, VT. Born in New York City on June 12, 1932, he was raised in Scarsdale, NY, and was a graduate of Wesleyan University and Harvard Business School. He was an investment banker on Wall Street, working for Blythe and Co, Merrill Lynch and Drexel Burnham. During that time he spent weekends on his farm in Millbrook, NY, where he raised black angus cattle and thoroughbred race horses. Sailing was a passion and Antigua, BWI was always special to him. For the last twenty years he visited friends and his schooner, Turanna, in Antigua as often as possible. He was a lifelong skier, mountain climber, and gardener. He was also a real estate investor, recently focusing his talents on the restoration of the historic Chittenden Trust Company building in Burlington, VT. Fred will be missed by his many friends, by his wife, Stephanie Sedlmayr Pape, his four children; Paul Frederick Pape lll of Bridgeport, CT, Todd Alexander Pape of Evanston, IL, Lisa Pape Tarr of Sanford, FL and Alexander Hempstead Pape of Chang Mai, Thailand, his stepdaughter Thea da Empoli of Florence, Italy, and his grandchildren Elizabeth Pape Tarr, Aiden Alexander Pape and Chance Nelson Pape. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The Salvation Army.

The American fashion industry has been pushing hard over the last four years for copyright protection for its designs. An earlier bill in the House was deemed too broad; clothing makers argued that protection against knock-offs would only encourage frivolous lawsuits from people claiming they had the idea first. Today, after a year of negotiations, Senator Charles E. Schumer introduced a bill that seemed to satisfy the different sides of the fashion industry - and may provide some protection, too. The bill, the Innovative Design Protection and Piracy Prevention Act, has the support of the Council of Fashion Designers of America (CFDA), whose individual members represent the creative core of the industry, and the American Apparel & Footwear Association (AAFA), which represents more than 700 manufacturers and suppliers and by its estimate accounts for about 75 percent of the industry's business. The AAFA had argued that the House bill was too broad and would expose its members to lawsuits.

FOR as long as I can remember, I've loved walking along the beach and picking things up -- shells, washed-up bottles, children's toys. In 2009, I started making paintings of the objects I'd scavenged. Every day for a year, I'd come home, lay them on a table and experiment with different combinations, then render the piece using acrylic on paper. The objects depicted below were found on the North Fork of Long Island this year. I chose them both for the beauty of their forms and for what they say about our relationship with -- and effect upon -- the sea.

After Chevrolet's announcement last week that its 2011 Volt plug-in hybrid would sell for $41,000, it seemed that only President Obama could muster an unequivocal assessment of the car. ''Pretty smooth,'' he said, grinning, after a brief test drive on the Volt's factory floor in Hamtramck, Mich. Others criticized Chevrolet's parent company, General Motors, for pricing the car beyond the reach of many taxpayers who buoyed the corporation before its June 2009 bankruptcy filing. That invective has grown amid reports that some of the 600 dealers selected to participate in the Volt's initial rollout, which is limited to California, Texas, Michigan, New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and the nation's capital are charging above the manufacturer's suggested retail price for the Volt. Dealers, meanwhile, feel that runaway consumer demand for the limited-production car handily justifies a price premium.

CRANE--Sarah Molloy. The Junior League of Brooklyn celebrates the life of its distinguished past President, Sally Crane, while it mourns her passing August 4, 2010. She was the true spirit and embodiment of voluntarism and leaves the Junior League of Brooklyn a legacy that fostered change and inspiration. Sally's leadership, built on an astute knowledge of Brooklyn, an understanding of our members' diverse priorities coupled with the ability to blend them into a coherent whole, as well as her great gift for friendship, made the League an effective force for community good. While she made us laugh, she also led us to accomplish more than we anticipated. Her loyalty was her greatest and most defining strength. Sally Crane will long be remembered for her contributions to Brooklyn and the community she loved so much. Tracie Williams, President and the Membership

First Paris began cracking down on short-term vacation rentals. Now, travelers who use apartment-rental Web sites to find lodging in New York may have fewer places to choose from. A law banning short-term rentals in New York City was signed recently by Gov. David A. Paterson. The law forbids rentals for periods of fewer than 30 days within apartment buildings that have five or more units.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. -- Hyundai said on Wednesday that its entire product lineup in the United States would average at least 50 miles per gallon by 2025 -- somehow. That would be an improvement of about 60 percent from the ratings of the cars and trucks Hyundai sells today. Hyundai Motor America's chief executive, John Krafcik, acknowledged that the goal was a stretch, but said he was ''very confident'' the company could reach it.

OLYMPIA SCARRY, artist. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW My father's jean shirt from the '70s, a pair of secondhand jean shorts, Givenchy black leather bandage platforms, nine different gold rings on my fingers and two gold necklaces, which my grandparents had made for each other.

SITUATED in SoHo, a block up from Jil Sander, Saturdays is not a typical SoCal surf shop. Nor does it pretend to be. Part espresso bar (serving cold-brewed iced coffee, with a Zen-like patio out back to better enjoy it), part meticulously curated boutique (stocking high-end sunglasses and Levi's XX work wear, in addition to Japanese wet suits and rare boards), it has, since opening last August, become the unofficial clubhouse for the highly stylized urban-surf set. And its new in-house line of Breton-striped sweatshirts, color-blocked swim trunks and graphic T-shirts is its member uniform. ''Our take on surf culture is unique,'' said Josh Rosen, a founder, along with Colin Tunstall and Morgan Collett. ''It has a New York sensibility. It's more fashion-driven.'' Note that a hang-loose attitude is required while wearing the clothing. Actual surfing skills? Not so much.

JUDT--Tony. The Faculty of Arts and Science and the entire NYU community mourns the loss of Tony Judt, the Erich Maria Remarque Professor of European Studies, the founder and director of NYU's Remarque Institute, and a University Professor. Renowned and revered historian, cherished colleague and friend, and intellectual leader, Tony Judt exemplified the highest traditions of scholarship, contributed mightily to the public discourse about some of the most important ideas in our time, and was a good friend, colleague, and man. He will be deeply missed. Our hearts go out to his wife, his children, and all his loved ones, friends, and admirers; we share their grief. Jess Benhabib Dean, NYU Faculty of Arts and Science
Theater Steven McElroy

Six hundred: a six followed by two zeroes. Just a number, and not even a prime number or anything like that. But in baseball, it is a milestone - though for a while, as one of the Yankees' YES Network commentators said on Wednesday, it seemed to be a millstone around Alex Rodriguez's neck. And then he passed it. On to 700. Not so fast. A question came to mind, even as he was rounding the bases and heading toward home plate at Yankee Stadium: What's so special about 600?
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

MAGAZINE An article on Page 28 this weekend about the writer Daphne Merkin's lifelong experience with psychotherapy misstates the status of a medical condition of a therapist of hers who died suddenly. It was a recurrence of leukemia, not a remission. Corrections in other sections: Travel, Page 2; Sunday Styles, Page 13; Real Estate, Page 2; Magazine, Page 6; Book Review, Page 5.

The Practical Traveler column on July 25, about the resurgence of bus ridership in the United States, referred imprecisely to the service that one bus line offers between Washington and New York City. While the bus company Vamoose serves the Washington metropolitan area, with direct service to Midtown Manhattan from both Arlington, Va., and Bethesda, Md., it does not provide service from the capital itself.

WENGER--Robert. Our loving and very lovable dad Bob was a spark of life, a creator, motivator, inspirer and innovator. He is dearly missed. His life lessons will endure. 1939-2010. Love Forever, Scott Wenger Jodi Wenger

IN the late 1970s and early 1980s, the photographer Christopher Makos carried a Polaroid SX-70 everywhere -- to the beach in Montauk, nightclubs in New York, Hollywood film sets, Warhol's Factory -- spontaneously shooting everything that appeared before his camera. Among his several thousand snaps are images of friends, lovers, cool cars, gorgeous sunsets, all of which wonderfully capture the hazy decadence of the era. ''I had the best fun of anyone,'' said Mr. Makos, who has now compiled 180 of his instant mementos into a book, published by Photology, and has 24 more on view at the Clic Gallery in East Hampton. Both are a must-see, if only for the strikingly candid shots of Debbie Harry, John F. Kennedy Jr. and O. J. Simpson, holding a gun in the air. ''No one was afraid of being photographed back then because it was more likely a picture would end up in the back of someone's drawer than on Facebook,'' Calvin Klein wrote in the book's foreword. ''There was a sort of shared promise that things could remain a secret.''

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Clare Sully and John Rose misidentified the institution where Mr. Rose is to begin studying next month for a doctorate in theology. It is the Princeton Theological Seminary, not Princeton University.

ALONG with live music, cocktails and hors d'oeuvres, guests at the Second Saturday party at the Katonah Museum of Art this month will be offered the chance to pose for members of EYE, a group of artists who, true to their chosen acronym, for ''Erase your ego,'' produce collaborative pieces through live public performances. The event, titled ''EYE on You!,'' is the third of four summer programs held on the second Saturday of the month in the sculpture garden of the museum, each aiming to illuminate different aspects of the art-making process.

An article on July 18 about young doctors who are including abortion as part of their practices misidentified the university where a family-planning position was filled after a long search. It was SUNY Upstate Medical University at Syracuse, not Syracuse University.

FISHMAN--Harry, died peacefully August 2 at the age of 88. Loving and devoted husband to Gloria, adoring father to Michael and Laurie, proud grandfather to Sam, Anna and Joshua, loving brother to Patty and Lila and loving father-in- law to Pam. Born in Philadelphia, one of 12 children, Harry was a self-made man with a passion for business. A giant of a man to those whose lives he touched, he had a charismatic presence, a radiant smile, amazing blue eyes and most of all a huge heart with so much love to give. He loved golf, gin games, vodka, telling jokes and singing old war songs, especially "A Wing and a Prayer". Most of all, he loved his family.

BRIZIUS--Sharon Kay, 67, of Highland Park, Texas, passed away peacefully on August 5th surrounded by family. Devoted and beloved wife of Charles Albert Brizius, Jr. Loving mother of Charles Albert Brizius III (and his wife Kathleen Middleton Brizius) of Cambridge, Massachusetts, grandmother of Alexandra Middleton Brizius, Caroline Grace Brizius, Charles Albert Brizius IV and Thomas Dalton Brizius, and aunt of Richard Brent Williams and Shannon Leigh Gillmore. She is also survived by her mother Ruth Julia Sebastian and sister Donna Williams Kerby. She was preceded in death by her father Charles Lamont Sebastian. After growing up in Temple, Texas, Sharon graduated from Mary Hardin-Baylor University in Belton, Texas with a degree in Education. For over 20 years, Sharon was a dedicated and loving high school teacher who inspired her students and peers in both Lancaster and DeSoto, Texas. Her love and kindness for others will always be with us. Interment will be private. A public memorial service will be held at 10am on Tuesday, August 10th at the Cox Chapel of Highland Park United Methodist Church, 3300 Mockingbird Lane, Dallas, Texas. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the Methodist Health System Foundation, P.O. Box 655999, Dallas, Texas 75265, Attn: Brizius Family Fund.

6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: BOB HOPE Vaudevillian, U.S.O. Ambassador of Goodwill and all-out funny guy, Hope topped more than a few polls of the 20th century's greatest entertainers. This 14-film tribute begins with ''Bachelor in Paradise'' (1961), in which he plays an expert on love who causes trouble when assigned to write about sex in suburbia. In the middle of the retrospective, Bing Crosby and Dorothy Lamour join Hope in five of the seven ''Road'' films the three made: ''Road to Singapore'' (1940), at 1:15 p.m.; ''Road to Zanzibar'' (above, with Hope, left, and Crosby, from 1941), at 2:45; ''Road to Utopia'' (1946), at 4:30; ''Road to Bali'' (1952), at 6:15; and ''Road to Morocco'' (1942), at 8. The celebration ends with ''Call Me Bwana'' (1963), at 4:15 a.m. on Monday, in which Hope, as a famous anthropologist who is really a fraud, hunts and golfs his way across Africa as he searches for a lost moon capsule. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Governor Mitch Daniels of Indiana discusses the 2012 presidential election; Theodore B. Every summer, the crowds descend on Saratoga Springs to see the horses run. But they rarely stray far from the Victorian houses and pricey shops that line Broadway, the town's main drag. For those seeking arts and crafts with a more local flavor -- and without all of that horse-and-jockey iconography -- there's a pocket of quirky boutiques and art galleries sprouting up along Beekman Street, an out-of-the-way row of formerly rundown houses now with flowers out front and artisans plying their trade in studios in the back. ''We have a no-horse-art policy here,'' said Alan Letko, general manager of Artery (44 Oak Street; 832-754-5079), a gallery that opened last year. And that's the way artists along this strip want to keep it.

An article last Sunday about curb cuts and driveways in certain Manhattan neighborhoods and the city's rush to restrict them misidentified the previous owner of 123 West 15th Street -- where a permit was filed to add a curb cut and driveway -- and described the disposition of that property incorrectly. The owner was Terrapin Industries LLC -- not Pamela and Colin Rath, who were officers of Terrapin. Terrapin filed for bankruptcy in September 2008; the Raths did not personally default on loans. The article also misstated a point in a letter that Robert Boddington, a member of the block association who lives four doors away from 123 West 15th Street, wrote to the Department of Buildings, complaining about the logic that the owners used to gain approval for a driveway. The letter referred to the current owners, SoHo Builders, not to the Raths.

CORY--Leonora, nee Alton. Died April 28, 2010 in New York City, where she was born on February 19, 1910. Late of Hollywood, Florida, Leonora was the daughter of Minnie and Maurice Alton, sister of William Alton, former wife of Victor Nathan Cory and the beloved mother of Maurice Cory, who survives her. Always cheerful, always understanding, always caring, your loving son will miss you every day of his life.

SIMON--Stanley, of New York City, husband of the late Marcelle Kramer Simon, father of the late Frederick Simon, beloved grandfather of Laura Simon Cronin, Lewis Benjamin Simon and Carl David Simon, great grandfather of Patrick Ross Cronin and Joshua Adam Cronin, and devoted brother of Hope S. Miller, passed away at 93 after a brief illness on August 5, 2010. Stanley demonstrated brilliance early in his life, graduating Harvard College at the age of 18 in 1936. In 1945 along with Arde Bulova, Chairman of the Board of the Bulova Watch Company, Stanley Simon established The Joseph Bulova School of Watchmaking. This school opened its doors to help disabled veterans learn watch making skills. Entirely supported by the Bulova Foundation, the school was equipped with state-of-the-art accessibility features, including automatic doors and extra wide elevators long before The Americans With Disabilities Act. Graduates of the school were assured employment with over 1,500 positions pledged by jewelers across the country. An international business consultant, Stanley served as a member of the Board of Trustees of Vornado Realty Trust and later as Trustee Emeritus. He also served as member of the Board of Directors of Marcal Paper Mills, Gerber Scientific Inc., Wetterau Inc., Bulova Watch Co., and New England College. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76TH Street and Amsterdam Ave. Internment at United Jewish Cemetery, Brookfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made to: The Jerusalem Fellowships of Aish Ha Torah, 28 Park Ave, Airmont, NY, 10952.

THE NEWSNaomi Campbell testified at the war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, that she was given a pouch of rough diamonds as a gift after she met Mr. Taylor at a dinner with Nelson Mandela. BEHIND THE NEWS Prosecutors sought to tie Mr. Taylor to ''blood diamonds,'' mined and traded surreptitiously and used by him, they said, to finance a vicious rebel group in neighboring Sierra Leone. Ms. Campbell said the pouch, containing ''very small, dirty-looking stones,'' was delivered to her by two men. ''A gift for you,'' one told her. She said she did not keep the diamonds, and denied flirting with Mr. Taylor at the dinner 13 years ago in South Africa.

MILLER--Richard Field, September 24, 1931-July 30, 2010, died in his sleep at home in Paris, France. Born in Lincoln, Nebraska, he moved with his family to Kansas as a child. After graduating from the University of Nebraska, Richard Miller joined the U.S. Army as an interpreter/translator for army intelligence in Europe. It was then that he fell in love with France. Following his military service, he worked for UNESCO in Paris, then for the United Nations in New York. He was an elegant and highly regarded translator of books by writers such as Roland Barthes, and of many plays and works on the arts. Upon his retirement from the United Nations, he returned to Paris, where he lived among his numerous friends and his even more numerous books and recordings.

First they took away the complimentary travel kits. Then the meals. The inexorable transition of the experience of flying into something more akin to public transportation may be taking a major step forward. Continental Airlines has begun testing out self-boarding at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston, it said recently, becoming the first airline in the United States to do so. Passengers who have checked in can swipe their boarding passes at gates reminiscent of turnstiles and then proceed to their departing flight. ''One gate has been tested, and so far we've been pleased with what we've learned with the experience,'' said Christen David, spokeswoman for Continental Airlines, who said that the airline had been experimenting with self-boarding since June. ''When we speed up the boarding process, it facilitates flights departing the gate on time,'' she said.While Houston's airport may be the nation's laboratory for self-boarding, the process is hardly new. As reported by USA Today, last year there were 14 airlines using self-boarding gates. Gate infrastructure includes two self-boarding lanes with turnstile-like entry points along with a third lane with assisted check-in.

RUBIN--Esther, wife of the artist Reuven Rubin, passed away on July 19 in her home in Tel Aviv, Israel, in her 100th year. Born on the Lower East Side, Esther (nee Davis) arrived in Tel-Aviv from the Bronx in 1929 after winning first prize in a national oratorical contest of Young Judea. Esther and her husband, who predeceased her in 1974, led an exciting and rich life and were at the forefront of Tel Aviv's cultural scene. They dedicated to the public their home on Bialik Street, which became The Rubin Museum. She is survived by her son, David Rubin, her daughter Ariella Giniger, her grand children, and great-grand children. She will be missed by her family and her many friends around the world.

AXELROD--Leon, 92, passed away on August 6 at his home in Palm Beach, Florida. Active and vigorous and an inspiration to his family and friends throughout his life, Leon embodied the creative spirit professionally and personally, creating beauty from inert stone, as well as being the patriarch of a cohesive and loving family who endearingly dubbed him Poppy. Leon was a self-made man with a consistent positive outlook on life. He was born in Chicago and raised in New York. After studying engineering at the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, he changed directions to cope with the hardships imposed by the great depression and learned to manufacture leather goods, eventually becoming a founding partner of Walco. Ultimately his combined experiences and talents in technology and design found permanent expression as a sculptor resulting in a body of unique works that wedded fluidity and motion with substance and strength within hundreds of pounds of stone. His works have been exhibited in galleries throughout the United States with permanent installations at NYU Langone Medical Center in New York City, and Jackson Memorial and Mt. Sinai Hospitals in Miami. He was the beloved husband of Florence, who passed in 2001, and present dear husband of Carole, loving father to Felicia and Alice, adoring father in law to Robert Porges and Monroe Chaikin, proud grandfather to John Porges, Vicki Porges Eisner, Melissa Chaikin Kahn, and Eric Chaikin, and their respective spouses, Alex, Joe, and Greg, and cherished great-grandfather to Dylan and David Porges, Erin and Jesse Eisner, and Faye and Miles Kahn. Leon leaves a legacy of love and beauty that will last forever. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Dysautonomia Foundation Inc, 315 W 39th St, Suite 701, New York, NY 10018.

MILLER--Charles J.,age 87. Manhattan. Charles Miller died of complications from cancer surgery on July 22, 2010. Charles grew up on the Upper West Side during the 1920s and 30s. He graduated from the Horace Mann School and New York University. He was a World War II combat veteran who served with distinction in Europe. After the War, Charles returned to a top position at the family business, I. Miller & Sons, maker of "beautiful" women's shoes. He was involved in all aspects of the business, especially shoe design and U.S. sales. Following the sale of the company in 1959, Charles and his late brother, Robert Miller, acquired D.H. Blair & Co., a Wall Street securities firm, where Charles was the managing partner into the early 1970s. In the mid-1970s, Charles' career began a third phase. He returned to school and obtained advanced training at Columbia and the Postgraduate Center for Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy. He had practiced as a psychoanalyst continuously since the early 1980s. Charles is survived by his wife, Madelyne Bailey of Manhattan, his daughter and son-in-law, Patricia Miller-Katz and Gordon Katz of Newton, Massachusetts, his son, Burton Miller of Huntington, New York, daughter, Rebecca Miller of Newark, New York, stepson and stepdaughter-in-law, Mark Bailey and Rory Kennedy of Los Angeles, California, stepson, Paul Bailey of Belmont, Massachusetts, special godson, Scott Carlin of Los Angeles, California, grandchildren, Emily Tess Katz, Michelle Miller, Georgia Kennedy-Bailey, Bridget Kennedy-Bailey, and Zachery Kennedy-Bailey, many nieces and nephews and their children, and numerous cherished friends. Charles was preceded in death by his first wife, Thelma Levine Miller. Funeral services and burial were privately held on July 25, 2010. A celebration of Charles' life will be held on Sunday, August 8, 2010, at 2-5pm at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC.

STEICHEN--Joanna Taub. 1933-2010. Beautiful, elegant, spirited, and accomplished: Joanna's sudden death is a great loss to those of us who knew and loved her, both here and abroad. She was born in Greenpoint, Brooklyn and spent her school years at St. Agnes Episcopal School for Girls in Albany, New York. She was accepted to Smith College, where she discovered her love of the theatre, a passion that endured throughout her life. After graduating from Smith she went to work as a copy writer for Young & Rubicam in New York where a few years later she was introduced to world-renowned photographer Edward Steichen by his brother-in-law, poet Carl Sandburg. She married Steichen at the age of twenty-seven; he was eighty. After his death in 1973 she became the guardian and gatekeeper of Steichen's legacy and his work. She earned her master's degree in social work from Columbia University and her professional life was spent as a psychotherapist in private practice. Leisure time was devoted to travel, friends, opera, theatre and music. She was the author of several books and many articles. She was an advocate for the Montauk Library, the Montauk Playhouse, and the Hampton Day School. After she was diagnosed with Parkinson's she worked tirelessly with the Parkinson's Disease Foundation for improved care, better education, and special exercise regimes for patients battling this relentless and devastating illness. Joanna Steichen died unexpectedly of complications from Parkinson's disease at her summer home in Montauk, New York on July 24, 2010. She was 77. She leaves behind many devoted friends and numerous cousins, as well as two step-granddaughters and three step-great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name should be sent to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation at 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018, or online at: www.pdf.org

You've received an invitation to a wedding, a bar or bat mitzvah, a party for a significant anniversary - in short, an event that includes a formal ceremony. If you don't inhabit the frenzied social stratosphere that views such missives as annoying encroachments on your private time, you're excited and say, ''Yes! We would love to come to your celebration! Count us in!'' Ideally, you've replied before the R.S.V.P. deadline, not letting the stylish invitation languish on your desk or refrigerator until the hosts are compelled to call you (but that is an entirely different rant).
Art Nicolai Ouroussoff

ON the matter of bicycling under the influence, Michael Dolan has known both pleasure and pain. Mr. Dolan, a 33-year-old public relations strategist, reported some happy two-wheeled encounters while drunk involving the singers David Byrne and Bjork - whom he witnessed ''being pedaled around and screeching like a child'' - as well as a ''surreal'' collision with a rider on a Penny Farthing.

SENSIBLE shoes? Pshaw. Our footwear, like that of most fashion followers, has long been divided into two categories: sky-high and nosebleed. Anything more down-to-earth, so to speak, was -- no offense -- for wusses. Well, no more. For fall, quite a few designers made a case for the practical, working gal's pump, sending out incarnations with a rather saucy appeal. Take, for instance, those at Stella McCartney: pointy nude versions that seemed to disappear on the foot. Or the lipstick-red styles at Isabel Marant, below. Embellished with a flirty bow, they assumed a kind of Betty Rizzo rebel feel. For its finale, Dolce & Gabbana sent out a small army of leggy women dressed in smartly tailored jackets and simple black heels. Perhaps it was the fact that they weren't wearing pants, but they had some serious sex appeal. And were able to walk so quickly!
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

I have been a college admissions junkie since 1972. Since 1985, I have been director of college counseling at Horace Mann School in the Bronx. Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Saturday, July 24th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

6:01 p.m. | Updated After years of looking for a new downtown home, the Drawing Center has decided to stay put in its SoHo neighborhood. "The economy made us re-evaluate what scale of project we want," said Brett Littman, the Drawing Center's director, in an interview on Monday. "We're like a nice small jazz club - the scale of what we do is intimate, drawings tend to be pretty small. The board leadership and myself have come to the conclusion that maybe the Drawing Center shouldn't be 30,000 square feet. It's not in the cards for us." The move was first reported by Crain's NY Business.

Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce are the latest fashion designers to make the foray into filmmaking. The designing duo's first feature length film, "Quando, Quando, Quando" comes out in September. The film's preview shows a lace-clad, pump-wearing woman exploring the Trevi fountain in Rome as lecherous local men of all ages ogle her, gesticulating dramatically. The melodramatic soundtrack, R-rating and black and white cinematography could either add up to cinematic genius or fashion fluff. Tune in in September to find out which.

Within three months of being hospitalized for an acute stroke, nearly one-quarter of patients stop taking at least one of the drugs prescribed by their doctors to prevent further cardiovascular problems, according to a study published on Monday afternoon in the medical journal Archives of Neurology.

Victoria Aitken, the New York and London-based socialite songstress, has teamed up with the Scumfrog, a New York-based D.J., on her recent single "Sunshine," which is currently No. 7 on the British dance charts. The light-spirited house track was inspired by a Latin loffer she met on holiday in Spain. "He was very charming, funny and interesting," she says. "The only problem was that others thought so too, and they were girls who dressed up to the nines in diamonds and couture." According to Aitken, the song is also a hit with her father, Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former Tory cabinet minister. (Dad wasn't a big fan of her last video, "I'll Be Your Bitch," in which she danced suggestively while brandishing a whip and in preparation for which she took pole-dancing classes.) The jury is still out on whether Victoria is a card-carrying blue blood - Dutch newspaper reports earlier this year claimed that her grandmother, Lady Penelope Aitken, was the longtime girlfriend of Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands (husband of Queen Juliana) - but one thing is certain: The Scumfrog's kiss has turned this sassy singer into a bona fide dance-floor princess. Her latest song, "Sexy Skirt," just entered the charts at No. 34. To listen to "Sunshine" and "Sexy Skirt" go to myspace.com/victoriaaitken.

A landslide buried and flooded hundreds of homes over the weekend in a remote mountainous region of Gansu Province in China, Michael Wines reported. Officials said Sunday evening that 127 bodies had been recovered and that nearly 2,000 people were missing. Torrential rains began to fall on Saturday, a local official said. "Then there were landslides, and many people were trapped," he said. "Now sludge has become the biggest hindrance to our operations. It's too thick to walk or drive through."

Starting Aug. 15, visitors to Damascus, Syria, will have a new stylish hotel to check into after a long day of strolling the souks. Dar al Mamlouka, located in the historic Christian quarter of Old Damascus, is a 17th-century Ottoman-style palace that has been converted into a lush retreat by the owners of Beit al Mamlouka, the first Oriental-style boutique hotel in the area. Built around a tranquil central courtyard with wisterias, lemon trees and a fountain, it offers 10 luxuriously decorated rooms. Each room celebrates a particular figure from Arab history - from poets to warriors - in the ornate Damascene style, with plenty of inlaid mother-of-pearl woodwork, colorful mosaics and Persian rugs.

In this week's Critics' Pick, A. O. Scott looks at the 1997 Errol Morris documentary "Fast, Cheap and Out of Control." The film digs deep into uncommon jobs of four men: an animal trainer, a topiary gardener, a robot scientist and a mole-rat specialist. Mr. Scott praises Mr. Morris's unique filmmaking, saying that the director has "turned the talking head documentary into a vehicle for artistic expression and philosophical inquiry." Have you seen "Fast, Cheap and Out of Control" or any of Mr. Morris's films? Please share your thoughts.

With the publication this week of his first novel, "Bill Warrington's Last Chance," James P. King, 55, is living the dream of every hopeful writer who persists at his work despite rejection slips from publishing houses and agents. After Mr. King, who lives in Wilton, Conn., won the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award, in which more than 6,500 writers from 22 countries competed, his novel, a road story in which an elderly veteran who is developing Alzheimer's disease travels across the country with his rebellious 14-year-old granddaughter, was acquired by Viking. "This is what reading is about, and what a good book is supposed to do," the mystery writer Sue Grafton writes in a blurb for the novel, Mr. King's fourth attempt at fiction.
