The Hilton Theater on 42nd Street, originally the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, has a new name - Foxwoods Theater. Live Nation, the concert and theater presenting company that operates the theater, and the Foxwoods Resort Casino, the Connecticut gambling and show center owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, announced the multiyear agreement on Monday but did not disclose financial arrangements. The agreement for exclusive naming rights means that the Foxwoods name will appear not only on the theater's marquee and tickets but also in advertising to promote the troubled multimillion-dollar musical "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark," which is bound for the theater. The show, which has as its lead producer Michael Cohl, a former chairman of Live Nation, begins rehearsals next week. The theater, which has been empty since January 2009 waiting for the much-delayed "Spider-Man" musical, was last home to "The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein."

In this week's installment of The Appraisal, I explore the debate about whether visitors to open houses should be expected to take off their shoes. Brokers say that more sellers are making this request because they don't want their children to be exposed to outside dirt; they want to protect their soft-wood floors; and, in some cases, they want to exert a smidgen of control on people who are in their home when they're not. Some brokers agree with the sellers' requests because they think that it makes apartments more desirable, and that these apartments often can be cleaner.

Before there was HGTV, there was Gaetano Pesce, the legendary Italian architect and designer who once espoused the joys of D.I.Y. in a column for French Elle and actually made good on it. His 1972 Golgotha chair, part of the permanent collection at MoMA, was the first of his many forays into the world of mass customization: its Dacron-filled seat assumed different shapes depending on who sat on it. Now, another clever bit of personalization: Pesce's new shoe for the Brazilian company Melissa - an ankle bootie composed of interconnected PVC circles, whose form can change at the whim of its owner with a swift slice of the scissors. Cut once, and the boot becomes a bootie; cut again, and it's a ballet flat, a peep toe, a sandal or even a flip-flop. ''This is the future of mass production,'' Pesce says. ''With the technology we have today, we can give people something that is half done and ask them to finish it.'' Go to melissashoes.com.

You are on the Grand Canyon Skywalk, shown above, standing on the glass-bottomed structure that projects out 70 feet over the edge. You look down through the glass below your feet at the sheer fall into the Colorado River 4,000 feet below. Click here, to get a sense of the experience. You know you are safe, but suddenly you are stricken with fear: the perfectly normal feeling of mild acrophobia. It almost overcomes you -- that tingling in your feet, that vague dread in the pit of your stomach, that imp in your mind insistently asking "What if I fell?" You brush away the feeling, trusting your rationality, trusting in the safety of physics and engineering. Today we'll look at over-the-precipice engineering, and then I'm going to do my best to give you some acrophobia again.

A special treat will soon await World War II history buffs outside the front entrance to the Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms in London. In commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the Battle of Britain, an exact, full-size replica of a Spitfire fighter plane will be on display from Aug. 16 to 31, decked out in wartime camouflage and free for all to admire. Credited with holding back the Nazi invasion and changing the course of the war, the plane has come to symbolize the bravery of the Royal Air Force.

Google Wave was one of Google's most prominent new services. Now it is one of its most prominent flops. On Wednesday, Google said that it would stop developing Wave as a standalone product and that the Web site could be shuttered by the end of the year. The technology will remain available if people want to develop new tools with it.

MERRILL--Beverly. Born March 17, 1928 in Los Angeles, CA. Died in Menlo Park, CA on Saturday, July 24, 2010. Survived by her brother Hugh A. Merrill, his family and friends she cherishes. Prayers have been offered for the repose of her soul. Her ashes have been scattered at sea as she requested. Contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.

Most New York City mayors are typically booed at ballgames, but fortunately only one, William J. Gaynor, was wounded in an attempted assassination. It happened a century ago on Monday. The bullet, fired by a disgruntled former municipal employee, remained lodged in Gaynor's neck. Three years later, suffering from the lingering effects of the wound, he succumbed to a heart attack - the only mayor of modern New York to die in office.

PALENVILLE, N.Y. - I am standing near the fifth green at the Rip Van Winkle Country Club, a public nine-hole golf course at the foot of New York's Catskill Mountains. A few minutes ago, a dog lazily pursued a deer across the fairway. They passed two ducks that did not bother to look up. The course was designed in 1919 by Donald Ross, who laid out the holes beneath a striking mountain ridgeline that remains the setting's dominating feature nearly a century later. Some things, though, have changed in 91 years. Greens fees have increased to $14 on weekdays and $17 on weekends.

She loved two countries well the United States and Ireland and always made us proud. Her death on August 5, 2010 deprives us of her wise counsel, good cheer, and valued friendship. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her family, especially her devoted nephew and our Vice President, Jim Cuggy. James A. Lombard, President

Family will be receiving at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY on Saturday, August 14 from 2-4pm. Funeral private.

AXELROD--Leon, 92, passed away on August 6 at his home in Palm Beach, Florida. Active and vigorous and an inspiration to his family and friends throughout his life, Leon embodied the creative spirit professionally and personally, creating beauty from inert stone, as well as being the patriarch of a cohesive and loving family who endearingly dubbed him Poppy. Leon was a self-made man with a consistent positive outlook on life. He was born in Chicago and raised in New York. After studying engineering at the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, he changed directions to cope with the hardships imposed by the great depression and learned to manufacture leather goods, eventually becoming a founding partner of Walco. Ultimately his combined experiences and talents in technology and design found permanent expression as a sculptor resulting in a body of unique works that wedded fluidity and motion with substance and strength within hundreds of pounds of stone. His works have been exhibited in galleries throughout the United States with permanent installations at NYU Langone Medical Center in New York City, and Jackson Memorial and Mt. Sinai Hospitals in Miami. He was the beloved husband of Florence, who passed in 2001, and present dear husband of Carole, loving father to Felicia and Alice, adoring father in law to Robert Porges and Monroe Chaikin, proud grandfather to John Porges, Vicki Porges Eisner, Melissa Chaikin Kahn, and Eric Chaikin, and their respective spouses, Alex, Joe, and Greg, and cherished great-grandfather to Dylan and David Porges, Erin and Jesse Eisner, and Faye and Miles Kahn. Leon leaves a legacy of love and beauty that will last forever. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Dysautonomia Foundation Inc, 315 W 39th St, Suite 701, New York, NY 10018.

Stuart Appleby had just birdied the last three holes. It was the final round of the Greenbrier Classic, and he had birdied nine holes and eagled another to shoot a historic 59. He had bogeyed only one of 72 holes during the tournament. He was on fire, playing almost as precisely -- 22-under par for the four days -- as any golfer could reasonably expect. So it's safe to say Appleby's aim was pretty good.

W, a magazine best known for ethereal photo spreads with dazed-looking models sporting Versace, Chanel, Prada and Ferragamo, is assuming a new look and editorial tone. It is becoming a place that its new editor, Stefano Tonchi, hopes readers will go to not only for high-end fashion but for profiles on cultural figures, travel essays and appraisals of art. The September W contains all of the above, and a healthy dose of pictorial spreads. Some of the elements are provocative: a bare-breasted model donning jewels; blurbs from actresses describing their first on-camera sex scenes (''I will make a sex scene as uncomfortable as I can just to break the ice,'' one says).

OLTARSH--Kenneth S. Impeccable wordsmith, beacon of legal correctness, he shepherded us through 60 years of business and family affairs. We will never forget him sitting in a sea of disputing lawyers and translators, quietly writing an agreement in longhand on a yellow legal pad, one ultimately accepted by all. Trusted friend as well as legal advisor, he and Naomi were a valued presence at our family functions. Ken's incomparable dance steps and his fondness of W.C. Fields' humor belied his serious, formal demeanor. He was a trusted advisor and everyone among us has heard or uttered the phrase: "Call Oltarsh." We will miss him. The Jadow Family

By the end of 2011, there could be more smartphones in the United States than the less advanced feature phones, according to a report released Monday by the Nielsen Company, a market trends monitor. The report also notes that the Google Android platform continues to show rapid growth and over the past six months has edged past the Apple iPhone platform with new subscribers.

HBO has announced plans to show ''The Promise: The Making of 'Darkness on the Edge of Town,' '' a documentary that follows the making of Bruce Springsteen's fourth album, Variety reported. Directed by Thom Zimney, who has made several films about Mr. Springsteen and his band, including the Emmy-nominated ''Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band: Live in New York City,'' the film chronicles Mr. Springsteen's work on ''Darkness'' from 1975, after the release of his pivotal album ''Born to Run,'' until 1978, a time when he was prohibited from recording any music because of a pending lawsuit with Mike Appel, his former manager. The film mixes footage from rehearsals during that time with recent commentary from Mr. Springsteen and the band. (Above, Mr. Springsteen, right, with Southside Johnny.) ''The fact that this footage has been sitting in a vault, and no one has seen it for more than 30 years is just extraordinary,'' Richard L. Plepler, a co-president of HBO, said at a Television Critics Association meeting on Saturday. Mr. Plepler and Michael Lombardo, programming president for HBO, said the documentary would be shown on the network in October, after a premiere on Sept. 14, as the opening film of the Toronto Film Festival.

Mention Tasmania, the island 150 miles south of the Australian mainland, and most people, if they think of anything at all, think of a carnivorous marsupial, the Tasmanian Devil. But Tasmania is leading Australia's ambitious broadband plan to wire more than 90 percent of the nation's homes with high-speed fiber optics. Today, South Korea and Japan are the leaders in putting fiber networks in homes, with about 40 percent penetration.

Somewhat hidden in a New Jersey suburb is a treasure trove of golf history. The United States Golf Association Museum in Far Hills, N.J., is more than a collection of golf memorabilia, though it is an impressive gathering of artifacts, clubs, garments, trophies, works of golf art and hundreds of other meaningful and memorable objects associated with the game. The museum, however, does more than show you important pieces of golf history; it puts them together to tell you the story of golf in America. There are Francis Ouimet's clubs from the 1913 United States Open, a Gene Sarazen 1932 sand wedge, tributes to Babe Zaharias, Mickey Wright, Patty Berg and entire rooms dedicated to Bobby Jones, Arnold Palmer and Ben Hogan. There are film clips and scorecards and a unique viewing gallery where you can watch video footage as seen on seven vintage 1960s television sets - except you never have to adjust the rabbit ears to improve the reception.

(TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: WARREN BEATTY Turner Classic Movies salutes Mr. Beatty, a film-industry jack of all trades -- actor, director, writer and producer -- as well as a onetime candidate for the sexiest man alive. The all-day tribute begins with ''The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone'' (1961), starring Vivien Leigh as an aging actress who flees to Italy after receiving poor reviews, and a 23-year-old Mr. Beatty as her gentleman caller. In ''Bonnie and Clyde'' (1967), at 6 p.m., Mr. Beatty is the Depression-era outlaw Clyde Barrow and Faye Dunaway is his sidekick, Bonnie Parker. In ''Splendor in the Grass'' (1961), at 8, Mr. Beatty and Natalie Wood are high school sweethearts in 1920s Kansas who can't resist their sexual urges in this drama written by William Inge, directed by Elia Kazan and scored by David Amram. And in ''Reds'' (1981), at 10:30, Mr. Beatty plays John Reed, the American journalist who worked for the Soviet propaganda ministry during the Russian Revolution. The film received 12 Academy Award nominations and earned Mr. Beatty an Oscar for best director.

A huge and previously unknown trove of archival material from Philip Johnson's architectural practice -- including his hand-drawn sketches for towers that helped define postmodern architecture -- is to be put up for sale by one of Johnson's former partners, who has had them in storage for years. The cache contains more than 25,000 design sketches, working drawings, renderings and photographs from the second half of Johnson's architectural career, covering more than 120 projects from 1968 to 1992. While there are collections of his early work at the Museum of Modern Art, the Getty Museum and the Avery Architectural & Fine Arts Library at Columbia University, documentation from this later period, in which he became known for his tall buildings, is much rarer. Included in the archive is material on the AT&T Building in Manhattan (now Sony's American headquarters); the Crystal Cathedral in Garden Grove, Calif.; PPG Place in Pittsburgh; Pennzoil Place in Houston; and smaller-scale structures that Johnson built around his celebrated Glass House of 1949 on his property in New Canaan, Conn., now owned by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

An article on Friday about the finances of Denver's public school system reported incorrectly an earlier connection between Senator Michael F. Bennet, a former superintendent of the school system, and Thomas Boasberg, the current superintendent. Both once worked in finance in the private sector -- Mr. Bennet for the Anschutz Investment Company and Mr. Boasberg in acquisitions at Level 3 Communications -- but they did not work together. The article also failed to note that Jeannie Kaplan, a former member of the school board who was quoted as criticizing a financial transaction reached during Mr. Bennet's tenure as school superintendent, is a fund-raiser and active supporter of Mr. Bennet's opponent in Colorado's Democratic primary race for the Senate.

YouGov, which measures public awareness for products and properties, assigns a positive or negative score based on perceptions people have formed through advertising, news and word-of-mouth. Facebook's continued growth is reflected in its positive score, and Dollar General, the discount retailer, has been helped by an increase in sales and earnings this year, as well as its community and literacy efforts. BP, after news of changing its chief executive and progress on containment and cleanup of the gulf spill, above, has earned a less negative score from June to July. SHELLY FREIERMAN

GREENBERG--Helen Constance, died August 3rd peacefully at home in Laguna Niguel, CA. A long time resident of New York City, Helen was predeceased by her husband Bernard Greenberg. She is survived by her five sons Jay, Steven, Lawrence, Michael and Daniel, her daughters-in-law Iris, Patti, Pat and Malti, her ten grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, brother Nathaniel and sister-in-law Sally Kurnick and husband Marvin Jekowsky. Her unwavering elegance, ageless outlook and loving empathy will be deeply missed. Memorial gathering for family and friends will be announced.

Berkeley, Calif. THE news of the day often includes an item about some development in artificial intelligence: a machine that smiles, a program that can predict human tastes in mates or music, a robot that teaches foreign languages to children. This constant stream of stories suggests that machines are becoming smart and autonomous, a new form of life, and that we should think of them as fellow creatures instead of as tools. But such conclusions aren't just changing how we think about computers -- they are reshaping the basic assumptions of our lives in misguided and ultimately damaging ways.

PROPP--Ephraim. We mourn the loss of our dear friend, Ephraim Propp. He was a man of great strength and courage. He fought a valiant battle with Parkinson's Disease. Our hearts go out to his adoring wife, Gail, his beloved children, Anna Propp, Eric (Yonina), and David (Sophia) Gomberg and his grandchildren. Rest in peace dear Effie. Roni, Sam, Jennifer and Michael Jacobson

AXELROD--Leon. The Dysautonomia Foundation deeply mourns the passing of Leon Axelrod. A kind and gentle man, Leon was a strong supporter of the Foundation's work to advance medical care for familial dysautonomia (FD), and the father of the NYU Dysautonomia Center's Director, Felicia Axelrod, MD. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Carole, his daughters Felicia and Alice, his sons-in-law Robert Porges and Monroe Chaikin, and his grandchildren John Porges, Vicki Porges Eisner, Melissa Chaikin Kahn, and Eric Chaikin. He will be truly missed.

Creon was a confidant and employee of the Aristotle S. Onassis empire from 1947 through 1991. Friends may call at Frank E. This all started the day Luigi gave me a haircut. I was starting to look like a mad professor: specifically like Doc in "Back to the Future." So Luigi took his scissors out and tried to fix me up. Except - and this is the point that occurred to me as I inspected the hair in the bathroom mirror the next morning - he didn't really take quite enough off. He had enhanced the style, true, but there was a big floppy fringe that was starting to annoy me. And it was hot out. So I opened up the clipper attachment on the razor and hacked away at it for a while. When I finally emerged there was a general consensus that I looked like a particularly disreputable scarecrow. In the end I went to another barbershop (I didn't dare show Luigi my handiwork) and had it all sheared off. Now I look like a cross between Britney Spears and Michel Foucault.

The fashion tribes descending on Paris for couture week in July might have done well to leave behind the elegant boutiques of the rue Boissy d'Anglas and the chic precincts of the Hotel Crillon and head instead toward La Bastille, where on a quay fringed with plumbing supply and carpet shops and overlooking the Canal Saint Martin, an extraordinary collection of accessories has taken up residence. There, the Maison Rouge, a nonprofit kunsthalle devoted to contemporary art, is showing more than 300 hats and headdresses from all over the globe, all of which belong to the institution's founder, Antoine de Galbert.De Galbert, a former gallery owner better known as a collector of both outsider and contemporary art, acquired the first hat in his collection about 15 years ago - a small headdress, intended as a sculptural ornament, and adorned with cassowary feathers from Papua New Guinea. He was hooked. His collection now numbers more than 400 pieces. It includes brilliantly beplumed Amazonian bonnets; sumptuously beaded, cone-shaped royal crowns worn by Yoruba chieftains, adorned with birds (symbols, according to the show's catalog, of "the mystical power of women"); a Burmese hunter's horned headdress, designed to inspire terror, with a monkey's skull posed atop a bit of bear fur; as well as more modest garments, like a simple cap from India, made of felted yak hair, to protect against the rain. There's a diadem once worn by an Uzbek bride on her wedding day, and a headband covered in cowry shells that announced the birth of a first child to a woman in Indonesia.

The death toll from landslides early Sunday morning in western China has climbed to 702, with 1,042 people still missing and 42 seriously injured, the state news agency, Xinhua, reported Tuesday afternoon. Vice Premier Hui Liangyu ordered rescuers to step up efforts to find people trapped under the rubble in Zhouqu, in Gansu Province, and noted that these people had the best chance of survival if found within 72 hours of the disaster. The landslide obliterated a large section of the town and then poured into a river, damming the waterway and causing it to flood and submerge part of the devastated community. Soldiers have been using explosives to clear the blockage and drain the town.

The negative view of Central American cuisine is that it's like Mexican food without the spice. While there is some truth to that, I love Central American originals like pupusas from El Salvador (corn tortillas stuffed with pork, cheese, beans or a combination cooked inside, topped with pickled cabbage and tomato sauce), and baleadas from Honduras (wheat tortillas topped with beans, cream and cheese, then folded in half). So I maintained my optimism that there'd be a gem to find in Nicaragua as well.

Rick Destito knew exactly what he was getting into when he bought a rundown, three-story Victorian house in one of the poorest neighborhoods of Syracuse. Built in the 1890s but left abandoned for years, the place was in serious disrepair: graffiti and mold stained the exterior, the windows were gone and the roof needed to be replaced. But under an innovative local housing program, he paid only a dollar for the place - plus another $60,000, and his own skilled labor, to make it suitable for his family, including a one-year old girl and a baby on the way.

When the Munich gallery owner Joëlle Chariau began collecting fashion illustrations, "it was a field that no one had been interested in," she says. "I could get the best artists without competition." Thirty years later, the Design Museum in London will display her collection for the first time this November. "Drawing Fashion," co-curated by the fashion historian Colin McDowell, brings together clothing by Poiret, Lanvin, Chanel, Alexander McQueen and others as drawn by Erté, Lepape, René Gruau, Antonio (left) and Mats Gustafson. In the digital age, Chariau says, drawing has new impact: "Today there are so many images that it's almost impossible to find one that strikes the imagination. When people look at drawings, they say: 'Oh, my God! It's fantastic!' " The accompanying book will be published by Prestel.

If you happened by Jeffrey New York earlier this year, it was impossible not to have noticed the dramatic paper wigs that crowned the mannequins wearing Yves Saint Laurent and the like. The designers, Nikki Salk and Amy Flurry, of Paper Cut Project in Atlanta, say they were inspired by Gidget, the Supremes and Billie Holiday. The partners have also created a collection of textured paper masks that look a bit like what Oscar Wilde would have worn to a masquerade ball. Which is not to say they have no modern applications: ''A bride in Japan wanted us to create a mask in a vintage Paris-meets-manga theme!'' Flurry says. And the bride isn't alone: ''We're currently working on an exclusive collection for Hermès and are very interested in designing a more elaborate series of masks and headwear for the runway.'' Are you listening, John Galliano?

My post last week asked, "Did Low Interest Rates Cause the Great Housing Convulsion?" as I discussed my research with Joseph Gyourko and Joshua Gottlieb. It drew a hefty dose of comments from readers, along the lines of, "You idiot, don't you know it was ridiculous lending with no down payments and no documentation?" Yet it is as hard to make a strong case that high approval rates and high loan-to-value ratios caused the boom as it is easy to opine that they obviously did.

HOCKSTEIN--Joseph, 90, on July 28. A WWII veteran, he resided in Riverdale and later Scottsdale. Friends old and new will miss Joe's unflagging charm and humor. MILSTEIN--Paul. The Board of Overseers of Columbia Business School expresses deep sorrow at the passing of Paul Milstein, a friend and supporter of the School. Columbia Business School extends its profound sympathy to the Milstein family. Glenn Hubbard, Dean, Columbia Business School

Bar-Ilan University (BIU) and the American Friends of Bar-Ilan University (AFBIU) note with profound sadness the passing of Ephraim Propp, a devoted Trustee of the AFBIU National Board and its long-time Treasurer. His generous support of BIU and the Propp family's sponsorship of a floor in the Gonda Nanotechnology Triplex will strengthen the University for generations to come. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Gail, a highly esteemed Trustee of AFBIU; his children Anna, Eric and David; and the entire family. Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President, BIU Dr. Mordecai D. BUSINESS DAY A chart on Wednesday with an article about automobile sales in July omitted one carmaker from a list of top sellers. A front-page article on June 7 about an investigation into possible collusion between the Taliban and Afghan security companies hired by the American military reported that Qayum Karzai, the brother of the Afghan president, was the principal shareholder of one of the companies, Watan Risk Management. In the article, Watan's chief executive denied that the company was connected to anyone in the president's immediate family. Qayum Karzai was not contacted for comment before publication, as called for by Times standards. He has since told The Times that he has no financial interest in Watan.

MILSTEIN--Paul, 88, one of the leading real estate developers of New York, died peacefully in his home surrounded by his wife and children. Born in 1922, he grew up in the Bronx, attended DeWitt Clinton High School and studied architecture at New York University. After military service during World War II, he joined the family business, Circle Flooring Company. Under his leadership, Circle Flooring became the dominant installer of floors, ceilings, and drywall both in New York and nationally. In the 1950s he began a lifelong career of significant real estate development projects centered in his beloved New York City. In the 1970s, he entered the coal, natural gas and oil business, while, at the same time, purchasing United Brands, the parent company of Chiquita Bananas. In the 1980s, he purchased Emigrant Savings Bank. Paul Milstein was as prolific in building important New York institutions as he was in developing real estate projects. Among the key beneficiaries of his vast philanthropy are: New York Presbyterian Medical Center, Columbia University, Cornell University, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, American Museum of Natural History, New York Public Library, UJA-Federation, and the Jewish Theological Seminary. A visionary, entrepreneur, philanthropist and devoted family man, Paul Milstein is survived by his adored wife of 63 years, Irma; children, Roslyn and Jerome Meyer, Howard and Abby Milstein, Barbara and David Zalaznick, and Edward and Robin Milstein; and sister, Gloria and Lou Flanzer; grandchildren Rebecca Meyer and Jeff Resnik, Michael Meyer, Jamie Meyer, Michael Morris Milstein, Jeffrey, Samantha and Amy Zalaznick, Andrew, Lexi, Benjamin, and Elizabeth Milstein, and great-granddaughter Lucy Meyer-Resnik. The funeral is private, and will take place on Tuesday, August 10, followed by a memorial service to be announced at a later date. Shiva will be observed at the family home in Manhattan on Wednesday and Thursday from 2-4:00pm and 5:30-8:30pm. In lieu of flowers, kindly honor Paul's memory, by sending donations to: American Museum of Natural History or the New York Presbyterian Medical Center. The Family of Paul Milstein

HONG KONG -- China's trade surplus surged last month to its highest level in a year and a half, while real estate prices leveled off, according to government data released Tuesday that pointed to possible trade frictions with the United States and slightly slower economic growth in China. Stock markets across Asia weakened in response to the latest economic statistics, which included an unexpected slump in China's imports that seemed to suggest a softening of demand.

FORROW--Brian Derek, of Greenwich, passed away peacefully on August 4, 2010. Brian graduated from The Stony Brook School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. He joined the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon where he was an associate and then partner (1950-1968). During this time, he spent two years as a First Lieutenant (JAG) in the U.S. Air Force (1951-1953). He was joined in Idaho by his new wife, Eleanor. Upon returning to New York, Brian enjoyed 14 years of successful practice with Cahill Gordon. Between 1968 and 1992 he served as Senior Vice President, General Counsel, and a member of the Board of Directors of Allied Signal and predecessor companies. He was a member of the New York and Connecticut Bars and the Bars of various Federal Courts, including the Supreme Court of the United States. He was author of articles in The Business Lawyer, the Harvard Law Review, Law and Contemporary Problems, and the American Bar Association Journal. He was a founding member of St. Barnabas Church in Greenwich and served as its first Senior Warden. Nicknamed "Anchor" by his grandchildren, he will be remembered by family and friends for his steady nature and love of sailing; his humanity, integrity, and great faith; the way he treated everyone he met with kindness, respect, and fairness; his passion for the practice of law; and as a cheerful individual who never failed to be grateful for the many blessings in his life. He is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Eleanor Reid Forrow; his devoted children (Lisa and her partner John, Lachlan and his wife Susan, Katie, and Derek); his cherished grandchildren (Melissa, Aden, Avery, and Lauren); and his dog, Skipper. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Episcopal Church Malaria Bed Net Fund at Episcopal Relief & Development, 815 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10017 (www.netsforlifeafrica.org).

GRUSZKA--Robert J.,died on July 27, 2010 in New York City at the age of 67. Born in Hammond, Indiana on August 26, 1942 to Harry and Dorothy (Davis) Gruszka. Graduated from DePauw University in Indiana in 1964, followed by graduate studies at Birmingham University (UK) where he met his wife Ilham Albasri, a fellow student, whom he married in 1968. Continued with graduate studies at Columbia University in New York City and received a Master of International Affairs and a Master a Philosophy. Devoted his career of over 30 years in the United Nations in New York City, where in 1972, he joined the office dealing with ocean affairs, to promoting the uses of the seas and oceans for the benefit of the world's nations, particularly developing nations. He participated in various intergovernmental bodies and programs, the most notable of which is the interdisciplinary Group of Experts on the Scientific Aspects of Marine Pollution (GESAMP). Bob, as he was known to his friends and family was truly a global man, befriending colleagues from many nations who were touched by his goodness and gentle nature. He enjoyed the opera and tennis, but most of all he devoted time to his family, caring for them with selflessness and generosity. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, nieces and nephews. His wife extends her gratitude to the friends and former UN colleagues for providing comfort and support. Bob will be remembered forever.

LOS ANGELES -- Of all the clichés about this town that are provably untrue -- no one reads, or has the lips that God gave them -- it is undeniable that Los Angeles has often been a poor guardian of its physical history. Scores of historical buildings have been razed or weirdly repurposed over the last century, and large areas of this young city have been plowed with nary a trace left to examine. An interesting exception is the Ebell Club, a women's social club that still operates in one of its original buildings, erected in 1927 in the Hancock Park neighborhood. Established in 1897 as a substitute for the university education that women were largely denied, the club had 2,500 members in its heyday in the 1920s, and activities included Shakespeare, gardening and art appreciation.

Arnold Scaasi’s mostly over-the-top creations have adorned everyone from Mamie Eisenhower to Louise Nevelson, from glittering trophy wives flush with 1980s money to an order of nuns in Pennsylvania. ‘‘Scaasi: American Couturier,’’ a survey opening Sept. 25 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, showcases his designs for four of his most loyal clients: the actresses Arlene Francis and Barbra Streisand, and the socialites Joetta Norban and Gayfryd Steinberg. Sitting beneath a late Picasso in his Manhattan living room, with a view of ships sailing leisurely along the East River in the background, the couturier (born Arnold Isaacs in 1930) talked to Leslie Camhi about his half century of making a very select group of women feel special.

For years, researchers have known that exercise can affect certain moods. Running, bike riding and other exercise programs have repeatedly been found to combat clinical depression. Similarly, a study from Germany published in April found that light-duty activity like walking or gardening made participants “happy,” in the estimation of the scientists. Even laboratory rats and mice respond emotionally to exercise; although their precise “moods” are hard to parse, their behavior indicates that exercise makes them more relaxed and confident.

.NASA has released video showing the pall of pollution spreading from the wildfires in and around Russia. (Here's a satellite-generated map of the fires.) The animation was created using data from the Atmospheric Infrared Sounder instrument on NASA's Aqua satellite. The colors reflect levels of carbon monoxide at an altitude of about 18,000 feet, with the gas providing an indirect indicator of other emissions.

On this week's New York Times Tech Talk podcast,  Brian Stelter, a Times media reporter, drops by to chat about Internet access regulation with J.D. Biersdorfer and Bettina Edelstein. The so-called net neutrality plan of Google and Verizon would exempt wireless and some other online services from rules for maintaining open access to the Internet, and Mr. Stelter says that while the two companies  appear to be staking out their ground now, other wireless carriers and media companies are watching and waiting as the Federal Communications Commission looks at ways of regulating broadband.

She may not be a household name, but the filmmaker Alia Raza is a name to watch and to drop. Raza, 32, is the creative force behind obscure film and video projects with fittingly abstruse titles like "The Fragile White Blossoms Emit a Hypnotic Cascade of Tropical Perfume Whose Sweet Heady Odor Leaves Its Victim Intoxicated." Her dazzling cast of subjects is equally enigmatic: the teen blogger Tavi Gevinson, whom Raza recently filmed constructing a dress out of black silk and bubble gum; the artist Terence Koh, whom she had perform surgery on a white cake; and the celebutante-around-town Julia Restoin Roitfeld, who appears in Raza's coming video project for Six Scents, a feminist take on the mythological Medusa figure. "Their notoriety is an element in the work," Raza says of the socially prominent actors she picks. "Someone said what I do is like 'Francesco Vezzoli going downtown,' which is funny because I live on the Upper East Side."

The United Nations is appealing for $459 million to provide immediate help to millions of flood victims in Pakistan, The Associated Press reported. What the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs calls ''the worst monsoon-related floods in living memory'' have affected more than 14 million people, and at least 6 million require immediate humanitarian assistance, including food, clean water, shelter and medical care. It said more than 1,200 people have died and at least 288,000 homes have been damaged or destroyed in the flooding.

ARLINGTON, Tex. - There is a metric, devised by the statistician Bill James, that evaluates a pitcher's performance in a particular game. It is called Game Score, naturally - click here to see how it is calculated - and it was highlighted Sunday after Brandon Morrow struck out 17 batters while coming one out short of a no-hitter. Morrow's Game Score of 100, as ESPN's Buster Olney wrote in his blog, is the highest since Randy Johnson recorded a 100 during his 2004 perfect game.

With apologies to Gran Tursimo, Forza Motorsport, Project Gotham and any number of hyperrealistic, console-based racing simulators and video games, arguably none channels the visceral thrill of hurtling around a course like the futuristic Wipeout series. Now, a German art collective has rendered that thrill tactile, using defiantly analog components: cardboard, glue and vintage-video-arcade kitsch.

My August 1 essay, "Philosophy and Faith," was primarily addressed to religious believers. It argued that faith should go hand-in-hand with rational reflection, even though such reflection might well require serious questioning of their faith. I very much appreciated the many and diverse comments and the honesty and passion with which so many expressed their views. Interestingly, many of the most passionate responses came from non-believers who objected to my claim that popular atheistic arguments (like popular theistic arguments) do not establish their conclusions. There was particular dismay over my passing comment that the atheistic arguments of Richard Dawkins are "demonstrably faulty." This follow-up provides support for my negative assessment. I will focus on Dawkins' arguments in his 2006 book, "The God Delusion."

One weekend morning last spring I felt like having pancakes. But my wife, Jackie, was away in England visiting her father and getting his vegetable garden started, and the idea of making and eating pancakes in solitude didn't really fly. I can almost hear some feel-gooder cooing, "Oh, but you're worth it." Horsefeathers. Where's the fun in a one-man pancake breakfast?

In a case study we've just published, Jessica Bruder writes about FreshDirect, the Internet grocer, and its struggle to overcome an employment crisis at a time when it was hemorrhaging money and customers. The article focuses on a decision made by Richard S. Braddock, FreshDirect's chief executive, in early 2008. Mr. Braddock decided that his company's customer service was so poor that it had to stop soliciting new customers -- its biggest source of revenue -- until it figured out how to serve them. The risk, of course, was that the company would run out of money before it solved its problems.
I suggest you like this article.

A  pilot program that would allow foreign visitors to the United States to apply for visas via video conference gained traction late last month, when it won approval from the Senate Appropriations Committee.

In June, there were fewer than five unemployed workers for each job opening, according to new Labor Department data. That is a less discouraging ratio than earlier this year, but the improvement may mainly be a result of workers who have given up looking for a job.

Kite design, anyone? One and all were invited to design and donate an original, handmade kite for FlyNY, the second annual New York City international kite design competition. The designs, which were due on Tuesday, will be presented on Aug. 21 at a public kite flying showcase on Pier I at 70th Street in Riverside Park South. The project was organized by the New York City office of Architecture for Humanity, the New York City Department of Parks & Recreation and Architizer LLC.

The veteran actress Jan Maxwell will star in the revival of Arthur Kopit's 1978 play "Wings" this fall at Second Stage Theater, the theater announced on Wednesday. The play, directed by John Doyle ("Sweeney Todd," "Company"), begins previews Oct. 5 and opens on Oct. 24.

A coalition of Greenwich Village community, preservation and parent groups has formed to register concerns about New York University's expansion plans, after a previous task force was suspended by Scott Stringer, the Manhattan borough president. Updated | Tuesday, Aug. 17 As my colleague James Barron reports, Steven Slater, the fed-up JetBlue flight attendant who on Monday used an aircraft's emergency slide to escape an unruly passenger and, most likely, his job, has already become, for some fans, "a folk hero, a real-life Howard Beale who found a way to channel his workaday frustrations." But was the specific cause of the altercation that caused Mr. Slater to snap - a shortage of space on board the jet for carry-on bags - a symptom of larger societal problems or merely a sign that the way the airline industry has a major flaw in the way it deals with luggage?

8:25 p.m. | Updated There are some heated headlines out there as fires spring up in the zone contaminated by the Chernobyl nuclear reactor disaster. His cottage was flanked by dozens of similar beach homes surrounded by sandy lawns, footpaths and summering families lolling in the summer heat. This was not Fire Island, but rather Staten Island.

Two consumer safety groups are asking the Federal Trade Commission to order Enterprise Rent-A-Car to start fixing every vehicle with a safety recall before renting them to consumers. Look at the lower left-hand corner: the real interest rate on 5-year inflation-protected securities is now negative. In other words, prospects for other investments are so poor that some investors prefer a safe asset that doesn't quite keep up with inflation.

The Place du Grand Sablon in Brussels is nothing like West 47th Street in Manhattan, although you can pick up a nice little brooch in either locale. The square and its surrounding streets are dominated by smart town houses occupied by dealers of sumptuous period furniture, chocolate, rare books and all manner of art, including one that's rarely mentioned in the same breath as sculpture and painting but is every bit as rarefied: costume jewelry made for the haute couture.

David Silva's second-half goal salvaged a 1-1 tie for Spain after Mexico earned an early lead on a goal by Javier Hernandez. It was Spain's first game since it won the World Cup in South Africa last month. Many of the stars of the tournament were on hand, but played only part of the game for Spain. Coach Vicente Del Bosque made eight substitutions at in the second half. "This was a party more than a game," Mexico captain Rafael Marquez said, according to the Associated Press.

Voters whittled the playing field for November in Congressional and gubernatorial races in four states on Tuesday. Here's a sampling: In Colorado, Senator Michael Bennet edged out tough competition in the Democratic primary to face Ken Buck, a conservative who narrowly defeated Lieutenant Governor Jane Norton for the Republican nod. Kirk Johnson notes that Mr. Bennet's victory suggests that Democrats' and President Obama's political clout hasn't disappeared in swing states. Still, The Times rates the race as a tossup.

Bedbugs, the bloodsucking scourges of sleepers everywhere, have had a mighty resurgence in recent years, enabled largely by their widespread resistance to once highly effective pesticides. After being virtually wiped out in the United States in the mid-20th century, infestations have again become common in cities from coast to coast.

The Spanish oil company Repsol will move forward with its plans to hold an initial public offering of its Brazilian business. The Financial Times reported that the offering could be worth about $4 billion.

1000Memories, a company that lets people create online memories for the dead, announced a partnership Tuesday with WePay, a payment provider. The deal will give users a free account and the option of raising money for projects, foundations or charities, according to its blog.

A federal judge on Tuesday ordered Wells Fargo to pay California customers $203 million in restitution for claims that it had manipulated transactions to maximize the overdraft fees it charged, Andrew Martin and Ron Lieber write in The New York Times.

A lot happens during the first few weeks of a deployment, even if there's not much action. Soldiers learn what it's like to live without family and friends. They adjust to the rhythm of life at the F.O.B. (one syllable, rhymes with mob, stands for forward operating base). And soldiers start going out on their first serious missions. They get a taste of how much adrenaline, boredom and uncertainty the rest of the year will bring.

BUTLER--Daniel William, 44. Of Los Angeles, died Sunday evening in Harrison, NY. He grew up in Sylvania, Oh., where he graduated from St. John's Jesuit High School in 1984 as the president of the student body and salutatorian of his senior class. After graduating from Indiana University in 1988, Dan studied film at New York University and worked in New York and Los Angeles in the film industry. Dan is survived by his loving parents, Nancy and Glen; his brothers, Brian, Kevin, David, and sister-in-law Clare; many cousins, aunts, uncles and close friends whom he loved dearly. Dan leaves three beloved nieces, Margot, Quinn and Emma, and his nephew and best buddy Liam. His love and kindness and extraordinary sense of humor will never be forgotten. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Dan Butler Memorial Fund to benefit the USC Center for Molecular Pathways and Drug Development, 1441 Eastlake Avenue Suite 8302, Los Angeles, CA 90033, or online at www.uscnorris.com/support; click on the "Memorial and Honor Donations." Memorial gifts should reference Dan Butler. A wake will be held from 5 to 8pm, Wednesday, at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. The funeral service will be 10am, Thursday, at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY.

An article on Tuesday about a shooting in Harlem in which one man was killed misstated the surname of a police officer involved in the gunfight. He is Douglas Brightman, not Bright. The article also erroneously attributed a distinction to the incident. A shooting incident in 2007 -- not the Harlem shooting -- involved the most police shots fired in a single episode since the Sean Bell shooting in 2006. (In the Harlem gunfight, the police fired 46 bullets. They fired 56 shots in the 2007 incident in which a gunman shot and killed a civilian and two auxiliary police officers.)

As a veteran flight attendant for JetBlue, Steven Slater undoubtedly logged many hours in training how to evacuate a planeload of terrified fliers down the emergency chutes. On Monday, he put those skills to use -- by quickly evacuating himself. No flier wants to use an aircraft's emergency slide in an actual emergency, but you can't help but wonder: Did Mr. Slater enjoy his seconds-long trip down the chute, that quick-escape device that looks like a grown-up slip-and-slide?

MILSTEIN--Paul, 88, one of the leading real estate developers of New York, died peacefully in his home surrounded by his wife and children. Born in 1922, he grew up in the Bronx, attended DeWitt Clinton High School and studied architecture at New York University. After military service during World War II, he joined the family business, Circle Flooring Company. Under his leadership, Circle Flooring became the dominant installer of floors, ceilings, and drywall both in New York and nationally. In the 1950s he began a lifelong career of significant real estate development projects centered in his beloved New York City. In the 1970s, he entered the coal, natural gas and oil business, while, at the same time, purchasing United Brands, the parent company of Chiquita Bananas. In the 1980s, he purchased Emigrant Savings Bank. Paul Milstein was as prolific in building important New York institutions as he was in developing real estate projects. Among the key beneficiaries of his vast philanthropy are: New York Presbyterian Medical Center, Columbia University, Cornell University, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, American Museum of Natural History, New York Public Library, UJA-Federation, and the Jewish Theological Seminary. A visionary, entrepreneur, philanthropist and devoted family man, Paul Milstein is survived by his adored wife of 63 years, Irma; children, Roslyn and Jerome Meyer, Howard and Abby Milstein, Barbara and David Zalaznick, and Edward and Robin Milstein; and sister, Gloria and Lou Flanzer; grandchildren Rebecca Meyer and Jeff Resnik, Michael Meyer, Jamie Meyer, Michael Morris Milstein, Jeffrey, Samantha and Amy Zalaznick, Andrew, Lexi, Benjamin, and Elizabeth Milstein, and great-granddaughter Lucy Meyer-Resnik. The funeral is private, and will take place on Tuesday, August 10, followed by a memorial service to be announced at a later date. Shiva will be observed at the family home in Manhattan on Wednesday and Thursday from 2-4:00pm and 5:30-8:30pm. In lieu of flowers, kindly honor Paul's memory, by sending donations to: American Museum of Natural History or the New York Presbyterian Medical Center. The Family of Paul Milstein

JOSEPHSON--Ben, Jr.,80 died at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx following a prolonged battle with cancer on August 4th. Born in 1930, he grew up in Manhattan, attended the Bronx High School of Science and studied Engineering Physics at Cornell. He received a Ph.D. in Physics from M.I.T. in 1958 and was a Fulbright Scholar studying at the University of Nottingham the following year. In the 1960s he worked as an Assistant Professor of Physics at Rice University and New York University. In the 1970s he was an executive at Riverside Research Institute and was a co-founder of Metis Associates, a consulting firm. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. A devoted father and grandfather, he is survived his son John, daughter-in-law Carolina Zapf and grandchildren Lily, Sophie and Nicholas Josephson. In lieu of flowers, kindly honor Ben's memory by sending donations to the Tamiment Library at New York University.

We shall always especially remember his support for our Centennial Campaign to ensure AJC's future. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Irma, a beloved member of our Women's Campaign, and the entire family. Robert Elman, Pres. David Harris, Exec. Dir.

The Yeshiva University/RIETS family mourns the passing of Ephraim Propp, a highly respected leader in the Jewish community and the husband of Gail Propp, who with his late brothers, Mortimer and Seymour, was a YU Guardian together with the late Eugenie, wife of Mortimer, and Gabrielle, wife of Seymour. It is not unusual to find coffee cups after police officers have finished an emergency call. But this one was a mystery: Did it belong to an investigator or to a victim? Early in the morning on July 8, the police were called to a building at Lenox Avenue and West 112th Street in Manhattan, where, it was reported, a man had jumped to his death. Investigators eventually came to a different conclusion. They said the victim, a 55-year-old man, had climbed to the roof about 5:30 a.m., tied his shoelaces to a pipe and then apparently tried to use them to lower himself into his girlfriend's apartment window. (She had refused to let him in.) A man on the second floor discovered the body when he heard a thump on the ledge outside his window. On the roof, the question remained: Who left the coffee cup? Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

KOTZEN--Leroy M.,M.D., 73 years old - October 4, 1936 to August 9, 2010. Suddenly, too early, still so strong and sharp. Loving and devoted son of the late Howard and Ida Kotzen and son in law of Irving and Estelle Brandwein. Graduate of Middlebury College, SUNY College of Medicine. Resident at NY Hospital Cornell, attending at Columbia Presbyterian, 38 years at Hackensack University Medical Center where he was a member of the Board of Governors and Chairman of the Radiology Department for more than a decade; he loved the medical center and was immensely proud of his department and colleagues. Lee was the bedrock of our family. He lived his life with a quiet strength that was filled with caring for others, dedication, hard work and ethics. He was a truly good man who touched all who knew him. He leaves a beautiful legacy. Loving and extraordinarily devoted son, husband, father, grandfather, brother. Survived by his best friend, adored and adoring wife of almost 49 years, Linda Brandwein Kotzen; his children Jennifer Wallis Kotzen and Jeffrey Howard Kotzen (Danielle Voogt); his grandsons Alexander Isaac, Nicolas Ian and Andrew Michael all of whom he loved dearly and filled him with pride and joy. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hackensack University Medical Center would be appreciated.

GRIFFENBERG--Dr. Grace L. Died August 8, 2010 while on vacation in Aruba. Grace was the adored mother of Susan Trovati of Closter, NJ and Stuart Griffen of Riverdale, NY. To her granddaughters Robyn and Joslyn Trovati, she was an amazing adventurer and the epitome of a lady. She was the devoted aunt of Steven Marmon, Nan Sabel and Elise Marmon. She was the beloved second mother of Dr. Ronald Gross. Grace was born on February 27, 1927, six minutes after her identical twin Betty Marmon who predeceased her twelve years ago. More than anything, her family and friends were treated with the utmost love, kindness and generosity. Grace's fan club crossed many disciplines, as she affected everyone she got to know. She was a sophisticated, intelligent, multi-career woman. She was an entrepreneur, as her mother was, decades ahead of her time. When her husband died in 1971, she went back to graduate school and got her PhD. She embarked on a new path of independence and self-sufficiency. "Dr. Grace" was charismatic, articulate, financially astute and held in the highest esteem by her colleagues. As a psychotherapist, her patients stayed in touch long after therapy was over. There was no role that she cherished more than being a mother. There will not be a day that goes by that we will not miss her sparkling spirit and unconditional love. Funeral services will be held at Plaza Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street on Thursday, August 12.

SCHRERO--Dr. Elliot M.,known as Mitch, beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother, died following a courageous battle fighting pneumonia. He was a native of Chicago, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Chicago, where he also earned his Masters Degree and Ph.D. in English Literature. He worked creative director in advertising at SCI and McCann-Erickson in advertising in New York City for many years before he returned to academia, where he was a tenured full professor of English at Rider University. Dr. Schrero was hospitalized within days of celebrating the 60th Anniversary of his wedding to his beloved wife, Artist, Ruth Lieberman Schrero, and his 88th Birthday. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughters, Elizabeth Schrero Cooper and Maggie Schrero D'Arcy, his grandchildren, Arielle Jae Cooper and Daniel Benjamin Cooper, his brother, Stanley Allan Schrero, and his sons-in-law, Jeffrey A. Cooper and Keith D'Arcy. Dr. Schrero was a true intellectual, with a real thirst for learning. He was a man of strong principles and integrity and had an unbounded capacity for empathy. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his memory, to the University of Chicago. Services Thursday 12 noon "Eden memorial Chapels" 327 main St., Fort lee, NJ (201) 947-3336.

An article on Thursday about differing accounts of the events surrounding an oil spill in Dalian, China, referred incorrectly to a toxic chemical that the environmental group Greenpeace said was stored at the facility where the spill occurred, and a correction in this space on Friday referred incorrectly to the account of two experts with authoritative knowledge of the spill. The chemical, dimethylbenzene, is a liquid at normal temperatures, not a gas, and the two experts confirmed that a spreading fire was endangering a chemical tank that could have emitted a cloud of toxic gas; they did not confirm that the chemical in the tank was dimethylbenzene.

SHRIVER--Donald Fowler, (88), formally of Maplewood, NJ, currently resided in Portland, Maine and Forestburgh, New York, passed away peacefully on August 8, 2010. He was predeceased by his loving wife, Joan Robertson Shriver, whom he married in 1949. Son of Alfred and Anna Shriver, he was born in New York City on October 19, 1921. Don graduated from Staten Island Academy in 1939 and from Williams College in 1943. He served in the Navy in World War II as a First Lieutenant. Don spent most of his professional career as an executive at AT&T and retired in 1977 after 30 years. In retirement, Don volunteered for the Red Cross and was Treasurer for Merriewold Club for more than ten years. He enjoyed reading and crossword puzzles. Don was a long time member of St. George's Episcopal Church in Maplewood, NJ. He was predeceased by his loving sister Nancy Hahn and brother Denton Shriver. Don is survived by his daughter Cathy Shriver Kalesnick and his son, Peter Hepburn Shriver. He is also survived by his four grandchildren, Kalvin and Jade Kalesnick, and Claire and William Shriver. He will be deeply missed. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to Merriewold Club Memorial Fund, 2674 Route 42, Forestburgh, NY 12777.

An article on July 15 about economic expansion in Singapore reported its second-quarter growth incorrectly. The economy expanded 19.3 percent from the same quarter a year earlier, not from the first quarter, and 26 percent on a quarter-on-quarter annualized basis, not from the second quarter of 2009.

MILSTEIN--Paul H. Cornell University mourns the loss of Paul Milstein, visionary entrepreneur, real estate developer, and philanthropist--and patriarch of a family whose ties to Cornell span three generations. The Milsteins are among Cornell's greatest benefactors, having devoted much of their service and philanthropy to the campuses in Ithaca, NY, and at Weill Cornell Medical College in New York City. Thanks to a generous gift from Irma Milstein in honor of her husband, Cornell's College of Architecture, Art, and Planning will soon open Paul Milstein Hall, designed by celebrated architect Rem Koolhaas. The building will stand as a lasting tribute to Paul Milstein's love of architecture, enduring commitment to education, and legacy as one of New York City's most prolific builders. On behalf of the Cornell community, we express our sincere condolences to Irma, Howard and Abby, Barbara and David, Roslyn and Jerome, Edward and Robin, and the entire Milstein family. Peter C. Meinig, Chair of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University David J. Skorton, President, Cornell University

Yields on 10-year Treasury securities, a vital benchmark for home mortgages and corporate loans, tumbled to the lowest level in more than a year on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve said it would buy up government debt in an effort to bolster the nation's increasingly fragile economy. With no more room to reduce interest rates by decree, the Fed has decided to use its considerable market influence instead. By committing to buy up United States debt, the Fed hopes to increase demand for Treasury securities, pushing up their price while reducing their yields and, in turn, a range of interest rates.

VAIL, Colo. -- I don't much enjoy watching dance on YouTube, but the scale of tango suits it better than any other genre. There you can see two ravishing clips of the Argentine tango dancers Natalia Hills and Gabriel Missé at the Vail International Dance Festival last year. (Search for their names and the Vail festival.) Even so, to watch them in live performance is altogether more sensational; and it's only then that you feel the full excitement of Mr. Missé's matchless footwork. Both last year and this they were the most absorbing luminaries at the festival's International Evenings of Dance, but this year the festival also programmed two remarkable all-tango events at the open-air Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater, confirming my view that in Ms. Hills and Mr. Missé, there is no more spellbinding dance partnership today.

GRIFFENBERG--Dr. Grace L. My mother's life was a collection of wonderful short stories. In her 83 years she was a teacher, guidance counselor, educational consultant, ombudsman, wellness advocate, psychotherapist and member of several boards of directors. Some homes away from home, whether owned or rented, are extensions of people's primary residence that allow them to carry on as usual in a refreshingly different location. Thus, chic, striving Manhattanites become chic, striving Hamptonites, and suburbanites enjoy flipping burgers at the lake or in the mountains instead of in their usual backyards. Other vacation homes, however, are so radically different that they become labs for experimenting with another way of life altogether. Our house in Dubois (DOO-boyz), Wyo., which is a small cowboy town southeast of Yellowstone National Park, falls into that category.

David Mamet's moral fable of pride and prejudices, "Race," has announced it will close its Broadway run at the Barrymore Theater on Aug. 21 after its 320th performance. The drama, which currently stars Eddie Izzard, Dennis Haysbert, Afton C. Williamson and Richard Thomas, is the longest running play of the 2009-2010 season. Productions are planned for next year in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Milwaukee, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. There are also plans for the play to be featured in London.

Artists make so many mash-ups of painting, sculpture and drawing these days that when one turns up with work in a traditional form, it seems almost radical. Shio Kusaka is such an artist. No two of the carved ceramic vessels in her current exhibition at the Anton Kern Gallery are alike. Yet they don't stray very far from those of a typical potter. Then again, Kusaka, 38, is not trying to reinvent the wheel. "I like ceramics because it hasn't changed for a long time," she says. "And I think that's amazing, what people can do with the hands. It's the same, and still they make it new."

Continuing my slow march through responses to my gay marriage column, I want to take up two somewhat-related critiques of my argument for holding up lifelong heterosexual monogamy as a distinctive legal and cultural ideal: First, that this ideal is too essentialist, and second, that it's too complicated. The too-essentialist critique has been raised by The American Prospect's Adam Serwer, among others, who scoffs at my suggestion that there's anything distinctive about heterosexual relationships as heterosexual relationships: Every intimate relationship, he suggests, is "'distinct' in its 'challenges and potential fruit,'" and so there's no reason why heterosexual marriages as a category deserve to be singled out or idealized in any way. The too-complicated critique was raised by Matt Feeney, who writes (well, "tweets") that "if there's an Ockham's Razor/Parsimony standard for 'ideals,'" then my marriage ideal "doesn't meet it," because "any marriage ideal strong enough to function qua ideal, as Ross uses the term, would have to be parsimonious enough to allow gay marriage."

My wife and I spent a lot of time driving on the Isle of Skye, off the west coast of Scotland, where I recently was reporting a story. That posed a few problems. First, I'd never driven on the left side of the road. (Let's just say it took a few days for me to adjust.) Second, Skye is full of single-lane roads with "Passing Places" -- you end up playing a friendly little game with oncoming cars as to who will pull over. (Don't forget to wave as you pass by - it's considered rude not to.) And then there was the livestock. Sheep, it turns out, will move when you honk (though we did hear stories of horned rams doing some damage upon seeing their reflection in car doors); cows are a bit more stubborn. But when you're surrounded by vistas as beautiful as those on Skye, you don't mind the occasional break in your journey.

On a recent Friday morning, lit white by the California sun, Nigel Dare was sitting in his shop, fielding calls from a movie set. "Is that a Japanese line?" he asked the makeup artist on the other end. "Never heard of it. But you'll have it by Monday." Dare is the ultimate Hollywood candy man - a warm, personable guy who can procure Fria, an Italian makeup remover, if that's what you need, or Collyre Bleu (1) for the hungover actor with bloodshot eyes. Nigel's Beauty Emporium, along with Naimie's Beauty Center and Frends Beauty Supply, is perhaps the San Fernando Valley's best-kept secret: a treasure trove of rarefied cosmetics brands where Hollywood makeup artists go to keep the likes of Sandra Bullock, Megan Fox and George Clooney powdered and buffed. Here they can scour hundreds of global brands, including ones you don't see everywhere (Embryolisse (2), La Peau (3) ) and the Japanese lines much beloved by the pros (KohGenDo, Kanebo). Here they can ask for and get Kate (5), the ultrathin Kanebo eyeliner that is barely detectable on the eye. Or the French - and much stronger - version of Anthelios, the sunscreen by La Roche-Posay. Or, for that matter, Labello lip balm (4), from Germany. Frends is the granddaddy of the bunch: founded in 1940, it catered to makeup artists who were stuck on a set for 18 hours straight and running on empty. Today all three stores are about turnaround, finding products anywhere they can and even picking them up at a competitor's if they have to - which, for the right client, they will.

As sales pick up, I've been trying to build our production capacity proportionally. This has been hard for me to accomplish in the past. During the last big expansion, between 2003 and 2008, I found myself in the position of hiring willy-nilly, throwing warm bodies at production bottlenecks. In the rush to get work out the door, we never set up a training program and we didn't do a good job of increasing productivity with technology. This was a disastrous mistake. More than anything else, an inflated payroll drained cash from the company and kept us from making a profit.

An article on Tuesday about a Los Angeles women's club founded in 1927 paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Michele Mount, the spokeswoman for the General Federation of Women's Clubs, about the estimated number of women who were members of the federation in the mid-20th Century. Heaven knows a seductive title can be tempting. ''Abraham Lincoln's Big, Gay Dance Party,'' for example. Granted, this grabber would not be much of a draw in American burgs that prefer tea at their parties, figuratively speaking. But for certain subsets of the culture -- New Yorkers with puckish senses of humor, say -- it's likely to be pure catnip. Consider yourselves forewarned, all ye tempted. The cheeky title is about the only irresistible element in this rambling pageant of clumsy drama and preachy moralizing, lengthened but not much enlivened by giddy dance breaks featuring a chorus line uniformly dressed in top hats and beards as the president of the title.

There are a number of text-blocking smartphone applications available that prevent the sending and receiving of texts in inappropriate situations, such as driving or attending class. Those products include tXtBlocker and ZoomSafer, among others. Recently I've been looking at a new one: SMS Replier, from Iconysys. The app, available for Android, BlackBerry and Windows Mobile phones, acts like an e-mail automated response; when someone sends a text to a phone with SMSReplier, the sender receives an automated message indicating that the receiver cannot respond at the moment.

FILENE--Adele Bleichroeder, died peacefully on August 8, in Stamford, CT at the age of 101. Born in Berlin of a family distinguished in banking and medicine, she took courses in Paris and Vienna in fashion and design. Forced to flee to London in 1938, she worked as a swim suit designer for Jantzen. When war started, she was designing handbags for Leopold Kahn and overnight found herself supervising the production of parachutes. Her twin boys were evacuated. Alone she experienced life in a city under heavy bombing and in austere conditions. With peace, she established her own haute couture salon, some of her more prominent clients being drawn from the staff of the German embassy an irony not lost on her. She moved to the U.S. in 1970 to marry Herman Filene, and was a founder member of the Costume Society of America, its treasurer, organizer of international study tours, and the establisher of a scholarship for students of fashion. A central focus became the Women's City Club of New York. She was a life member, director, chair of the Arts & Landmarks and Membership Committees, and an indefatigable contributor to the club's goals. In her private life, she bore with fortitude the loss of relatives under persecution in Germany, and the death in action of a son in the Korean War. For her family she was a formidable presence, yet encouraging, perceptive, and a mine of sound counsel. Adele was self-reliant. Despite more than her share of vicissitudes, she was always positive. She personified duty and determination, resilience, courage, and a stoic grace, the latter so noticeable as friends passed on and her own strength diminished. But she lost none of her acuity and involvement with the world around her, in her last days suggesting refinements for her daughter-in-law's hand sewn skirt, and chuckling mischievously during a discussion on what matters and what does not. She is survived by a son, Thomas Juliusburger and his wife Machiko, of Stamford, CT, three grandchildren, Susanna Allen and her husband Jonathan, of Henley, UK, Stephan Juliusburger of Miami, FL, and Nicholas Juliusburger, of Fairfield, CT, and three great grandchildren, Dr. Kirsty Allen and Mr. James Allen in England, and Sage Juliusburger in Fairfield. We respect her for what she achieved and miss her profoundly.

MILSTEIN--Paul, 88, one of the leading real estate developers of New York, died peacefully in his home surrounded by his wife and children. Born in 1922, he grew up in the Bronx, attended DeWitt Clinton High School and studied architecture at New York University. After military service during World War II, he joined the family business, Circle Flooring Company. Under his leadership, Circle Flooring became the dominant installer of floors, ceilings, and drywall both in New York and nationally. In the 1950s he began a lifelong career of significant real estate development projects centered in his beloved New York City. In the 1970s, he entered the coal, natural gas and oil business, while, at the same time, purchasing United Brands, the parent company of Chiquita Bananas. In the 1980s, he purchased Emigrant Savings Bank. Paul Milstein was as prolific in building important New York institutions as he was in developing real estate projects. Among the key beneficiaries of his vast philanthropy are: New York Presbyterian Medical Center, Columbia University, Cornell University, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, American Museum of Natural History, New York Public Library, UJA-Federation, and the Jewish Theological Seminary. A visionary, entrepreneur, philanthropist and devoted family man, Paul Milstein is survived by his adored wife of 63 years, Irma; children, Roslyn and Jerome Meyer, Howard and Abby Milstein, Barbara and David Zalaznick, and Edward and Robin Milstein; and sister, Gloria and Lou Flanzer; grandchildren Rebecca Meyer and Jeff Resnik, Michael Meyer, Jamie Meyer, Michael Morris Milstein, Jeffrey, Samantha and Amy Zalaznick, Andrew, Lexi, Benjamin, and Elizabeth Milstein, and great-granddaughter Lucy Meyer-Resnik. The funeral is private, and will take place on Tuesday, August 10, followed by a memorial service to be announced at a later date. Shiva will be observed at the family home in Manhattan on Wednesday and Thursday from 2-4:00pm and 5:30-8:30pm. In lieu of flowers, kindly honor Paul's memory, by sending donations to: American Museum of Natural History or the New York Presbyterian Medical Center. The Family of Paul Milstein

CHEREMETEFF--Maiko. The Countess Cheremeteff, 74, peacefully in her sleep on August 9, 2010. Beloved and loving wife of 49 years of Nikita, The Count Cheremeteff, of Chevy Chase, MD; devoted mother and mother-in-law of Constantin and Jane Cheremeteff of Bethesda, MD; Kyra Cheremeteff and Thomas Richardson of Washington, DC; Mother Seraphima, of Etna, California; and Nicholas and Fiona Cheremeteff, of Moscow, Russia. Proud and adoring grandmother of Alexandra Richardson and Andrew Richardson of Washington, DC, and Isabella Cheremeteff and Katerina Cheremeteff of Bethesda, MD. Loving sister and sister-in-law of Zurab and Elizabeth Kobiashvili of The Woodlands, TX, and loving aunt of Gettys and Major Michael Nelson, Sasha (+), Peter, Andrew and Kyra Nelson of Monterey, CA; Henry and Katherine Christner of Richmond, VA; Sarah Kobiashvili of London, UK. Born in Thorn, Poland on March 12, 1936, the beloved daughter of Simon Kobiashvili and Kyra Bakradze Kobiashvili, of Tbilisi, Georgia, St. Petersburg, Russia, and later Arlington, Virginia. Maiko had a deep and abiding faith and was unwaveringly devoted and beloved of a richly diverse community of family and friends in many countries. An ever generous hostess and volunteer, her deep spirituality, unconditional love for her family and friends, generosity and warm spirit, vivacious intelligence, grace and exceptional elegance and beauty will be deeply missed. Service and funeral will be held on August 16, 2010 at 1pm at Novo Diveyevo Convent. www.novo-diveyevo.org. 100 Smith Road, Nanuet, NY, 10954. Following funeral, family will receive at Westchester Marriot, 670 White Plains Rd, Tarrytown, NY. In lieu of flowers, family asks for donations to The American Friends of Georgia. In the past, setting up a full-featured Webcam to monitor your home (or your kids and pets) remotely was too confounding for the average user, what with the tweaks needed to network and router settings. Worse, your efforts often yielded blurry, low-resolution video with unreliable availability. Logitech has addressed these issues with a line of new home-monitoring Webcams that are remarkably easy to set up and that deliver high-resolution video for a consumer-level camera.

MILSTEIN--Paul. The Board of Directors and staff of Citizens Housing & Planning Council mourn the loss of Paul Milstein, a generous benefactor whose visionary leadership changed the landscape of New York City. We extend our deepest condolences to his son Howard and all the members of the Milstein family. Marvin Markus, Chairman Jerilyn Perine, Executive Director

GRIFFENBERG--Dr. Grace L. Died August 8, 2010 while on vacation in Aruba. Grace was the adored mother of Susan Trovati of Closter, NJ and Stuart Griffen of Riverdale, NY. To her granddaughters Robyn and Joslyn Trovati, she was an amazing adventurer and the epitome of a lady. She was the devoted aunt of Steven Marmon, Nan Sabel and Elise Marmon. She was the beloved second mother of Dr. Ronald Gross. Grace was born on February 27, 1927, six minutes after her identical twin Betty Marmon who predeceased her twelve years ago. More than anything, her family and friends were treated with the utmost love, kindness and generosity. Grace's fan club crossed many disciplines, as she affected everyone she got to know. She was a sophisticated, intelligent, multi-career woman. She was an entrepreneur, as her mother was, decades ahead of her time. When her husband died in 1971, she went back to graduate school and got her PhD. She embarked on a new path of independence and self-sufficiency. "Dr. Grace" was charismatic, articulate, financially astute and held in the highest esteem by her colleagues. As a psychotherapist, her patients stayed in touch long after therapy was over. There was no role that she cherished more than being a mother. There will not be a day that goes by that we will not miss her sparkling spirit and unconditional love. Funeral services will be held at Plaza Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street on Thursday, August 12.
SAPHIR--Joel Leonard, 73, formerly of Sherman, CT, died of cancer on August 9, 2010, at his home in Howey in the Hills, FL. He is survived by his wife, Tamsin.

It's easy to see why; many people are not satisfied with the earbuds that come with their MP3 devices, and few are happy with the battery life of their iPhone.

His new willingness to be a captain's pick for the team represents a 180-degree turn, not a 360-degree turn.

The Adidas version, miCoach, is available for the BlackBerry, iPhone and iPod Touch, and offers a real-time coach that tracks speed and endurance through a phone's built-in GPS sensor.
