HAVEN, Wis. - A scene right out of a World Wrestling Entertainment event erupted at the staid P.G.A. Championship on Wednesday when Jim Gray of the Golf Channel called the United States Ryder Cup captain Corey Pavin ''a liar'' and told him, ''You're going down.'' According to Pavin and witnesses, Gray entered the media center through the back door after Pavin and the European captain, Colin Montgomerie, had concluded their news conference. During the news conference, Pavin had reiterated a denial of a report Gray broadcast Tuesday night. The report stated that Pavin told Gray exclusively that Tiger Woods would be one of his four captain's selections for the 12-man United States team that will play Europe in October.

KRAISKY--Benjamin P. The partners and staff of J.H. Cohn LLP note with deepest sorrow the passing of Benjamin P. Kraisky, Senior Tax Partner. Ben was esteemed by all who had the good fortune to know him and work with him. His dedication, ethics, and commitment to the highest standards were matched only by his good humor and mentorship. Ben was truly an ambassador for the firm. His clients, peers, and colleagues held him in the highest regard and with great affection. Prior to joining J.H. Cohn, Ben was a partner and senior corporate tax executive for Ernst & Young LLP. He was a native of Mount Vernon, NY and graduated cum laude from the Carroll School of Management at Boston College. Ben was known for his philanthropic spirit, was a great supporter of the theater arts, and was on the Board of Directors for the Alliance Resident Theatres, A.R.T./New York. Ben's legacy at the firm is one of unparalleled professional expertise and unwavering dedication to his clients. He was a true mentor to the people in his charge, a tireless provider to his clients, an invaluable resource to his colleagues, and a good friend. The character of the life he lived might be summed up in a few words: he was sincere; he was earnest; he was loyal; he was a person with a great intellect and big heart. Ben will be missed greatly by all of his friends and colleagues at J.H. Cohn. Our sorrow is lessened only slightly with the comforting thought that we had the privilege to know him, learn from him, and work alongside him. Our deepest sympathies go out to the Kraisky family.

A headline on Tuesday about criticism of Hewlett-Packard after the resignation of its chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, misstated, in some copies, the recommendation of a public relations specialist consulted by the company. The specialist urged the company to disclose accusations of sexual harassment against Mr. Hurd; the specialist did not advise the company to oust him.

The Critical Shopper column last Thursday, about the Chico's store in East Hampton, N.Y., misstated the number of Chico's stores in the United States. There are 651, not 240. The article also misstated the length of time the East Hampton store has been open. It is four months old, not eight.

ROCHE--Kevin M. The family of Kevin Roche announces with deep sadness his sudden and unexpected death at age 50 in his home in Vienna, Austria on August 9, 2010. Loving father, son, brother and husband, Kevin will be laid to rest near his home in Vienna. The family will announce plans for a New York memorial service and celebration of his life in the coming weeks. Kevin is survived by his nine-year-old daughter Caitlin, and wife Sabine of Vienna; and his father Michael of the Bronx, and sister Colleen of Ossining, NY. His cherished memory will live with us always.

ZIELINSKI--Walt on August 9, 2010 former Chief Counsel of International Paper, husband of Patricia, father of Mark, Anne, Jean Monaco, and Carol Paine, loving grandfather. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Walt may be made to a Hospice of your choice.

PROPP--Ephraim. The principals, officers and staff of Tahl Propp Equities are deeply saddened by the passing of Ephraim Propp, of blessed memory, uncle of our chairman and founder, Rodney M. An article on Monday about the newly discovered archive from Philip Johnson's architectural practice misstated the name of one of the institutions that houses collections of his early works. It is the Getty Research Institute, not the ''Getty Museum.'' (The J. Paul Getty Museum and the research institute operate as different programs under the J. Paul Getty Trust.)

Max Osterweis, the chief executive and creative director of the fair-trade clothing line SUNO, has been making trips to Kenya’s Lamu Island long before glamorous Euros attempted to replace plodding donkey rides with a few modern conveniences, like the automobile. A favorite of Michelle Obama and Sofia Coppola, SUNO has been known since its birth in 2008 for its progressive approach to factory labor in Kenya as well as for its vivid multicolored garments inspired by traditional kangas. Here the filmmaker-turned-designer provides us with his local Lamu favorites. Seafood lovers, get ready to salivate.

Susan Spungen has had many careers: restaurant cook and caterer, Martha Stewart’s culinary right hand for a dozen years, food stylist (for T Magazine and others). In recent years, she’s brought the meals in the top food movies to life, from the duck en croute for “Julie & Julia” (even Jacques Pépin approved) to the plot-advancing croissants in “It’s Complicated” and now the Roman feasts in “Eat Pray Love,” which opens today. The Moment caught up with Spungen over a cappuccino at Bluebird Coffee to find out how she kept her pasta from outshining Julia Roberts, and to get her tips for dining in Rome.

The flooding in Pakistan, which began in late July, has killed an estimated 1,600 people and affected a total of 14 million, Salman Masood and Waqar Gillani reported. Aid agencies and the United Nations warned Friday that the disaster was still mounting, with outbreaks of water-borne disease an additional likelihood. "We want to warn everyone that the crisis facing Pakistan is enormous," said Mengesha Kebede, a representative of the United Nations refugee agency. "There continues to be massive destruction as the bloated rivers flow inexorably southwards across the plains."

If not for his massive rubber sculptures and short films of burning skulls, Paolo Canevari, 47, may have only been known as the ex-beau of a certain Yugoslavian performance artist. "For me, Marina has always been first a woman, my companion, and then an artist," says Canevari, who separated from Marina Abramovic in 2009. Born into a family of classically trained Italian painters and sculptors, Canevari came to New York in the 1980s to assist the South Korean experimental video artist Nam June Paik. Since his first New York show in 1989, Canevari has produced politically responsive artworks in a diverse array of mediums: sculptures made of car tires, video installations and photographs. He even dipped a toe into the slightly more frivolous world of fashion after meeting Riccardo Tisci in 2007 to collaborate on a project for AnOther magazine. "He gave me a Givenchy haute couture dress and said, 'Do what you like with it.' I burned it on a wooden cross." As for the clothing he doesn't set aflame, Canevari sticks to vintage. "I have a collection of vintage suits and several vintage motorcycle jackets ... around 35!" Concerning the overall inspiration behind his works, including his 2007 Venice Biennale entry, "Bouncing Skull," the artist is very frank. "Life and death have been a source of inspiration for centuries for artists," he says. "I'm not an exception."

Harold C. Turner, the incendiary Internet radio host, was found guilty on Friday afternoon of threatening to assault or kill three federal judges in Chicago because he was angered by an opinion they had issued supporting a local handgun ban.

Before he got to the Galápagos Islands, Charles Darwin spent two years studying the distinct flora and fauna of the southern tip of South America, making observations that came to influence his groundbreaking theory of natural selection. Though the Galápagos typically draw Darwin tours, two cruises aim to shadow the H.M.S. Beagle's less celebrated time in Tierra del Fuego.

Like a true revolutionary, I was born on Bastille Day (July 14), 1960, in Dahomey, which was then a part of the French Empire in West Africa. A few days later, on August 1st, 50 years ago this month, my country was declared independent: I was French for just 18 days! It is not easy for me to judge the 50 years of independence of my small country, now called Benin. I feel that my life has been shaped in many ways by the political tribulations of West Africa. I consider myself a true daughter of my country's recent independence.

Play resumed at Whistling Straights on Friday after another fog delay. Matt Kuchar made a birdie on his first hole and finished the fog-delayed first round at 5-under 67, one stroke ahead of Bubba Watson and Francesco Molinari, who finished the first round Thursday at 4-under.

THE newly revamped W now comes with a slanted logo, as if to say, "Let's go!" The energized logo might be the most promising thing about the magazine, which has a new editor, Stefano Tonchi, formerly the editor of T: The New York Times Magazine, as well as a new creative director, Jody Quon. I've been a reader of W since its broadsheet days, when it was driven by the curiosity and often deliciously snippy tongue of its founder, John Fairchild. In 2000, I wrote a profile of its then creative director, Dennis Freedman, and the way he cultivated photographers and helped bring to life sometimes-difficult ideas in fashion and art. In its long history W, at its best, was a scrappy journalistic player with a knowing sense of the people it covered.

"What kind of culture develops on an island?" asks Edward Rothstein in today's Weekend section. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan's shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. On ArtsBeat today, critics from several disciplines will be discussing the island's role as a cultural destination. Check back for regular updates throughout the day and share your own thoughts about the island, too. Read previous entries here.

Best applied under moisturizer, serums are said to penetrate more deeply than creams, delivering ingredients that promise anti-aging benefits, like brighter complexions and renewed volume. Among the multitudes, here are our new favorites. (Related article: Am I Young Yet?)

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

For children, the playground means a chance to stretch their legs and imaginations, while their parents, in increasing numbers, exercise their thumbs. With a so-called smartphone seemingly at every adult's fingertips, many parents are finding playtime to be the ideal time for answering e-mails, firing off text messages and browsing the Web - leaving their children to cavort about virtually unattended at playgrounds, pools and kiddie gyms.

For a 20-something slacker from Toronto, Scott Pilgrim is looking very ambitious. Tuesday saw the release of the soundtrack of "Scott Pilgrim vs. the World" and the film version, starring Michael Cera, opens on Friday. This week also saw the premiere of the Scott Pilgrim video game. A review at Comics Alliance called it "fun" and "old school." The character's quest to be the king of all media has also landed his publisher, Oni Press, a deal with comiXology to create an application that make the six volumes of the comic available for purchase on iTunes. Those six volumes can also be found in the top seven of our softcover list this week. (The latest volume of "The Walking Dead" enters our list at No. 2.)

The Times reports this morning that a shift in research strategy among scientists is beginning to yield insights into how Alzheimer's disease begins. The key to the Alzheimer's project was an agreement as ambitious as its goal: not just to raise money, not just to do research on a vast scale, but also to share all the data, making every single finding public immediately, available to anyone with a computer anywhere in the world.

Have you accidentally imported the same CD twice, or do you have duplicated songs in your iTunes library? A built-in feature of iTunes lets you easily weed out doubles. Just open the iTunes program and click on the icon for your Music library on the left side of the window. Next, go to the File menu and choose the Display Duplicates option.

The euro-area economy grew 1 percent in the second quarter, a much better rate than had been expected, due largely to Germany's best quarterly performance since reunification, according to data released on Friday.
In New York, if not the nation, the Jets are the team people are talking about. That's the way the Jets like it, and their publicity push far predates "Hard Knocks."
RSA, the British insurer, has approached rival Aviva about buying its general insurance operations in Britain and elsewhere for £5 billion ($7.83 billion), Sky News reported Friday.
In its debut on the American market, MakeMyTrip skyrocketed 89 percent. The Indian travel agency offered five million ordinary shares priced at $14 a share in its initial public offering.

Li & Fung, the biggest supplier to retailers including Wal-Mart Stores, is offering about 7 billion Hong Kong dollars ($901 million) for a distribution company to gain a network in China. Both companies' shares rose in Hong Kong on the news.

Citigroup is helping the kids of its wealthiest clients to manage their allowances. The bank, Bloomberg News reported, is testing a Web site to let millionaires' children manage their money, while alerting parents and bankers when scions blow through cash too quickly.

Barclays, Credit Suisse and Royal Bank of Scotland, which added 6,500 staff at their securities units in the past year, may lead a slowdown in hiring in Europe as the fixed-income trading boom fizzles, Bloomberg News reported, citing comments by recruiters.

For Hong Kong fashion mavens, shoes are often not an accessory, but the main item. So it's not surprising that shoe boutiques of all styles and prices proliferate across the city. But fans of luxury footwear have been making a special pilgrimage to the recently opened Rupert Sanderson boutique, the brand's flagship store in Asia.

Billionaire Li Ka-shing made his biggest investment in Hutchison Whampoa shares in at least seven years, boosting a stock that has already been the best performer of the month in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, Bloomberg News reported.
Hedge funds stabilized somewhat in July as investors poured more money into the sector amid rebounding stock markets, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing estimates published by HedgeFund.net.

The story of a flight attendant escaping from an airplane down an inflatable chute after an altercation with a passenger has attracted a lot of attention. The City Room blog compared the response of Steven Slater, the attendant, to a difficult situation with that of pilot Chesley Sullenberger, who famously landed a plane in the Hudson River. City Room suggests that we all look inside and ask, "Am I a Sully? Or am I a Slater?" Which are you?

Vedanta Resources is in talks to buy a controlling stake in Cairn Energy's Indian subsidiary, The Financial Times reported. Cairn India's stock rose 1.6 percent on the Bombay Stock Exchange in morning trading Friday following the disclosure. In separate statements, both Vedanta and Cairn confirmed talks were ongoing.

CA Technologies, the business management software company formerly known as CA Inc., said Thursday that it had acquired a privately held virtualization and cloud-computing consulting firm for an undisclosed amount, The Associated Press reported.
Warner Chilcott, the Irish drug maker, said Thursday its subsidiaries sold $750 million of senior notes in a private placement, The Associated Press reported.

A Utah investor who lost a $5 million private jet, a luxury car and his membership in the Utah Jazz's premier fan club in a bankruptcy said his company will resurrect a moribund central Idaho ski and golf resort, The Associated Press reported.

Ssangyong Motor, the South Korean automaker, named Mahindra & Mahindra, the top sport utility vehicle maker in India, as its preferred buyer Thursday, demonstrating the growing clout of manufacturers from emerging markets.
Airstrip Technologies has closed an undisclosed round of financing from venture firm Sequoia Capital.

WePay, a company that lets groups of people make online payments from a single account, has raised $7.5 million more in a second round of funding, VentureBeat reported. The money will be used to expand marketing and development for a growing user base, the company said.

Speculative-grade companies are doubling the rate at which they are repaying leveraged loans, as they try to curb the likelihood of rising defaults amid signs the American economy is slowing, Bloomberg News reported.
More than half of the 100 biggest takeovers made during the last mergers-and-acquisitions boom have something in common: By one measure, they never should have happened, Bloomberg News reports.

Trubion Pharmaceuticals, a Seattle biotech firm, agreed to be acquired by Emergent BioSolutions for $96.8 million in cash and stock and a potential later payment of as much as $38.7 million, Bloomberg News reported.

China's households hide as much as 9.3 trillion renminbi of income that is not reported in official figures, with 80 percent accrued by the wealthiest people, Bloomberg News reports.

Greece's recession deepened in the second quarter, according to official estimates released Thursday, as the country felt the painful consequences of the government's drive to reduce its debt load with aggressive austerity cuts, The Associated Press reports.

RUDD--Paul Ryan, 70, passed away on August 12, 2010 at his home in Greenwich, CT, of pancreatic cancer. Mr. Rudd was surrounded by, and is survived by his wife Martha Bannerman and their children, Graeme, Kathryn and Eliza. He is also survived by his mother Kathryn Rudd of Hingham, MA and numerous cousins. Mr. Rudd was born in 1940 in Boston, MA and attended the Boston Latin School and Assumption Prep. He graduated from Fairfield University. After a brief career in advertising in New York City, Mr. Rudd worked as a professional actor and director both on and off-Broadway from 1967 through 1986. Notable roles include Henry V in Henry V at the Delacorte Theater, Scooper in the original Broadway cast of Bosoms and Neglect, Romeo in Romeo and Juliet at Circle In The Square, Gentleman Caller in the original Broadway cast of The Glass Menagerie, and Billy Wilson in the premiere of David Rabe's Streamers. His television and film credits include Brian Mallory in Beacon Hill, JFK in Johnny We Hardly Knew Ye, and guest roles in episodes of Moonlighting, Knot's Landing, Hart to Hart, and Murder, She Wrote. In 1986 Mr. Rudd left acting to raise his children. As they grew, he began teaching theater, especially Shakespeare, and poetry in local middle schools and high schools. He continued his teaching career at Sarah Lawrence College (1999-2006) and the New School for Drama (2004-present) as a teaching faculty member and the Associate Director of the MFA Drama program. His passion and enthusiasm as a teacher inspired deep admiration and affection in his many students. Mr. Rudd's keen intellect, irreverent sense of humor, and vivacity were present in all facets of his life. He delighted in music, literature, art, cooking, and the company of his friends. His greatest joy was that of being a father and a husband. A service will be held this Sunday, August 15th at 2pm at Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, CT.

Just under 50 games remain on the schedule for each major league team, and the playoff races are coming into focus. Through Wednesday, six teams (the Yankees, Tampa Bay, Chicago, Minnesota, Texas and Boston) in the American League and six teams (Atlanta, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, St. Louis, San Diego and San Francisco) in the National League were within four games of a playoff position. Since the move to three divisions in 1995, there have been only four cases of a team that was behind in the standings by five or more games on or after Aug. 11 but came back to win its division: the 1995 Mariners, the 2006 and 2009 Twins, and the 2007 Phillies. So although it would not be unprecedented for the Rockies, down by five games, and the Dodgers, down by five and a half games, to come back to win the division, it appears unlikely.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the Bruce Springsteen documentary ''The Promise: The Making of 'Darkness on the Edge of Town' '' included several errors. The name of the festival where it is being shown is the Toronto International Film Festival, not the Toronto Film Festival. The opening-night film will be ''Score: A Hockey Musical,'' not ''The Promise.'' And the surname of the director of the Springsteen documentary is Thom Zimny, not Zimney.

The Scouting Report column on Thursday misstated the starting date of the IF Boutique basement sale in SoHo. It is scheduled to start on Monday and run through Sunday, Aug. 22; it did not start on Thursday.
A chart on Wednesday with an article about Tuesday's stock market performance was published in error. The chart showed the Dow's minute-by-minute positions on July 29, not on Tuesday.

An article last Friday about the political effects on November's midterm elections of the decision to invalidate Proposition 8, California's same-sex marriage ban, referred incompletely to the credentials of Maggie Gallagher, who commented about the future of the case. While she is indeed president of the Institute for Marriage and Public Policy, it was in her role as the chair of the National Organization for Marriage, not as president of the institute, that she commented -- including her statement that ''We are also looking for opportunities to demonstrate that pro-gay marriage Republicans lose.''

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the Connecticut primary election results misstated the history of the Republican Party's control of the governor's office. A Republican has held the office every year since 1995, not since 1991. (Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who had been a Republican congressman, was elected governor as an independent and served from 1991 to 1995.)

An obituary on Thursday about the former Illinois congressman Dan Rostenkowski referred incorrectly to the political career of his father, Joseph P. Rostenkowski. While he was a longtime Chicago alderman, he never served in Congress.

What can the Senate get done with only two members in the chamber? A fair amount, it turns out. In a highly unusual session, the chamber of filibusters and anonymous holds temporarily came back from its summer recess on Thursday to send a border security measure to President Obama's desk and to pass a resolution honoring former Senator Ted Stevens -- with only two senators present, Charles E. Schumer of New York and Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland, both Democrats.

HAVEN, Wis. - Every golfer has days in his career that he would very much like to forget, and for Stuart Appleby, one of them came the last time the P.G.A. Championship was played here at Whistling Straits, back in 2004. Appleby, a 39-year-old Australian, got off to a hot start on Thursday, holding an early lead and finishing with a three-under-par 33. He also played well in 2004, finishing that tournament tied for 17th at three under, five strokes behind the winner, Vijay Singh.

An article on Wednesday about the evolution of plans for a proposed Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan misstated the role of Daisy Khan in the 9/11 Memorial and Museum. Ms. Khan, one of the organizers of the center, has been part of an advisory panel for the museum; she is not on its board. The article also misstated, in some copies, the age of Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, another of the organizers of the center. He is 62, not 61. And the article misstated, in some copies, the date of the arrest of Faisal Shahzad, the suspect in the failed Times Square bombing, an event that helped stoke an uproar over the center. The arrest was on May 3, not on May 4.

KABUL, Afghanistan - Memorial services inevitably have their awkward moments. So did Thursday's gathering of Kabul's international community to remember the 10 slain aid workers, held at the old British Cemetery in Kabul, around the corner from Chicken Street. Presiding over the affair was Geoff Robinson, the grandmaster of the Kabul Hash, that quirkily British social and athletic event. An Australian engineer, he was drafted partly because he knew one of the victims, Dr. Karen Woo, the British surgeon, and partly because he was a confident public speaker.

8 P.M. (Disney) DEN BROTHER (2010) In this original movie, Hutch Dano (''Zeke and Luther'') plays Alex Pearson, a narcissistic high school hockey star who is force-fed a lesson in teamwork after pulling a stunt that leads to suspension from the rink, a bottomless list of chores and baby-sitting for his little sister, Emily (G. Hannelius). When she talks Alex into coming to the aid of her Bumble Bee troop, it looks as if perhaps he really had learned the concept of charity. What the girls don't know is that Alex has a lot to gain from his act of kindness -- like the attention of Matisse Burrows (Kelsey Chow, above right with Mr. Dano and Ms. Hannelius), the school babe who won't give him the time of day. What Alex doesn't know is how much his life is about to change. 8 P.M. (Fuse) LOLLAPALOOZA 2010 Allison Hagendorf and Juliya report from Grant Park in Chicago, where Lady Gaga, Green Day and the reunited Soundgarden headlined this three-day rock festival, which ended on Sunday. The hourlong special packs in interviews with MGMT, Perry Farrell and Cypress Hill, as well as a behind-the-scenes tour from B.o.B. and an acoustic performance by Phoenix. ''No. 1 Countdown: Lollapalooza All Stars,'' at 9, offers videos from veterans of the festival, like Kanye West and the Red Hot Chili Peppers.

An article on Wednesday about the debate over nuclear power in Germany misstated the contribution of nuclear power to the nation's energy mix. It provides about 11 percent of Germany's total energy supply, not 11 percent of its electricity. (Its contribution to electricity output averages about 26 percent.)

Reliever Ryota Igarashi may have brought new meaning to the phrase taxi squad with his scrambling efforts to get to Citi Field on Thursday, an amusing affair on a grim day for the Mets. With Francisco Rodriguez on the restricted list for two games after he was arrested on an assault charge, the Mets called up Igarashi from Class AAA Buffalo to replace him. The Bisons were in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., on Thursday when the Mets reached out to Igarashi's interpreter, Mike Phillips, at 9:30 a.m. and told him to get Igarashi to Flushing as quickly as possible.

HUME--Stephen N.,84, Hilton Head Island, SC died August 11, 2010. He was predeceased by wife Lacey Hall Hume and survived by present wife Nancy Ludington Hume, son Peter Hume, son Dr. Gregory (Charlaine) Hume, daughter Martha (Paul) Clark and grandchildren Jennifer Hadsell, Thomas Hadesll, Kimley Primavera and Teron Cox. Born in New Milford, CT, son of May Hume and Dr. Nelson Hume, founding headmaster of Canterbury School. Mr. Hume graduated from Canterbury in '43, enlisted in the Navy, commissioned Ensign and served in the Pacific Theater. He graduated from Yale (BA '47) and Columbia Universities (JD '50) and was a partner of Cramer & Anderson, New Milford, for 39 years. Mr. Hume's extensive public service included eight years chair New Milford Board of Education; 10 years chair New Milford Hospital Board of Directors and 15 years service Canterbury School Board of Trustees. The memorial service at Canterbury School will be on September 18.

EILER--Jim, 83, Actor, writer, director, and founder of The Prince Street Players, Ltd. died on July 20th at his home in Boca Raton, FL. David Lile, his life-partner of 45 years, announced his death. Mr. Eiler created Broadway style musicals for young audiences. CBS-TV produced four National Emmy Winning Specials of his work starting in 1965 which are considered some of the finest ever created for children. Critics praised his songs and clever updating of the classic fairy tales "Pinocchio, "Jack and The Beanstalk," "Emperor's New Clothes" and "Aladdin," calling them "Sparkling and humorous", noting, "adults enjoyed them as much, or more, than the children." Born in Granite City, Illinois, Mr. Eiler's early career included the Nat. Companies of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," and "Kismet" (Omar Khayyam). He appeared in major stock productions playing comedy leads. His favorite was Og, the leprechaun, in "Finian's Rainbow." Performing aboard ship on a lengthy world tour, there was constant need for new material which he could quickly supply. On his return to NY this talent led to writing "special material" for many stars, and eventually to the founding of the Prince Street Players. He will be remembered by the many actors and directors who got their first break performing in a Prince Street show. All eleven of his scripts and scores are now leased throughout the world by Music Theatre International. His legacy is a joyous one of shared love and laughter through his words and music.

I've always sort of known this, but wasn't able to articulate it until I read the article.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Igor Sutyagin, who was freed last month by Russia in a spy swap after being imprisoned there for 11 years, misidentified the office that Vladimir V. Putin assumed in August 1999, two months before Mr. Sutyagin was accused of espionage. He became Russia's prime minister, not its president. (Mr. Putin, a former K.G.B. colonel, became acting president on Dec. 31, 1999, when Boris Yeltsin resigned; Mr. Putin was elected president in 2000, and held that office until 2008, when he became prime minister again.)

And these buyers were stuck - walking away, they were told, would mean the loss of their down payments.

An article on Friday about cultural life on Governors Island referred imprecisely in some editions to the role that the Trust for Governors Island plays in bringing exhibitions and events to the island. While the trust and its president, Leslie Koch, influence which organizations come to the island, they do not select them. 8 P.M. (Showtime) INGLOURIOUS BASTERDS (2009) Christoph Waltz won an Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as Col. Hans Landa, a charming, nattily dressed Nazi in this sixth feature from Quentin Tarantino. Brad Pitt, above, plays Lt. Aldo Raine, the leader of a pack of Jewish avengers. ''As usual Mr. Tarantino gives you a lot to chew on, though there's plenty to gag on as well,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Much depends on whether you can just groove on his framing and staging, his swooping crane shots, postmodern flourishes (Samuel L. Jackson in voice-over explaining the combustibility of nitrate prints) and gorgeously saturated colors, one velvety red in particular.'' The film serves as a testament to Mr. Tarantino's ''movie love,'' she said, rather than to his interest in history. The problem, she added, ''is that by making the star attraction of his latest film a most delightful Nazi, one whose smooth talk is as lovingly presented as his murderous violence, Mr. Tarantino has polluted that love.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson reports on Project 100 Percent, a controversial program in San Diego created to prevent welfare fraud. Opponents say the program treats those in need like criminals and discourages them from applying for welfare; the county government maintains that it's an ethical way to save taxpayer dollars. APPEL--Jonathan Bruce, December 18, 1974--July 29, 2010, passed away-- too young-- in Santa Monica, California. So loved by his family, friends and colleagues, his kindness, compassion, warmth, wit, and brilliant array of talents will be sorely missed. Jonathan was born and raised in Toronto, but educated, worked, and excelled in both Canada and in the United States. He loved all the arts and mastered many, from sculpture, painting and drawing to comedic improvisational theatre, from documentary to narrative film. He graduated from Upper Canada College in 1992 and entered the University of Michigan's School of Art & Design to study sculpture. There, he won the Jean Paul Slusser Gallery Prize and graduated Magna Cum Laude in 1997. In 2002 he earned a Masters of Fine Arts from New York University's Gallatin School of Individualized Study for his work in improvisational theatre and film. He served as musical assistant to Paul Shaffer on the movie Blues Brothers 2000, wrote two novels, and then polished his timing and quirky, lovable wit at Toronto's legendary Second City. In New York, he worked with Gotham City Improv and The Upright Citizens' Brigade, while he also pursued his dream of making improvisational narrative films. He wrote, produced, shot, and edited his films himself, yet he warmly welcomed others' contributions, always seeking to create community through art making. His works, accepted and shown at various film festivals, include: Falling Together; Snowdown; Play the Muse; Once Brothers. His last film, Souled Out Comedy, was shown in 2009 at New York's Friars Club Comedy Film Festival where it won the Audience Choice Award. In 2005, Jonathan married Allene Quincy and moved with her to Santa Monica where he continued his film work. Jonathan is survived in sorrow by his parents, Mark and Gail Appel, his sister Liz Appel, her partner Cobb Mixter, his Uncle David and Aunt Carol Appel, his cousins Jacqueline, Alex and James Appel, his aunts and uncles on the Levchenko side of the family, his former wife Allene and a wide circle of friends. Jonathan will be laid to rest at Toronto's Mount Pleasant Cemetery on August 19 at 1:00pm following a ceremony at the Visitation Centre ( 375 Mount Pleasant Road--East Gate) presided over by the Reverend Carol Luther, Episcopalian, of Marin County, California. The Appel family suggests that those who wish to celebrate Jonathan's life by making contributions may direct them to charities in support of theatre and the arts.

An article on Thursday about an Air Force officer's facing possible discharge under the military's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy, using information from an Air Force spokesman, misstated the status of the officer's case. BLUM--Howard Louria, of Solvang, CA, passed away at age 90. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Graduate of Horace Mann School in Riverdale and Haverford College, PA. It is a defining image of the American century, one that expressed the joy of a nation at its moment of greatest triumph: on the day the Japanese surrender in World War II was announced, a sailor grabbed a nurse in the middle of Times Square, bent her back and kissed her. That kiss on V-J Day was captured in at least two photographs -- one iconic, one merely famous. And for decades since, there have been debates. Who was the sailor? Who was the nurse? A number of people have staked claims, and countless stories have tried to sort them out.

Imagine being a slave in ancient Rome. Now remember being one. The second task, unlike the first, is crazy. If, as I'm guessing, you never were a slave in ancient Rome, it follows that you can't remember being one - but you can still let your imagination rip. With a bit of effort one can even imagine the impossible, such as discovering that Dick Cheney and Madonna are really the same person. It sounds like a platitude that fiction is the realm of imagination, fact the realm of knowledge.

SCHEURER--Edwin Charles, 77, died August 14th, 2010. The cause of death as Myelodisplastic Syndrome. Born June 1st 1933. Beloved husband of Edie (Raabin). Loving father of Lynne Norma Scheurer and her husband Peter Foster and Andrew Raabin Scheurer and his wife Juliette. Adored Poppa of Sarah Norma Rish, Noah Scheurer Rish, Edwin Charles Scheurer II and Rayna Louise Foster. Cherished brother of Joan Mintz and Donald. Devoted uncle, cousin and friend. Eddie grew up in the Bronx and went to DeWitt Clinton High School. He graduated from Upsala College. In 1955 he joined Frank B. Hall which became Aon. In 1956 he joined the Army and was stationed at the Pentagon in the Crypto Division. He married Edie Raabin on November 10th 1957 after 14 dates. On September 11 his office was on the 105th floor of Tower Two. He voted in the mayoral primary in the morning and arrived at the building two minutes after it was attacked. He saw the horrific site from the street. He never recovered from this and always felt guilty that his life was spared while thousands of young people were killed. It haunted him the rest of his life. He retired as Vice Chairman from Aon in 2008. Eddie embraced life. He was a loving and devoted family man in every way. His charm and charisma were captivating. His wonderful smile lit up a room and his presence was strongly felt anywhere he went. He loved the golf games and gin games with his buddies and was always there to lend a hand to anyone in need. His amazing disposition was enviable. He rarely saw the glass half filled-he saw it entirely full. Ed, representing the insurance industry, accompanied Mayor Lindsay to Japan. He was a former chairman of the insurance division of the UJA Federation. He was a board member and past chairman of the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation and worked tirelessly for this organization. Our gratitude to Dr. Stuart Orsher and his team who did all that could possibly be done in an impossible situation. Our very special thanks, appreciation and love to Dr. Richard Bader who for twenty years accompanied us from city to city, hospital to hospital and doctor to doctor. He guided and advised us in our multitude of medical decisions. We will forever be grateful to him. Contributions in Eddie's memory to the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation 1150 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128 would be greatly appreciated or a special charity of your choice. The family will receive at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave on Monday August 16th from 4-8pm. The funeral will be Tuesday, August 17th 2010 at 11:30am.

Will the entire known world eventually be a Unesco World Heritage Site? As of Sunday, 890 locations were designated by the World Heritage Committee as ''having outstanding universal value.'' On Monday, when the committee completed its consideration of new nominees, a new set of 21 places joined that list. The additions range from remote natural locations, like the central highlands of Sri Lanka, to well-trodden urban places, like Amsterdam's 17th-century canal belt. The committee also added four locations to their list of sites in danger, including the Everglades National Park in Florida. They removed the Galapagos Islands from that list as well, having found that significant progress had been made in combating ''threats posed by invasive species, unbridled tourism and over-fishing.'' (The islands remain on the larger site list.)

TAXI video screens, introduced by the Taxi and Limousine Commission in 2007 with the intention of providing useful information to riders, have turned into a loud and confusing visual stew of advertisements, entertainment and the occasional buried bit of information. We came up with a few suggestions for a cleaner screen design -- to make taxi rides more pleasant. (And maybe also to make it easier for passengers to avoid being overcharged.)

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Half the Holes, No Less the Charm,'' Aug. 9: I have seen the demise of the nine-hole golf course. The Bergen County golf facility at Rockleigh in New Jersey has an 18- and 9-hole course, which is a Robert Trent Jones design. Sad to say that the little nine-hole gem has seen better days. The 18-hole course attracts the county dollars for upkeep. On the nine-hole course, a drainage problem has shaved a par 4 down to a par 3 while a par 5 has been eliminated -- replaced with a makeshift par 3. Snagging a weekend morning tee time on the Rockleigh 18-hole course is tantamount to winning the lottery, but, conditions being what they are, one can pretty much get out on the nine-hole course at any time.

LONDON -- In the last few weeks, an unlikely image from the archives has created a commotion, raising questions about celebrity and justice, and where they could possibly intersect. The photograph shows the principal guests at a charity dinner given by Nelson Mandela in September 1997, at his presidential residence in Pretoria, South Africa. It's a panoply of people with disparate claims to fame: Mia Farrow, the actress; Imran Khan, the cricketer and politician from Pakistan; Quincy Jones, the American music impresario; Graca Machel, soon to become Mr. Mandela's wife.

The Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, agreed to in 1989 and now adopted by a majority of nations, was meant to stop the dumping of toxic waste in poor countries. But what if the waste arrives as a gift? In Agbogbloshie, a slum in Accra, the capital of Ghana, adults and children tear away at computers from abroad to get at the precious metals inside. The computers and other equipment in this digital cemetery come mainly from Europe and the United States, sometimes as secondhand donations meant to reduce the ''digital divide'' -- the disparity in computer access between poor nations and rich. As Pieter Hugo shows in these haunting photographs, the equipment often becomes part of a particularly toxic recycling business. In 2008, Greenpeace sampled the burned soil at Agbogbloshie and found high levels of lead, cadmium, antimony, PCBs and chlorinated dioxins. At the dump, the machines are dismantled and often burned to extract metals for resale. Copper is perhaps the most desirable, then brass, then aluminum, then zinc. Prices in Agbogbloshie are about four times below the international market price, but for the scavengers of the dump, the income is incentive enough. Many of the workers there are boys, sent by their families in the impoverished north of the country to work at the dump and send back what money they can. Toxic OUTBOX Additional photos are at nytimes.com/magazine.

The Practical Traveler column on Aug. 1, about ways to avoid high phone bills when traveling abroad, referred imprecisely to a Boingo Wireless plan for travelers who sign up for a $7.95 monthly fee. While the fee for that service, called the Boingo Mobile plan, includes Wi-Fi access for smartphones and mobile devices in hotels, restaurants, airports and more in over 70 countries, it does not provide access for computers. (A $59 plan called Boingo Global includes Wi-Fi access for both mobile devices and computers.)

Visitors in Barcelona rarely cross the city's broad Avinguda Diagonal, sticking close to the harborside Gothic quarter. But Barcelona natives love -- and many live in -- the quirky residential neighborhood of Gràcia, which fills the urban grid on Diagonal's north side, between Passeig de Gràcia and Passeig de Sant Joan. Once a separate town outside the city's (long-gone) medieval walls, Gràcia was eventually absorbed into the fabric of Barcelona. But it's never lost that village feeling and remains a jumble of narrow streets and tree-shaded plazas dotted with Art Nouveau architecture. Often the first address of 20-something natives and newly arrived expatriates, Gràcia today is a lot more vibrant -- and international -- than it used to be. ANDREW FERREN GOYA 18 Carrer Goya 18 Open less than a year, this charming wine shop already feels like a permanent neighborhood fixture. Specializing in vintages from small, artisan wineries (like a Rimarts cava, from 7.95 euros a bottle, $10.25 at $1.29 to the euro), it also stocks single-malt whiskeys and a wide range of prepared local delicacies, including partridge in escabeche (9.90 euros).

1961 FERRARI 250 SWB SEFAC HOT ROD A rare lightweight version of Ferrari's famous dual-purpose short-wheelbase Berlinetta, it is expected to bring from $6 million to $8 million at the Gooding & Company auction. Highly desirable -- and second only to the legendary 250 GTO in collectibility -- this represents the last of the front-engine Ferrari sports cars that were equally at home on road and racetrack.

KALMAN--C. A. "Joe", age 90, died Tuesday August 3. He was born in St. Paul, MN, August 20, 1919, the son of Charles Oscar Kalman and Alexandra Robertson. A graduate of St. Paul Academy, 1937, Mr. Kalman completed a B.S. degree in engineering and business administration at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1941. After MIT, he worked for two large shipbuilding concerns on Navy combat vessels and, then, the American Machine and Foundry Company. In 1950, he joined Booz Allen & Hamilton, management consultants, where he had a 35-year career as senior vice-president with clients primarily in transportation, aerospace, and telecommunications. He also served on a wide range of corporate directorships. Mr. Kalman was committed to supporting basic and medical research and served as a member of the International Council of the Salk Institute in La Jolla, CA. His other activities included membership in the Aspen Institute Society of Fellows, the Wings Club, New York Yacht Club, Wee Burn Country Club and the Tokeneke Club, where he enjoyed his greatest pleasure, playing the bass in the Club's Sunday jazz session. He is survived by his wife Diana Jacobs Kalman and two children by his first wife, Marie Dickey Kalman: Charles Eric Kalman of Woodland Hills, CA and Kristina Kalman Fares of Wilton, CT; and two grandchildren, Emile and Melissa Fares. Memorial contributions may be made to The Salk Institute 10010 North Torrey Pines Road, La Jolla, CA., 92037-1099. A service will be held September 11 at 11am, St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Road in Darien.

What if there was open competition at quarterback and nobody came? Or a bunch of nobodies came? The Bills are trying to answer those questions by letting Trent Edwards, Ryan Fitzpatrick and Brian Brohm battle for the starting job. Three developmental quarterbacks mean minimal development; Edwards has the slight edge over the others, but the man fans call ''Captain Checkdown'' has earned only faint praise from his new coach Chan Gailey.

LENART--Yvonne Ramus (Mrs. Harry Lenart). Born April 18, 1915 in Nova Scotia, Canada, died August 10, 2010 in Los Angeles, CA. Resident of Los Angeles since 1931. Predeceased in 1984 by her loving husband Harry. During her long life, Yvonne was surrounded by her brother's children: Ilene Ramus Secrist (Phoenix, AZ), Ronald and Dean Ramus and their respective spouses Anna and Marlene (Los Angeles, CA), grand niece Erica Secrist and grand nephew Ryan Secrist and by Harry's sister's children: "the Kingsley side of the family," now numbering 24 nieces, nephews, grands and great-grands. All were frequent visitors and houseguests in their beloved Aunt Yvonne's home. Yvonne, AKA "Probono Publico", was a long term Trustee of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, where she and her husband Harry provided significant support for the museum's collection of South and Southeast Asian art. Yvonne was a major donor to the UCLA Department of Humanities, most recently providing travel educational scholarships. Throughout her life she supported many organizations and institutions, including Planned Parenthood, UCLA Arts Council, The Associates of Southern California, The Arthritis Foundation, The Nature Conservancy, Neighborhood Youth Association and Family Service Los Angeles. The family, friends, associates and neighbors who were fortunate enough to share time with Yvonne will remember her as a life-long vegetarian and mentor who role-modeled integrity, graciousness, generosity and humility. Yvonne taught others the importance of striving to make a difference in the lives of others. When in her presence you always felt blessed and she never left your presence without saying, "Bless You." During the last four years of Yvonne's life, she was lovingly cared for by "Her Angels": Maria, Lily, Mayra, Eileen, Angie and Lisa RN. In lieu of flowers, tribute gifts can be made to: "The Yvonne Lenart Children's Education Fund" at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 5905 Wilshire Blvd., Los Angeles, CA 90036. A memorial service will be held at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art on September 11, 2010. Please call LACMA at 323-857-6521 for more information.

Charles Guislain was just 15 when he crashed his first Paris runway show, Gareth Pugh in 2008. For a petit ecolier, he cuts an unusual image, clad in an apocalyptic Rad Hourani chain mail sheath or a princely Martin Margiela cape with hooflike Rick Owens wedge boots. The fashion commentariat thinks of him as the goth counterpoint to the kooky, hat-loving Tavi, but Guislain is no blogger. He was discovered by the raspy-voiced cult fashion journalist Diane Pernet and became something of a flaxen-haired YouTube curiosity, and he was recently the subject of a spread in Italian Vogue. He's still in school, studying Rimbaud, Barthes, Proust - serious reading for a serious boy. ''I'm not really into parties, to be honest,'' Guislain says. He first fell in love with fashion at age 13, when he came across a pair of Dior Homme suspenders designed by his idol, Hedi Slimane. Now 17, he's already toying with retirement from the show-hopping scene: ''I need to escape European life. I am a little bored with this now, as there are too many rude people,'' he says. ''People forget that fashion can also be funny.''
Pop Ben Sisario

Q.I just moved to Orange County in California from the Midwest. I have friends coming to visit, and I am interested in exploring beaches and towns close to home. Any hints for Balboa Island or Newport Beach (or thereabouts)? A.Frommer's describes the Orange Coast as ''one of Southern California's best-kept secrets - a string of seaside jewels that have been compared with the French Riviera or the Costa del Sol.'' The coastline, more than 40 miles, offers pristine stretches of sand, tidal marine life, ecological preserves, secluded coves and legendary surf breaks.

Before he got to the Galapagos Islands, Charles Darwin spent two years studying the distinct flora and fauna of the southern tip of South America, making observations that came to influence his groundbreaking theory of natural selection. Though the Galapagos typically draw Darwin tours, two cruises aim to shadow the H.M.S. Beagle's less celebrated time in Tierra del Fuego. In October, the 64-cabin Via Australis from Cruceros Australis cruise line will ply the Strait of Magellan and the Beagle Channel between Punta Arenas, Chile, and Ushuaia, Argentina, on two Darwin-focused itineraries.

For years, researchers have known that exercise can affect certain moods. Running, bike riding and other exercise programs have repeatedly been found to combat clinical depression. Similarly, a study from Germany published in April found that light-duty activity like walking or gardening made participants ''happy,'' in the estimation of the scientists. Even laboratory rats and mice respond emotionally to exercise; although their precise ''moods'' are hard to parse, their behavior indicates that exercise makes them more relaxed and confident. But what about anger, one of the more universal and, in its way, destructive moods? Can exercise influence how angry you become in certain situations?
International A FADING CULTURE,

RUDD--Paul Ryan, 70, passed away on August 12, 2010 at his home in Greenwich, CT, of pancreatic cancer. Mr. Rudd was surrounded by, and is survived by his wife Martha Bannerman and their children, Graeme, Kathryn and Eliza. He is also survived by his mother Kathryn Rudd of Hingham, MA and numerous cousins. Mr. Rudd was born in 1940 in Boston, MA and attended the Boston Latin School and Assumption Prep. He graduated from Fairfield University. After a brief career in advertising in New York City, Mr. Rudd worked as a professional actor and director both on and off-Broadway from 1967 through 1986. Notable roles include Henry V in Henry V at the Delacorte Theater, Scooper in the original Broadway cast of Bosoms and Neglect, Romeo in Romeo and Juliet at Circle In The Square, Gentleman Caller in the original Broadway cast of The Glass Menagerie, and Billy Wilson in the premiere of David Rabe's Streamers. His television and film credits include Brian Mallory in Beacon Hill, JFK in Johnny We Hardly Knew Ye, and guest roles in episodes of Moonlighting, Knot's Landing, Hart to Hart, and Murder, She Wrote. In 1986 Mr. Rudd left acting to raise his children. As they grew, he began teaching theater, especially Shakespeare, and poetry in local middle schools and high schools. He continued his teaching career at Sarah Lawrence College (1999-2006) and the New School for Drama (2004-present) as a teaching faculty member and the Associate Director of the MFA Drama program. His passion and enthusiasm as a teacher inspired deep admiration and affection in his many students. Mr. Rudd's keen intellect, irreverent sense of humor, and vivacity were present in all facets of his life. He delighted in music, literature, art, cooking, and the company of his friends. His greatest joy was that of being a father and a husband. A service will be held this Sunday, August 15th at 2pm at Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, CT.

''It worked wonders.'' - Leslie-Ann Ogiste of Boston, who along with her 9-year old son received vegetable prescription vouchers that encouraged her to buy healthier food at a nearby farmers' market. She says that they have been eating fewer snacks and sodas.

SILBERFEIN--Michael L, age 71, of Fort Lee, on August 13, 2010. Founder and former owner of Riverdale Bus Company. Beloved husband of Jane (nee Engelhardt). Devoted father of Andrew (Amy), James (Diane) and the late Richard (Carol). Cherished grandfather of Joshua, Julie, Rebecca, Tori and Matthew. Period of morning Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, 1-4pm and 7-9pm at his residence. For info www.edenmemorial.com or Call (201)947-EDEN.

The five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for Aug. 7 to Aug. 13. 1. CYCLISTS SAID TO BACK CLAIMS THAT ARMSTRONG DOPED Federal prosecutors have intensified their criminal investigation of the cyclist Lance Armstrong since the end of the Tour de France.
Living until 150 years old is impossible in the natural world. But it is not impossible in the world of Japanese public administration.

TEICH--Victor, 93, died August 12. Union activist, teacher, documentary filmmaker. Beloved wife Selma died 1990. Children Judy (Tom), David and Esther (Jerry), grandchildren Stephanie, Andrea, Joey, Rebecca, Stephen, companion Peggy Watson and her niece Clay Dilworth, loving family, many friends. Burial Monday, 1pm, Mt. Hebron, Queens. Memorial, October in East Hampton. Donations: Murder Victims' Families for Reconciliation.

A listing in the Westchester Calendar last Sunday for the Music Conservatory of Westchester's Benefit Concert misstated the date and the Web site for the concert. It will be held on Thursday, not on Tuesday, and the Web site is augustconcert.eventbrite.com -- not the conservatory's site, musicconservatory.org.

LUSTBADER--Pearl, 87, of Greenwich Village, NY passed away peacefully at home on August 13, 2010. She loved New York City, theater, and an occasional glass of Dewar's. Devoted wife and mother, she is survived by her sons Ned and Ken and was predeceased by her adoring husband Fred. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, NYC, 10003.

HAVEN, Wis. - The PGA Tour has felt more and more of an international affair of late, and there is no shortage of metrics to show as much. Foreign-born players winning 17 of the 35 events on the Tour so far this year, and 13 of the top 20 players in the world rankings hail from elsewhere than the United States, to cite two. And if an international player wins the P.G.A. Championship here at Whistling Straits in what is golf's last major of the year, it will be the first time in two decades that United States-born golfers have been limited to only one major championship.

No matter what you've encountered while scuba diving, chances are you've never seen anything as dramatic as a firsthand view of 14 underwater stagehands navigating 630 cues for a Las Vegas show with synchronized swimmers. This unusual form of aquatic life is on view at the Wynn Las Vegas, where certified scuba divers can get a behind-the-scenes look at ''Le Reve'' as part of a new two-night package.

Two consumer safety groups are asking the Federal Trade Commission to order Enterprise Rent-A-Car to start fixing every vehicle with a safety recall before renting them to consumers. The groups say the request highlights the lack of a requirement that rental companies must fix recalled vehicles before renting them. The request comes about three months after Enterprise admitted in a California court that its failure to fix a Chrysler PT Cruiser was responsible for the deaths of two California women when it caught fire and crashed.

MANHATTAN Hudson Heights . . . . . . . . $342,500 900 West 190th Street, Cabrini Terrace r 1 f 1 h 0 o 5 weeks 730-sq.-ft. co-op in a postwar building; Hudson River view, 24-hr. doormen, dining alcove w/window, h/w floors; maintenance $729, 42% tax deductible; listed at $375,000. Broker: Simone Song Properties.

THE newly revamped W now comes with a slanted logo, as if to say, ''Let's go!'' The energized logo might be the most promising thing about the magazine, which has a new editor, Stefano Tonchi, formerly the editor of T: The New York Times Magazine, as well as a new creative director, Jody Quon. I've been a reader of W since its broadsheet days, when it was driven by the curiosity and often deliciously snippy tongue of its founder, John Fairchild. In 2000, I wrote a profile of its then creative director, Dennis Freedman, and the way he cultivated photographers and helped bring to life sometimes-difficult ideas in fashion and art. In its long history W, at its best, was a scrappy journalistic player with a knowing sense of the people it covered. Though Mr. Tonchi will need to produce several more issues before his W can be assessed fairly, it is clear from the September issue that he wants to restore its journalistic flavor. The cover tagline promises ''Who, What, Where, When, and Why in the World of Style,'' and the inside pages are spelled out accordingly. The front-of-the-book has the usual newsy blend of features on fashion, beauty and travel, with some of the photography and layouts lacking a sharpness that would help separate them from the ads. There is a lengthy profile of Riccardo Tisci of Givenchy that describes his friendships with Marina Abramovic and Courtney Love. Party coverage is scant, though that will probably change in time. I thought the fashion spreads were generally strong - in particular, a feature shot in Brooklyn by Mert and Marcus, with right-on styling by Alex White, and Tim Walker's sweet images of eccentric young Londoners. (I adored a young man named Scottee who favors adult baby clothes.)

STATER--Phroso, 94, of Cliffside Park, NJ, on August 3, 2010. Graduated from Northfield Mount Hermon and Oberlin. Retired from Union Carbide. Survived by two nieces and one nephew: Suzanne Hope Graham, South Nyack, NY, Margaret Hope, Mechanicsburg, PA and Thomas Stater Hope, South Gouldsboro, ME. Memorial service 11am Saturday, August 21, Grantwood Congregational Church, 264 Columbia Avenue, Cliffside Park. Donations in her memory may be made to the Cliffside Park Free Public Library, 781 Palisade Avenue, Cliffside Park, New Jersey 07010.

During Vintage Dance Week in Newport, R.I., held from Aug. 1 to 6, participants spent part of their daytime hours in character, going to tea dances and touring mansions while dressed as visitors would have been from the 1850s to the 1920s. Some subjects seemed to have stepped right out of a seaside painting by Monet. Others recalled Winterhalter's canvas of Empress Eugénie at a picnic. Left, at Easton's Beach, a dance, carousel rides and strolls among bikinied bathers. Below, a visit to Marble House, the summer cottage of William K. Vanderbilt, which has a teahouse. Right, a luncheon and tea dance at Linden Place, an 1810 mansion in Bristol, R.I.

THE STONE I suspect that the day Britney Spears shaved her own hair off represented a kind of Sartrean or Socratic argument, rather than, say, a nervous breakdown. She was, in effect, shrewdly de-mythifying beauty. The hair lies on the floor, ''inexplicably faded'' and the conventional notion of femininity does too. I see Marilyn Monroe and Brigitte Bardot in a similar light: both -- one by dying, the other by remaining alive -- deviated from and deflated their iconic status. The beautiful is not some far-flung abstraction. Beauty is a thing, whereas I am no-thing. And that explains why I can never be truly beautiful, even if it doesn't stop me wanting to be. Perhaps this explains why Camus, Sartre's more dashing sparring partner, jotted down in his notebooks, ''Beauty is unbearable and drives us to despair.'' -- Andy Martin, excerpt from

POLISAR--Jane. August 13, 2010. Beloved daughter of Roslyn; sister of Donna, Patti, Nicky; Federal judge with a distinguished public service career; generous to friends and the arts. Smart, funny and brave; sophisticated with a touch of kindergarten. Can't help loving that Jane of ours. For memorial details: honJP3@gmail.com

1958 FERRARI 250 TESTA ROSSA This immensely successful racecar is very rare, given that only 21 pontoon fender cars were built. A similar Testa Rossa with a more extensive racing history was sold in Italy in May 2009 (by RM Auctions, which is also offering this car) for $12.4 million. The Testa Rossa is the car that built Ferrari's racing reputation. If the reserve is met and the car sells, it is likely to be the top sale of the weekend.

The Web has changed the way that artisans sell their wares, helping to overcome marketing and distribution hurdles. Now, thanks to Web sites like Etsy, DaWanda, 1000 Markets, ArtFire and Silkfair, people all over the world can see -- and buy -- handmade jewelry, clothing, artwork, ceramics and furniture. Etsy, the largest of the sites, has grown to 5.5 million members from 1 million just two years ago; the total value of the goods it sold was $180 million in 2009, more than double that of 2008. And many Websavvy artisans aren't stopping there. They're creating their own Web sites and sending out marketing blasts through their Twitter and Facebook accounts -- bringing a modern twist to the oldfashioned cottage industry. John T. Unger, hand-cuts steel fire bowls in Mancelona, Mich. Selling mainly through 1000 Markets and his own Web site, johntunger.com, he had gross sales of $188,000 last year.

Styled to a T takes the trends to the streets. Pretty much every follower of fashion has a case of Phoebe fever right now, but personally I am hot for the matching tunic and pants looks like the ones she showed for Celine Resort. At a moment when sundresses are all too ubiquitous, this combo provides a fresh way to beat the oppressive summer heat. I like a monochrome version - a neutral color worn top to bottom - but to avoid looking like you're wearing scrubs (or Lindsay Lohan's prison garb) add some great accessories worthy of Anjelica Huston in the 1970s. Gold and graphic jewelry, like symmetrical cuffs from Repossi, and a clean, envelope clutch in an exotic skin keep the look polished and urban. This long silhouette looks great - and even more attenuated - with heels, but if it's easy breezy you're after, these simple leather flat sandals from K. Jacques do the trick.

WILSON--John H.T. The board and staff of Environmental Defense Fund mourn the death of John H.T. Wilson, who served on the board for 20 years and as its chairman from 1997 to 2002. With his natural warmth and wonderful sense of humor, John could always be counted on to guide us through even the most difficult of decisions. He oversaw a doubling of EDF's capacity, shepherding the growth and impact of our climate, oceans and ecosystems programs and guiding our first strategic plan. Whether rafting down the Colorado River or presiding over a board meeting, John showed a passionate love for the environment and gave selflessly to protect it. Our thoughts are with his beloved wife, Sandy, his children, Emily, David, Will and Tucker, and his grandchildren. He will be greatly missed. Carl Ferenbach, Chairman, Board of Trustees Fred Krupp, President

An article last Sunday about the longtime sports broadcaster Dick Enberg's new job as the San Diego Padres' announcer misstated a brand of sausage that Enberg took note of when the Padres played at Milwaukee's Miller Park on Beerfest Night. It is Johnsonville, not Nashville.

The Webster, a South Beach luxury boutique, has transformed the ground floor of the 20,000-square-foot space into a surfing-inspired pop-up store called Surf the Webster. Conceived in collaboration with Timothee Verrecchia (the editor of L'Officiel Homme and the multi-hyphenate behind such disparate ventures as the new Cafe Gitane at the Jane Hotel and D.J.'ing with his brother as Tim & Vass), it's intended to educate shoppers about Florida's surf culture. Along with the surfboards, books and accessories will be educational talks and panels intended to create a community for surfers. The swell store, which is open until Aug. 31, also offers a variety of exclusive products, including Basta Swimsuits, original prints from the pro surfer turned photographer Danny Fuller and surfboards by both Baron Wells and SoHo's own surf shop, Saturdays. A bonus of visiting the Collins Avenue store is that 10 percent of the proceeds will benefit the Surfrider Foundation, which promotes protection and enjoyment of the world's beaches. Get amped, dude.

The races were a week away and the Dragonflies were anxious. Their strokes were not in sync; the first five looked a little choppy and confused. They were digging deeper into the water than they should have at the start. They had entered GPS data into Google Earth and found their speed was 10 kilometers an hour; the ideal was 12.5.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the emergence of the queue in India overstated what was known about the nationalities of the people shown in line. While the they were gathered outside a hospital in India, they were not necessarily Indians.

An article last Sunday about the improving performance of international players on the PGA Tour misstated the number of years since American golfers were limited to a single victory in the four major professional tournaments. It has been two years, not 20. (International players swept all four tournaments in 1994.)

VINTAGE DANCE WEEK was started by Hannah Roberts Artuso, a Boston lawyer, 26 years ago to revive the ballroom dances of the 1850s to the 1920s. From Aug. 1 to 6, dancers once again filled the grand ballrooms of Newport and Bristol, R.I., dressed in the style of the respective eras and ready for a waltz, polka, cakewalk, quadrille or grand march. The New River Dance Orchestra from Connecticut provided the music. The week's events are open to the public by subscription, which includes housing at Roger Williams University. The number of guests is limited by the size of the Gilded Age ballrooms: this year, 95 attended.

Updated, 3:28 p.m., Aug. 10 | The fracas on Monday aboard a JetBlue plane at Kennedy International Airport has us thinking at City Room - and wanting to hear from you. Have you ever, like Steven Slater, the flight attendant on JetBlue Flight 1052 from Pittsburgh, reached your absolute limit of aggravation and annoyance at work? Have you ever wanted to deploy an inflatable evacuation slide on the job and get out of Dodge? Have you ever witnessed someone else in such a meltdown? Call into our Last Straw Hotline at (646) 402-5679, extension 84022, to leave a voice mail relating your story or commenting on the events on Flight 1052. Or, use the comments section below to share your I'm-not-going-to-take-this-anymore experiences. We will be compiling your voice mails and posts here on City Room as long as you keep sending them.

''It seems to me that when we speak of the fully adult human person, we must be speaking of Man and Woman. So, there will always be plenty of ballet stories to tell.'' JAMIE BALLENGER of Charlottesville, Va., responding to Alastair Macaulay's column about narrative and ballet.

WHAT was the last thing you bought at Wal-Mart? Some toothpaste? A futon? Whatever it was, it probably didn't cost $2 million. You would not, however, be hard pressed to spend such a figure on the Walton family's personal real estate.

FINDLAY--Cuyler W.,died at his home in New Canaan, CT, July 19 of complications following ten years of Alzheimer's. He was 77 years old. Mr. Findlay enjoyed a 30-year career with Scudder, Stevens & Clark, Inc., a privately owned investment counseling firm founded in 1919 in New York City and Boston. He began as an investment counselor managing institutional accounts and upon retirement in 1998, he held the titles of Managing Director, Scudder Board of Directors; Chairman and Trustee of the AARP Investment Program; and Senior Vice-President and Director of Scudder Investor Services. He was instrumental in starting Scudder's first money market mutual fund which launched in 1974, setting a new standard within the financial industry. Outside of his career, Mr. Findlay took great pleasure in his work with the New Canaan Nature Center, bird watching, gardening and looking through his telescopes at the night sky. He was a member of The Country Club of New Canaan, The Sea Island Club and Ocean Forest Golf Club. Described by many as a "Southern Gentleman," Mr. Findlay was known for his interest in nature, his enthusiasm for dancing and music, and for his dedication to family. Mr. Findlay is survived by his wife of 56 years, four children and seven grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to the Findlay Scholars Program, Wesleyan College, 4760 Forsyth Road, Macon, GA 31210.

WILSON--John H.T. Classroom, Inc. mourns the passing of John H.T. Wilson, our beloved colleague and friend. John was one of the Founders of Classroom, Inc. and Treasurer of the Board for over 15 years. He was exceptionally generous with both his time and resources and deeply committed to helping the hundreds of thousands of at-risk students we have served since 1991 have the opportunity to achieve success in school. We have greatly benefited from his wisdom, intelligence, energy and enthusiasm. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Sandy and all of his family. Lewis Bernard, Chairman Jane Canner, President

SILVERBERG--Gittel, 79, died peacefully at home after a long illness. Her family was the center of her universe. Beloved wife of Mervin, her soulmate since they met at camp when she was 15. Adored mother to Shonni and John, Lori, Robbin and Andras, Yael and Tacy, and Jordanna. The very best Bubbe imaginable to Zachary, Nathaniel, Tova, Jared, Teagan, Maya, Lilly and Menyus. Survived also by loving sisters and brothers in law Ruth and Dan Frankfurt, Esther and Irv Beckman and Seymour and Terri Silverberg and a large extended family in the US, Canada and Israel. Born in Montreal, Canada in 1930, Gittel was educated at Jewish People's School, Baron Bing High School, McGill University and Sarah Lawrence College, where she was a member of the 2nd class of graduates in the then new field of Genetic Counseling. Retired in 2000 after many productive years as the senior genetic counselor at North Shore University Hospital. Steadfast supporter of the Jewish community at home, in Israel and around the world. A woman of boundless enthusiasm who will be missed by all who knew her. Donations can be made to the Gittel Silverberg Fund, Joan Marks Graduate Program in Human Genetics, Sarah Lawrence College, Advancement Office, 1 Mead Way, Bronxville, NY 10708. Funeral service August 16, 12pm noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

THE NEWS Worries that the fragile recovery was faltering sent stock markets around the world sharply lower and prompted the Federal Reserve to buy government securities to keep interest rates low. BEHIND THE NEWS The Fed, led by Ben S. Bernanke, has revised its earlier, more optimistic outlook. Britain and China cut their forecasts for growth, and the Dow Jones industrial average slid about 3 percent for the week as nervous investors looked for safe bets. One bright spot was austerity-minded Germany, posting its best quarterly performance since reunification.

MacKINNON--Robert Harold. It is with great sadness that Bob MacKinnon's family announces his sudden death from heart failure on July 6, at age 74, in Cape Cod, MA. Survivors include his wife Ilse; daughter Elizabeth Henrici; stepchildren Chase and Peter Livingston; six grandchildren; and four siblings: Lois Davis, Jean Rogers, Richard MacKinnon, and William MacKinnon. A public memorial service will be held in the chapel of Northfield Mount Hermon School, Mount Hermon, MA, on Saturday, September 11, at 2:00pm following a 1:00pm gathering for out-of-town guests at the school's Mary E. MacKinnon Cottage. After the chapel service there will be a reception at the headmaster's residence. Bob MacKinnon was born in Schenectady, NY on November 22, 1935 to Harold Alexander MacKinnon and the former Mary Ethel Costello. He attended Schenectady public schools, and for high school went to Northfield Mount Hermon (1953), on whose Board of Trustees he later served with great distinction. Bob was also an alumnus of Yale University (B.A., 1957) and Harvard Law School (L.L.D., 1960). Throughout his student days he was active in Boy Scouts, athletics, and singing. Following Harvard, Bob entered the U.S. Army Reserve, and in New York commenced a life-long career with the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, from which he retired as a senior partner in 2001 and counselor in 2007. As an attorney he was a respected leader and mentor, active in his firm's governance while founding and leading its practice areas in bankruptcy, reorganization, and private finance. Bob was a truly global practitioner, having worked in Shearman & Sterling offices in five countries. He was an advisor to and director of multiple American and international corporations. Amidst all of these responsibilities, Bob MacKinnon took great satisfaction in the building and naming of the Mary E. MacKinnon Cottage, a student residence at Northfield Mount Hermon, as a memorial to his late mother.
Dance Jack Anderson

With apologies to Gran Tursimo, Forza Motorsport, Project Gotham and any number of hyperrealistic, console-based racing simulators and video games, arguably none channels the visceral thrill of hurtling around a course like the futuristic Wipeout series. Now, a German art collective has rendered that thrill tactile, using defiantly analog components: cardboard, glue and vintage-video-arcade kitsch. Called (with a wink) Racer 0.2, the project is the creation of three media artists collectively known as Sputnic.

KALIK--Allen, died on August 14, 2010 at the age of 59, leaving behind his best friend and life partner Patricia Kalik and their children Lisa and Daniel Kalik. He is survived by his parents Betty and Larry Kalik, his sister Millie Kalik and his nieces and nephews Melanie, Julie, David, Jessica, Zach, Kylie, Josh, Danielle and Emily. He was born on September 17, 1950 and grew up in New York City. He graduated from Cornell University in 1972 and went from teacher to ski bum to successful entrepreneur, all while windsurfing around the world, speaking French and playing acoustic guitar to whoever would listen. Forever passionate in life and in his fight against cancer, he left peacefully with all of his loved ones nearby. Funeral service to be held Monday, August 16 at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City. Memorial Service to be held in Manchester, New Hampshire at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center: 866-815-9501 or http://mskcc.convio.net/.

I will be based in London for about a month in September. I want to take an overnight trip to York and Durham to see York Minster and Durham Cathedral. Does it make sense to go to Durham first and then stop at York on my way back to London, or go to York and then make my way to Durham? Which is the better city to find inexpensive overnight lodgings? Nina Koenigsberg, New York

1972-73 PORSCHE 917 INTERSERIE SPYDER An open version of Porsche's most famous endurance racer. While this is not the iconic coupe version that won at Le Mans -- this car competed in the European Interserie championship -- 917s rarely come to market, so bidding is likely to be active. The auction company, Bonhams & Butterfields, declined to publish a presale estimate, but 917s can change hands at seven-figure prices.

BLUM--Howard Louria, of Solvang, CA, passed away at age 90. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Graduate of Horace Mann School in Riverdale and Haverford College, PA. Proudly served as Lieutenant Commander in the U.S. Navy, World War II Pacific theater. He was Senior Vice President, National Sales Director of Julius Wile Sons & Co., importers of wines and spirits. Survived by his devoted wife, Janine, sons Ward, Tom and Bill, step-daughters Susan, Jo Ann and Patty, and their families. Burial private, in New York.

A article last Sunday about the changing Republican stance on immigration misspelled the given name of a Republican senator from South Carolina who first raised repealing the 14th Amendment, which grants citizenship to anyone born in the United States. He is Lindsey Graham, not Lindsay. The article also referred imprecisely to the 100,000 people forced to relocate to camps during World War II. While they were of Japanese descent, they were not necessarily Japanese immigrants. (Most were American-born citizens.)

Donations in her memory may be sent to Children's Guardian Fund, PO Box 49722, Sarasota, Florida 34230.
