FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel heads to Guatemala, where he finds a $100-a-week home stay with a Tz'utujil-speaking family in a town called San Juan La Laguna on Lake Atitlán.

For children, the playground means a chance to stretch their legs and imaginations, while their parents, in increasing numbers, exercise their thumbs. With a so-called smartphone seemingly at every adult's fingertips, many parents are finding playtime to be the ideal time for answering e-mails, firing off text messages and browsing the Web - leaving their children to cavort about virtually unattended at playgrounds, pools and kiddie gyms. In the past few weeks alone, I saw a father by the sandbox at our local playground tapping away at his BlackBerry as his son repeatedly grabbed toy trucks from my 4-year-old. Another father essentially ignored his daughter's repeated questions, his left hand pushing her on the swing while his right deftly manipulated a smartphone. And a mother at the town pool stared at her digital companion as her way-too-big-for-the-kiddie-pool lout of a son trampled my 2-year-old.

To the Sports Editor: It looks like Jerry Manuel might have inadvertently discovered the answer to the Mets' bullpen problems: leave the starter in the game. How much worse could Jon Niese's or Mike Pelfrey's eighth innings be than those perpetrated by their relief?Robert A. Myers

APPEL--Jonathan Bruce, December 18, 1974--July 29, 2010, passed away-- too young-- in Santa Monica, California. So loved by his family, friends and colleagues, his kindness, compassion, warmth, wit, and brilliant array of talents will be sorely missed. Jonathan was born and raised in Toronto, but educated, worked, and excelled in both Canada and in the United States. He loved all the arts and mastered many, from sculpture, painting and drawing to comedic improvisational theatre, from documentary to narrative film. He graduated from Upper Canada College in 1992 and entered the University of Michigan's School of Art & Design to study sculpture. There, he won the Jean Paul Slusser Gallery Prize and graduated Magna Cum Laude in 1997. In 2002 he earned a Masters of Fine Arts from New York University's Gallatin School of Individualized Study for his work in improvisational theatre and film. He served as musical assistant to Paul Shaffer on the movie Blues Brothers 2000, wrote two novels, and then polished his timing and quirky, lovable wit at Toronto's legendary Second City. In New York, he worked with Gotham City Improv and The Upright Citizens' Brigade, while he also pursued his dream of making improvisational narrative films. He wrote, produced, shot, and edited his films himself, yet he warmly welcomed others' contributions, always seeking to create community through art making. His works, accepted and shown at various film festivals, include: Falling Together; Snowdown; Play the Muse; Once Brothers. His last film, Souled Out Comedy, was shown in 2009 at New York's Friars Club Comedy Film Festival where it won the Audience Choice Award. In 2005, Jonathan married Allene Quincy and moved with her to Santa Monica where he continued his film work. Jonathan is survived in sorrow by his parents, Mark and Gail Appel, his sister Liz Appel, her partner Cobb Mixter, his Uncle David and Aunt Carol Appel, his cousins Jacqueline, Alex and James Appel, his aunts and uncles on the Levchenko side of the family, his former wife Allene and a wide circle of friends. Jonathan will be laid to rest at Toronto's Mount Pleasant Cemetery on August 19 at 1:00pm following a ceremony at the Visitation Centre ( 375 Mount Pleasant Road--East Gate) presided over by the Reverend Carol Luther, Episcopalian, of Marin County, California. The Appel family suggests that those who wish to celebrate Jonathan's life by making contributions may direct them to charities in support of theatre and the arts.

An article last Sunday about classic Blue Note jazz recordings being rereleased on vinyl misidentified the Web site for Music Matters Jazz, one of the companies that makes these records. It is musicmattersjazz.com -- not musicmatters.com, a site devoted to music education.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, July 31st 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. HUME--Stephen N.,84 Hilton Head Island, SC died August 11, 2010. He was predeceased by wife Lacey Hall Hume and survived by present wife Nancy Ludington Hume, son Peter Hume, son Dr. Gregory (Charlaine) Hume, daughter Martha (Paul) Clark and grandchildren Jennifer Hadsell, Thomas Hadesll, Kimley Primavera and Teron Cox. Born in New Milford, CT, son of May Hume and Dr. Nelson Hume, founding headmaster of Canterbury School. Mr. Hume graduated from Canterbury in '43, enlisted in the Navy, commissioned Ensign and served in the Pacific Theater. He graduated from Yale (BA '47) and Columbia Universities (JD '50) and was a partner of Cramer & Anderson, New Milford, for 39 years. Mr. Hume's extensive public service included eight years chair New Milford Board of Education; 10 years chair New Milford Hospital Board of Directors and 15 years service Canterbury School Board of Trustees. The memorial service at Canterbury School will be on September 18. Memorials may be sent to the Hume Endowment for Music at Canterbury School, 101 Aspetuck Ave, New Milford, CT 06776.

If you were lucky enough to be invited to Richard Olney’s for lunch in the dry and scratchy hills outside Sollies-Toucas, north of Toulon in Provence, two things were certain: That you would have a meal you would never forget, and that he would greet you in his herb and vegetable garden in a pair of beat-up espadrilles, a ravaged shirt left completely unbuttoned and a tiny excuse for a bathing suit. Because he was always running back and forth between the garden and kitchen to check on whatever was on the hob, a dish towel hung in his waistband.

When fashion editors were given an intimate viewing of Alexander McQueen’s final collection in Paris this past spring, this dress was not part of it. Perhaps the last piece touched by the designer’s hands, it was made by McQueen especially for his longtime friend Annabelle Neilson, and its only outing has been to Elton John’s White Tie and Tiara Ball in June. Neilson was notorious for wearing McQueen’s clothes and she did so with a fierceness befitting her status as his muse. A sheer black jumpsuit from 2006, a mere figment of McQueen’s imagination that left nothing to anyone else’s, generated reams of chatter and flaunted the designer’s devilish streak. Indeed he was often heralded as fashion’s enfant terrible No. 1. But in this simply elegant silk charmeuse gown with its collar of silvered feathers, Neilson appeared as the vision of an angel.

White leather lace-ups, as recently worn by Mark Ronson, are associated with mimes and '80s tribute bands, but they actually have a stylish past. While perusing some images from the latest photography installation at Colette in Paris (the work of Trujillo/Paumier and Nick Meek), I was blindsided by a mannequin wearing the most perfect dress I've seen in a while - a beautifully draped one-shoulder number in a divine shade of emerald green. I called the store immediately for more information in the hopes that the price was somewhere in the realm of my Amex limit. As it turns out the dress is by Hervé Leroux, who you may remember as Hervé Leger, the king of bandage. The bad news? 4,630 euros. If this weren't enough to bring a tear to my covetous eye, I was immediately reminded of another dress I couldn't afford, in my fashion fledgling days back in the early '90s, modeled by a smoldering Karen Mulder on the Leger runway. I kept a photo of it pinned to the bulletin board of my cubicle for at least a year. To be sure, a lot has changed since my first Leger obsession, but what hasn't changed is that the man still has a way with elastic. And a girl can still dream, right?

Marc Toberoff, the lawyer who has represented heirs to the Superman creators Jerome Siegel and Joseph Shuster in their fight to reclaim copyrights from DC Comics, a division of Warner Brothers Entertainment, asked a court in Los Angeles on Friday to dismiss the complaint filed against him personally last May in connection with the long-running legal battle. In its complaint, DC Comics claimed that Mr. Toberoff had manipulated the heirs for years in an effort to capture a huge share of the copyrights for himself. In asking the United States District Court for the Central District of California to dismiss the complaint, Richard B. Kendall, a lawyer for Mr. Toberoff, called it "an absolutely meritless attack" that was meant to undermine Mr. Toberoff's relationship with the Siegel and Shuster heirs in the wake of a previous victory in court over DC Comics. A hearing in the case is set for Oct. 18.

The determination of probabilities is a well-established branch of mathematics. Very often probability calculations are simple and yield exact values that seem absolute and objective. Not so! Today I give you three scenarios with questions whose calculations are mostly simple. They are meant to show two things: first, that probability is relative - the probability of something may be very different depending on the way it is measured; and second, that probability is a measure of our ignorance. Any piece of knowledge, no matter how seemingly irrelevant, can change the probability for us.

"What kind of culture develops on an island?" asks Edward Rothstein in the Weekend section on Friday. Eight hundred yards from Manhattan's shores, Governors Island has been shaping its own cultural identity, writes Mr. Rothstein, which he says is eccentric, surprising and fanciful. Such questions came to mind Sunday, the day after Alex Rodriguez bashed three homers and flogged himself for not being productive enough this season. With his latest line for Dior Beauty, Tyen, the company's creative makeup director, takes the concept of matching your lipstick to your dress to a whole new level. Each color in his new 32-shade Rouge Dior Lipcolor range ($30 each at Dior counters) was inspired by the hues of haute couture ensembles from the atelier's archives. ''I tried to find shades that brighten life and make sadness disappear,'' Tyen says. The formula is an haute concept, too, containing hyaluronic microspheres that promise to soften, replenish and plump lips into a perfect pucker.

If you've paid close enough attention to folding money to have noticed - say - the arrival of clouds above the Lincoln Memorial, you'll gladly pore over "Money Talks," by the Japanese-Italian photojournalist Naoki Tomasini, 35. Fascinated by the symbols of power that appear on paper currency worldwide, Mr. Tomasini has produced a series of extreme close-ups of the intricate artwork on bills. "We all need to believe that what we receive in exchange for our work is value," he said, "not mere paper."

As the global economy struggles to recover from its crisis, here comes yet another dissection of a Wall Street firm - this one of Lehman Brothers, whose collapse helped set off the mess. But this very readable book, "The Last of the Imperious Rich: Lehman Brothers, 1844-2008" (Portfolio, $27.95), by Peter Chapman, takes a unusually long view of the situation. It looks at the bank in the context of one and a half centuries of financial evolution.

Lorelei Scarbro's husband, Kenneth, an underground coal miner for more than 30 years, is buried in a small family cemetery near her property here at the base of Coal River Mountain. The headstone is engraved with two roosters facing off, their feathers ruffled. Kenneth, who loved cockfighting, died in 1999, and, Ms. Scarbro says, he would have hated seeing the tops of mountains lopped off with explosives and heavy machinery by mining companies searching for coal.

SILVERBERG--Gittel. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Gittel Silverberg, beloved mother of Shonni Silverberg, and mother-in-law of UJA-Federation of New York Past President John M. Shapiro. Our dear friends, John and Shonni, are admired for their leadership and unwavering commitment to philanthropic causes in New York, in Israel, and around the world. With true dedication, Shonni serves as a member of the board for the Metropolitan Council for Jewish Poverty, a UJA-Federation funded agency, while John's inspiring legacy as Past President will be felt for generations to come. We extend our sympathies to her husband, Dr. Mervin Silverberg; to John and Shonni; to their two sons, Nathaniel and Zachary; to Gittel's daughters, Lori, Robbin, Yael, and Jordanna; and to the entire Silverberg family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

PETZ--Edwin V.,died August 13, 2010 at home in the arms of his wife, Louise, as he wished. He also leaves behind his daughter Katherine, his son Christopher and their spouses, Jeff Becker and Leah Jones. Ed was born in Beatrice, NE in 1935 and decided at an early age that he wanted to be a lawyer not a farmer. He left the farm at 16 and, after obtaining his BA from Principia College, graduated cum laude from The Harvard Law School in 1958. He held a number of positions in corporate General Counsel offices, but his final employment with various entities owned by the Milstein Family lasted 35 years and provided him with great professional and personal satisfaction. When he died, he was Sr. Vice President-General Counsel for Ogden CAP Properties, LLC. Ed was a man who will be remembered for a quiet reserve that hid a broad sense of humor and irreverence. Many described him as the consummate gentleman. He will be greatly missed by family, friends and many others he worked with over the years. Visitation and funeral services will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Visitation hours are 3-5 and 7-9 on Tuesday, August 17, with the funeral service at 11:30 the following day. A reception will be held at the family apartment on Wednesday August 18, 5-8. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to New York Presbyterian-Columbia University Medical Center/ Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- Gen. David H. Petraeus, the commander of American and NATO forces, began a campaign on Sunday to convince an increasingly skeptical public that the American-led coalition can still succeed here despite months of setbacks, saying he had not come to Afghanistan to preside over a ''graceful exit.'' In an hourlong interview with The New York Times, the general argued against any precipitous withdrawal of forces in July 2011, the date set by President Obama to begin at least a gradual reduction of the 100,000 troops on the ground. General Petraeus said that it was only in the last few weeks that the war plan had been fine-tuned and given the resources that it required. ''For the first time,'' he said, ''we will have what we have been working to put in place for the last year and a half.''

Appel; sister Diane (Deedy) Tohn and her husband Jerry; nieces Ellen Tohn (John Harper), Susan Tohn (Jordan Oshlag), and Margot Tohn; niece Deborah Bormann (Douglass); nephew Charles Bumbar (Vicki); and grandnieces and nephews Daniel, Seth and Jeremy Harper; Lainie and Elise Oshlag; and Emma Bumbar. Services August 17th, Tuesday 11:45am at The Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be sent to the Stephen Gaynor School, NYC.

SILVERBERG--Gittel, 79, died peacefully at home after a long illness. Her family was the center of her universe. Beloved wife of Mervin, her soulmate since they met at camp when she was 15. Adored mother to Shonni and John, Lori, Robbin and Andras, Yael and Tacy, and Jordanna. The very best Bubbe imaginable to Zachary, Nathaniel, Tova, Jared, Teagan, Maya, Lilly and Menyus. Survived also by loving sisters and brothers in law Ruth and Dan Frankfurt, Esther and Irv Beckman and Seymour and Terri Silverberg and a large extended family in the US, Canada and Israel. Born in Montreal, Canada in 1930, Gittel was educated at Jewish People's School, Baron Bing High School, McGill University and Sarah Lawrence College, where she was a member of the 2nd class of graduates in the then new field of Genetic Counseling. Retired in 2000 after many productive years as the senior genetic counselor at North Shore University Hospital. Steadfast supporter of the Jewish community at home, in Israel and around the world. A woman of boundless enthusiasm who will be missed by all who knew her. Donations can be made to the Gittel Silverberg Fund, Joan Marks Graduate Program in Human Genetics, Sarah Lawrence College, Advancement Office, 1 Mead Way, Bronxville, NY 10708. Funeral service August 16, 12pm noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

KALIK--Allen, died on August 14, 2010 at the age of 59, leaving behind his best friend and life partner Patricia Kalik and their children Lisa and Daniel Kalik. He is survived by his parents Betty and Larry Kalik, his sister Millie Kalik and his nieces and nephews Melanie, Julie, David, Jessica, Zach, Kylie, Josh, Danielle and Emily. He was born on September 17, 1950 and grew up in New York City. He graduated from Cornell University in 1972 and went from teacher to ski bum to successful entrepreneur, all while windsurfing around the world, speaking French and playing acoustic guitar to whoever would listen. Forever passionate in life and in his fight against cancer, he left peacefully with all of his loved ones nearby. Funeral service to be held Monday, August 16 at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City. Memorial Service to be held in Manchester, New Hampshire at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center: 866-815-9501 or http://mskcc.convio.net/.

CLARVIT--William, born May 16, 1926, died August 13, 2010. Raised six children, eight grandchildren, four great-grandchildren with Selma Yvette Clarvit and two step children and four step grandchildren with Helen Broisman Clarvit. Co-founder and operator of C & R Grand Stores for 40 years throughout Long Island. He was a hard worker, hands on fixer and lover of tennis and yoga.

WILSON--John H.T. Union Settlement Association notes with sorrow the passing of John H.T. Wilson, our former Board Chair who served for over 40 years on our Board and Advisory Council. We express our deepest sympathies to his wife Sandy and family.

WOLFSOHN--Annette. Born Pretoria, South Africa on March 6, 1927, died in Sydney, Australia on August 14, 2010, aged 83. Loved and sorely missed by her children, Roger and Leora, their spouses, Jeanie and Simon, her grandchildren Jessica, Chloe, Zac and Alexander, and wonderful family and friends. Funeral to be held in Sydney.

SCHEURER--Edwin C. - The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Edwin (Eddie) Scheurer. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his wife Edie, and to his entire family. Calvin W. Roberts, President Stephen Karotkin, Secretary

Android cellphone screens could soon have fewer finger smudges. On Thursday, Google introduced a bunch of new features for the latest versions of Android phones that eliminate the need for typing -- and compete with Apple's voice-command app, Siri.

An article last Monday about a dispute over Research In Motion's security approach for its BlackBerry devices misstated the Justice Department position once held by Mark Rasch, who commented on the debate. Mr. Rasch prosecuted computer crimes at Justice, but he was not the head of its computer crimes unit, which was created after his departure.

WATJEN--Craig. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the passing of former trustee Craig Watjen, who served on the Juilliard School Board of Trustees from 2005-2008. A person of intelligence, creativity, wit, and gentleness, he had an important role in the Campaign for Juilliard and represented the School in various initiatives outside of New York City. An accomplished clarinetist, who graduated from Juilliard in 1961 before beginning a successful business career, he will be deeply missed by us all. Our condolences go out to his beloved wife Joan. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

Thursday night I had dinner in the future, and the hamburgers were shaped like doughnuts. Before I get to these strange hamburger shapes, let me explain why they were from the future: my burger was created on the Internet and broadcast to Twitter, Foursquare and Facebook, part of a multiplayer online game, and my order was checked in by a receptionist with an iPad.

HUGHES--Annette McMaster, 81, on August 12, died the same way she lived: peacefully, with love, and comforted by her nearest and dearest at her Manhattan home. Her chief delight was the family she created in concert with her husband of fifty-three years, the late Sidney Hughes. Her children Nancy and Tom were with her, her grandsons Philip and Matthew bade her farewell, and her cherished daughter-in-law Catherine was in her heart. She had happy memories of The Spence School, Bryn Mawr College, and serving as a School Volunteer. All who knew her remember her generous spirit, her love of reading, and the grace and quiet humor she brought to her life and the lives of all she touched. The funeral service will be private.

FLORIN--Vivian, 83, of Sarasota, Florida, formerly of Hewlett, NY, beloved wife of the late Donald Florin, died August 11, 2010. Her sense of optimism, charity and public spirit reflects in her years of service through organizations such as The League of Women Voters, the Democratic Club, Salvation Army, SPARCC and Guardian ad Litem. She will be greatly missed by her family and wide circle of friends. She is survived by her son, Bill Florin, daughter, Peggy Florin, sister, Edith Finck and granddaughter Dana Florin-Weiss. Donations in her memory may be sent to Children's Guardian Fund, PO Box 49722, Sarasota, Florida 34230.

It remains to be seen whether or not ''The Social Network,'' the highly fictionalized retelling of the origins of Facebook, will be a box-office hit. After all, although the film, which opens in October, has some notable names attached to it, the phrases ''Internet biopic'' and ''Hollywood blockbuster'' aren't exactly synonyms.

MacKINNON--Robert Harold. It is with great sadness that Bob MacKinnon's family announces his sudden death from heart failure on July 6, at age 74, in Cape Cod, MA. Survivors include his wife Ilse; daughter Elizabeth Henrici; stepchildren Chase and Peter Livingston; six grandchildren; and four siblings: Lois Davis, Jean Rogers, Richard MacKinnon, and William MacKinnon. A public memorial service will be held in the chapel of Northfield Mount Hermon School, Mount Hermon, MA, on Saturday, September 11, at 2:00pm following a 1:00pm gathering for out-of-town guests at the school's Mary E. MacKinnon Cottage. After the chapel service there will be a reception at the headmaster's residence. Bob MacKinnon was born in Schenectady, NY on November 22, 1935 to Harold Alexander MacKinnon and the former Mary Ethel Costello. He attended Schenectady public schools, and for high school went to Northfield Mount Hermon (1953), on whose Board of Trustees he later served with great distinction. Bob was also an alumnus of Yale University (B.A., 1957) and Harvard Law School (L.L.D., 1960). Throughout his student days he was active in Boy Scouts, athletics, and singing. Following Harvard, Bob entered the U.S. Army Reserve, and in New York commenced a life-long career with the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, from which he retired as a senior partner in 2001 and counselor in 2007. As an attorney he was a respected leader and mentor, active in his firm's governance while founding and leading its practice areas in bankruptcy, reorganization, and private finance. Bob was a truly global practitioner, having worked in Shearman & Sterling offices in five countries. He was an advisor to and director of multiple American and international corporations. Amidst all of these responsibilities, Bob MacKinnon took great satisfaction in the building and naming of the Mary E. MacKinnon Cottage, a student residence at Northfield Mount Hermon, as a memorial to his late mother.

GREENWALD--Dr. Stanley, passed away at home, peacefully with his family's love surrounding him on August 13. There will be a celebration of life Sunday afternoon August 22 in Atlantic Beach, NY. Please call Wendy or Debby for details.

An article on Thursday about a decision by Marc Hauser, a Harvard researcher, to go on leave after problems were found with his research misstated part of the name of the university with which Justin Wood, the senior co-author of a paper under review, is affiliated. He is with the University of Southern California; there is no University of ''South California.''

LENART--Yvonne Ramus (Mrs. Harry Lenart). Born April 18, 1915 in Nova Scotia, Canada, died August 10, 2010 in Los Angeles, CA. Resident of Los Angeles since 1931. Predeceased in 1984 by her loving husband Harry. During her long life, Yvonne was surrounded by her brother's children: Ilene Ramus Secrist (Phoenix, AZ), Ronald and Dean Ramus and their respective spouses Anna and Marlene (Los Angeles, CA), grand niece Erica Secrist and grand nephew Ryan Secrist and by Harry's sister's children: "the Kingsley side of the family," now numbering 24 nieces, nephews, grands and great-grands. All were frequent visitors and houseguests in their beloved Aunt Yvonne's home. Yvonne, AKA "Probono Publico", was a long term Trustee of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, where she and her husband Harry provided significant support for the museum's collection of South and Southeast Asian art. Yvonne was a major donor to the UCLA Department of Humanities, most recently providing travel educational scholarships. Throughout her life she supported many organizations and institutions, including Planned Parenthood, UCLA Arts Council, The Associates of Southern California, The Arthritis Foundation, The Nature Conservancy, Neighborhood Youth Association and Family Service Los Angeles. The family, friends, associates and neighbors who were fortunate enough to share time with Yvonne will remember her as a life-long vegetarian and mentor who role-modeled integrity, graciousness, generosity and humility. Yvonne taught others the importance of striving to make a difference in the lives of others. When in her presence you always felt blessed and she never left your presence without saying, "Bless You." During the last four years of Yvonne's life, she was lovingly cared for by "Her Angels": Maria, Lily, Mayra, Eileen, Angie and Lisa RN. In lieu of flowers, tribute gifts can be made to: "The Yvonne Lenart Children's Education Fund" at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 5905 Wilshire Blvd., Los Angeles, CA 90036. A memorial service will be held at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art on September 11, 2010. Please call LACMA at 323-857-6521 for more information.
SMYTH--Roger. Been a year, but feels like a lifetime. Miss you so very much. Always in our hearts. Never will forget you. Boo, Fran and Tony

SCHEURER--Edwin Charles, 77, died August 14th, 2010. The cause of death was Myelodisplastic Syndrome. Born June 1st 1933. Beloved husband of Edie (Raabin). Loving father of Lynne Norma Scheurer and her husband Peter Foster and Andrew Raabin Scheurer and his wife Juliette. Adored Poppa of Sarah Norma Rish, Noah Scheurer Rish, Edwin Charles Scheurer II and Rayna Louise Foster. Cherished brother of Joan Mintz and Donald. Devoted uncle, cousin and friend. Eddie grew up in the Bronx and went to DeWitt Clinton High School. He graduated from Upsala College. In 1955 he joined Frank B. Hall which became Aon. In 1956 he joined the Army and was stationed at the Pentagon in the Crypto Division. He married Edie Raabin on November 10th 1957 after 14 dates. On September 11 his office was on the 105th floor of Tower Two. He voted in the mayoral primary in the morning and arrived at the building two minutes after it was attacked. He saw the horrific sight from the street. He never recovered from this and always felt guilty that his life was spared while thousands of young people were killed. It haunted him the rest of his life. He retired as Vice Chairman from Aon in 2008. Eddie embraced life. He was a loving and devoted family man in every way. His charm and charisma were captivating. His wonderful smile lit up a room and his presence was strongly felt anywhere he went. He loved the golf games and gin games with his buddies and was always there to lend a hand to anyone in need. His amazing disposition was enviable. He rarely saw the glass half filled-he saw it entirely full. Ed, representing the insurance industry, accompanied Mayor Lindsay to Japan. He was a former chairman of the insurance division of the UJA Federation. He was a board member and past chairman of the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation and worked tirelessly for this organization. Our gratitude to Dr. Stuart Orsher and his team who did all that could possibly be done in an impossible situation. Our very special thanks, appreciation and love to Dr. Richard Bader who for twenty years accompanied us from city to city, hospital to hospital and doctor to doctor. He guided and advised us in our multitude of medical decisions. We will forever be grateful to him. Contributions in Eddie's memory to the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation 1150 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128 would be greatly appreciated -- or a special charity of your choice. The family will receive at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave on Monday August 16th from 4-8pm. The funeral will be Tuesday, August 17th 2010 at 11:30am.

SHERMAN--Louis J.,93, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Long Beach, NY. Passed away on August 13, 2010. Beloved and devoted husband of Muriel (Kroman), who cherished him dearly for more than 63 years. Cherished father of Rabbi Alan and Marilyn Sherman, Michael and Ruth Sherman, and Cantor Glenn Sherman. Loving grandfather of Pamela and Spencer Linden, Larry and Rachael Sherman, Joshua and Andrea Sherman, Laura and Avi Fisher, Jonathan Sherman, Steven and Lisa Sherman, Traci Sherman, Hannah Sherman, and Amy, Shira and Rena Diem. Terrific in every way, he was a successful Cantor and partner with his brothers in Sherman Brothers Corp, World War II veteran who served in the China Burma India Theatre, fabulous host and soccer enthusiast. We will miss him greatly. His life was an example to us all. His memory will forever remain in our hearts.

The Kampala Journal article on July 22, about the concerns of Somali refugees in Uganda after the July 11 bombings in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, that were carried out by militants from the Shabab, a Somalian Muslim extremist group, misstated the year that Ali Mohammed Muse, a refugee who worried that the attack hurt his chances of emigrating to the United States, had come to Uganda. It was 1991, not 2004. The article also misstated the age of another refugee, Ahmed Uleh, who said he had once been kidnapped by the Shabab. He is 29, not 34.

A common thread running through the fiction of Jonathan Franzen is the author’s preoccupation with the Midwest, specifically with its cities and suburbs: St. Louis (“The Twenty-Seventh City”), Evanston, Ill. (“Strong Motion”), St. Louis again (called “St. Jude”) in “The Corrections” and now St. Paul, Minn. (in “Freedom,” to be published later this month). As it happens, Franzen, though he grew up in the St. Louis suburb Webster Groves, has been an East Coaster for 30 years or more. He attended Swarthmore College (class of 1981), worked briefly in Cambridge, Mass., and is today a more or less entrenched Manhattanite.

The best-tasting oyster I will ever consume came at 8 a.m. on a warm late-July Wednesday in the middle of Wellfleet Harbor. I was attempting to remove the mollusk’s various attachments with a small Estwing drywall hammer when its shell accidentally cracked open. With few viable options, I selflessly did the humane thing: I slid it down my gullet. It was delectable — rich, creamy and absurdly fresh — and no more than 30 seconds between sea and belly.

Pablo Picasso, you still got it! The Metropolitan Museum of Art said on Tuesday that its recent exhibition of works by that 20th-century titan of creativity was its seventh-highest-attended show in the museum's history. The exhibition, called "Picasso in The Metropolitan Museum of Art," drew 703,256 visitors during its 17-week run from April 19 through Aug. 15, making it the museum's best-attended show since 2001. The Met said that the exhibition, which featured the museum's complete Picasso holdings of some 300 examples of the artist's painting, drawing, sculpture and ceramics, attracted as many as 10,000 visitors on some busy Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Still, it wasn't enough to top the Met's sixth-most-attended exhibition, "The Horses of San Marco," which drew 742,221 visitors over seven months in 1980. Maybe next time, Picasso.

Recently, a bevy of cool men's shops have sprung up on the streets of Shoreditch, in London's East End, including Hostem, where customers are welcomed into an olde-world interior designed by the eccentric duo at Jamesplumb. The front desk is made from an old church pew, the ceilings are draped in Swedish linen, and vintage lighting swings from long cables, allowing customers to maneuver the lights for closer inspection of the duds.

So what happens to "The Savory Collection" of classic jazz now that its existence is no longer a closely guarded secret and the first fragments of its riches have spilled into the public domain? There are nearly 1,000 discs in the collection, recorded by the audio engineer William Savory in the late 1930s and into 1940, the height of the swing era, but barely 10 percent of them have been digitized. What about all those other records?

This year the French are returning on Sept. 24 and 25 with the second edition of Le Grand Fooding, their tasting of food and drink to benefit Action Against Hunger. It will be held at MOMA PS 1, 22-25 Jackson Avenue (46th Avenue), Long Island City, Queens. Starting at 6 p.m. both days there will be a Champagne reception and preview of the food for those who buy $80 tickets. General admission, $50, starts at 7 p.m. The theme this year is New York vs. San Francisco, with chefs from both cities, including Richard Torrisi and Dan Barber from New York, Brian Leth and Jeremy Fox from the West Coast, preparing food. The lineup of chefs is not the same for each night. Tickets include food and limited alcoholic beverages and are available now at a special Web site for Diner's Journal readers.

A suicide bomber struck early on Tuesday at an army recruiting office in Baghdad, Stephen Farrell reported, killing dozens in the first major bombing during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan - a period made more fraught than in previous years by the looming deadline for American forces to replace their combat mission in Iraq with a training role. Moises Saman was on the scene, photographing for The Times.

There's been a lot of criticism of my column's suggestion that the idea of America as a distinctive culture - English-speaking, Anglo-Saxon and/or Western, Protestant and then "Judeo-Christian" - has driven both a positive assimilationism and a darker nativism over the years, and indeed that these two impulses are often intertwined. Many writers seem convinced that that assimilation and nativism aren't intertwined at all, but rather diametrically opposed. "Nativism in the late 19th century was preoccupied with keeping foreigners out of the United States," not assimilating them, Jamelle Bouie writes. "The pro-assimilation forces are on the progressive side, in the first camp Douthat mentions," objects Phoebe Maltz, rather than having anything to do with cultural conservatives. "The assimilationists and the exclusionists aren't and haven't been the same people," Jacob Levy tweets. And so forth.
The first regular season N.B.A. games are more than two months away, but it's not too early to start your financial planning for them, especially if you want to see the Miami Heat's first games.

The U.S. Open of Surfing, which wound down last week, is held over nine days in Huntington Beach, Calif. There are surfing, skating and BMX competitions, and the beach overflows with 400,000 kids over the course of the event. Not being a sports photographer, or anything close to it, I wasn't sure what to expect. I thought the surfing would be cool, which it proved to be, but that really was the least of it.

The conventional art fair - for which collectors, dealers and other art-world professionals jet into a city for several days of looking, buying, partying and networking - is about to face a challenge. The online-only VIP Art Fair, which will take place for the first time in January, is similarly time-limited (at a week long), but different in almost every other way from a normal fair. The "booths" are virtual; conversation (and haggling over prices) will take place by instant messaging, phone or Skype; and no one will get sore feet. The event is the brainchild of two couples, the art dealers James and Jane Cohan and the Internet entrepreneurs Jonas and Alessandra Almgren, who are neighbors and friends in Park Slope.

The case study we published last week recounted growing pains at FreshDirect, an online grocer that was already in a heap of trouble -- hemorrhaging money and churning through customers -- when an immigration audit decimated its work force in late 2007. Written by Jessica Bruder, the article looked at FreshDirect's struggle to reinvent itself and buck the conventional wisdom that Internet grocers cannot win profits.

A paternity test ordered by the Icelandic Supreme Court to determine if the chess champion Bobby Fischer was the father of a 9-year-old Filipino girl came back negative on Tuesday, according to people involved in the dispute over his estate.

"Dancing With the Stars" is taking the show's promotion to a new extreme, announcing its new contestants in a prime-time press conference on ABC later this month. The Obama administration is planning to expand opportunities for Americans to travel to Cuba, The Times's Ginger Thompson reports, the latest step aimed at encouraging more contact between people in both countries, while leaving intact the decades-old embargo against the island's Communist government, according to Congressional and administration officials. Every day in studios across New York City, theater hopefuls take their first steps into an uncertain world. Whether it's Acting 101 or Movement for Dummies, aspiring stars have to start somewhere.

Mazda is recalling about 215,000 of its 2007-9 Mazda 3 and Mazda 5's because of a steering problem that could increase the chance of a crash, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The agency says the problem is a loss of power assist which reduces "the driver's ability to steer the vehicle as typically expected."
BHP Billiton's $38.6 billion play for Canadian fertilizer producer Potash Corporation is a bet on the ever-increasing demand for food.

Every year the administrators at Wisconsin's Beloit College put together a list of information about incoming freshmen that is shared with the school's professors. It's not a list of student names, or the books they'll need to order for class. Instead, professors are told about the "cultural touchstones that shape the lives of students entering college this fall."
The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, contributed $1 million to the Republican Governors Association this summer, the Bloomberg news service reported this week.

As my colleague Brian Stelter reported last week, Levi Johnston, "a bit player in the last presidential election, is pitching a reality television show to several cable channels. He and his producers are calling the show 'Loving Levi: The Road to the Mayor's Office.' That would be the mayor's office in Wasilla, Alaska, where Sarah Palin got her start."

In Pakistan, there is rising debate over whether climate change is to blame for the country's devastating floods. "Global warming results in catastrophic weather events," a Pakistani geographer and water specialist says. "The recent floods are a result of climate change, undoubtedly."  [Inter Press Service]
In today's Timescast, Did Lou Gehrig have Lou Gehrig's disease?, faltering aid to flood ravaged Pakistan and the media's role in the debate over plans to build an Islamic center near ground zero.

Five weeks after wildlife authorities rounded up Prospect Park's geese and gassed them, provoking the ire of residents and wildlife advocates alike, legions of new, death-defying geese continue to move into the prime real estate that is Prospect Park Lake.
As you might be able to tell by my column this week, I love mezcal. Even more so than its cousin tequila, which I love as well, mezcal is the most under-recognized great spirit on the planet.

An interesting phenomenon of the Dustin Johnson rules controversy is that Monday seemed to be the day that most defended Johnson and blamed the rules officials. On Tuesday, however, the tide seems to have turned in favor of crediting the rules officials with simply doing their jobs.

Listeners who tuned in Monday to "The Leonard Lopate Show" on WNYC expecting to hear its regular host got an unusual surprise: Christopher Walken, the "Deer Hunter" and "Behanding in Spokane" star, loaned his lifelong interest in broadcasting and burgeoning skills (not to mention his unmistakable stop-and-start delivery) to the program, where he acted as guest host for the afternoon, and conducted interviews with friends and colleagues like Jack O'Brien and Richard Easton; his "Behanding" co-star Zoe Kazan; the chef Lidia Bastianich and her mother, Erminia Motika; and the dancer and choreographer Jacques d'Amboise, who shared his airtime with a couple of surprise guests.

The Reynolds Group, part of the global packaging business owned by New Zealand's richest man, said Tuesday that it would pay about $4.4 billion for Pactiv, the maker of the Hefty brand trash bags. With debt included, the acquisition is valued at about $6 billion.

In an article on Sunday, I outlined the relationship between climate change and a rise in extreme weather. Scientists cite several statistical indicators that suggest the number of extreme events like heat waves and floods is rising. This evidence has taken on a new meaning in this summer of weather disasters, especially the floods in Pakistan and the heat wave in Russia. The United States has not been spared from weather extremes, notably deluges like the disastrous downpour in Tennessee that led to extensive flooding in May.
Shares in American Apparel, the clothing choice of urban hipsters, plummeted more than 13 percent as the company disclosed receiving a federal subpoena over its change in accounting firms.
The end (of summer) is near!

Chandra Hoffman has decided to home-school her 8-year-old son Hayden once this school year ends. She certainly didn't make this choice to fill her "free" time -- her first novel, "Chosen," is coming out this fall, and most authors clear their calendars for an event like that. But her overstuffed calendar -- and her son's -- is precisely the reason she is making this choice.

In yet another setback in efforts to treat Alzheimer's disease, Eli Lilly & Company announced on Tuesday that it had halted development of an experimental treatment after the compound actually made patients worse in two late-stage clinical trials.

It's time for a second report on the nitty-gritty of my frugal budget. During the middle five weeks of my trip, I once again averaged well under my $500-a-week (about $70 a day) maximum. Here's how it breaks down, including transportation costs this time.
A brief revisiting of the issues I raised more than a year ago regarding alternative views of interest rates.

I've just finished rereading Richard Koo's The Holy Grail of Macroeconomics, as part of a multi-book review project. It's one of the few books out there that talks about what you should do in the aftermath of a burst bubble -- almost everyone else obsesses on the causes of the bubble, and possibly on how to prevent the next bubble, neither of which is the clear and present issue.

One of the perks of being a famous fashion designer is getting to hang out with the Rolling Stones or Britney Spears and cast David Bowie in your ad campaigns. And it's true that when it comes to his musical inspirations, Tommy Hilfiger doesn't just talk the talk - he rocks the rock. A new book from Assouline, celebrating Hilfiger's 25th anniversary, covers these greatest-hit moments and more. (You may not be invited to the anniversary bash, but you can tune in with his playlist, below.) Here is Hilfiger, in a photo from the book, with his wife, Dee, on their way to Kid Rock's wedding. Shine on you crazy diamond, indeed!

We suppose an exhibition of paintings by Bob Dylan could depict anything from Einstein disguised as Robin Hood to a fight between Ezra Pound and T.S. Eliot - and that's just if he sticks to the lyrics of his song "Desolation Row." So what will visitors to Mr. Dylan's show at the Danish National Gallery in Copenhagen actually see when it opens there next month? As Kaspar Monrad, the museum's curator and director, told Agence France-Presse, the works will include paintings of Brazil, containing "scenes from daily life in the cities, the slums and the countryside in Brazil where Bob Dylan has been several times."
The fallout from France's World Cup fiasco continues: Nicolas Anelka was suspended for 18 games for his frustrated rant at the former coach Raymond Domenech.

The brevity of the storm belied its destructive strength: in just over half an hour, it felled more than 500 trees in Central Park and damaged hundreds more so badly that they had to be removed in the months that followed. That was one year ago on Wednesday.

Back in the dot-com boom of the late 1990s, Lycos was one of the first major Web brands. After being acquired by Terra Networks for $12.5 billion in 2000 and then by Daum Communications in 2004 for just $95 million, it has now been sold to Ybrant Digital for less than half that, at $36 million.

Aspen Pharmacare Holdings, Africa's largest drugmaker, agreed to buy a unit of Sigma Pharmaceuticals for $806 million in cash to gain assets from a company that's lost about half its value in the past year, Bloomberg News reported.

News item from Monday, via ProFootballTalk.com: On the Dan Patrick Radio show, the former Colts coach Tony Dungy said he wouldn't hire a coach like Rex Ryan if given the chance because of his frequent use of profanity. Most of my work as a photographer centers on urban development in the sense of construction and expansion. But not all development succeeds, and not all construction lasts. In recent years a number of cities in Britain have recognized that some of the large public housing projects built during the postwar era have been failures; what were supposed to be new residential communities have been overtaken by crime and drug use. In several cases, particularly unmanageable buildings have even been torn down.

To the Editor: I'm sure many readers had the same reaction to ''A Masterpiece of Nature? Yuck!'' (Aug. 10) as I did. At first glance, the pictures of those misshapen creatures were shocking and repulsive. But after I gazed at them and returned for another look, they seemed endearing, even lovable. Only one explanation suffices for me: inner beauty. Larry Garzillo

SAKS--Denise, our Tanty, was one of a kind. She died on August 5, 2010, at the age of 95 while hiking in Switzerland, where she had been gathering dear friends from around the world every summer for 30 years; she never became complacent about life nor lost her profound openness to meeting new people. Denise was born in London in 1914 where her Belgian family had sought shelter during WWI. They returned to Belgium after that war where she began her life-long love of learning. She had received her law degree when WWII broke out. Her family fled Belgium on May 10 1940, during the bombing of Brussels. She often told stories of their journey, focusing on the joy they found with family and friends on their journey through France, Portugal, Mozambique, and South Africa, finally arriving in New York in December 1940. She found her home in New York, where she was part of an amazing group of Jewish emigres. She received her Master's in Science and Social Work from Columbia University in 1945 and opened a successful group practice, focusing on families, in Westchester. She then went on to work with students at Barnard College. Following her retirement from Barnard she volunteered for many years at the United Nations helping families find the right resources for their children. The "younger generation," as she called her great, and great great, nieces and nephews, delighted in spending time with her getting down on the floor with them until the age of 90 showing her excellent rooster imitation and special ability to wiggle her ears. She was deeply interested in and supportive of all of our efforts to contribute to the world. She always had something to offer, a friend who worked in the field, an interesting article she had just read, and her keen observations. She fostered in all of us a love of art, music, theatre, and travel. We miss our beloved Tanty, who lives on in all of us: Marianne Holstrom and Fred Chapnick, Claude and Bette Saks, Pierre LeBlache, Jacqueline Hart and Pierre Vilain, Catherine Hart and Christopher Wottowa, Eric and Suzanne Saks, Marc and Anne Saks, Claire and Carl Iverson, Dominique, Megan, Isabel, Maxwell, Annick, Olivier, Miles, and Silas.

MOORE--Martha Bennett, a longtime resident of Bronx-ville, NY, passed away peacefully at age 87 on August 15, 2010. Ms. Moore had been married for 46 years to the late Dr. Ivan Bennett, Jr., former Dean of New York University School of Medicine. She subsequently was married for eight years to the late Harrison Moore of Bronxville. An active figure in Bronxville civic life, Ms. Moore served as President of the Bronxville League of Women Voters and was an active Member of the Board of the United Nations Association of Westchester County. She had also been Director of an after-school youth program at Forest Hills Community Center in Queens, New York. Ms. Moore was born Martha Rhodes in Atlanta, Georgia, where she graduated from Agnes Scott College. She went on to earn a masters degree from the Bank Street College of Education in New York. As her health deteriorated, Ms. Moore spent the last year of her life in Palo Alto, CA in the loving care of her daughter, Katherine Evans. In addition to Katherine, Ms. Moore is survived by her brother, Robert C. Rhodes of Arkadelphia, AR, and by her other three children, Susan Anderson of Baltimore, Paul Bennett of New York, and Dr. Jeffrey Bennett of Springfield, IL. Martha is also survived by six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In addition, she is survived by Christopher Moore of Charlotte, NC, Harrison's son by a previous marriage. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to be sent in Ms. Moore's memory to the Community Unitarian Church of White Plains, NY. A memorial will be held at the church at 1pm on September 12, 2010. The address is 468 Rosedale Ave., White Plains, NY, 10605.

SCHWARTZ--Lucille, age 92, died peacefully at home on August 15, 2010. Lucille was the beloved wife of Dr. Sheldon Schwartz. WASHINGTON -- At a gathering last month over drinks and finger food, a specialist at the World Bank related the story of how female weavers in a remote Amazonian region of Guyana had against all odds built themselves a thriving global online business selling intricately woven hammocks for $1,000 apiece. The state phone company had donated a communications center that helped the women find buyers around the world, selling to places like the British Museum. Within short order, though, their husbands pulled the plug, worried that their wives' sudden increase in income was a threat to the traditional male domination in their society.

BAUMGOLD--Buzz, July 26, 1946, died on August 15, 2010. He lived for his family: his wife of 41 years, Mary Anne; his children, daughter Rebecca Baumgold Prenner and Dr. Jonathan Prenner, and son Joseph Nicholas Baumgold and Jennifer Baumgold; his grandchildren, his great joys, Sofia and Maxwell Prenner; and his dogs. Donations can be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (www.jdrf.org). Services are private.

The Russian artist Kazimir Malevich, known for painting the Black Square and espousing an artistic philosophy that held geometric forms supreme, had a previously unknown son in a town in Russia before he went on to join the avant-garde in Moscow and Paris, the chief archivist in Kursk, Margarita Litvinova, told Russian news agencies Monday. An entry in a state registry indicates Mr. Malevich was the father of a boy named Anatoly, born in 1902, she said. Biographers had formerly known only of two other children, she said.

KASTRINSKY--Leonora, 92, of Fair Lawn, NJ, formerly of Queens, NY died Sunday, mother of Ira (Joan) Kastrinsky and Alan (Robin) Kastrinsky, grandmother of Stefanie, David, Rachel and Jordan. Services 10am, Wednesday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, NY.

HELLMAN--Rose, 95, beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother died on Friday, August 13, 2010 with her husband, Gabriel, her eldest son, Dr. Richard Hellman and his wife, Julie at her side. She died at her home at Sunrise of Leawood, an assisted living facility. The funeral service will be held on Tuesday, August 17 at 11:30am at Congregation Beth Torah, 6100 W. 127th Street in Overland Park, Kansas. Following the funeral, graveside service will be held at the Mt. Moriah Cemetery at 10507 Holmes Road in Kansas City, Missouri. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Hadassah organization of which she was a lifetime member. Rose was born in New York City but was brought up on a farm in northern New Jersey with her parents, Louis and Minnie, and her three brothers, Joe, Hy and Al. She moved to the Bronx, New York at age 10 and entered City College of New York at age 14, graduating with a degree in accounting and a degree in Elementary Education. She married on June 29, 1941 to Gabriel M. Hellman and had two sons, Richard and Geoffrey. She was a gifted teacher of mathematics in the New York City public school system for 34 years and a guidance counselor until her retirement. She subsequently lived inWestchester County, then North Stanford, Connecticut, and for twenty five years in Boca Raton Florida. She spent the last seven years of her life in Leawood, Kansas with her husband Gabriel, near her son, Richard. She leaves behind her husband of 69 years, Gabriel, her brother Alex Eventoff and his wife Renee, and her two sons, Richard (wife Julie) and Geoffrey, eleven grandchildren, three great-grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. She will be remembered, not just for her remarkable range of talents, from mathematics and her love of education to gardening and art, but for her love and devotion to her family. She was an endless source of energy and creativity, and was particularly invested in her children, grandchildren, nieces and nephews. She was generous to all in many ways. Her love of flowers was expressed not only in her gardens, but in her often unannounced trips to family and dear friends just to plant beautiful flowers around their homes and then quietly depart. She has planted flowers in countless hearts as well and will be greatly missed by all of us. Her chronic heart disease finally claimed her life but her memory will live on forever.

For four weeks, my 11-year-old daughter has been coughing. It is not your run-of-the-mill summer cold, but a violent, debilitating cough that takes over her body, usually at night. During these fits, her face turns red, and tears start streaming from her eyes. She coughs so hard she eventually starts to gasp for air, making a horrifying sucking sound that at one point had me reaching for the phone to call 911. But eventually she catches her breath. Several times she has coughed so hard she begins to throw up.

APPEL--Herbert N. The Board of Trustees and Faculty of the Stephen Gaynor School mourn the loss of Herb Appel, a friend and long time member of the Board of Trustees. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Susan and his family.

SCHEURER--Edwin Charles, 77, died August 14th, 2010. The cause of death was Myelodisplastic Syndrome. Born June 1st 1933. Beloved husband of Edie (Raabin). Loving father of Lynne Norma Scheurer and her husband Peter Foster and Andrew Raabin Scheurer and his wife Juliette. Adored Poppa of Sarah Norma Rish, Noah Scheurer Rish, Edwin Charles Scheurer II and Rayna Louise Foster. Cherished brother of Joan Mintz and Donald. Devoted uncle, cousin and friend. Eddie grew up in the Bronx and went to DeWitt Clinton High School. He graduated from Upsala College. In 1955 he joined Frank B. Hall which became Aon. In 1956 he joined the Army and was stationed at the Pentagon in the Crypto Division. He married Edie Raabin on November 10th 1957 after 14 dates. On September 11 his office was on the 105th floor of Tower Two. He voted in the mayoral primary in the morning and arrived at the building two minutes after it was attacked. He saw the horrific sight from the street. He never recovered from this and always felt guilty that his life was spared while thousands of young people were killed. It haunted him the rest of his life. He retired as Vice Chairman from Aon in 2008. Eddie embraced life. He was a loving and devoted family man in every way. His charm and charisma were captivating. His wonderful smile lit up a room and his presence was strongly felt anywhere he went. He loved the golf games and gin games with his buddies and was always there to lend a hand to anyone in need. His amazing disposition was enviable. He rarely saw the glass half filled-he saw it entirely full. Ed, representing the insurance industry, accompanied Mayor Lindsay to Japan. He was a former chairman of the insurance division of the UJA Federation. He was a board member and past chairman of the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation and worked tirelessly for this organization. Our gratitude to Dr. Stuart Orsher and his team who did all that could possibly be done in an impossible situation. Our very special thanks, appreciation and love to Dr. Richard Bader who for twenty years accompanied us from city to city, hospital to hospital and doctor to doctor. He guided and advised us in our multitude of medical decisions. We will forever be grateful to him. Contributions in Eddie's memory to the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation 1150 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128 would be greatly appreciated -- or a special charity of your choice. The family will receive at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave on Monday August 16th from 4-8pm. The funeral will be Tuesday, August 17th 2010 at 11:30am.

For lovers of classic jazz, many of the most memorable moments came on the radio, where the live shows of great musicians often reached experimental heights too bold for commercial sale. Once on the radio. Then gone forever. Now, remarkably, some of these lost moments are back.

PETZ--Edwin V.,died August 13, 2010 at home in the arms of his wife, Louise, as he wished. He also leaves behind his daughter Katherine, his son Christopher and their spouses, Jeff Becker and Leah Jones. Ed was born in Beatrice, NE in 1935 and decided at an early age that he wanted to be a lawyer not a farmer. He left the farm at 16 and, after obtaining his BA from Principia College, graduated cum laude from The Harvard Law School in 1958. He held a number of positions in corporate General Counsel offices, but his final employment with various entities owned by the Milstein Family lasted 35 years and provided him with great professional and personal satisfaction. When he died, he was Sr. Vice President-General Counsel for Ogden CAP Properties, LLC. Ed was a man who will be remembered for a quiet reserve that hid a broad sense of humor and irreverence. Many described him as the consummate gentleman. He will be greatly missed by family, friends and many others he worked with over the years. Visitation and funeral services will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Visitation hours are 3-5 and 7-9 on Tuesday, August 17, with the funeral service at 11:30 the following day. A reception will be held at the family apartment on Wednesday August 18, 5-8. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to New York Presbyterian-Columbia University Medical Center/ Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center.

The potential of Internet-based collaboration was vividly demonstrated this month when complexity theorists used blogs and wikis to pounce on a claimed proof for one of the most profound and difficult problems facing mathematicians and computer scientists. Vinay Deolalikar, a mathematician and electrical engineer at Hewlett-Packard, posted a proposed proof of what is known as the ''P versus NP'' problem on a Web site, and quietly notified a number of the key researchers in a field of study that focuses on problems that are solvable only with the application of immense amounts of computing power.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- President Hamid Karzai is planning to sign a decree this week ordering the disbanding of all private security forces by the end of the year, his spokesman said Monday. But it is not clear how the move, which would constitute an extraordinary change in the security makeup of the country, could be carried out. There are at least 24,000 private armed guards in the country, some foreign but most Afghan, and there is no immediately available alternative for the array of crucial tasks they perform.

GILBERTSON--Ellen S. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Museum of the City of New York acknowledge with sadness the passing of Ellen S. Gilbertson, the devoted mother of our Trustee Mark F. Gilbertson, the very able and longtime leader of the Museum's Director's Council. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and deepest condolences to Mark and his brother Hank.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about the ''Star Wars'' films being released on Blu-ray DVD next year misidentified the film in the deleted scene shown. It was from ''Return of the Jedi,'' not ''Star Wars.''

SEOUL, South Korea -- Tens of thousands of South Korean and United States troops began a new round of war games on Monday, as North Korea threatened a ''merciless counterblow'' amid heightened tensions on the Korean Peninsula. The drills are the South's third major exercise -- the second conducted with the United States -- since the sinking of a South Korean warship in the spring for which the South blamed the North.

FRIEDLANDER--David, son of the late George and Christine Friedlander, died peacefully August 15, 2010. Loved by many, he is survived by his son George, wife Edi and sister Eva. Memorial to be announced.

An article on Saturday about Hiram Monserrate's bid for a state Assembly seat referred incorrectly to an appearance by Mr. Monserrate and his companion, Karla Giraldo, at a street renaming ceremony on July 31. It was at least their second public appearance -- not their first -- since a judge lifted a restraining order against Mr. Monserrate earlier in the month. (They appeared together at the Colombian parade on July 25.)

GOLDSTEIN--Mildred. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with deep sorrow the passing of our dear friend and Benefactor. Mrs. Goldstein's vision and generosity are helping advance important biomedical research at Einstein in women's health and cancers, through the Louis Goldstein Swan Chair in Women's Cancer research, established in memory of her daughter. We extend heartfelt condolences to Fredericka and David and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. ROLL--Dale. The family of Dale mourns her passing. She was a dear friend to so many who will miss her and love her forever. Loving daughter, sister, aunt and wife. The family will be attending a private graveside service. May she rest in peace.

An article in some editions on Monday about a bleach spill that closed part of Times Square on Sunday night for about an hour misstated the surname of a woman who commented on the scene. She is Naytira Baker, not Smith.

MESHEKOFF--Edward, artist/ designer/ creator, died August 9, 2010 at 92 in New York City. Bronx-born, his legacy includes many public works of art notably the decorative railings that fill the promenade of Lincoln Center's New York State Theater, murals and mosaics gracing the Met Life, AT&T and Amoco buildings, and imaginative paintings for the SS United States. He received many commissions from such architects as P. Johnson, F. Gina and A. E. Poor. Meshekoff received formal art training at UCLA and pioneered the concept of using visual aids to facilitate training during WWII. He leaves behind his beloved wife Helen, sister Phyllis, dancer/sculptress daughter Luisa, son Matthew, six grandchildren and extended family and friends.

To the Editor: Dr. Perri Klass's article about the difficulties of diagnosing appendicitis (18 and Under, Aug. 10) was terrific. As a retired general surgeon, I would add that it is still a serious disease at times, and can even cause death if allowed to progress without treatment.

Services August 17th, Tuesday 11:45am at The Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be sent to the Stephen Gaynor School, NYC.

She's already the rare woman on the roster of late-night comedy hosts, and now Chelsea Handler, the star of the E! network series "Chelsea Lately," is about to join another mostly male club. On Wednesday, she was officially announced as the host of the 2010 MTV Video Music Awards, which will be shown on Sept. 12. That makes Ms. Handler the first woman to get the gig since 2007 (when the program was hosted by Sarah Silverman) and only the fourth female M.C. to come from outside MTV's walls (the awards program was hosted by Roseanne Barr in 1994, and Bette Midler was a co-host in its 1984 debut.)

Like that of most men, York Wu's first experience with a bow tie involved a wedding. "My cousin was getting married, and I hated the tie that came with my tuxedo," Wu recalls. "So I decided to make my own." From that moment, he was a convert, showing up at the Toronto design firm where he worked sporting a different handmade bow tie every day. With his new line, Noeud Papillon - French for "butterfly knot," the double Windsor of the bow tie world - Wu has elevated the geekiest of accessories to I-want-one status. His designs range from a studded black leather version to a white chiffon confection that does double duty as a Wildean boutonniere. (Female friends have been known to borrow it as a hair ornament.) The attention he lavishes on them - each one is handmade from couture-grade fabrics and individually numbered, with no visible stitches - rivals that which Alber Elbaz of Lanvin, Wu's design hero and himself a bow tie man, devotes to his frocks. "I want Noeud Papillon ties to be the equivalent of Lanvin," he says, "structured and strong on the inside, elegant and effortless on the outside."

On a snow-covered Alpine roadway, tire tracks veer from the worn ruts and continue down a slope. They disappear before abruptly re-emerging at a tree, where the fated vehicle lies on its back, wheels to the sky, with the silhouettes of two bystanders near the wreckage. On closer scrutiny, what appears to be a perfunctory archival accident photo adopts qualities of fine-art photography: intersecting planes, rich grays and a pervasive sense of downward motion, as if the landscape would, if allowed, slide out of frame.

September is almost here, with its cooler temperatures (at least we in New York hope they're cooler) and, even better, the arrival of a new John Derian collection for Target. The East Village master of decoupage plates, trays, lamps and other decorative items has followed his 2008 effort for the design-centric retailer with a bigger, more varied collection that includes stationery, home décor, housewares and storage - all at I'll-take-10-of-those prices. Signature designs run through the collection: for example, a silhouette that adorns the cover of a composition book ($2.50) also appears on a ceramic mug ($4.99). Storage bins covered in geranium-leaf or moth prints are too pretty to hide in a closet, and there are plastic trays for every possible use. My favorites among the latter are the Tapered Tray ($19.99, shown here in pale geranium), which is large enough to carry drinks outside, or to stack books or magazines. A smaller tray ($12.99) is perfect for organizing jars of cotton swabs and makeup brushes in the bathroom or for putting your keys on near the front door. Its image of a pink room (called House-Mouse in the collection), taken from a late-19th-century German print, is one of Derian's favorites. "It's so conceptual," he said, "as if you're putting your things down in a room." And the oval tray ($12.99), with its Home Sweet Home motto (based on a print that Derian found when he bought an old frame), would look great hanging on a wall, with its old-fashioned, almost camp sensibility. Derian particularly likes the way that these pieces work in modern as well as more traditional rooms. "They all cross over, which is cool," he added. The collection will be available beginning Sept. 5, but as always with Target's designer collaborations, supplies are limited.

In Charlotte Salomon's art, text and image meet in an exuberant burst of joy and anguish. Brooding, fluid figures are drawn with a line that seems ready to disappear into the vortex of color on the page. Tight columns of text are piled one atop the other like hieroglyphs in an Egyptian relic. An exhibition at the Jewish Historical Museum of early gouaches by the artist, who was killed at Auschwitz during World War II, examines this mix of text and image, and the explicitly lyrical nature of her work.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Lebanon passed a law on Tuesday granting Palestinian refugees here the same rights to work as other foreigners, a step in ending years of discrimination that had restricted them to the most menial of jobs. A bill was approved after months of debate in Parliament that cut across decades of history in Lebanon and the rest of the Middle East, where the refugees' fate remains a pressing question. While about 4.7 million refugees from the Arab-Israeli wars of 1948 and 1967 are spread across the region, many of them in the West Bank, Gaza, Jordan and Syria, the estimated 400,000 in Lebanon have endured some of the most wretched conditions.

MEXICO CITY -- President Felipe Calderón on Tuesday summoned legislators to participate later this week in his continuing discussions with all of Mexico's political establishment about how to win the war against the drug cartels. With the pace of killings rising, officials have backed off their effort to persuade Mexicans that the mounting death toll was proof that the government was succeeding in disrupting the cartels. Instead, Mr. Calderón set up the high-level forums in an effort to show that the Mexican government was willing to engage its critics and listen to suggestions.

SUSSMAN--Ethel K.,96, a 30 year resident of Somers, NY died August 17, 2010 at her home. Ethel, together with her husband, Emanuel were founding members of Bet Torah Synagogue in Mt. Kisco, NY. She is survived by her daughters: Natalee Morse of Dallas, TX and Lilyan (Donald) Seixas of New York, NY and her grandchildren Ken Glasser, Lisa Albanese, Mark Rothenstein, Kim Reist and Jeffrey Morse, eight great-grandchildren and her companion of the last five years: Simone King. The funeral will be held on Thursday, August 19 at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY at 12:00pm. Burial will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

SEAMAN--Lynn J.,formerly Reynolds, of Rockville Centre and East Hampton, NY, passed away on August 3rd at the age of 65. Graduate of Hunter College High School and Muhlenberg College, Lynn was a devoted teacher of French and Spanish in the Bellmore-Merrick School District for more than 30 years. She died at home surrounded by her loving husband, Gary, and devoted daughters, Nicole and Jessica. Lynn will be remembered for the love and support she gave her family and friends and her love of music, literature, languages and the New York Times' crossword. Lynn is also survived by her siblings, John, Nancy, Deborah and Margaret, cousin, Joanne, grandchildren, Drew, Jake, and Amy. Donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

MASSAD--Robert. Died August 10. Bob Massad cared passionately about community health care. As former Director of the Residency Program in Social Medicine at Montefiore Medical Center and Chairman Emeritus and founding chair of the Department of Family Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, he brought charm, irascibility and his considerable skills as a physician, teacher and leader to the task of transforming the health of poor communities. He will be missed. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to the All Stars Project or the American River Conservancy.

ETRA--Dr. Bernard died peacefully of natural causes on Tuesday, August 10th. He was a great pediatrician for over forty years and was revered at both Hackensack Hospital Pediatrics and Columbia Presbyterian Babies Clinic. He was a founding member of the Teaneck Jewish Community Center. He was a devoted husband to Diane Etra, beloved father to William, David, and Jeanie, Grandfather to Rachel Anne, Weylin, and AnnaRose, and his grand-dog Buddy.

PETZ--Edwin V.,died August 13, 2010 at home in the arms of his wife, Louise, as he wished. He also leaves behind his daughter Katherine, his son Christopher and their spouses, Jeff Becker and Leah Jones. Ed was born in Beatrice, NE in 1935 and decided at an early age that he wanted to be a lawyer not a farmer. He left the farm at 16 and, after obtaining his BA from Principia College, graduated cum laude from The Harvard Law School in 1958. He held a number of positions in corporate General Counsel offices, but his final employment with various entities owned by the Milstein Family lasted 35 years and provided him with great professional and personal satisfaction. When he died, he was Sr. Vice President-General Counsel for Ogden CAP Properties, LLC. Ed was a man who will be remembered for a quiet reserve that hid a broad sense of humor and irreverence. Many described him as the consummate gentleman. He will be greatly missed by family, friends and many others he worked with over the years. Visitation and funeral services will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Visitation hours are 3-5 and 7-9 on Tuesday, August 17, with the funeral service at 11:30 the following day. A reception will be held at the family apartment on Wednesday August 18, 5-8. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to New York Presbyterian-Columbia University Medical Center/ Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center.

BRINCKERHOFF--H. Todd, Jr.,77, family patriarch, passed away August 16, 2010. Born in Beacon on June 26, 1933, he was the son of the late Hampton Todd and Esther Barkalow Brinckerhoff. A lifelong resident of Fishkill, he was born and raised in the Brinckerhoff Homestead. He also maintained additional residences in Wolfeboro, NH and Ocean Reef Club, FL. In 1961 with partner John Neuville, he founded Brinckerhoff and Neuville Insurance. He served on the boards of Mount Saint Mary College and Marist College where he was a devoted trustee and advisor and inspiration for the Hudson River Valley Institute. He was one of the founders of the Fishkill Bank and Trust Company, which eventually became M&T Bank. He was a member of the Sons of the American Revolution and the Holland Society. He was predeceased by his wife of 54 years, Beverly (Baader); and is survived by his three daughters, Mary, Barbara and Margaret and many other loving family members and friends. For more information, please contact McHoul Funeral Home at (845) 221-2000 or www.mchoulfuneralhome.com

LONDON -- In the land of the embattled motorist, Haroon Zafaryab emerged on Tuesday as the people's champion, a sort of Steven Slater of the roadways. Mr. Zafaryab, 27, defied a tow-truck team by sitting in his car for 30 hours, eventually running up $5,560 in parking fines, as towing company officials, supporters of Mr. Zafaryab and police officers gathered in the delivery area behind a shopping plaza where he had started it all by parking for two hours in a restricted zone.

SPEAKING WORDS OF WISDOM Q.I have been inviting new acquaintances for brunch, dinner or even just tea in order to welcome newcomers to my neighborhood or have them meet other neighbors, or to just expand my circle of friends. I enjoy their company, and most will bring flowers, a bottle of wine or a small gift (which I don't think is necessary). Most will call the next day to thank me for a pleasant get-together. But very seldom do these guests ever invite me back. If they don't want to invite me to their homes, they could invite me to go to a movie or concert with them, or even a picnic in a public park. Reciprocity doesn't seem to occur to very many people.

CARTER--Charles E.,died on August 1, 2010, at age 82. He was predeceased by his wife of 41 years, Ruth W. Berenda, Ph.D. Charles was born in Calais, France and was a graduate of the University of California at Berkeley. For many years, he operated his own independent travel agency. Charles was an avid traveler, passionate about opera and art, and a master of French language and culture. He was well known for his lavish parties, culinary skills and he delighted in the company of his friends. Charles was a respected teacher at the Quest Learning Center for Mature Adults. His customs and manners were "Old World" and he enriched the lives of everyone who knew him. He was much loved and will be missed and remembered by his family of many friends. A memorial gathering will be held in Manhattan on Saturday, August 21.
