8 P.M. (13, 49) SOUTH PACIFIC Kelli O'Hara and Paulo Szot, above, play Nellie Forbush, a Navy nurse, and Émile de Becque, a French plantation owner, whose romance falters when she learns he had children with a Polynesian woman, in this Lincoln Center Theater revival of the Rodgers and Hammerstein classic. The production (which closes on Sunday), directed by Bartlett Sher and presented here by ''Live From Lincoln Center,'' won seven Tony Awards. Reviewing the musical in The New York Times after it opened in 2008, Ben Brantley described Ms. O'Hara and Mr. Szot as the revelatory stars of a pitch-perfect cast. ''Above all, though, what impresses about this 'South Pacific' is how deeply, fallibly and poignantly human every character seems,'' he added. ''Nearly 60 years ago Brooks Atkinson, writing in The New York Times, described the show as 'a tenderly beautiful idyll of genuine people inexplicably tossed together in a strange corner of the world.' I think a lot of us had forgotten that's what 'South Pacific' is really about. In making the past feel unconditionally present, this production restores a glorious gallery of genuine people who were only waiting to be resurrected.'' 8 P.M. Chicago IN May 1980, during the height of the movement to add an Equal Rights Amendment for women to the Constitution, an activist named Wanda Brandstetter delivered a note to Nord Swanstrom, an Illinois state representative. ''Mr. Swanstrom,'' it said, ''the offer to help in your election and $1,000 for your campaign for pro-E.R.A. vote.'' Things did not go as Ms. Brandstetter hoped. The measure was never ratified by the Legislature, while her offer of $1,000 lead directly to her conviction for bribery in the Illinois courts.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about Lebanon's setting up a fund for Lebanese at home and abroad to help arm the country's underequipped military misidentified the nation that has provided more than $720 million in assistance to the Lebanese Army since 2006, It is the United States, not Iran. (A correction in this space on Tuesday referred incorrectly, in some editions, to the original error. The article did not cite Lebanon as the source of the money.)

Sometimes, after the police and ambulance workers leave the scene of a crime, the most mundane items are left behind to mark the violence. In this case, after a shooting on July 21 at Madison Avenue and East 132nd Street in Manhattan, it was a blue glove, discarded in haste as medical workers rushed to get a man identified as Dereck Nelson, 25, to Harlem Hospital Center. Similar gloves were scattered on the blood-spotted passenger seat of a black S.U.V. parked nearby. At one point, the police began removing the yellow tape, but quickly put it back up to discourage curious passers-by. As for Mr. Nelson, he was pronounced dead when the ambulance arrived at the hospital. Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

You do not have to serve smoked salmon with Scotch or fried chicken with bourbon. But mezcal is so deeply rooted in the heart of Mexico that whatever you serve alongside begs for chilies and cilantro at the very least. Glasses of mezcal, perhaps with a beer chaser, could accompany a dinner, but my preference is to sip mezcal with snacks or appetizers that have a Mexican accent. At a farm stand, I saw fresh, shiny, hunter-green poblanos, and pounced on them. These generously sized, almost triangular chilies deliver moderate heat and are usually stuffed and fried, though sometimes baked.

BELL--Martha. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Professor Martha Bell, a Brooklyn College faculty member for more than three decades, and a member of the University Faculty Senate, whose academic integrity, outstanding leadership and dedication to diversity, access to education and financial support for CUNY evoked great admiration. She was Chair of the Brooklyn College SEEK (Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge) Department, developed innovative nationally-praised strategies to help educationally disadvantaged students succeed in college, and served on the Board of Trustees' Committee on Student Affairs and Special Programs. We offer our deepest sympathy to her husband, Professor George Shapiro, their son, Isaac Shapiro, and her extended family. She will be greatly missed. Benno Schmidt Chairperson, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

GRUTCHFIELD--Martha Nelle (nee Welday) Died August 12, 2010, age 79. Martha was born July 11, 1931 in Dayton, OH, the second child of Howard Welday, a pharmacist, and Bonnie Birt Welday, a teacher. She was educated in the public schools of Dayton, then attended the University of Dayton, Earlham College (Richmond, IN) where she studied music, and Columbia University (New York City) where she studied library science. She worked for Anderson's Music Co. in Dayton and the Dayton Public Library, then later in New York she was an editor at the Wilson Co. and a music cataloger at City College. Her first marriage to John Young ended in divorce. She married Walter Grutchfield in 1968. She raised her children, Alice and Michael Grutchfield, in New York City in the 1970s and 1980s, then returned to work as an archivist at the American Music Center and the New York Public Library in the 1990s. She was a member of the Morningside Meeting of the Society of Friends. For many years she was an avid birder in Central Park and belonged to the Nature Conservancy and the Linnaean Society. Survivors include her husband, Walter, her children, Alice and Michael, her grandson, Kai Grutchfield, and her sister, Venabelle Williams of Sidney, OH.

SCHAFFER--Irving, 87, died August 17, 2010. Beloved husband of Ilse. Loving father of Wendy, Carole, Paul and Amy. Adoring grandfather of Emily, Kathryn, Eli and Robert. Brother of Muriel Epstein. Veteran of World War II. Services Thursday 11:00am at Gramercy Park Chapel, 353 2nd Avenue, New York.

The Music Albums listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday, showing the top 10 albums by sales in the week ending Aug. 8, misidentified the recording label for Arcade Fire, whose album ''The Suburbs'' was No. 1. A paternity test ordered by the Icelandic Supreme Court to determine if the chess champion Bobby Fischer was the father of a 9-year-old Filipino girl came back negative on Tuesday, according to people involved in the dispute over his estate. Officials took a sample on July 5 from Mr. Fischer's remains in the cemetery of Laugardaelir Church in Iceland to determine if he was the father of Jinky Young, the Filipino girl.

An obituary on Monday about Stanley Simon, a founder of the Joseph Bulova School of Watchmaking, misstated the title of Arde Bulova, who conceived the school. He was chairman of the Bulova Watch Company, not president.

An article on Aug. 10 about a study testing the use of the drug ketamine to treat depression in patients with bipolar disorder misstated, at one point, the affiliation of the paper's senior author. As the article noted elsewhere, the scientist, Dr. Carlos A. Zarate Jr., is a clinical investigator at the National Institute of Mental Health, not at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

The brevity of the storm belied its destructive strength: in just over half an hour, it felled more than 500 trees in Central Park and damaged hundreds more so badly that they had to be removed in the months that followed. IT seems appropriate to say I love the new Hermès scarf site, jaimemoncarre.com, which the Paris company just introduced. I've been a fan of the main Hermès site, but this is a clever addition for a house that is known for silk scarves and derives a lot of revenue from them. Hermès focuses on young women in Paris, London, New York and Tokyo, offers brief bio sketches and then shows how they wear scarves - which are having a comeback. The photographs are a cut above street-fashion images, and yet not as glossy-perfect as those found in magazines.

For years Americans had been labeling more and more appliances and other purchases as "necessities," rather than "luxuries." Microwaves, computers and other wonders of modern civilization, upon being adopted in greater numbers, became more likely to be considered need-to-haves instead of nice-to-haves, according to surveys conducted by the Pew Research Center.

Delta Airlines recently added a feature on its Facebook page that allows users to book travel through the social networking site. The application, the Delta Ticket Window, offers a pared-down version of the booking service on Delta's own (also recently retooled) Web site. There is no option to book a multicity trip or to buy a ticket using rewards, for example. But there is one crucial add-on: you can share your travel plans with friends of your choice.

Everyone knows swimming is excellent exercise, but it is also terrific therapy. A striking rise in sea temperatures in waters off Indonesia may be responsible for one of the most rapid and destructive coral bleaching events on record, a marine conservation group reported this week. Large swaths of coral reef in the Andaman Sea off the north coast of Sumatra are now up to 80 percent bleached, with more colonies expected to die off in the coming months, according to marine biologists who conducted extensive surveys of the area.

In the first ambitious journal article related to the gulf oil spill, scientists report that a huge plume of dispersed oil may not be breaking down rapidly. The data used to form their conclusion was gathered in late June.

The powerful antitax fund-raising group, the Club for Growth, endorsed four Republicans vying for  House seats in November: Todd Young in Indiana, Mick Mulvaney in South Carolina, Stephen Fincher in Tennessee and Tim Griffin in Arkansas.

Newark will be turned into a Poetry Village in October, when the Dodge Poetry Festival, the largest of its kind in the nation, comes to town. Opening Oct. 7, the 13th biennial will feature an impressive lineup of poets, including four poets laureate -- Billy Collins, Rita Dove, Kay Ryan and Mark Strand -- as well as other acclaimed wordsmiths like Galway Kinnell, Amiri Baraka, Bob Hicok, Martín Espada, Dunya Mikhail, Joseph Millar, Nancy Morejón, Sharon Olds, Marie Ponsot and Claudia Rankine. More than 20,000 people are expected to attend the four days of readings and discussions. The festival is usually held at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., but it ran into financial difficulties this year. That is when the City of Newark and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center agreed to help sponsor the festival with the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation.

I based Tuesday's column on a peach crostini I tasted at Roman's in Brooklyn last month. More recently, I returned to the restaurant. The crostini was off the menu, and in its place was a special of figs nestled on a bed of ricotta, topped with spiky arugula. It was reminiscent of the crostini - the sweet fruit, creamy cheese and tangy greens - but without the crunch of toasted bread. I liked the dish a lot, especially the luscious figs, which were grown as locally as you can get: in the Bushwick backyard of Scarlett Lindeman, one of the cooks.

"Look up" might have been the catch phrase of last night's Target Kaleidoscope Fashion Spectacular at the Standard Hotel but there was plenty to dazzle the eye everywhere you turned. Even before the entire south side of the hotel was transformed into a neon spectacular featuring 66 models in 155 rooms, a visual feast that hinted at artist In Sook Kim's "Saturday Night" voyeuristic hotel series, the Standard's biergarten was a light show of flashing rave rings and bright psychedelic bellinis. Holding court in the middle of the colorful fray were "Gossip Girl" sweetheart Penn Badgley, Prabal Gurung, Richard Chai, Marchesa's Georgina Chapman and hubby, Harvey Weinstein. Elsewhere, little Langley Hemingway and Leigh Lezark, who dominated in a game of table tennis earlier in the night, huddled in a secluded corner. In other words, plenty of eye candy for the onlookers on Washington Street craning their necks to spy on the invited peeping Toms.

Geraldine Brooks, a novelist and journalist who covered conflicts in the Balkans, the Middle East and Africa, was named the recipient of the 2010 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for Lifetime Achievement, its organizers said on Thursday. Sharon Rab, the founder and a chairwoman of the Dayton Literary Peace Prize Foundation, said that Ms. Brooks "reveals to her readers what their political leaders try to hide - the ugly realities of conflict and its destructive effects even on those far from the frontlines." She continued, "We are delighted to be honoring a writer whose skill, imagination, and unique background allow her to create vivid characters whose stories help people understand the vital importance of fostering peace throughout the world." Ms. Brooks, 54, also the winner of the Pulitzer Prize in fiction in 2006, for her novel "March," will receive a $10,000 prize.

In last Sunday's Book Review, we published a letter from Peter Crane of Seattle commenting on Jay Parini's recent review of "Sophia Tolstoy: A Biography." Crane's great-grandfather Raphael Löwenfeld , who was Tolstoy's German translator and biographer, had visited the Tolstoys at their estate, Crane writes, and he was distressed by Sophia's ill-treatment by Leo Tolstoy's disciples - one subject of the book Parini reviewed. It was an interesting story, and we asked him to expand on it.

Months before the official opening of "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown," theatergoers have thrilled to each incremental casting announcement for this musical adaptation of the Pedro Almodóvar comedy, as celebrated Broadway stars like Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott and Laura Benanti were added to its ensemble. Who, these impatient observers wondered, would be cast in the final principal role of this production? Now they have their answer.Justin Guarini, the runner-up on the first-ever season of "American Idol," has joined the musical's cast, Lincoln Center Theater said on Thursday. Mr. Guarini, who was edged out by Kelly Clarkson for the "Idol" crown in 2002, will play the role of Carlos, the son of Ivan (Mr. Mitchell) and Lucia (Ms. LuPone). It will be the Broadway debut of Mr. Guarini, who previously appeared in a workshop version of the Beach Boys musical "Good Vibrations" and with Ms. Clarkson in the film "From Justin to Kelly."

Though he may or may not continue to exist in the Tralfamadorian sense of the word, a part of Kurt Vonnegut will live on in an Indianapolis library dedicated to him that will contain artifacts from his life and career. The Associated Press reported on Wednesday that the Kurt Vonnegut Memorial Library will have its opening in November, where it will display first-edition books by the "Slaughterhouse Five" and "Sirens of Titans" author, who died in 2007, as well as a replica of his writing studio, items he collected during his service in World War II and numerous rejection letters he received before achieving his literary fame.

Daniel Cho was a cellist. He said good-bye to his wife, Julia, and his 22-month-old daughter, Audrey, when he left on a European tour in June -- a few weeks of touring with Regina Spektor. He was making his mark in the music world after years of working two jobs and chasing a dream. The day before he was to appear with Spektor at the Montreux Jazz Festival in Switzerland, he went to Lake Geneva, showed friends some videos of Audrey that he carried on his iPhone, left his phone and wallet on a towel and went for a swim. What happened next is not clear, perhaps never will be, but somehow Dan, who was a strong swimmer, drowned. He was 33.

Would Catherine Deneuve have made as convincing an ice maiden had she been a brunette? That question gets explored in depth in ''Brune/Blonde,'' an exhibition by Alain Bergala opening this October at the Cinémathèque Française in Paris. Blondes, as it turns out, were most often cast as housewives until the 1930s, when flaxen-haired women became typecast as sultry and dangerous. A book of the same name will be released concurrently and include essays by film and cultural historians like Michelle Perrot, Dominique Païni and Stéphane Guéguan, along with an interview with Deneuve herself. And to get to the root (pun intended) of the issue, ''Brune/Blonde'' looks beyond cinema to the significance of women's hair color in art (Alphonse Mucha, Francesca Woodman) and mythology. Somehow we already knew Rapunzel couldn't have pulled off a Louise Brooks.

At dinner with a friend recently, the subject of writers' Web sites came up, and this friend mentioned Jennifer Egan's Web site, which she said was "incredible" or "amazing" or some such superlative. As this friend is not the sort to indulge in reckless superlative tossing, I went home and, as soon as I had a spare moment, looked up Egan's site. That "moment" turned into at least an hour.The site isn't your standard author-Web-site fare. Yes, there are the usual pages cataloging books, interviews, other writings, reviews. There are several examples of the "standard 'grinning mug,'" as Egan herself describes her author photos. But these requisites are handled discreetly. The bolder elements, the first to catch the reader's eye, are the names of places and dates.

When it's hot in Rome, survival instincts kick in. City dwellers tend to stay indoors, with their shutters closed tight against the blazing sun. When they do venture outside during the day, there is fierce competition for shade and it's every man for himself. Evenings are much more civil, however, as Rome wakes up from its heat-induced slumber and people hit the local piazza or neighborhood bar. This ritual, called aperitivo, is a sort of Italian happy hour in which drinks are consumed sparingly and always in the company of snacks.

When I was in college, I had an enormous pair of stereo speakers housed in wood cabinets. Back then, most speaker makers favored wood because it radiated a rich, warm sound. Now a handful of companies offer wooden earbud headphones, suggesting that they recreate that natural resonance for iPods and other portable audio devices. Can it possibly work?

The Droid2 inspires a sense of familiarity. Physically, it is almost identical in size and weight to the first Droid released nine months ago, and has the same 3.7-inch screen and a slide-out keyboard configuration. But there is a big difference under the hood. The new Droid is almost twice as fast, and promises longer battery life. The Droid2 runs on the newest version of the Android operating system installed, 2.2, also called ''Froyo,'' which offers a pile of new features. Chief among them is the ability to view Flash video and animation, which is limited on iPhones and some other smartphones.

In my recent article about iHome, the largest manufacturer of iPhone/iPod speaker docks, I pointed out that Apple's strict design regulations make it easier for accessories makers to create products, secure in the knowledge that they won't quickly need to reposition one feature or another in response to an Apple design change. That standardization has allowed a large number of iPod accessory manufacturers to flourish, including iLuv.

I understand social. I understand entrepreneur. But when you put the two words together, I have to pause. I pause because I wonder whether social entrepreneur is really entrepreneurship the way I understand it -- where a business owner takes risk in the hope of making money. I guess my question is this: If it's mostly about the social good, what makes it entrepreneurship? And if it's mostly about the entrepreneurship, what makes it social? Isn't the phrase an oxymoron?

An article and a headline last Thursday about portable housing misstated the price per square foot of one model, the HabiHut. It is $20, not $2. The article also referred imprecisely to the terms of a 2008 California housing law. While the law requires municipalities to set aside land for emergency shelters for the homeless, it does not extend to homeless encampments.

The case study we published last week recounted growing pains at FreshDirect, an online grocer that was already in a heap of trouble -- hemorrhaging money and churning through customers -- when an immigration audit decimated its work force in late 2007. Written by Jessica Bruder, the article looked at FreshDirect's struggle to reinvent itself and buck the conventional wisdom that Internet grocers cannot win profits. For two years, FreshDirect stopped soliciting new customers to work on better serving its existing patrons. That strategy seems to have paid off: A loyal core of repeat customers -- about 45,000 to 50,000 in all -- now generates two-thirds of the company's revenue. Richard S. Braddock, chief executive, reports that the company had its first profitable year in 2009 on revenue of $250 million and he expects the company's 2010 revenues will rise to $300 million.

An Op-Ed article on Wednesday about the Rod Blagojevich trial incorrectly named the chief executive of Massey Energy. It is Don Blankenship, not Joe. The article also gave an incorrect date for a Supreme Court ruling on campaign finance laws. Buckley v. Valeo was decided in 1976, not 1974.

Federal regulators accused the State of New Jersey of securities fraud on Wednesday for claiming it had been properly funding public workers' pensions when it was not. The Securities and Exchange Commission said the action was its first ever against a state, and only its second against any government over the handling of a public pension fund. The first was the city of San Diego. More may be in store; the agency announced in January that it had a special unit looking into public pension disclosures. The S.E.C. has been trying to assume more authority over municipal securities.

BOORSTEIN--Raymond, 66, August 18, Sarasota, FL. Ray has lost his futile battle with ALS. He will be lovingly remembered by his wife Marilyn, sons Jay and Todd, grandchildren, brothers, nieces and nephews and many friends and relatives. The Boorstein Family

KRUESI--Oscar R, M.D.,86 passed away June 27, 2010, following a brief illness. A renowned physician and teacher, Dr. Kruesi was a long-time resident of Bernardsville, NJ, before retiring to Fort Myers, FL three years ago. He graduated from Union College, Schenectady, NY, following service in the U.S. Air Force during World War II. He later graduated Cornell University Medical School. An internist, he was a pioneer in preventive care who, starting in the 1960s, used primarily nutritional supplements to treat mental and physical disorders. He was an Assistant Clinical Professor of Medicine for Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, in addition to teaching across the U.S. and Europe. For many years he served as a trustee of Morristown Memorial Hospital, where he started the Cardiac Care Unit in the 1960s and co-founded the Alcohol Service. He was a trustee also of the Somerset Hills YMCA, Schizophrenia Foundation of New Jersey, Princeton Bio Center, and many other organizations. He was an emeritus member of the Explorers Club. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Elizabeth, his brothers Frank, of Boise, ID, and Paul of Golden, CO, his sons Markus of Isle of Palms, SC, Hugo of Fairfax, VA, and Bernardsville, NJ nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to The Shelter for Abused Women and Children, P.O. Box 10102, Naples, Florida 34101.

10 P.M. (ABC) NIGHTLINEPRIME: SECRETS OF YOUR MIND -- WHY WE DO WHAT WE DO ABC News inaugurates its first prime-time series with this four-part special, which explores the mysteries and science of the brain through some unusual case studies. In this premiere episode, the ''Nightline'' anchor Cynthia McFadden, left, examines the brain in love, starting with the story of a love lost -- and found again -- after a traumatic head injury. She also speaks with a man who is literally paralyzed by romantic feelings for his wife and views the before-and-after brain scans of a couple who took a journey to deepen their relationship. 8 P.M. (13) ARMIDA The soprano Renée Fleming plays Rossini's vengeful sorceress opposite six tenors -- Lawrence Brownlee, John Osborn, Yeghishe Manucharyan, José Manuel Zapata, Kobie van Rensburg and Barry Banks -- in this infrequently heard 1817 work, given its Metropolitan Opera premiere in April and presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met.'' ''This was Ms. Fleming's show, and she was impressive over all,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in his review in The New York Times.

The versatile Wii Remote can be snapped inside a steering wheel or guitar, so why not a graphics tablet? The uDraw GameTablet ($70) is a 4 inch by 6 inch drawing tablet that rests on your lap. When used with uDraw Studio, the included disk, children can draw pictures with charcoal or opaque water colors. This is no Wacom tablet. There's a slight lag when splotching paint, and you can't import digital photos. But you can export projects in JPG format to an SD card, and there's a mesmorizing replay feature that reviews paintings, one stroke at a time. So, if your kids don't like what's on TV, they can draw their own.

Dorothy is survived by her brother, Dr. Jerome Green (Lila), her daughter, Louise Vermillion (Judd), two grandchildren, Nicholas Frame and Jessamine Vermillion, and several nephews and nieces. Contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Public Library.

An article on Wednesday about plans for the Nokia Theater in Times Square to be renamed Best Buy Theater, using information supplied by a publicist, referred imprecisely to the executive position that Drew Panayiotou holds at Best Buy. He is chief marketing officer of United States-based operations; he is not the company's top marketing officer. (Barry Judge, an executive vice president, is head of global marketing for Best Buy.)

An article on Aug. 6 about the annual report of the Social Security trustees, using information from a written statement by Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner, referred incorrectly to the financial history of the government program. And an article on Sunday about President Obama's radio address on preserving Social Security repeated the error. This year, for the first time since 1983, the program will pay out more money than it takes in; this will not be the first time that has ever happened. (Mr. Geithner's statement said the shortfall would occur ''for the first time this year, six years earlier than was projected last year.'' But the trustees' summary of their report said the shortfall would occur ''this year for the first time since 1983.'')

A review on Tuesday about the Downtown Dance Festival in Battery Park, using information from a publicist, misidentified the lone boy who is with Figures in Flight Dance Company. He is Liam Appelson -- not Ryan Ludwig, a female dancer in the company.

An obituary on Tuesday about the classics scholar Bernard Knox misstated the publication dates of two books for which he wrote introductions. Robert Fagles's translation of the ''Iliad'' was published in 1990, not 1991, and his translation of the ''Odyssey'' was published in 1996, not 2002.

Sometimes in a city as nonstop as Manhattan, a night out requires little more than stepping out of the house and looking around. It was 9:30 p.m. on Tuesday in Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, but it seemed as packed as at midday, dotted with people who played music, conversed, cuddled or just watched as others transformed the park into an extension of their living rooms. ''It's an ongoing carnival -- it's a spectacular spectacle, an event of its own accord,'' said Alexander Sun, who travels every evening from Borough Park, Brooklyn, to spend the waning hours in Washington Square Park, where he is a fixture. ''It's an amazing kaleidoscope of humanity.''

As sales pick up, I've been trying to build our production capacity proportionally. This has been hard for me to accomplish in the past. During the last big expansion, between 2003 and 2008, I found myself in the position of hiring willy-nilly, throwing warm bodies at production bottlenecks. In the rush to get work out the door, we never set up a training program and we didn't do a good job of increasing productivity with technology. This was a disastrous mistake. More than anything else, an inflated payroll drained cash from the company and kept us from making a profit. As we ramp up again, I'm doing it differently. It's become apparent to me over the years that the key to a highly productive work force is training and specialization. On the shop floor, that means that the guys are doing a narrower range of things. We don't make all kinds of furniture any more -- now it's conference tables and more conference tables, with a credenza or two thrown in.

Burned by a previous experience running a venture-capital-backed technology start-up, Elizabeth Charnock vowed to do things differently the next time. Despite challenges, Ms. Charnock, 43, is now making good on her promise as chief executive and founder of Cataphora, a bootstrapped, 60-employee firm that makes software used to track and analyze computer users' online activity and communications. So far, the company, founded in 2002 and based in Redwood Shores, Calif., has focused on gathering evidence for lawsuits and internal corporate investigations -- such as unearthing incriminating patterns in an employee's e-mailed communications. Now, Cataphora is entering the consumer market with Digital Mirror, software that allows its users to manage and optimize their online identities. Ms. Charnock, author of ''E-Habits: What You Must do to Optimize Your Professional Digital Presence,'' recently explained that diversifying on a shoestring is just the latest test for her company. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

WITTEK--Alec, M.D.,58, suddenly, on August 14, 2010. Devoted son, beloved husband of Dr. Pamela Cohen, son Max and sister Jackie, dear uncle and friend. A man of manifold talents, Alec was a revered pediatrician and expert in infectious disease drug and vaccine development, musician and artist who produced works in photography, pen, ink and his most recent passion, pottery. Jeopardy champion. His was a unique combination of wit, compassion, humor and love. He had such a big heart. Memorial donations to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Association (www.4hcm.org).

Football players were holding out for more money long before the N.F.L. even existed. In 1892, the Allegheny Athletic Association faced the Pittsburgh Athletic Club in an ''amateur'' football game; in the era before air quotes, some folks naively believed none of the players were paid. According to a history on the Pro Football Hall of Fame Web site, both teams scoured the country offering to compensate ringers, with both teams hoping to land the grand prize: William Heffelfinger, a three-time all-American guard at Yale who was known as Pudge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Most research on renewable energy has focused on replacing the electricity that now comes from burning coal and natural gas. But the spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the reliance on Middle East imports and the threat of global warming are reminders that oil is also a pressing worry. A lot of problems could be solved with a renewable replacement for oil-based gasoline and diesel in the fuel tank -- either a new liquid fuel or a much better battery. Yet, success in this field is so hard to reliably predict that research has been limited, and even venture capitalists tread lightly. Now the federal government is plunging in, in what the energy secretary, Steven Chu, calls the hunt for miracles.
BAUMGOLD--Morris "Buzz". His intelligence, warmth, kindness, and wit will be sorely missed, and the 4th floor will not be the same without him. Condolences to the Baumgold family. D&E Singer Inc.

ROSEN--Martin W.,89, of Palm Beach, FL and Greenwich, CT, passed away on August 18, 2010. Beloved husband of Selma, father of Robert and Nancy Rosen, Harold and Marian Rosen, Lee and Julia Rosen, and Susan and Andrew Alisberg, Grandfather of 10 adoring grandchildren, and great- grandfather of four. Funeral noon Thursday, August 19, 2010 at Temple Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Anti-Defamation League, 621 NW 53rd St, Suite 450, Boca Raton, FL 33487 or Greenwich Hospital, Development Office, 5 Perryridge Rd, Greenwich, CT 06830.

PORTLAND, Me. -- Even as this city has evolved into a showplace for locavore restaurants and edgy designers, its working waterfront has remained a point of pride. Across Commercial Street from the gaslight-and-cobblestone retail district, the rough-hewn wharves and piers of Portland Harbor still house bait shops, ship chandleries and other marine businesses. But with the fishing industry in constant decline, a push is on to relax zoning rules in the central waterfront district and allow other businesses on the wharves.

Just before dusk in Sitges, Spain, a few bathers are still bobbing up and down in the gentle surf of the Mediterranean, and a man dressed in white is stacking the beach loungers for the day. Starlings streak through a melon-colored sky garnished with raspberry-colored clouds, and when the lights come on at the parish church on the promontory overlooking the sea, it means it’s probably time to start to thinking about dinner.

At T, we strive to make every issue a well-rounded one. And this season, fashion is actually on the same page, with its embrace of women who literally bust the mold. Suzy Menkes contemplates the sudden appearance of breasts on the runway. Our cover star, Freida Pinto, of “Slumdog” fame, a rare beauty with a candor to match, throws a few curve balls at Horacio Silva — and a glass of wine at the photographer Ryan McGinley. Linda Yablonsky encounters the artist Nathalie Djurberg, whose twisted, animated feats of clay celebrate bodies emaciated, voluptuous and obese; Christopher Petkanas delves into Maxime de la Falaise‘s smoldering unpublished memoirs and discovers a true lady Libertine; and Holly Brubach rediscovers the work of Caroline Blackwood, a brilliant writer whose talents are often eclipsed by her status as muse to Lucian Freud. Elsewhere, Daphne Merkin wonders if a couple of bosomy looks on the Louis Vuitton runway can conquer our much larger social fear of flesh (probably not); Ford Models revs up its engines with a more diverse lineup of faces and bodies; and the actress Laetitia Casta fills Brigitte Bardot’s shoes — and everything else. Do you think Barack Obama is a Muslim? According to the Pew Center, many Americans do. According to Politico's Josh Gerstein, Time magazine's pollsters found that a majority of Republicans do. But here's another question: How many of the Americans who say they think Barack Obama is a Muslim actually believe that he is one? That's not as obtuse a query as it might appear, as some of the blogosphere's better minds have argued in recent days.

'Oh, those are fantastic! I want to see them! They're adorable! Let me fix your socks," Patricia Fox cries out when she spies Suzanne Golden's shoes, a pair of black and white Comme des Garçons winkle pickers festooned with rhinestone buckles that serve as a counterpoint to the rest of Golden's black-and-white Junya Watanabe ensemble. Fox, who is wearing a veiled chapeau with a blossom brim, a 1950s sequined floral jacket, a chiffon dress with a hobble skirt and a pair of beaded gloves, is meeting Golden for the first time at a tea party I have organized at the Carlyle Hotel, an event I refer to (but not out loud) as a "nutty-dressers" luncheon. In addition to Golden and Fox, there are two other invited guests: Tziporah Salamon (1930s cheongsam, bamboo pinwheel hat, 200-year-old Chinese handbag) and Iris Apfel (a tunic made by one of China's ethnic minorities, a clanging necklace from a Tunisian souk, signature humongous spectacles). I've been seeing these grande dames around town for years, and now, finally, I've got them all in one spot - at one table - so I can ask them how it came to be that the four of them glitter like spectacular if wacky jewels in an otherwise mostly mundane pedestrian landscape.

When Mikhail Baryshnikov defected from the Soviet Union in 1974, it was a major news event, drawing world attention to both the ballet dancer and ballet. With "Head-On" (2004) and "The Edge of Heaven" (2007), Fatih Akin made two important films that mine the politically charged frontier between Turkey, the country abandoned by Akin's immigrant parents, and Germany, where the director was born and raised. "Soul Kitchen," which opens in New York today, is Akin's latest film but it is a break from the trilogy, not its finale. The devil, Akin says, will have to wait.

Clothes don't really come to life until they are on a living - moving - body. So whatever you want to make of the proliferation of electronic media, it makes sense that a lot of fashion designers are gravitating toward film and video as a way of presenting and promoting their collections. "I feel videos are much more liberating in that they show movement and action," says the designer Victoria Bartlett. "In my eyes it's a more modern way of capturing an image. There is a natural ease that comes with video - it's more spontaneous and produces more surprising results." For her fall collection, which she says is "all about fracturing, fragmenting and re-assembling," she teamed up with the artist Jessica Mitrani and the dancer Maria Hassabi to create a video that explores Siamese twinning with graphic, optical effects created in post-production, and also with a pair of doubled underwear.

Wheat got a bad rap in the 1930s, and has been faulted in environmental retrospectives ever since as the crop that caused the Dust Bowl in the Great Depression. It's only partly true, of course -- it could have been any of a number of other crops that boomed too hard in the go-go 1920s, causing too many small farmers on the high plains to plant too much on land too fragile to sustain the load. Drought and the collapse of farm prices did the rest. A newly vulnerable landscape peeled up from its moorings and blew away before the eyes of a horrified nation.

10 P.M. (ABC) 20/20 By all accounts, Melissa Moore (above left with Juju Chang) was adored by her father, Keith Hunter Jesperson. What she didn't learn until years later was that he was a murderer known as the Happy Face Killer, named for the smiley face with which he signed letters to newspapers about his five-year string of killings: eight women in five states. Ms. Chang interviews Ms. Moore, the author of ''Shattered Silence: The Untold Story of a Serial Killer's Daughter,'' about her discovery at 15 of Mr. Jesperson's crimes, her attempt to keep them a secret for 15 more years, her fears of having children and how she has lived with what her father did. Ms. Moore returns to an area in Washington State where she lived as a child, near a place where her father killed. In a telephone interview from the Oregon State Penitentiary in Salem, where he is serving three consecutive life sentences, Mr. Jesperson recounts the details of his killings. 8:30 P.M. (13, 49) NEED TO KNOW Juan Cole, a Middle East scholar and professor of history at the University of Michigan, talks with Alison Stewart about the drawdown of American forces in Iraq and the prospects for peace. Jon Meacham takes viewers on a historical walking tour of Lower Manhattan and to the proposed site two blocks from ground zero of an Islamic center and mosque that has been criticized. Gary Shteyngart talks about his new book, ''Super Sad True Love Story,'' about a future America that has become an economic supplicant of China. Other segments look at the pros and cons of blood transfusions and the five things to know about seafood from the Gulf of Mexico.

MEYER--Sarah Glenn. On August 16, at age 68. Beloved wife of George (Tony), mother of Willets, Edie and David; grandmother of Willets, Hannah, Cole and Gwen. Services on Saturday, August 21, 10:00am, Christ Church. Memorials in her honor to be made to Christ Church, 61 East Main St, Oyster Bay, NY 11771 or The Oyster Bay Sailing Foundation.

A film entry in the Listings pages last Friday misspelled the surname of one of the actors in ''Cairo Time.'' He is Alexander Siddig, not Siddiq. Another film listing misspelled the given name of the director of ''Step Up 3D.'' He is Jon M. Chu, not John.

New York City's unemployment rate dipped to 9.4 percent in July, continuing a gradual but steady improvement as hiring rebounded faster locally than in the rest of the country, the state Labor Department said Thursday. The city's unemployment rate, which was 9.5 percent in June, has now declined for seven straight months since peaking at 10.5 percent at the end of 2009. It was slightly lower than the national unemployment rate - 9.5 percent in July - as it was in April and May.

OLMSTED--Robert Amson, P.E.,F. ASCE, 85, died suddenly but peacefully on August 16, 2010. Devoted husband of 61 years to Pauline; loving father of Larry, Alan and Elizabeth; and proud grandfather of Nicholas, Timothy, and Andrew; he was one of New York's leading transportation planners, former Planning Director of the MTA and a veteran of WWII. A memorial is planned for the fall. Donations in his memory may be made to the the Nicholas J.P. Kau Fund for Shakespeare and Wrestling at Trinity School, 139 W. 91 Street, New York, NY 10024.

NETREBA--Sydney S.,passed away peacefully in Millbrae, CA on August 14, 2010 at the age of 91. Born in Pennsylvania on December 4, 1918, grew up in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Abraham Lincoln High School. He earned a B.S. from City College of NY in 1940. He served in the U.S. Army Air Corps and saw heavy battle in the South Pacific during WW II. After the war, he earned a doctorate in economics from Johns Hopkins University. During his long career in the financial field, he was a partner first at Kuhn, Loeb & Co. and then at Bear Stearns in New York and closed his professional career with Robert C. Brown & Co. in San Francisco. Together with his wife, Mildred Dubrow Netreba, who pre-deceased him in 2000, and daughter Laurie, who pre-deceased him in 1998, he was a long term resident of Atherton, CA. He is survived by many nieces, nephews, grand-nieces, and grand-nephews. Dearly loved by his many friends and former colleagues for his intellect, kindness quick wit and plethora of talents, he will be sorely missed. His memory will forever remain in our hearts. Funeral services are to be private.

Earlier this week, Christine Haughney, who writes the weekly column, The Appraisal, recounted how weird little details at open houses can turn off potential buyers. She asked readers for some that they'd seen. Here are our favorites:''It was a good house, well-maintained. Joe L. Brown, the Pittsburgh Pirates general manager who built two World Series championship teams and five National League division winners in the 1960s and '70s, died Sunday in Albuquerque. He was 91. His death was announced by the Pirates.

An article on Wednesday about a British motorist's successful nonviolent protest against Britain's private towing companies over their power to issue fines and impound illegally parked vehicles misstated the amount of fines the motorist had amassed while sitting in his car for 30 hours in a restricted zone. It was more than $6,000, not $5,560.

Tourists shuffling out of Grand Central Terminal would be forgiven for wondering what the heck kind of low-rent horror movie about giant rats is being filmed on East 42nd Street. Immobile, fat and grinning with big yellow teeth - yikes! New Yorkers, of course, will recognize the big inflated pests, familiar sights all over town, wherever a labor union has taken umbrage with the goings-on at the location. The rat may stay an hour or a day or longer, with handy fliers explaining the nature of the dispute. Indeed, the rats are almost counterproductive among natives, who barely bother to look up and notice anymore, as with panhandlers and police sirens and smiling people who want you to stop in the middle of the sidewalk and sign something.

An article on Friday about the financial viability of Chicago's charter schools gave an outdated statistic for the percentage of students at Perspectives Calumet High School who had been accepted to at least one college. It is now 96 percent, up from 70 percent in March.

A picture caption on Wednesday with a music review about the International Contemporary Ensemble's performance at the Mostly Mozart Festival misidentified the type of instrument played by one of the featured performers, Pierre-Laurent Aimard. It was a celesta, not a piano.

The TV Sports column on Wednesday, about the aggressive interview style of the reporter Jim Gray, misidentified the location of his interview with Pete Rose when Gray tried to persuade Rose to apologize for gambling on baseball. It was at Turner Field in Atlanta, before Game 2 of the 1999 World Series; it was not in Yankee Stadium.

An article in some copies on Monday about the final round of the P.G.A. Championship misstated the number of European Tour victories by Martin Kaymer, who won the P.G.A. on Sunday in a three-hole playoff. He had five, not 13.

An article on Thursday about a settlement between New Jersey and the Securities and Exchange Commission over accusations of securities fraud involving the state's pension funds erroneously included one bond underwriter on a list of those that had underwritten New Jersey's bonds during the period in question, from 2001 to 2007. Barclays Capital, which did not enter the municipal securities business until 2008, did not underwrite any New Jersey bonds during that time.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a deadly attack on United Nationspeacekeepers in the Democratic Republic of the Congo misattributed the assertion that the identities of the attackers were unclear. That assertion was made by officials from the United Nations, not the United States.

An article on Monday about an Indian church's Assumption Day Parade on Long Island referred incorrectly to Malayalam, which the parishioners speak. It is a language, not a dialect. The article also misspelled the name of a drum played in the parade. It is a chenda, not a chemda.

BELL--Martha. Brooklyn College deeply mourns the passing of Professor Martha Bell, Chair of the SEEK Department. Professor Bell's countless contributions to the students and faculty of Brooklyn College have been remarkable. A member of the faculty since 1977, Professor Bell was an outstanding leader among her colleagues and a mentor for thousands of SEEK students. She was an articulate member of several important college councils and served with great capacity as a member of the CUNY Faculty Senate. Her academic interests were wide ranging, her commitment to diversity and student access was unwavering, and her influence over the years on major college issues was profound. Our collective admiration for the values she lived every day on our campus and in the community will be long standing. Karen L. Gould, President

HARRIS--Fredda Bonnie (Schiff), 67, of Hewlett Neck, NY passed away peacefully August 18th. She is survived by her beloved husband Alan of 47 years, her son Todd, her devoted sister Joan (Hauser) and her husband Paul, her sister-in-law Marilyn Yaeger, her adoring nieces, nephews, cousins, aunts, and many devoted friends. Fredda taught special education in the Hewlett/Woodmere school district for over 25 years. She was a lifetime member of Hewlett Hadassah. She was also a member of the Board of Trustees and founder of the May Museum at Temple Israel in Lawrence, NY. Fredda was loved by all who knew her and will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be held Sunday at 10am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557, 516-295-3100. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Dr. Andrew Zelenetz, Lymphoma Chairman.

The National Baseball Hall of Fame's election system is heading for a meltdown. With an abundance of qualified candidates becoming eligible and the cloud of steroid accusations and perjury indictments, the elections for the classes of 2013 and 2014 appear likely to cause the kind of Hall of Fame ballot gridlock we haven't seen since the Hall's creation in 1936. In 1938, more than 50 eventual Hall of Famers received votes, but just one, Pete Alexander, received the 75 percent of votes necessary for induction. In 1945 and 1946, after a break in voting because of World War II, the top 28 vote-getters were all eventually inducted, but the vote was divided among so many qualified players that not one reached the 75 percent threshold needed for induction in either year. To break this logjam, the Hall of Fame convened an old-timers committee, which selected 30 individuals, and cleared the ballot enough so that in 1947 the writers managed to induct four players.

Internment will be in East Hampton, NY.

CLARK--F. Lamar A native of Mobile, Alabama and resident of Alpharetta, Georgia, died at his residence on August 17, 2010. He is survived by his devoted wife of 53 years, Ann H. Clark; his loving son, Joe and daughter-in-law, Nori; his adoring grandchildren, Tommy and Angela Clark all of Suwanee, Georgia; one sister, Gini C. Nelson (Ed) of Spanish Fort, Alabama; and a brother-in-law John Hudgens (Debbie) of Creola, Alabama; one uncle, Gerald Clark of Millbrook, Alabama, many nieces, nephews and other relatives. He was preceded in death by his parents, Tom and Flossie Clark, sisters, Sue C. Ryals and Karen C. Connell. Mr. Clark was a resident of Woodbridge, New Jersey for 37 years and retired as Senior Vice President of Hess Corporation. He was with the company for 45 years at retirement. Mr. Clark retired to Alpharetta, Georgia to be near his grandchildren. He loved spending time with them and was affectionately known as "Papa". He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. His kind generosity was well known to many people. Visitation will be at Ingram Funeral Home in Cumming, Georgia on Saturday, August 21, 2010 from 10:00am until 1:00pm followed by a graveside service at Sawnee View Memorial Gardens with Rev. Mike Schmid officiating. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials be made to Whispering Hope in care of First Redeemer Church, 2100 Peachtree Parkway, Cumming, Georgia 30041-7497. Ingram Funeral Home & Crematory, Cumming, GA is in charge of the services. Condolences may be made at www.ingramfuneralhome.com.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - The phrase "three on a match" comes from the old superstition that if three people light a cigarette from the same match, the third is going to die. I learned this from a wonderful 1932 film of that name -- a good example of the wit and sophistication of American films before the Hayes code. Check it out if you love movies.

Jimsonweed has been on my radar ever since I researched it for a presentation on wild weeds and fungi last year, so I was intrigued when I discovered some spiny seedpods recently in an alley in Gowanus, Brooklyn. Originally thinking they were empress tree pods, which are similarly sculptural but smooth, I brought them back to my workspace, where a friend helped to correctly identify them as Datura stramonium, or jimsonweed, and their source (the garden of a local artist around the corner).

Thirty-five weeks pregnant, Robin Rodgers was vomiting and losing weight, so her doctor hospitalized her and ordered that she be fed through a tube until the birth of her daughter. But in a mistake that stemmed from years of lax federal oversight of medical devices, the hospital mixed up the tubes. Instead of snaking a tube through Ms. Rodgers's nose and into her stomach, the nurse instead coupled the liquid-food bag to a tube that entered a vein.

Sooner or later, every traditional faith has to confront sexual impropriety by its spiritual leaders: extramarital sex, or sex with the wrong people (members of the congregation, minors) or, for supposedly celibate clergy, any sex at all. But there are great differences in how religions handle these transgressions. For Jews and many Protestants, it is the local congregation that decides what sins are too great to countenance, and what kind of discipline is needed. For Roman Catholics, a worldwide hierarchy decides, depending on reports from local representatives. And for Buddhists -- well, the answer is not so clear.

MILLER--Alan Noel, Dr.,76, passed away on Friday, August 20th after a short battle with pancreatic cancer. Alan was widowed after 37 years of marriage to Libby Shana Halpern Miller, PhD. Prior to becoming a nephrologist, Dr. Miller earned an MBA in Finance and also had a career as an engineer. He served as a captain in the Special Forces training Green Berets. Alan was a loving and generous man with strong principles and convictions. An avid learner, he continued his education and quest for knowledge by taking classes at Columbia University all his life. He fostered others' desire for higher education through the sponsorship of mentoring programs and scholarships. Dr. Miller was a devoted Columbia man. He worked tirelessly to keep his class of 1956 connected and served as their president for many years. He also wrote the Class News for the Columbia Paper on a quarterly basis, and fellow "Columbians" referred to him as "The Class Act." A dedicated advocate of the 3x5 index card form of organization, he was also a proud cigar smoker, stock watcher and wine collector. Ol' Doc Al, or GGA, Grumpy Grandpa Al, as so lovingly referred to by his grandchildren, will be deeply missed. Always larger than life, he leaves a huge hole in his death. He is survived by his partner, Helene Ruddy, his mother Iris Miller, his daughter and son in law, Elisa Miller and Greg Griffin, his daughter, Jennifer van Voorst van Beest, his sister and brother-in-law, Barbara and Maurice Kupritz, his sister and brother-in-law, Mona and Lee Berg, his grandchildren, Zachary and Elana Griffin, Elijah and Isaac van Voorst van Beest and many other close relatives and friends. We love you doc. God speed. The funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday August 22nd at 11:45am. A graveside service will follow at Sharon Gardens. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the Columbia College Class of 1956/Alan N. Miller Scholarship would be greatly appreciated. We will be sitting shiva at 257 Central Park West, Apt 9D beginning Sunday evening after 6pm and during the week between 11am-9pm.
ROSEN--Marty. We will forever treasure our friendship and the joyful memories we shared together. With much love to the entire Rosen family, Lee and Howard Kaliner.

CLARK--Ann Lystad, of Colorado Springs, CO. Born May 12, 1923; died August 11, 2010. Survived by her children Robert D. Clark (spouse Laurie Bennett) of Denver, CO; Dr. Margaret C. Golden (spouse Richard Golden) of Brooklyn, NY; and Julia C. Clark of Asheville, NC; and by her grandchildren Rebecca B. Clark of New York, NY; Abigail S. Golden of New York, NY; and Samuel B. Clark of Denver, CO. Mrs. Clark's husband Brigadier General Cuyler L. Clark, Jr. predeceased her. May her memory be a blessing.

HARRIS--Fredda Bonnie (Schiff), 67, of Hewlett Neck, NY passed away peacefully August 18th. She is survived by her beloved husband Alan of 47 years, her son Todd, her devoted sister Joan (Hauser) and her husband Paul, her sister-in-law Marilyn Yaeger, her adoring nieces, nephews, cousins, aunts, and many devoted friends. Fredda taught special education in the Hewlett/Woodmere school district for over 25 years. She was a lifetime member of Hewlett Hadassah. She was also a member of the Board of Trustees and founder of the May Museum at Temple Israel in Lawrence, NY. Fredda was loved by all who knew her and will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be held Sunday at 10am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557, 516-295-3100. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Dr. Andrew Zelenetz, Lymphoma Chairman.

LONDON -- The story of a short summer should never be about a referee. The exception might be the Frenchman Stéphane Lannoy. In late June, Lannoy was sent home from the World Cup after angering both Brazil and the Ivory Coast in their first-round match. He was fooled by Luis Fabiano, allowing the Brazilian to use an arm twice while scoring a goal. Later, the referee sent off Ricardo Kaká after the Brazilian was barged into by Kader Keita, who then theatrically fell to the ground.
CORBIE--Dr. Leo A. , Sr. 8/20/1930 - 10/1/2007 Poppa, on the anniversary of your birth, we love you, we miss you & will do so for an eternity. Love, Helen, children and grandchildren

ARBUCKLE--Thomas Steele, age 66, died on August 13th, 2010 at his New York City apartment surrounded by his beloved family. He leaves behind his wife Joanne, son and daughter-in-law, Robert and Ruth Manna, granddaughter Eva Louise Manna. Tom had a long and illustrious career and was the Vice President and General Manager of the International Toy Center for 31 years. He served in the U.S. Marine Corps from 1962-1965. A memorial service will be held at 10:30am on Saturday, September 11th, 2010 at the Community Church of Mountain Lakes in Mountain Lakes, New Jersey.

MADRID - Nenad Krstic, the starting center for the Oklahoma City Thunder, spent Thursday night in police custody in Athens for his role in a bloody brawl in an exhibition game between Serbia and Greece in preparation for the FIBA world championship. A video of Krstic, who plays for Serbia, attempting to throw a chair at center Sofoklis Schortsanitis of Greece became a sensation on the Internet on Friday. Krstic missed his target but hit the Greek reserve Yannis Bouroussis, who had blood streaming from his head.

BYSTRYN--Jean-Claude, MD on August 19, 2010, died in the company of his family. Physician, scientist, adventurer, and singular husband and father. His loss is deeply mourned by his wife, Marcia, children Annie and Alex, and his sister, Denise. Servies Monday, August 23rd, 11am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St., New York City. Contributions may be made to: Institut Seculier Notre Dame De Vie a Venasque, 84210 Venasque, France.

Over the years, parents have often used the dollar (or half a dollar) a week for each year of age formula to set a child's allowance. ThreeJars.com, an online bank of sorts to help parents and children keep track of allowance and money, recently introduced a new idea. It's also suggesting an adjusted figure based on the allowance the parent received as a child.

KNOPKA--Nancy, 83, of Woodmere, NY, died August 18, 2010. Cervantes scholar, educator, musician. Predeceased by her loving siblings, Phyllis Cahen Sokolow and First Lieutenant James P. Cahen III. Loving aunt of Jeffrey, Judith and Jonathan Sokolow. Devoted great-aunt of Esther, Miriam, Beth, Jesse and Julia Sokolow. LEON--Joseph L. (1928-2008) Miss your smile, love & wisdom. Masha, Laura, Karen, Nina & family

LENT--John Edward, EdD, age 84, died at home surrounded by family and friends on August 18th. John is the loving father of three sons; John, William and Michael and their wives Lillian, Nansi and Joanne; grandfather of John Blaise, Jennifer, Sarah, Liam, Edward and Julia; brother of May Hughes, uncle of Patricia Hughes and Dorthy Bonomo and her husband John; great-uncle of Meghan and Michael Bonomo. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Helen Lane Lent. Dr. Lent obtained a master's degree from Columbia University in 1951, and his doctorate in education from New York University in 1958. He taught at the College of St. Thomas, Queens College, Hunter College and Adelphi University. He served as the Director of Speech Improvement for the NYC Board of Education from 1969-1988. A deeply prayerful man, John lived his life with kindness, compassion, humility, humor, and Courage. He had a great devotion to St. Therese of the Child Jesus. Wake at Glascott Funeral Home (102-03 Metropolitan Ave., Forest Hills) on Sunday August 22nd and Monday August 23rd from 2:00-5:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs RC Church at 110-06 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills on Thursday August 24th at 10:30am. Contributions may be made in his name to The CHARGE Syndrome Foundation, Inc. at 141 Middle Neck Rd., Sands Point, NY 11050 or to The Catholic Worker, 36 East First St., New York, NY 10003.

The Books of the Times review on Oct. 8, 2009, about ''Half Broke Horses'' by Jeannette Walls, referred incorrectly to one of three children shown in the book's cover photograph -- one of Dorothea Lange's Depression-era images for the Farm Security Administration. The scene shows children from the Arnold family, a household that Ms. Lange photographed extensively, in Washington State. The book's subject, Lily Casey Smith, was not ''the oldest of three raggedly beautiful kids'' shown in the picture. This correction was delayed because the error was not pointed out until Thursday, in an e-mail from a reader.

A report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about the disclosure that the early 20th-century Russian artist Kazimir Malevich, known for his Black Square painting, had a previously unknown son misidentified the son. He was Georgy -- not Anatoly, who was one of the children already known to biographers.

Back in late 2008, Max Levitte was looking for a vacuum to clean up the one rug in his New York apartment. He searched online for reviews of really cheap vacuums, but all of the recommended vacuums he could find were in the $150 to $250 range -- an amount he didn't want to spend on cleaning just one living room carpet. Ultimately, he ended up sorting prices on Amazon and buying a $60 vacuum that didn't work well.

An article on Friday about the Yankees' 11-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers on Thursday misstated the career number of hits by Jorge Posada, who passed Thurman Munson on the Yankees' list. Posada had 1,559 hits after Thursday's game, not 1,159.

An article on Wednesday about the passage of a law in Lebanon granting Palestinian refugees the same rights to work as other foreigners referred imprecisely to the refugees. Although the United Nations now registers about 4.7 million Palestinian refugees across the region, most are the descendants of the 700,000 who fled the Arab-Israeli war of 1948 and the 300,000 who fled in 1967.

SEOUL, South Korea -- A South Korean Christian pastor who has fueled a bitter debate by visiting North Korea without government permission was arrested on Friday during his trip home across the heavily guarded border between the countries. The pastor, the Rev. Han Sang-ryol, a self-styled ''unification activist,'' was waving a ''one-Korea'' flag that showed an undivided Korean Peninsula as he stepped across the military demarcation line at the border village of Panmunjom, government officials said. He was immediately whisked away by South Korean authorities for interrogation.

CLARK--F. Lamar A native of Mobile, Alabama and resident of Alpharetta, Georgia, died at his residence on August 17, 2010. He is survived by his devoted wife of 53 years, Ann H. Clark; his loving son, Joe and daughter-in-law, Nori; his adoring grandchildren, Tommy and Angela Clark all of Suwanee, Georgia; one sister, Gini C. Nelson (Ed) of Spanish Fort, Alabama; and a brother-in-law John Hudgens (Debbie) of Creola, Alabama; one uncle, Gerald Clark of Millbrook, Alabama, many nieces, nephews and other relatives. He was preceded in death by his parents, Tom and Flossie Clark, sisters, Sue C. Ryals and Karen C. Connell. Mr. Clark was a resident of Woodbridge, New Jersey for 37 years and retired as Senior Vice President of Hess Corporation. He was with the company for 45 years at retirement. Mr. Clark retired to Alpharetta, Georgia to be near his grandchildren. He loved spending time with them and was affectionately known as "Papa". He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. His kind generosity was well known to many people. Visitation will be at Ingram Funeral Home in Cumming, Georgia on Saturday, August 21, 2010 from 10:00am until 1:00pm followed by a graveside service at Sawnee View Memorial Gardens with Rev. Mike Schmid officiating. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials be made to Whispering Hope in care of First Redeemer Church, 2100 Peachtree Parkway, Cumming, Georgia 30041-7497. Ingram Funeral Home & Crematory, Cumming, GA is in charge of the services. Condolences may be made at www.ingramfuneralhome.com.

Think tennis in New York and Queens comes to mind, either the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, where the U.S. Open begins Aug. 30, or the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. PITTSBURGH - Mets left fielder Jason Bay's season may be over because of lingering effects of a concussion, Manager Jerry Manuel said Friday. ''Not to be out of bounds, but that's the way I see it,'' Manuel said before the Mets beat the Pirates, 7-2.

An article on Tuesday about a proposed solution of a classic mathematical formula called P versus NP described NP incorrectly and misidentified the location of the CERN physics research center. NP stands for the class of problems for which solutions can be verified relatively quickly, not the class of problems that are difficult to solve but easy to verify. And the CERN laboratory is near Geneva, not in Zurich.

8 P.M. (CNN) IN AMERICA: NEW ORLEANS RISING Five years after Hurricane Katrina ravaged New Orleans, Soledad O'Brien reports on the rebuilding of Pontchartrain Park, a largely black middle-class neighborhood born out of segregation, which had one of the lowest rates of returning homeowners after the storm. This special follows the actor Wendell Pierce -- a star of HBO's ''Treme,'' who evacuated his elderly parents (above with Mr. Pierce at left) from their Pontchartrain home before Katrina -- as he battles red tape, financing and reluctant residents to lead a charge to return his childhood community to its former glory, despite no experience as a developer. Ms. O'Brien also visits two families: Hurby Oubre, who is committed to staying in the neighborhood, and his wife, Lisa, who, seeing no possibility of returning, has moved to Baton Rouge with her son; and Meldon and Audrey Woods, who have taken out a loan they fear they will never be able to repay in order to rebuild their home. Lisa P. Jackson, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, who grew up in Pontchartrain Park, and the former New Orleans mayor Ray Nagin weigh in. The jazz trumpeter Terence Blanchard, who called the neighborhood home as a child, composed and performed the program's theme music. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton looks at a kidney exchange program in which donors who are not a match for a friend or family member can give a kidney to someone else, in exchange for a compatible kidney for their loved one. Lucky Severson interviews the inventor Ray Kurzweil, who believes that artificial intelligence will surpass human intelligence by 2050, leading to a hybrid of man and technology.

LONDON -- Andrew Roth, a New York-born journalist with left-wing ideals who fled the McCarthy-era America of 1950 for a new life as a meticulous and often abrasive chronicler of the foibles, business links and private lives of British politicians, died in London on Thursday. Here's a thought for all those insisting that there's a bond bubble: how unreasonable are current long-term interest rates given current macroeconomic forecasts? I mean, at this point almost everyone expects unemployment to stay high for years to come, and there's every reason to expect low or even negative inflation for a long time too. Shouldn't that imply that the Fed will keep short-term rates near zero for a long time? And shouldn't that, in turn, mean that a low long-term rate is justified too?

If you have ever dreamed of having a snoop around Jimi Hendrix's apartment, now you can. Forty years after his death, the American rock legend, who performed, recorded and lived in London, will be reincarnated through the "Hendrix in Britain" exhibition at the Handel House Museum, starting Aug. 25. OLMSTED--Robert Amson, P.E.,F. ASCE, 85, died suddenly but peacefully on August 16, 2010. Devoted husband of 61 years to Pauline; loving father of Larry, Alan and Elizabeth; and proud grandfather of Nicholas, Timothy, and Andrew; he was one of New York's leading transportation planners, former Planning Director of the MTA and a veteran of WWII. A memorial is planned for the fall. Donations in his memory may be made to the the Nicholas J.P. Kau Fund for Shakespeare and Wrestling at Trinity School, 139 W. 91 Street, New York, NY 10024.

Delta Airlines recently added a feature on its Facebook page that allows users to book travel through the social networking site. The application, the Delta Ticket Window, offers a pared-down version of the booking service on Delta's own (also recently retooled) Web site. There is no option to book a multicity trip or to buy a ticket using rewards, for example. But there is one crucial add-on: you can share your travel plans with friends of your choice. That means if you're traveling to San Francisco, for example, you can give your friends there a heads-up with one additional click as you buy your ticket.

How do we maintain Social Security in the fairest way? Consider progressive indexing, which would preserve benefits for the bottom third of wage earners who rely on the program for almost all of their retirement income, but recalculate the benefits of higher-paid workers who have other sources of retirement income -- including 401(k)s and IRAs -- that are tax-subsidized by the federal government. To calculate initial benefits at retirement, Social Security currently takes workers' average career earnings and increases them by the rate at which average wages rose during their careers, a mechanism called wage indexing. Once workers start receiving benefits, they are increased annually by the amount that consumer prices rose in the prior year, called price indexing.

GAIA REPOSSI, the artistic director of her family's 80-year-old jewelry house, has an aversion to ''shy'' designs. In her world, rings cover most of the finger; cuffs, half the forearm. As such, her new collections for Joseph Altuzarra and Alexander Wang -- which were introduced on the fall runways and will become part of Repossi's permanent offerings -- are hard to miss: elongated silver and pink gold-banded rings for Altuzarra that take their cue from ancient nomadic tribes; yellow gold Art Deco-inspired collars, rings and cuffs for Wang, burned (or ''destroyed,'' as she put it) at the ends for a dégradé effect. Precious these are not. ''I like breaking the expectations of high-end jewelry,'' she said. Gaia Repossi for Altuzarra ring, about $1,085 at Colette.fr and by e-mail at boutique@repossi.com.

WITTEK--Alec, M.D.,58, suddenly, on August 14, 2010. Devoted son, beloved husband of Dr. Pamela Cohen, son Max and sister Jackie, dear uncle and friend. A man of manifold talents, Alec was a revered pediatrician and expert in infectious disease drug and vaccine development, musician and artist who produced works in photography, pen, ink and his most recent passion, pottery. Jeopardy champion. His was a unique combination of wit, compassion, humor and love. He had such a big heart. Memorial donations to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Association (www.4hcm.org).

The Federal Aviation Administration has announced that it was downgrading its rating of Mexico's oversight of civil aviation from Category 1 to Category 2 because Mexico had failed to meet the international safety standards of the United Nations agency for civil aviation. Because the decision, which came late last month, hampers partnerships between American and Mexican airlines and it bars Mexican carriers from adding any new routes to the United States, it effectively reduces the options for air travel between the two countries.The downgrade came shortly before Mexicana Airlines filed for bankruptcy, suspending ticket sales and several flights. Not only will other Mexican carriers be unable to make up for the loss of Mexicana's service in the United States, the move also halts several code-share agreements, which allow domestic airlines to sell tickets for routes that Mexican carriers operate. (The reverse can still occur.) The affected code-share arrangements include one between Delta and AeroMexico and one between American and Mexicana, although the latter has been further complicated by Mexicana's bankruptcy.

Venus Williams turned 30 this year and remains one of the top tennis players in the world. A winner of 19 Grand Slam titles, she is ranked No. 5 in singles, and No. 2 in doubles with her sister Serena. On Thursday, she will conduct the Legends Clinic II, a live, interactive online clinic presented by Ralph Lauren from the courts on Randalls Island in New York. Tennis fans can submit questions in advance at RalphLauren.com. Q.Where did you get the idea for a virtual clinic days before the start of the United States Open?A.Boris Becker did it at Wimbledon, and I thought it was very interesting. I've never done anything like this before, but I'm excited because after 25 years of tennis, I have a lot to teach. With the Internet and all of the technology we have, a virtual clinic is probably the wave of the future.Q.This is your 12th trip to the Open, which you won in 2000 and 2001. How do you assess your chances this year?A.I like my chances because I grew up on hardcourts, so I feel most comfortable in New York at the U.S. Open. This is where I had my first real breakout. I love to play before New York fans because they love to root for the underdog, but they also love rooting for champions.Q.How long will you keep playing?A.There really is no limit to that. I don't have any plans on stopping right now because I'm still competing for major championships. Now if I wasn't playing that well, it would be a different story.Q.As you have matured as a person and a player, do you see the game any differently?A.I'm more appreciative nowadays of everything the game has given me, and with each passing day, I'm more and more grateful that I'm still playing the game.Q.How do you think you would you have fared against Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert?A.I don't really know because things are different now than they were back then. Technology is different and training is different. Also, all three of us had such different styles. The only real way to know is that they would have had to play in my era or I would have had to play in theirs. If that had happened, it would have made for some epic tennis.Q.Whom did you idolize as a youngster?A.I really liked Monica Seles and Boris Becker. I grew up trying to serve like Becker and hit hard like Monica.Q.You have a clothing line, Eleven. Is this something you might consider full time when your playing days are over?A.Oh, yes, I went to school to study fashion design. I've always wanted a career in design, so what I'm doing now is all a part of the grand plan for when my tennis career is over. I plan on designing not just sports clothing, but regular daywear and other kinds of styles.Q.Tell us something that no one knows about you.A.I am an ubergeek. People think I'm this famous jock with such an exciting life, but when I'm not playing tennis, I'm reading or studying something that I'm curious about, and doing it quietly.

With his latest line for Dior Beauty, Tyen, the company's creative makeup director, takes the concept of matching your lipstick to your dress to a whole new level. Each color in his new 32-shade Rouge Dior Lipcolor range ($30 each at Dior counters) was inspired by the hues of haute couture ensembles from the atelier's archives. ''I tried to find shades that brighten life and make sadness disappear,'' Tyen says. The formula is an haute concept, too, containing hyaluronic microspheres that promise to soften, replenish and plump lips into a perfect pucker. SANDRA BALLENTINE

For me, a school librarian, back to school means only one thing: handing out 3,500 textbooks and begging students to treat them kindly. I am still in shock from June, when a parent returned his daughter's 10th-grade English text. It looked just like its name: ''Things Fall Apart.'' Ripped and torn, its cover was splattered with tomato sauce, as if it had been shot in the heart. My horrified expression did not register with the student's father. ''Do we owe you anything?'' he asked. Flummoxed, I just smiled and issued his daughter full credit for returning her books.
