If the clothes Phoebe Philo wears shape the clothes that she designs -- ''I've always had a sense,'' she said in a recent interview, ''that if I can't wear it, what's the point?'' -- then what pieces from her personal wardrobe has she drawn from for Céline? Here, an imaginary peek into the designer's drawers. ALEX HAWGOOD

Everyone knows swimming is excellent exercise, but it is also terrific therapy. Nothing frees my mind as dependably as the rhythm of my arms and legs propelling me from one end of the pool to the other. Also, as I have discovered in the 18 months since the death of the man I loved, in the pool, no one can tell the water running down your face is tears. Since I moved to Upper Manhattan in 2007, I have swum several mornings each week at Riverbank State Park, which runs 69 feet above the Hudson River between 137th and 145th Streets, atop a wastewater treatment plant (no, it does not smell). Riverbank is not luxurious - the locker room and shower area are almost spartan - but its price tag, $3 a swim or $30 for a monthly lap pass, is a pittance for a slice of serenity.

Coming soon to a saloon (or brasserie) near you. LEE CARTER 1. Cerruti, the house that began as a textile mill in 1881 and became known for outfitting major Hollywood films a century later, also has a new man at the helm. For fall, the British designer Richard Nicoll dresses his ladies for drama (belted coats, leather shell tops, wool capelets over pencil skirts) or rom-coms (diaphanous silks, floral prints, gauzy angora). Go to cerruti.com.

An essay by Oscar Robertson on Aug. 8 about the 1960 United States Olympics men's basketball team erroneously included one member of the team among those who are deceased. Warren Womble, an assistant coach, is 90 and attended the team's induction into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame on Aug. 13. (The deceased include Coach Pete Newell; the team manager, Dutch Lonborg; the trainer, Dean Nesmith; and a player, Les Lane.)

In 1913, the provocateur Marcel Duchamp created a ruckus at the New York Armory Show with his ''Nude Descending a Staircase (No. 2).'' The painting didn't go down well; apparently nudes don't use staircases, they're busy lolling on divans or dancing with seven veils. Looking at ''Nude'' today (in the Philadelphia Museum of Art), the Samurai Shopper sees nothing R-rated, just a fractured maze of lines and planes. What's naked is Duchamp's ambition to shock the stuffed shirts. But critics back then had a point: nudes should avoid staircases. Time's depredations cause body parts to crumple, wobble or sag -- a very off-putting aesthetic. Particularly afflicted by gravity's curse is the neck. Farther south, the décolletage, that creamy expanse of skin that has inspired brooding fugues and tortured quatrains, suffers equally from age and dereliction. Neglect neck or dec and Father Time will one day call your bluff and morph you into a maze of fractured lines and planes.

An art feature on Page 21 this weekend about Broadway illustrators misidentifies the play that goes with Robert Risko's drawing of Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton. It is ''Private Lives,'' not ''A Little Night Music.''

The idea that fashion is one long promenade around the contours of the body, alighting on various erogenous zones, has taken a beating in this new millennium. The focus has been so evidently on legs -- in brief skirts, tight pants, shorts and leggings -- that the age-old notion of an alternating sexual focus seems to have been abandoned. Not one season from 2000 onward (and not many before that) traced the curves of hips, waist or bust, the landscape of the hourglass figure. Even the red-carpet parades of strapless gowns have seemed modest rather than thrusting.

Q.My husband and I have a tradition of taking each of our grandchildren on a special trip. The next one up has her heart set on Paris. We have visited Paris several times, and it just doesn't seem like a child's city. What can you suggest that would be fun for a 10-year-old? Though Paris is often touted as a destination for adults, children can fare just as well there. One place to start: the city's beautifully manicured gardens, which offer wonderful entertainment for youngsters. In the Jardin des Tuileries (Metro to Tuileries or Concorde), on the Right Bank of the Seine, you'll find pony rides, ice cream stands and trampolines. The Jardin du Luxembourg (Metro to Odeon), on the Left Bank, has a playground, a pond where kids can sail toy boats and absorbing puppet shows - though the Champ de Mars, near the Eiffel Tower, reputedly offers the best shows in town.

Family Matters For Aerin Lauder, who is the senior vice president and creative director for Estée Lauder, the flagship brand of the Estée Lauder Companies, it really is a family affair. She was groomed from an early age by her grandmother, Estée, and her parents, Ronald and Jo Carole, and it was a given that Aerin would rise through the ranks of one of the world's largest cosmetics companies. But it's dedication, not privilege, that gives her an edge. Like most working parents, this mother of two tries to balance a high-octane schedule with family time. A common misconception about Lauder is that she's a social butterfly. ''I go to business-related events once or twice a week, but I rarely have the catch-up dinner with a girlfriend,'' she says. ''That's one thing I don't get to do very often, because I'd rather help my children with their homework, put them to bed and then order in sushi or pizza or make dinner for my husband.'' Her idea of familial bliss? Sporty weekends on Long Island filled with long beach walks, tennis, swimming and sailing. Back in the city, it's the occasional late-night cheeseburger date with her husband, Eric Zinterhofer, at Bemelmans Bar.
PARK SLOPE CO-OP $825,000

''Four years of unemployment is a luxury we can no longer allow ourselves.'' Claus Hjort Frederiksen,the Danish finance minister. Denmark has cut its benefits system, the world's most generous, by limiting unemployment payments to two years instead of four.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Penalty and Playoff Cap Wild P.G.A.,'' Aug. 16: The rules of golf are ridiculous. Dustin Johnson gets knocked out of a major championship for grounding his club in a so-called bunker -- really a waste area outside the ropes -- which had been trampled on by spectators.

Beloved by Belgian royalty and society types for almost 200 years, the luxury leather goods purveyor Maison Delvaux is finally coming to America. This bag is a slouchier, modern take on the sleek, structured Brillant, which was originally designed in 1958 for the Brussels world fair. Handmade from supple Bridon leather with 24-karat-gold-plated brass hardware, it's available exclusively at Barneys New York for $5,600. SANDRA BALLENTINE

IT seems appropriate to say I love the new Hermes scarf site, jaimemoncarre.com, which the Paris company just introduced. I've been a fan of the main Hermes site, but this is a clever addition for a house that is known for silk scarves and derives a lot of revenue from them. Hermes focuses on young women in Paris, London, New York and Tokyo, offers brief bio sketches and then shows how they wear scarves - which are having a comeback. The photographs are a cut above street-fashion images, and yet not as glossy-perfect as those found in magazines. Remember how fuddy-duddy scarf-tying demonstrations used to be? Remember when people knotted a Hermes scarf on the strap of their bag? Well, here is how a luxury-goods company can make the connection between its heritage (and ultimately sales) and street-style sites. Some of you will recall Burberry's The Art of the Trench site, which shows images of people in their trench coats. But I think there's a little more value in the information contained in jaimemoncarre.com. It feels new. And arguably there are more ways to wear a scarf than a trench.

No one knows for sure whether the name Dogtown, for the area of North Little Rock, Ark., now known as the Argenta Arts District, originally came from the abandoned animals that once roamed its streets. What is certain is that in these six square blocks of vintage storefronts and artists' studios, a trolley ride across the Arkansas River from downtown Little Rock, urban desolation is giving way to urban cool. ''There's been a dramatic change even since we arrived,'' said Jody Hardin, who in 2008 co-founded the district's popular Saturday farmers' market, where only Arkansas purveyors are welcome. ''The galleries and restaurants, the new town homes and restored houses, are making this a place to be.'' CHRISTOPHER HALL
UPPER EAST SIDE CO-OP $879,000

At the turn of the last century, the belles of the French belle époque came down with a collective case of avian flou. ''A well-dressed woman nowadays,'' one journalist noted, ''is as fluffy as a downy bird fresh from the nest.'' From bonnets to boas and courtesans to countesses, lavish, look-at-me plumes covered everything and everyone posh. Like all status symbols, feathers were pricey -- the premium ostrich variety cost as much per pound as diamonds. Hard to fathom? Not really. If the feathered finery swanning down this season's runways makes one thing clear, it's that birds are the new/old/new bling. Twisting around gloves and lapels at Ann Demeulemeester, clustered on dress seams and shoe heels at Lanvin, sprayed across T-shirts at Givenchy, plumage has emerged, phoenix-like, from the fin de siècle's ashes. Notwithstanding the old saw about a bird in the hand, a well-dressed woman nowadays will surely want two in the bush. With its fluttery sensuousness and fragile grace, the feather might seem like the Platonic ideal of feminine adornment. But in fact, its migration to the Paris runways has only come after an extended exile in Guyville. In the ancient patriarchies of Babylon (2105-1240 B.C.) and Assyria (1200-540 B.C.), plumes mingled with palm fronds in sacred headgear for men. In medieval Europe, feathers featured principally on the metal helmets (heaumes) that men donned for war. Because their heaumes hid their faces, knights needed a means of distinguishing friend from foe in a split second. Feathers also came in handy when the knight tried his luck with the ladies. Based on the era's protocol for ''courtly'' love -- which served, in a brutish age, to separate the gentleman from the savage -- a suitor wore feathers in his damsel's special colors when he jousted or did battle, albeit with no guarantee of currying favor. As the 14th-century poet Christine de Pizan noted dismissively: ''To wear blue is no proof of love for one's lady.'' Henri IV, the first of the Bourbon monarchs and a fabled womanizer, made the feather a linchpin of his own, masculine mystique. At the end of the 16th century, when civil conflict threatened to tear France asunder, this great warrior-king enjoined his fractious subjects to ''rally around my panache blanc.'' This slogan was a spirited reference to the large white plume Henri wore in his hat, but the king was also reminding his people that his feather, like the medieval knights', would orient them in the chaos of war. Less loftily, the motto was a coarse anatomical pun, for it posited an equivalency between the king's big, long panache and his big, long . . . appendage. With this double entendre, Henri abandoned the delicacy of courtly love and rebranded the French lord as an unapologetic slayer of both ladies and men.

Many New York women of style have a dependency. It's the wearing of all black. The habit, which used to start as Labor Day approached, is now year-round. Marjorie Stern, top left, is one of the devotees. But last Monday while on her way to work, Ms. Stern appeared in shades of gray and exclaimed, ''I'm sick and tired of black.'' On Tuesday, as she made her way to the office, her threat appeared to be real. She had a leopard printed jacket -- yes, it was worn with black trousers -- but she returned to her old ways on Wednesday, dressed totally in black. But the coat was a sheer fabric, an interesting starlet of this steamy, scorching summer. Other women wore lacy black clothes, and a few wore sinuous black dresses for daytime. And even in the heat of summer, black leggings seemed glued to the legs of others. The majority of women rely on the basic black dress, top right. And two junior sophisticates at a party came in, what else, all black.

SCHILLER--Lynn C.,August 20, 2010. Loving and beloved wife of the late Dr. Carl Schiller. Beloved grandmother, great-grandmother and great-aunt. Cherished and devoted aunt, step-mother and friend. Her spunk and joie de vivre will be missed by all. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam on Monday at 12pm.

Do you want to know how much LeBron James pays in Social Security taxes each year? Bill Gates? Oprah? Your dermatologist? $6,622. That's the maximum anyone pays in Social Security taxes, because earnings above $106,800 are not taxed. By slowly raising the cap -- say, 2 percent each year, though increasing it faster would raise more revenue -- so that it eventually covered 90 percent of all income, we could eliminate roughly a third of Social Security's projected shortfall. Next year, people like Mr. James would pay slightly more than they pay now while eventually receiving slightly higher benefits.

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the wedding of Susan Dempsey and Gerald Halloran misidentified the Web site for which the bride's mother is editor in chief. It is onPhilanthropy.com, not Philanthropy.com.

In an extreme case of camel coat envy, a frustrated New York socialite who had long fetishized the trench coat Ali MacGraw wore in ''Love Story'' engaged a patternmaker last year to copy it in caramel cashmere, down to the patch pockets and double-wide lapel and collar (which, like MacGraw's character, Jenny, you gotta wear popped). From Paris to New York, from Kate Moss to Blake Lively (who seem to be as attached to their fawn-colored coats as Grace Kelly and Katharine Hepburn were to theirs), camel is dans l'air this fall. Céline's Phoebe Philo jump-started the trend last spring with the ultimate boyfriend coat, a honey-toned Crombie. Jean Paul Gaultier -- in his penultimate, fall collection for Hermès -- showed a three-quarter camel coat pinched from the guys, saving his most luxurious discursion for duffel coats like the ones once worn by the British Royal Navy. Michael Kors imagined a gender mix-up at the coat check, or maybe that blushingly erotic moment when a gentleman slips his camel coat over his date's chilly shoulders. If it's all beginning to sound like a male conspiracy, well, a lot of women's outerwear in the buff register does lead back to the blokes. Think of the peacoat -- and the polo coat. Around 1900, polo players began wrapping themselves in camel ''wait coats'' -- patterned, essentially, on a dressing gown -- to keep warm between chukkers. Later, women borrowed freely of the details: half belt, full cut, chest pocket. In 1949 the camel coat was the American coed's favorite. Kors made winking reference to all that history, pairing a great big muff of a fur skirt with a camel knit tee. Among the other camel offerings were satin blouses and high-waisted slacks (Chloé), even a strapless dress (Gianfranco Ferré). But in the end, it was the camel coat that scored, whether sable-trimmed at Carolina Herrera or sleeveless at Alexander Wang. A real love story. CHRISTOPHER PETKANAS

'Oh, those are fantastic! I want to see them! They're adorable! Let me fix your socks,'' Patricia Fox cries out when she spies Suzanne Golden's shoes, a pair of black and white Comme des Garçons winkle pickers festooned with rhinestone buckles that serve as a counterpoint to the rest of Golden's black-and-white Junya Watanabe ensemble. Fox, who is wearing a veiled chapeau with a blossom brim, a 1950s sequined floral jacket, a chiffon dress with a hobble skirt and a pair of beaded gloves, is meeting Golden for the first time at a tea party I have organized at the Carlyle Hotel, an event I refer to (but not out loud) as a ''nutty-dressers'' luncheon. In addition to Golden and Fox, there are two other invited guests: Tziporah Salamon (1930s cheongsam, bamboo pinwheel hat, 200-year-old Chinese handbag) and Iris Apfel (a tunic made by one of China's ethnic minorities, a clanging necklace from a Tunisian souk, signature humongous spectacles). I've been seeing these grande dames around town for years, and now, finally, I've got them all in one spot -- at one table -- so I can ask them how it came to be that the four of them glitter like spectacular if wacky jewels in an otherwise mostly mundane pedestrian landscape. So how did it all begin for you? I ask the ladies, who are busy fussing with the tea and looking one another up and down. (It should be noted that I am dressed very simply for the occasion, in a Gaultier dress printed with fish scales over a Bottega Veneta skirt so wide it might have daunted Marie Antoinette.) Fox gives her shoulder-grazing LaCroix earrings a toss (because her outfit needed one more thing?) and says seriously, ''I am consistent. My outward appearance goes with my inward feelings. My spirit is timeless; my age doesn't matter. It's a reflection of my mood.''

The odd collection of merchandise spills from Benny Villanova's garage and threatens to overflow onto the sidewalk: a wheeled office chair, a park bench, boxy computer monitors of 1990s vintage. A hand truck with a flat tire, a dirty sink. A rocking horse. This he dates to the 1930s and offers to sell for $20. Or $10. It's negotiable. Mr. Villanova himself can usually be found among the junk piles in his driveway in Woodhaven, Queens. He lounges on a worn couch with his assistant, Danny Neaman, smoking, sipping drinks and peddling wares many might dismiss as garbage.

FROM diapers to shapewear, Cynthia Rowley has been busy jazzing up one unseemly necessity after another. Now comes something everyone could use: 14 fashion-friendly Band-Aid designs, created in collaboration with Johnson & Johnson. Among them, strips of sequins, gold chains and lace, as well as square-cut bandages that look like jewels. Packaged in two different arty tins, the Band-Aids are a limited edition, and $1 from each sale at Cynthia Rowley stores will be donated to Design Ignites Change, which mentors high school students. As we see it, no pain, no gain. Cynthia Rowley Dress Up Band-Aids, $10 at the Shop at Cooper-Hewitt and Cynthia Rowley stores; cynthiarowley.com.

STEINER--Phillip Lawrence, died on August 12, 2010. He was 82 years old. He is survived by his wife Elisabeth, daughters Jane and Diane, granddaughter Bianca, and stepson Daryl. Mr. Steiner had an illustrious career in the chemical and plastics industry. Its highlights include executive at Hi-Lux Tape Corporation and Tenneco Chemicals, specializing in market aspects of the plastics industry. Prior to that he was manager at Whittaker Corporation. In his earlier years, he had created his own company and invented, among other products, a plastic road marker adopted by cities nationally and internationally. For the last two decades, he was a sales representative for CPI Packaging, covering the entire tri-state area. His inexhaustible energy, standards of ethics, sense of humor, and caring spirit, made him outstanding in his career and earned him the loyalty his customers and friends. Phillip was president of the Antique Car Club of New Jersey and a collector of antique cars for many years. He also was a passionate aviator. At one time he owned a farm in Claverack, New York. His love of nature made him a generous contributor to the welfare of animals. A celebration of his life will take place at the family home. In place of flowers, contributions may be made to the Tenafly Nature Center.

WITH next month's release of ''Trespass: A History of Uncommissioned Urban Art'' (Taschen) and word that Jeffrey Deitch will be mounting a graffiti show at MoCA in Los Angeles, it is clear that street art -- no matter how much of an eyesore it may be to some -- is having a high-brow moment. It has even hit the Hamptons. ''Down by Law,'' a new show at the Eric Firestone Gallery in East Hampton, features rarely shown old and contemporary pieces from the pioneers of the genre. People like Coco 144; Mare 139; the late Dondi White (whose ''Hammers in Hell'' is at right); Dr. Revolt, who created the ''Yo! MTV Raps'' logo; and Blade, known as the King of the Trains, have tagged more than 5,000 of them. ''Everyone's into the term 'street art' -- it's become very sexy,'' said Mr. Firestone, who, in visiting many of the artists in the outer boroughs, jokes that his graffiti name became GPS. ''But there's more to it than Banksy, and I'm hoping to open up that world.'' ''Down by Law'' runs through Sept. 26 at the Eric Firestone Gallery, 4 Newtown Lane, East Hampton. N.Y.; (631) 604-2386, ericfirestonegallery.com.

SCHUELLER--Charlotte Haas, of Manhattan, passed away on June 5, 2010, just short of her 98th birthday. She was born in Munich, Germany and is survived by her brother, Gerhard Haas, nephew, David Haas, and niece, Andrea Haas. Mrs. Schueller was predeceased by her husband Otto in 1976.

For the YouTube how-to maven Michelle Phan, making up is easy. CHRISTINE MUHLKE. 1 The beauty universe has embraced the future, thanks in no small part to women like Michelle Phan. The 23-year-old former Floridian, who still has a year to go at Ringling College of Art and Design, uses her talent with brushes and pencils to create video makeup tutorials that attract millions of viewers to her YouTube channel. (One of her Lady Gaga how-to's has garnered more than 10 million hits.) ''I consider beauty another form of painting,'' she says. ''Color theory and understandinghow the product works on a surface really helps me when I'm applying makeup.'' These days, she has less time to paint: she was tapped to be the (talking) face of Lancôme as its official video makeup artist. 2 Phan is already playing with fall's trends, from hot pink lipstick -- like this Lancôme Color Design Matte in Posh Pink ($22 at lancome.com) -- to the dramatic eyes and eyebrows seen at Balenciaga, Giorgio Armani, L'Wren Scott and the Row. 3 She's using the new brushes from her Iqqu collection, inspired by calligraphy brushes, to achieve the look. (This red kabuki brush is $30 at iqqubeauty.com.) 4 When not online,she finds time to read. ''I'm actually reading the Bible in a comic-book form,'' she says. ''It's crazy how entertaining it is when you see it drawn out!''5 Lancôme put Phan on its makeup team at Chris Benz's fall show, where she used the brand's new hyper-metallic Ombre Magnétique shadow in Black Macadam ($20, available at lancome.com) to create a grungy, street-chic look. (''It's like Play-Doh,'' she says of the texture.) Phan loved the energy backstage: ''It felt like I was on 'Iron Chef' for makeup artists!'' 6 Food is a passion. ''If I had to eat one thing for the rest of my life, that would be pho, a Vietnamese soup that not only tastes delicious but also cures sickness and hangovers.'' She seeks it out in local restaurants in Los Angeles, but her mom's is still her favorite. 7 Her preferred hunting ground for cosmetics? ''The more obscure, the better,'' she says. ''I'm a big Sephora fan. I also love drugstore finds,'' like L'Oréal H.I.P. Color Truth Cream Eyeliner ($12 at Walgreens) and Maybelline the Falsies mascara ($8 at drugstores). ''I use false lashes in most of my videos, so I'm always curious about any mascara that really amps up your lashes.'' 8 Phan gets hundreds of tutorial requests from her followers on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube -- ''anything with Miley Cyrus or Lady Gaga,'' she says with a laugh. Her lessons on five-minute makeup, smoky eyes for women who wear glasses and a sexy vampire makeover are especially popular. For her Halloween series, she's working on a full-blown Na'vi look from ''Avatar'': ''Contacts, fangs, ears and the tail . . . O.K., maybe not the tail. You wouldn't believe how many requests I've gotten for this.'' 9 Each video is a homemade production. Phan uses her Canon HD camcorder to film against a customized background projected on her TV screen (like the Alexander McQueen shoes in a Gaga how-to) and adds her favorite music for the soundtrack. (These days, Late Night Alumni, Kaskade and Samantha James are in heavy rotation.) 10 For someone who experiments with her looks for a living, Phan is surprisingly old-fashioned when it comes to beauty icons. Her favorite is Audrey Hepburn for her ''classic, timeless'' appeal. ''Her heart outshined her beauty.'' 11 Millions of women follow Phan's every stroke. Her best beauty tips? ''Tight-lining the eyes gives an appearance of fuller-looking lashes,'' she says, explaining,''This is where you apply your eyeliner to the top waterline, right underneath your lashes. Next, a light line of concealer running straight down the nose will give an illusion of a taller, skinnier nose. Lastbut not least, if all else fails, just smile.''

Three books due out this fall find fashion in a retrospective mood. ''Yohji Yamamoto: My Dear Bomb'' (Ludion), the first-ever biography of the designer, fittingly ditches an orthodox chronology for a series of short fictions written by Yamamoto interspersed with vivid reminiscences. (For those looking for something a little more linear, the book concludes with a timeline featuring never-before-seen personal images.) Anna Sui's eponymous biography (Chronicle Books), on the other hand, is a more visual feast. Written by Andrew Bolton, a curator at the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this book will showcase 400 photographs from the Sui archives and include text by the White Stripes frontman Jack White and her longtime collaborator Steven Meisel. Finally, two photographers put the art in Rodarte in a new book from JRP Ringier. ''Rodarte, Catherine Opie, Alec Soth'' (left ) is an off-the-cuff collaboration with Kate and Laura Mulleavy that delves into the design duo's myriad obsessions. ALEX HAWGOOD
MoMA's ''New Photography 2010'' series opening next month focuses on hippersnappers like Alex Prager (''Desiree,'' above), who get their material from magazines, television and movies. ALIX BROWNE

Loughlin, Jr. of Hackettstown, NJ, nieces Patricia Dolgert of Springfield VA, Miriam Edwards of Aston, Pa, Suzanne Loughlin of Newton, MA and Mary Ann Shanahan of Stamford, CT, nephews John Loughlin of Yukon, OK and Kevin Maguire of Centereach, NY. As well as many grand nieces and nephews. Visitation at Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th Street on August 22, 2-5 and 7-9pm. On Aug. 31, Portfolio will publish ''Debt-Free U: How I Paid for an Outstanding College Education Without Loans, Scholarships or Mooching Off My Parents'' by Zac Bissonnette. Mark Kantrowitz, an occasional contributor to The Choice and the publisher of Finaid.org, suggested that this was a book worth bringing to the attention of readers of our blog. In response, I did a brief interview-by-e-mail with Mr. Bissonnette, who has written for AOL's DailyFinance.com, among other news media outlets. Excerpts of our exchange, which have been edited, are below.Q.You're entering your senior year at the University of Massachusetts, and the subtitle of your book suggests you paid your own way ''without loans, scholarships, or mooching off'' your mother and father. Roughly how much has your education cost, and how did you manage to pay for it?

On a recent Friday morning, lit white by the California sun, Nigel Dare was sitting in his shop, fielding calls from a movie set. ''Is that a Japanese line?'' he asked the makeup artist on the other end. ''Never heard of it. But you'll have it by Monday.'' Dare is the ultimate Hollywood candy man -- a warm, personable guy who can procure Fria, an Italian makeup remover, if that's what you need, or Collyre Bleu (1) for the hungover actor with bloodshot eyes. Nigel's Beauty Emporium, along with Naimie's Beauty Center and Frends Beauty Supply, is perhaps the San Fernando Valley's best-kept secret: a treasure trove of rarefied cosmetics brands where Hollywood makeup artists go to keep the likes of Sandra Bullock, Megan Fox and George Clooney powdered and buffed. Here they can scour hundreds of global brands, including ones you don't see everywhere (Embryolisse (2), La Peau (3) ) and the Japanese lines much beloved by the pros (KohGenDo, Kanebo). Here they can ask for and get Kate (5), the ultrathin Kanebo eyeliner that is barely detectable on the eye. Or the French -- and much stronger -- version of Anthelios, the sunscreen by La Roche-Posay. Or, for that matter, Labello lip balm (4), from Germany. Frends is the granddaddy of the bunch: founded in 1940, it catered to makeup artists who were stuck on a set for 18 hours straight and running on empty. Today all three stores are about turnaround, finding products anywhere they can and even picking them up at a competitor's if they have to -- which, for the right client, they will. SUSAN CAMPOS

Social Security, now celebrating its 75th birthday, is receiving mixed diagnoses. Some analysts think the program is on solid fiscal ground for decades to come, while others fear that the impending retirement of the baby boom generation precipitates a crisis. In either case, it is always worth considering innovations to make the program more efficient and equitable. The Op-Ed page editors asked six experts to recommend specific fixes that could be part of a comprehensive reform package for the nation's largest social insurance program.

Movies haunt culture like starlit ghosts, circling our collective unconscious. Some insinuate themselves because they are comforting and friendly, which is not the case with ''Last Year at Marienbad,'' a famously impenetrable monument to the avant-garde directed by Alain Resnais. But the discovery of six reels of behind-the-scenes footage from 1960 forever fractures the movie's cool, calculated surface. With a Super-8 camera, Françoise Spira, a young cast member with a bit part, produced what seems like an amateur version of the film itself, her relationship to its protagonist, played by Delphine Seyrig, as intimate as Resnais's. Spira committed suicide a few years later, and her celluloid diary languished until 2008. The movie's second assistant director, Volker Schlöndorff, later turned it into the documentary ''The Making of 'Last Year at Marienbad,' '' which Diane von Furstenberg toasted at her studio in June after a screening at New York University. Schlöndorff was there, as well as Jean-Luc Godard's biographer Richard Brody, the photographer Steven Klein, Ahn Duong, Daphne Guinness and the documentary's principal promoter, Bernard-Henri Lévy. The film triggered an evening of mannered nostalgia. Von Furstenberg mused that when she's alone in a hotel she often thinks of Seyrig's character, captive of a fictional hotel, trapped in cycles of elegance and desire. Not surprisingly, von Furstenberg couldn't help referring to the film in creating interiors for Claridge's in London, trapped in her own way by Marienbad's spell. And while cinephiles are keenly aware of the picture's masterly construction, hallucinatory settings and gestures (the actors are often frozen in place, a sort of nascent voguing), fashion feeds what may be its truest fetish: dresses adapted from Chanel; Seyrig's haircut; and two feathered gowns by Bernard Evein, one white and one black, that have returned to us, visitations from a filmic netherworld, through the avian flutter of the fall collections. PIERRE ALEXANDRE DE LOOZ

Before Saturday's game, Manager Joe Girardi was asked about Javier Vazquez's velocity, which has been a point of concern for some, but not Girardi.''When he lost a couple, people started talking about his velocity,'' Girardi said. ''You know, you can make something out of nothing, but his velocity has not been 91-93 all year long.'' Vazquez has proved he can go through winning and losing stretches with his fastball hovering around the mid to high 80s, but his recent rough patch continued Saturday, as he yielded as many home runs as innings pitched (three).

We have been invited to stay in a farmhouse owned by an English family in October, in Calamandrana, Italy, which is in the vicinity of Asti. Do you have any suggestions for sightseeing? Are there any wineries we can visit? Is Turin far? I know there is a lot to see there. Asti, once known as the city of 100 towers, offers more than just the area's famous sparkling wine. The city is also home to the medieval Old Town (still home to a few of those towers), Renaissance palaces and grand piazzas, where you'll find some of the town's best food and clothing markets. Look for San Secondo, a Romanesque-Gothic church dedicated to the town's patron saint, and the red-brick Cattedrale di Santa Maria Assunta, one of the biggest cathedrals in Piedmont.

Social Security should invest in collateralized debt obligations backed by subprime mort ... oops, that doesn't work. Actually, Social Security is not that bad off. It is in much better shape than state and local pensions or Medicare. In fact, it is in better shape than the rest of the federal budget, which has been borrowing the surplus that Social Security accumulated over many years and is now fretting because it will soon have to pay the money back. Got that? I didn't think so. Let's try again. Before ''fixing'' Social Security, we should think about what it is that we want to cure. The actuarial problem in Social Security is that, instead of each generation supporting itself, as in a normal pension system, in Social Security each generation supports its elders. Therefore, any generation has the power to bankrupt the system simply by failing to adhere to the Biblical injunction to ''go forth and multiply.'' If we baby boomers would have had no children, Social Security would be over, although our savings on education would be considerable. Seriously, though, we did have too few kids. So the system needs tinkering -- and it will always need tinkering as demographic patterns shift from one decade to the next.

MILLER--Alan Noel, Dr.,76, passed away on Friday, August 20th after a short battle with pancreatic cancer. Alan was widowed after 37 years of marriage to Libby Shana Halpern Miller, PhD. Prior to becoming a nephrologist, Dr. Miller earned an MBA in Finance and also had a career as an engineer. He served as a captain in the Special Forces training Green Berets. Alan was a loving and generous man with strong principles and convictions. An avid learner, he continued his education and quest for knowledge by taking classes at Columbia University all his life. He fostered others' desire for higher education through the sponsorship of mentoring programs and scholarships. Dr. Miller was a devoted Columbia man. He worked tirelessly to keep his class of 1956 connected and served as their president for many years. He also wrote the Class News for the Columbia Paper on a quarterly basis, and fellow "Columbians" referred to him as "The Class Act." A dedicated advocate of the 3x5 index card form of organization, he was also a proud cigar smoker, stock watcher and wine collector. Ol' Doc Al, or GGA, Grumpy Grandpa Al, as so lovingly referred to by his grandchildren, will be deeply missed. Always larger than life, he leaves a huge hole in his death. He is survived by his partner, Helene Ruddy, his mother Iris Miller, his daughter and son in law, Elisa Miller and Greg Griffin, his daughter, Jennifer van Voorst van Beest, his sister and brother-in-law, Barbara and Maurice Kupritz, his sister and brother-in-law, Mona and Lee Berg, his grandchildren, Zachary and Elana Griffin, Elijah and Isaac van Voorst van Beest and many other close relatives and friends. We love you doc. God speed. The funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday August 22nd at 11:45am. A graveside service will follow at Sharon Gardens. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the Columbia College Class of 1956/Alan N. Miller Scholarship would be greatly appreciated. We will be sitting shiva at 257 Central Park West, Apt 9D beginning Sunday evening after 6pm and during the week between 11am-9pm.

Massimiliano Giornetti planned to spend his summer vacation in Puglia, a popular Italian getaway several hours from his home in Florence. ''I'm not entirely a free spirit on holiday,'' says the 38-year-old designer, who was recently named Ferragamo's creative director. ''I like some structure, with a little room to be adventurous.'' A perfect metaphor for his design mantra at Ferragamo, where he has helmed the men's-wear divison for the last decade. Any question as to whether Giornetti could translate his masculine sensibilities to the more mercurial closets of women was answered in his much lauded fall collection. He managed to channel the independent spirit of Salvatore Ferragamo's devoted customer, Greta Garbo, while creating sharp, assertive glamour: fur-lined capes, cuffed leather shorts, thick cable knits and a three-piece pinstriped suit that seemed like a 21st-century version of ''Annie Hall.'' ''I don't believe in fashion as provocation. I'm not interested in the 'wow' effect,'' he says. ''I'm more concerned with beauty and decoration. Fashion is not a primary necessity in life. The point of fashion is to make your daily life more special.'' Surprisingly, the designer felt no timidity tackling women's wear. ''Doing men's wear was actually more of a shock to me,'' he says. ''Women are braver about fashion. There is much more freedom in what you can attempt.''
Now's the time to grin and bear it.
LIPPOLD--Richard. 8 years after your tragic death there is still no closer. I will never forget nor forgive. Your Gianni

Arnold Scaasi's mostly over-the-top creations have adorned everyone from Mamie Eisenhower to Louise Nevelson, from glittering trophy wives flush with 1980s money to an order of nuns in Pennsylvania. ''Scaasi: American Couturier,'' a survey opening Sept. 25 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, showcases his designs for four of his most loyal clients: the actresses Arlene Francis and Barbra Streisand, and the socialites Joetta Norban and Gayfryd Steinberg. Sitting beneath a late Picasso in his Manhattan living room, with a view of ships sailing leisurely along the East River in the background, the couturier (born Arnold Isaacs in 1930) talked to Leslie Camhi about his half century of making a very select group of women feel special. LESLIE CAMHI Do you still follow fashion?

When the Munich gallery owner Joëlle Chariau began collecting fashion illustrations, ''it was a field that no one had been interested in,'' she says. ''I could get the best artists without competition.'' Thirty years later, the Design Museum in London will display her collection for the first time this November. ''Drawing Fashion,'' co-curated by the fashion historian Colin McDowell, brings together clothing by Poiret, Lanvin, Chanel, Alexander McQueen and others as drawn by Erté, Lepape, René Gruau, Antonio (left) and Mats Gustafson. In the digital age, Chariau says, drawing has new impact: ''Today there are so many images that it's almost impossible to find one that strikes the imagination. When people look at drawings, they say: 'Oh, my God! It's fantastic!' '' The accompanying book will be published by Prestel. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

Karl Lagerfeld's directive? ''Chic but slightly destroyed.'' So Peter Philips used black liner to ''dash on'' an eye similar in texture to some of the accessories in the show, while Sam McKnight gave the models a bouffant mane inspired by a snow lion.

TOYOTA, Goldman Sachs and BP have shown some of the steepest declines in public perception this year, according to research groups that analyze corporate reputations based on online polls and phone calls. Although some experts say the online polls should be used with caution -- as the respondents may not represent the entire population -- others say they are one of the best ways to keep tabs on fast-moving public sentiment. Toyota has regained close to half the public support it lost after late January, according to daily public perception scores collected by YouGov, a market research firm. (That month, Toyota suspended sales of eight models over fears about uncontrolled acceleration.) Experts attribute Toyota's rebound to its longstanding reputation for quality and doubt about whether the company was to blame for the problems. Goldman Sachs, on the other hand, has had a negative public perception score since 2008, when the government helped bail out Wall Street. And after the company was charged with fraud in April -- a case later settled -- it continued to see damage to its reputation.

A slide show of other non-traditional yoga practices is here. I was in a vile, despicable mood when I arrived at laughter yoga. It was Wednesday, and my brain felt torn in one too many directions; the usual, only worse. Laughter seemed a remote possibility.

At a recent Chanel party, a little-known D.J. took the stage to a remix of ''Carmina Burana'' and spun the crowd -- which included Tim Burton, Vanessa Paradis and Johnny Depp -- into a frenzy. This mix master wasn't a model or a downtown doyenne: it was Ruth Flowers, a k a Mamy Rock, a grandmother well into her 70s who has put in appearances at Cannes, Glastonbury and Paris, where her ''factotum'' is based. ''I thought, What are they going to think of this old biddy who gets up there to play records?'' she says from her home in southwest England. Inspired to become a D.J. when she attended her grandson's birthday party, Flowers has worked with a French producer on mixing, as well as on her ''stage persona,'' which includes a hairstyle that ''looks as if I've been plugged into an electricity cord.'' Spinning has eclipsed some of her other hobbies, like giving historical talks about Henry VIII, but she's happy to be busy. ''When you get to 60, that's when you just go to bingo, I suppose,'' she says, adding unnecessarily, ''That's not my scene.'' HOLLY SIEGEL
''I never once thought that it was a sand trap.'' DUSTIN JOHNSON, after being assessed a two-stroke penalty for grounding his club during the final round of the P.G.A. Championship.

WEISS--Kenneth Holden, on August 17, at age 78, of lymphoma. Born in New York City, he was the husband of Maxine Bader Weiss, father of Susan Weiss (Roger Marsden) and Jane Weiss, and grandfather of Nicole Marsden. A founder of Shire Village Camp in Massachusetts, he was a noted film historian and collector, and the author of several books, including "To Be Continued," "The Movie Collector's Catalog," and "To the Rescue: How Immigrants Saved the American Film Industry, 1896-1912."
To have and to hold on to. SANDRA BALLENTINE

KHAKOO--Dr. Yusuf M.,died August 12, 2010 at home in Bronx, NY, aged 74. One of nine children, he was born in Pemba, in the Zanzibar archipelago of present-day Tanzania. After secondary school, he immigrated to India to study at the prestigious Elphinstone College and Grant Medical College, both in Bombay. There he met Hamida, his wife of 42 years and also a physician, who predeceased him in May 2004. Since the early 1970s, he worked at Harlem Hospital, specializing in the treatment of children with sickle cell disease. He was dedicated to, and deeply loved by, his patients and their families. He was on the faculty of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, educating generations of medical students. Besides his family and Mets baseball, his enduring passions were for things outdoors. He was a skilled fisherman and gardener, an extension of a childhood spent on the hills and shores of Zanzibar. He was a beloved member of the Shia Ithna-Asheri Jamaat of New York, where he served his Islamic community when called upon. He was a devoted father and doting grandfather. He is survived by a daughter and two sons: Yasmin Khakoo and husband Robert Fisher; Aashik Khakoo and wife Jillian Hiris; and Aarif Khakoo and wife Shibani Pati. He will be sorely missed by seven grandchildren: Alex, Anika, Manisha, Wesley, Aliya, Cullin, and Thelonious. He leaves behind a brother, Sherali, of Milton Keynes, UK.

If you happened by Jeffrey New York earlier this year, it was impossible not to have noticed the dramatic paper wigs that crowned the mannequins wearing Yves Saint Laurent and the like. The designers, Nikki Salk and Amy Flurry, of Paper Cut Project in Atlanta, say they were inspired by Gidget, the Supremes and Billie Holiday. The partners have also created a collection of textured paper masks that look a bit like what Oscar Wilde would have worn to a masquerade ball. Which is not to say they have no modern applications: ''A bride in Japan wanted us to create a mask in a vintage Paris-meets-manga theme!'' Flurry says. And the bride isn't alone: ''We're currently working on an exclusive collection for Hermès and are very interested in designing a more elaborate series of masks and headwear for the runway.'' Are you listening, John Galliano? HOLLY SIEGEL

His loss is deeply mourned by his wife, Marcia, children Annie and Alex, and his sister, Denise. Services Monday, August 23rd, 11am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St., New York City. Contributions may be made to: Institut Seculier Notre Dame De Vie a Venasque, 84210 Venasque, France.

Julien David apprenticed with Narciso Rodriguez and Ralph Lauren in New York, but when the 31-year-old French designer ventured out on his own, he went back to Square 1: the scarf. His collection, which he started in Tokyo in 2007, uses the finest Japanese silks and cashmere -- to wildly irreverent effect. Artificial growth, for example, is his theme for this fall. This plays itself out in something as unusual as a pill motif, which the designer blows up into a giant two-toned capsule (left), whose colorful geometry drapes around the neck. ''I tend to like gigantism,'' David says. ''I thought I could make the silk scarves look very different and interesting [by] changing prints and proportions.'' This September, David will add coats and bags to the mix. Artificial growth? More likely, natural progression. AMY THOMAS

CLARK--F. Lamar A native of Mobile, Alabama and resident of Alpharetta, Georgia, died at his residence on August 17, 2010. He is survived by his devoted wife of 53 years, Ann H. Clark; his loving son, Joe and daughter-in-law, Nori; his adoring grandchildren, Tommy and Angela Clark all of Suwanee, Georgia; one sister, Gini C. Nelson (Ed) of Spanish Fort, Alabama; and a brother-in-law John Hudgens (Debbie) of Creola, Alabama; one uncle, Gerald Clark of Millbrook, Alabama, many nieces, nephews and other relatives. He was preceded in death by his parents, Tom and Flossie Clark, sisters, Sue C. Ryals and Karen C. Connell. Mr. Clark was a resident of Woodbridge, New Jersey for 37 years and retired as Senior Vice President of Hess Corporation. He was with the company for 45 years at retirement. Mr. Clark retired to Alpharetta, Georgia to be near his grandchildren. He loved spending time with them and was affectionately known as "Papa". He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. His kind generosity was well known to many people. Visitation will be at Ingram Funeral Home in Cumming, Georgia on Saturday, August 21, 2010 from 10:00am until 1:00pm followed by a graveside service at Sawnee View Memorial Gardens with Rev. Mike Schmid officiating. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials be made to Whispering Hope in care of First Redeemer Church, 2100 Peachtree Parkway, Cumming, Georgia 30041-7497. Ingram Funeral Home & Crematory, Cumming, GA is in charge of the services. Condolences may be made at www.ingramfuneralhome.com.

The Place du Grand Sablon in Brussels is nothing like West 47th Street in Manhattan, although you can pick up a nice little brooch in either locale. The square and its surrounding streets are dominated by smart town houses occupied by dealers of sumptuous period furniture, chocolate, rare books and all manner of art, including one that's rarely mentioned in the same breath as sculpture and painting but is every bit as rarefied: costume jewelry made for the haute couture. Utterly dazzling and totally faux, these limited editions are the handiwork of paruriers who collaborated with the major couture houses from the 1920s until fashion went corporate in the '90s. Lovingly collected by a handful of dealers, the crème de la bling can be found here. BRONWYN
Dance Claudia La Rocco

A picture caption in some editions last Sunday with an article about disabled veterans' competing in the Mayor's Cup Kayak Championships around Manhattan misidentified the bridge that kayakers were shown passing under. It was the Williamsburg Bridge, not the Manhattan Bridge.

KRUESI--Oscar R. M.D.,86 passed away June 27, 2010, following a brief illness. A renowned physician and teacher, Dr. Kruesi was a long-time resident of Bernardsville, NJ, before retiring to Fort Myers, FL three years ago. He graduated from Union College, Schenectady, NY, following service in the U.S. Air Force during World War II. He later graduated Cornell University Medical School. An internist, he was a pioneer in preventive care who, starting in the 1960s, used primarily nutritional supplements to treat mental and physical disorders. He was an Assistant Clinical Professor of Medicine for Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, in addition to teaching across the U.S. and Europe. For many years he served as a trustee of Morristown Memorial Hospital, where he started the Cardiac Care Unit in the 1960s and co-founded the Alcohol Service. He was a trustee also of the Somerset Hills YMCA, Schizophrenia Foundation of New Jersey, Princeton Bio Center, and many other organizations. He was an emeritus member of the Explorers Club. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Elizabeth, his brothers Frank, of Boise, ID, and Paul of Golden, CO, his sons Markus of Isle of Palms, SC, Hugo of Fairfax, VA, and Konrad of Tinmouth, VT, daughters Charlotte Tarr of Naples, FL, and Katherine Lincoln of Bernardsville, NJ, nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to The Shelter for Abused Women and Children, P.O. Box 10102, Naples, Florida 34101.

BILGREI--Donna Hoffman, 67, died August 16, 2010. Devoted wife of Michael Bilgrei, adored mother of Rachel (Robert Brous), and Joshua (Lisa), beloved sister of Ellen Lieberman (Robert). She is also survived by her precious grandson Jackson Henry. Loving aunt to Allyson, Jeremy and great-aunt of Owen. For over 30 years Donna worked for the New York City Board of Education. She will be greatly missed for her love of family, intelligence, lively conversation and sense of humor. Her strength will stay with us always.

Houston's newest form of shared transportation, the Washington Wave, is a welcome addition to the city's expanding party corridor along Washington Avenue. Operating since November, this privately owned jitney service picks up within the Washington Avenue district, Midtown and the Heights ($5 for one way or $10 for all night), making it easier to barhop (and restaurant-hop) along Washington Avenue's three-mile strip. To find a jitney, partygoers can flag one down along its established routes or call (713) 863-9283 for a pickup. The wave bracelet (which riders show to board the shuttle) also gets discounts, like 10 percent off the tab, at several area hot spots. Two free parking lots, located at 230 TC Jester or Lot H at the southwest corner of Houston and Memorial Drive, let drivers leave their cars overnight without getting towed.

NEHRING--Janet (Jay), 60, died August 16, 2010. Beloved daughter of Virginia and the late Richard Nehring; loving sister of Ginger Miller-Jones (Bob), Carol Phinizy (Coles), and Tom Nehring (Amy); and a favorite aunt and great-aunt to numerous nieces and nephews. Graduated from Arcadia University with a BFA, Jay was a copywriter for Ogilvy and Mather in NYC before moving to Australia where she continued her award-winning work in advertising. Taken too soon, Jay will be missed by family and friends. A service will be held at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Amityville on August 28. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to the American Cancer Society.

THE NEWS Republican Congressional candidates sought to inject the controversy over the planned Islamic center near ground zero in New York into the midterm elections, saying President Obama was out of touch with average Americans in defending the right of developers to pursue the project. BEHIND THE NEWS Republicans called the location ''sacred ground.'' But politics of the issue did not divide neatly along party lines. Democrats weighing in against the proposed project included Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, and Howard Dean, the former national party chairman, who call the project ''a real affront to those who lost their lives.''

ALEXANDER--R. Bernard The family of Bernie Alexander mourns his death, at age 92, on August 11, 2010, in Kennett Square, PA. Husband of 64 years of Eleanor Jane (Teedie) Alexander, who died April 2, 2009; father of Joan Leonhardt of Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY, Steve Alexander of North Ferrisburgh, VT, and Polly Alexander of Essex Junction, VT; father-in-law of Bob Leonhardt and Kathy Alexander; grandfather of David Leonhardt (married to Laura), Robin Leonhardt Peterson (married to Eric), Tyler Nash, and Maria, Jackson and Daisy Alexander; great-grandfather of four. Located in a former brothel in the Union Square area of San Francisco, Michael Kelter's new store definitely aims to seduce. The sprawling space, outfitted with antique haberdashery and factory fixtures, is a perfect foil for the cutting-edge fashion on offer. ''The décor is mysterious yet inviting and evokes a sense of history,'' Kelter says. Go to downtownshop.com. SANDRA 1. Many items in the store, like this suede and pinstriped denim jacket ($6,250) by Agatha, are one of a kind. Kelter suggests wearing it with skinny jeans, a black high-heeled boot and a custom bowler (he has them made in England), for an eccentric ''rocker banker look.''

As a design critic, it's my job to decide whether things are well designed and, if so, why. Because they're environmentally sound? Ethical? Innovative? Emotionally expressive? All good reasons, sure, but sometimes we're drawn to things simply because they give us a warm, fuzzy feeling, which is harder to explain. And I felt it recently when I spotted a set of strangely shaped water carafes at a design show in Milan.

An article on Aug. 8 about the enforcement of music-copyright laws gave an erroneous definition of a kind of right involved in music distribution. A mechanical right is the right to record and distribute a recording and must be obtained from the publisher or songwriter of the work. It is not a payment to a performer who plays a song, regardless of who wrote it.

An article last Sunday about the Arcade Fire's album ''The Suburbs'' having reached No. 1 on the Billboard charts misidentified the previous No. 1. album. It was Avenged Sevenfold's ''Nightmare,'' not Eminem's ''Relapse.'' (Eminem's album had been No. 1 for the previous five weeks.)

By ALIX BROWNE When fashion editors were given an intimate viewing of Alexander McQueen's final collection in Paris this past spring, this dress was not part of it. Perhaps the last piece touched by the designer's hands, it was made by McQueen especially for his longtime friend Annabelle Neilson, and its only outing has been to Elton John's White Tie and Tiara Ball in June. Neilson was notorious for wearing McQueen's clothes and she did so with a fierceness befitting her status as his muse. A sheer black jumpsuit from 2006, a mere figment of McQueen's imagination that left nothing to anyone else's, generated reams of chatter and flaunted the designer's devilish streak. Indeed he was often heralded as fashion's enfant terrible No. 1. But in this simply elegant silk charmeuse gown with its collar of silvered feathers, Neilson appeared as the vision of an angel. ALIX BROWNE

LANGLOIS--John D. China scholar, historian and banker John D. Langlois died in New York City early on August 19th, surrounded by family and friends, after a courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Hsin I and other family members. Known as Jack to his many friends, he passed between the worlds of academia and finance as smoothly as he traveled between Asia and the United States. He took equal pleasure in unraveling the intricacies of Chinese history and the complexities of international finance. Jack spoke Chinese and Japanese with elegance, precision and wit, informed by years of classical study and practical negotiation. A Ming specialist and talented Chinese linguist with a PhD from Princeton, where he studied under the legendary Fritz Mote, Jack was Professor and Chairman of the History Department at Bowdoin College before embarking on a successful career as an investment banker. Jack held several senior positions with J.P. Morgan and Morgan Stanley in Asia, including Managing Director of J.P. Morgan (China) and Chairman of Morgan Stanley Properties (China). Combining his experience in finance and fluency in Mandarin, Jack served on the board of Directors of China's CITIC Bank, Shenzhen Development Bank, Bank of Nanjing, Bank of Shanghai, and the Agricultural Bank of China - one of the first and very few foreigners to do so. His discreet advice was valued by finance and treasury officials in both Beijing and Washington. He most recently served as Vice Chairman of Global Strategic Associates in New York. Jack continued work as a scholar during his finance career, contributing his deep knowledge of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) to the Cambridge History of China, presenting academic papers, and teaching a course at Princeton University. His gracious and subtle scholarship appealed to his colleagues and students, while his gentle humor and quiet integrity endeared him to his many friends on both sides of the Pacific. Funeral Services are private. There will however, be a celebration of Jack's life at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please send all memorial donations in Jack's name to The Pulmonary Education Fund, Lennox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th Street, New York, NY 10075. For further details please send emails to drJDL123@gmail.com or mail c/o Ms. Kano Mitchell, Global Strategic Associates, LLC, 445 Park Avenue, 10th floor, New York, NY 10022.

WILSON--John Hill Tucker, a leading investment banker who spent 33 years with Morgan Stanley before beginning a second, and equally distinguished, 17 year career in public service and philanthropy, died on August 12, 2010 at his home in Greenwich, CT after a valiant, five year battle with cancer. He was 76. Throughout his life Mr. Wilson distinguished himself through force of intellect, boundless energy, innate leadership, extraordinary sense of humor and, most importantly, kindness and concern for family and friends. These qualities made him one of the most successful and productive citizens of his generation. At Morgan Stanley, Mr. Wilson was a Managing Director, serving in many capacities, including Head of the Financial Institutions Group and Co-Head of the Investment Banking Division. During his 33 year (1960-1993) career with the firm his clients included many of the major corporate enterprises of the country. In 2005, he was one of the so-called "Group of Eight," former senior executives of Morgan Stanley and significant shareholders who organized to express their concern over the leadership, governance and direction of the firm. Mr. Wilson's charitable endeavors included his service as Trustee, and for five years Chairman, of Environmental Defense, a leading advocate for environmental causes. He also served as Trustee of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation, Chairman of the Union Settlement Association in East Harlem, Chairman of Board of Trustees of Greenwich Hospital (Greenwich, CT), Chairman of Board of Trustees of Brunswick School (Greenwich, CT), Advisory Board Member of the Princeton University Environmental Institute, and a Co-Founder and Director and Officer of Classroom, Inc., an NGO that developed innovative technologically based teaching methods for use in public schools nationally. In 1962, Mr. Wilson married Sandra Wilson (no relation) of Rye, NY. This marriage of almost five decades was a fortress of love, strength and support not only for themselves but for their children, grandchildren and the exceptionally large number of friends this union touched through their 48 years together. Mr. Wilson will be remembered particularly for the care and support he gave to his wife, family, friends and the community through and despite the health challenges of recent years and his remarkable ability to find contentment, even happiness, in the most challenging of circumstances. Mr. Wilson was born on May 24, 1934 in Charlotte, NC. He graduated in 1956 from Princeton University, with a B.A. degree in history, magna cum laude, and a Phi Beta Kappa key. He was a Baker Scholar at Harvard Business School, graduating in 1960. He served in U.S. Army Intelligence from 1956 to 1958. Sandra survives Mr. Wilson, as do his four children, Tucker, Will, Emily and David, and ten grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on September 24, 2010 at 12 noon at the Round Hill Community Church located at 395 Round Hill Road in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, please direct donations to any of his causes referenced above.

SPENTTHRIFT/ (spentthrift) /n. / A neologism used to describe voluptuaries who are unwilling to conceal their love of luxury and shopping [see also ''frugality fatigue''], as in, ''Call me a spentthrift, but I'm tired of penny-pinching and shopping my closet.'' PHILOGYNY/ (fi läj$(4$) e ne) /n. / Admiration for women; moth-eaten academic jargon that has come out of the closet to emerge as fashion rhetoric in a season in which designers worshiped at the altar of womanly curves, e.g., ''The Bardot-inspired collection was philogyny incarnate -- Marc Jacobs couldn't have proclaimed his love of women any louder had he jumped on Oprah's couch and screamed it.''

NETREBA--Sydney S.,passed away peacefully in Millbrae, CA on August 14, 2010 at the age of 91. Born in Pennsylvania on December 4, 1918, grew up in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Abraham Lincoln High School. He earned a B.S. from City College of NY in 1940. He served in the U.S. Army Air Corps and saw heavy battle in the South Pacific during WW II. After the war, he earned a doctorate in economics from Johns Hopkins University. During his long career in the financial field, he was a partner first at Kuhn, Loeb & Co. and then at Bear Stearns in New York and closed his professional career with Robert C. Brown & Co. in San Francisco. Together with his wife, Mildred Dubrow Netreba, who pre-deceased him in 2000, and daughter Laurie, who pre-deceased him in 1998, he was a long term resident of Atherton, CA. He is survived by many nieces, nephews, grand-nieces, and grand-nephews. Dearly loved by his many friends and former colleagues for his intellect, kindness quick wit and plethora of talents, he will be sorely missed. His memory will forever remain in our hearts. Funeral services are to be private.

LILIENFELD--Frances, nee Weissler, born May 24, 1915. Beloved companion of Curtis Kelley. Adored mother of Elizabeth, Linda and Amy. Cherished grandmother of Benjamin, Jordan, and Asa. Beautiful great-grandmother of Jessica, Tali, and Eathen. Daughter of Annie and Abraham. Sister of Irving and Manny (deceased). Widow of Dr. Jack Lilienfeld. She was known as "Frantic Fran". One of the few ideas for cutting Social Security benefits that seems to have bipartisan support is raising the normal retirement age to perhaps 70. (It has recently risen to 66 for people born after 1942, and it will rise to 67 for people born after 1959.) Because such an age increase would need to be phased in over a long period, it doesn't generate as much opposition as other cost-saving measures or tax increases. The problem is that hardly anyone retires at the normal retirement age. According to the Social Security Administration, 43 percent of men and 48 percent of women on Social Security in 2008 began drawing benefits at age 62. An additional 15 percent of men and women started at age 63 or 64. In short, about two-thirds of those eligible are retiring before the normal retirement age.
Television Ginia Bellafante

Before there was HGTV, there was Gaetano Pesce, the legendary Italian architect and designer who once espoused the joys of D.I.Y. in a column for French Elle and actually made good on it. His 1972 Golgotha chair, part of the permanent collection at MoMA, was the first of his many forays into the world of mass customization: its Dacron-filled seat assumed different shapes depending on who sat on it. Now, another clever bit of personalization: Pesce's new shoe for the Brazilian company Melissa -- an ankle bootie composed of interconnected PVC circles, whose form can change at the whim of its owner with a swift slice of the scissors. Cut once, and the boot becomes a bootie; cut again, and it's a ballet flat, a peep toe, a sandal or even a flip-flop. ''This is the future of mass production,'' Pesce says. ''With the technology we have today, we can give people something that is half done and ask them to finish it.'' Go to melissashoes.com.br JILL SINGER
Classical Anthony Tommasini

8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS JR.John Lithgow hosts this summer edition of must-see films for young viewers, which ends for the season with a double bill starring the English actor John Mills. The tribute beings with Disney's ''Swiss Family Robinson'' (1960), based on the book by Johann Wyss, in which Mills portrays the patriarch of a family (above, from left, Tommy Kirk, Dorothy McGuire, Mills and James MacArthur) en route to New Guinea. The family members build a new life -- and an enormous treehouse -- after they're shipwrecked on a tropical island. At 10:15 in ''The Rocking Horse Winner'' (1949), adapted by Anthony Pelissier from the short story by D. H. Lawrence, Mills plays a former stable boy turned handyman to an upper-class London family in financial ruins. The family's 10-year-old (John Howard Davies) discovers that he can pick winning race horses by riding his hobby horse into a furious frenzy. Valerie Hobson is the boy's extravagant mother, who spends the money as fast as her son makes it. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour interviews President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan.

KULKWITZER SEE, NEAR LEIPZIG, GERMANY, JULY 10, 2010 Each summer, I leave my hometown of Tucson in search of cooler climes. Last year's summer refuge in Portland, Ore., delivered 106 degrees for three days, so this summer, with the euro down, I decided to rent an apartment with my partner in Leipzig, Germany. Alas, the usually mild summer in Germany arrived with a blast this year. The day I shot this picture, it was in the mid-90s. In fact, it was hotter than Tucson, and virtually nobody has air-conditioning in Leipzig. Our apartment didn't even have a fan. Rather than stay at home with wet towels over our heads, we headed to the lake to sit in the shade and soak in the cool water of Kulkwitzer, an old mine turned into a lake. At sunset, we went in for one last dip, promising not to leave until we were shivering cold. David A. Gilmore, Tucson

Viktor & Rolf What wild things have the Dutch designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren done with makeup? For their controversial ''Black Hole'' show in 2001 (center), they covered their models -- and themselves -- in black. And in 2003, they commissioned the makeup maestro Peter Philips to paint a patchwork of past collections onto a naked Maggie Rizer (above) -- a kind of retrospective en maquillage. (A look from fall 2010 is at far left.) Now, given the chance to riff on our logo, they had the makeup artist Val Garland slap a giant ''T'' on the face of the golden blond model Jessica Stam, whom the megawatt photographer Nick Knight then photographed (''Fresh Paint,'' Page 179). As with most of the duo's creative decision-making, coming up with this concept was a case of tea -- or make that T -- for two. ''We are control freaks,'' Snoeren says. ''Everything we decide together, in harmony.''

Representing South Florida in Congress, I regularly hold town meetings with retirees. Inevitably, the first question from the crowd is one I often ask myself, ''Why are folks in Washington lying about Social Security?'' There is a bizarre consensus that dismantling this cherished program by raising the retirement age or cutting benefits would somehow fix the federal budget. But that would only inflict harm on the millions of Americans who rely on Social Security to survive.

Over the next two decades, 78 million Americans will quit working, quit paying into the Social Security system and start drawing benefits, straining the resources of our public pension system. Is there a way to persuade them to stay in the labor force -- continuing to contribute their skills and talent -- and postpone their Social Security payments?

MATTHEWS--Marie Lewis, 79, of Princeton, NJ died Wednesday, August 18, 2010 in the University Medical Center at Princeton. She is survived by her husband of 56 years, Edward Matthews of Princeton; one daughter Louise Matthews Flickinger of Winnetka, Illinois; three sons, Gregory Matthews of Princeton, Douglas Matthews of Mendham, New Jersey and Russell Matthews of Redondo Beach, California and twelve grandchildren. Marie graduated from the University of California-Berkeley and also received a Masters in Education from Goucher College, Towson, Maryland. After teaching elementary school for four years after graduation, she retired to raise her growing family. An accomplished nature photographer, she was also very active in philanthropic affairs. Marie was trustee of the Mothers 2 Mothers Program, a renowned AIDS prevention program in Africa, a trustee of the Lymphoma Research Foundation and a trustee of the Corner House Foundation. She was also a member of the Library Advisory Committee of the University of California-Berkeley. She was a past trustee of the McCarter Theatre Center and Princeton Day School. Funeral services have been made by the Kimble Funeral Home of Princeton. The funeral and burial will be private and limited to family members. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to either Friends of the Mothers Programmes, the University of California-Berkeley Foundation for the Benefit of California Alumni Association Scholarship Fund or the Princeton Health Care System Foundation.

MOORE--Martha Bennett, a longtime resident of Bronx-ville, NY, passed away peacefully at age 87 on August 15, 2010. Ms. Moore had been married for 46 years to the late Dr. Ivan Bennett, Jr., former Dean of New York University School of Medicine. She subsequently was married for eight years to the late Harrison Moore of Bronxville. An active figure in Bronxville civic life, Ms. Moore served as President of the Bronxville League of Women Voters and was an active Member of the Board of the United Nations Association of Westchester County. She had also been Director of an after-school youth program at Forest Hills Community Center in Queens, New York. Ms. Moore was born Martha Rhodes in Atlanta, Georgia, where she graduated from Agnes Scott College. She went on to earn a masters degree from the Bank Street College of Education in New York. As her health deteriorated, Ms. Moore spent the last year of her life in Palo Alto, CA in the loving care of her daughter, Katherine Evans. In addition to Katherine, Ms. Moore is survived by her brother, Robert C. Rhodes of Arkadelphia, AR, and by her other three children, Susan Anderson of Baltimore, Paul Bennett of New York, and Dr. Jeffrey Bennett of Springfield, IL. Martha is also survived by six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In addition, she is survived by Christopher Moore of Charlotte, NC, Harrison's son by a previous marriage. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to be sent in Ms. Moore's memory to the Community Unitarian Church of White Plains, NY. A memorial will be held at the church at 1pm on September 12, 2010. The address is 468 Rosedale Ave., White Plains, NY, 10605.

Consider the Polaroid picture. When taken by a great artist, does it somehow become more than just a dull and grainy impression? Last year, this question prompted a shouting match on The Moment, with readers arguing about the artistic merit of a series of Andy Warhol Polaroids shown at Danziger Projects. Now the artist and filmmaker Julian Schnabel shows us his own Polaroids in a new book by Prestel creatively titled “Julian Schnabel: Polaroids.” In addition to shots of his Montauk, N.Y., studio, his family and a series of rephotographed late-19th-century images called “Crazy People,” Schnabel pointed his rare 1970s-era Polaroid camera at Lou Reed, Placido Domingo, Christopher Walken, the Beastie Boys and Mickey Rourke. The book comes out Sept. 1 and is already on sale via Amazon.com.

The dark ’n’ stormy has become a cult highball due to a felicitous combination of its no-fault simplicity and the balance of its exotic, headstrong ingredients, each of which is perfectly suited to the common goal: reviving the flagging, heat-pummeled constitution. It is simply dark rum — very dark rum — with ginger beer and some fresh lime. The rich spirit is shaken awake by the buoyant piquancy of the ginger beer, while the lime slashes through the sweetness of both.
One in five teenagers suffer from at least slight hearing loss, a marked increase from a decade ago, according to a study reported in today’s Vital Signs column.

In 1959, when Robert A. McCabe ventured to Antarctica as a freelance photojournalist, there were no rules against handling penguins and seals. So when an emperor penguin wandered onto McMurdo Base, Mr. McCabe and his cohorts put the almost three-foot-tall bird on a bar for snapshots. At Cape Royds, he photographed a man holding a diminutive Adélie penguin under its wings as if it were a toddler. Another photograph shows a man about to pet a seal pup.

The irrational economic exuberance of the 1990s and 2000s has been rightly criticized for creating overheated markets and overextended pocketbooks, particularly in housing. That money, especially in luxury apartment towers, promoted a group of designers who emerged largely in the wake of postmodernism and who brought an unprecedented level of futuristic glamor to domestic lifestyles. Think Frank Gehry, Jean Nouvel and Herzog & de Meuron, people referred to, derisively or not, as "starchitects."

The bailed-out insurer American International Group confirmed on Monday that it had paid back nearly $4 billion in government loans in its single largest cash payment so far to reduce its debt to taxpayers, Reuters reports.

More than 30 new coal-fired power plants have been built since 2008 or are under construction, representing the coal power industry's largest expansion in decades. "Building a coal-fired power plant today is betting that we are not going to put a serious financial cost on emitting carbon dioxide," an energy policy expert says. [Associated Press]

In an interview with the Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet on Monday, Sweden's chief prosecutor, Eva Finne, said that she expects to make a decision about whether or not to charge the founder of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, with the crime of molestation or harassment this week, "hopefully tomorrow."

The philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad has selected the architecture firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro to design a museum for his contemporary art collection on Grand Avenue in downtown Los Angeles, Mr. Broad and his wife Edythe announced on Monday. The museum also received its last round of public approvals on Monday when the Grand Avenue Authority, a panel of city and county officials, approved a plan to lease 2.5 acres of county-owned land to Mr. Broad.

In another reminder how far the real estate market has fallen from its frothy peak, this week's Appraisal column explores how buyers, sellers and renters are taking their anger out on real estate brokers. Sellers are demanding that brokers clean their apartments and change their sheets before open houses. Buyers are demanding that brokers tell coop boards how long their interviews will last. Renters are just engaging in full-fledged arguments with brokers.

Prosecutors have arrested a top official in Egypt's culture ministry and some museum security guards pending an investigation into the theft of a van Gogh painting over the weekend, Reuters reported. The painting, a depiction of a vase filled with yellow poppies, known as "Poppy Flowers" or "Vase and Flowers" and valued at more thanr $50 million, remains missing after it was stolen Saturday from the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum in Giza, where none of the alarms and only some of the security cameras were working at the time. Egypt's minister of culture, Farouk Hosni, retracted an announcement that the painting was recovered at the Cairo airport, saying the announcement was based on faulty information.

What started with some comfortable ski wear for his girlfriend grew into one of the world's first fashion lifestyle houses. From bathing suits to bath towels, if there was a need, Pucci sought to fill it in print.

Nascar began running the three races 15 years ago.

The homecoming leg of Fischerspooner's recent tour found Casey and the gang at the Highline Ballroom on Aug. 12. Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce. There are several things that you have to be very conscious of when planning a food shoot. The first thing I do, almost without fail, is look at a weather report. Like surfers, baseball managers and airline pilots, you will become an amateur meteorologist when you commit to a food photo shoot. I prefer to shoot in daylight whenever possible, and the quality of that light is obviously a major factor.

Four years ago Spike Lee took his cameras to New Orleans to document the disaster wrought by Hurricane Katrina in 2005, as told by the people still dealing with its calamitous effects. The film Mr. Lee returned with was "When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts," a four-hour HBO documentary that won a Peabody Award and three Emmys. So as the fifth anniversary of Katrina approached, Mr. Lee went back to New Orleans this year, hoping to tell the story of that city's recovery and rejuvenation, starting with the Super Bowl victory of its underdog New Orleans Saints football team.

The default layout of the Windows 7 Start menu is designed to give you quick access to the most-used folders on the PC. If you'd prefer to see the contents of those folders in a submenu instead of having Windows pop open a whole new window, just right-click the Start Menu button and choose Properties. In the box that appears, click on the Start Menu tab and then on the Customize button.
