Anyone who has spent time in Madrid knows that Madrileños don't like to go to bed, preferring to walk the streets with friends and hang out in cafes, restaurants and clubs until the sun comes up. So, it seems only natural that the city should treat its citizens, and visitors, to an all-night celebration of contemporary art and culture. Planned to coincide with the full moon, White Night in Madrid, takes place on Sept. 11.

ALEXANDER--R. Bernard The family of Bernie Alexander mourns his death, at age 92, on August 11, 2010, in Kennett Square, PA. Husband of 64 years of Eleanor Jane (Teedie) Alexander, who died April 2, 2009; father of Joan Leonhardt of Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY, Steve Alexander of North Ferrisburgh, VT, and Polly Alexander of Essex Junction, VT; father-in-law of Bob Leonhardt and Kathy Alexander; grandfather of David Leonhardt (married to Laura), Robin Leonhardt Peterson (married to Eric), Tyler Nash, and Maria, Jackson and Daisy Alexander; great-grandfather of four. Bernie had a distinguished career at Business Week magazine, where he became Advertising Sales Director and eventually Publisher. He was born in Philadelphia and also lived in New Canaan, CT, and Avalon, NJ.

We've all been there. Fresh out of the dentist office after a little procedure that leaves us numb in the jaw or tipsy from laughing gas, or both. But most of us didn't have our parents there to capture it on video as David DeVore did. You may recall David, who is now 9, from a 2009 YouTube video that showed him in an anesthesia-induced haze, his head bobbing, asking his father ''Is this real life?'' and at one point, screaming at the top of his lungs. It didn't take long for David to become viral-video famous, with 65 million views. There has to be a way to capitalize on that, right?

NEHRING--Janet (Jay), 60, died August 16, 2010. Beloved daughter of Virginia and the late Richard Nehring; loving sister of Ginger Miller-Jones (Bob), Carol Phinizy (Coles), and Tom Nehring (Amy); and a favorite aunt and great-aunt to numerous nieces and nephews. Graduated from Arcadia University with a BFA, Jay was a copywriter for Ogilvy and Mather in NYC before moving to Australia where she continued her award-winning work in advertising. Taken too soon, Jay will be missed by family and friends. A service will be held at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Amityville on August 28. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to the American Cancer Society.

OXENBERG--Henry, died at age 98, August 20, 2010 in Atlantic City, NJ. Born in Philadelphia, PA, son of Jacob and Blima (Marcus). A resourceful and creative businessman, he and his wife, Sylvia, founded, and for twenty-five years, operated the successful Boardwalk leather goods store, J.S. Briggs, ltd., in Atlantic City. He is survived by his brother Morris, daughter Judith Rubin and her husband, Robert, grandson James Rubin and his wife, Gretchen, grandson Philip Rubin and his wife, Lauren, and great-grandchildren Eliza, Eleanor and Henry. Graveside service will be held 11am, Tuesday, August 24th at Beth Israel Cemetery, Black Horse Pike, Egg Harbor Township, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Shore Memorial Health Foundation, 1 East New York Avenue, Somers Point, NJ 08244. Services byRoth-Goldsteins' Memorial Chapel, Atlantic City, NJ. www.rothgoldsteins.com

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about plans for Betty White to write two books, including one about animals, misstated her role with the Los Angeles Zoo. She is on the board of trustees of the Greater Los Angeles Zoo Association, which is the private, nonprofit organization that supports the city-owned Los Angeles Zoo. Ms. White is not a board member of the Los Angeles Zoo.

(Lifetime) BOND OF SILENCE (2010) Kim Raver, below, portrays Katy McIntosh, who is confronted by a shroud of secrecy after her husband, Bob (David Cubitt), is murdered while trying to calm a raucous teenage house party on New Year's Eve. This made-for-television movie is based on a 1997 homicide in Squamish, British Columbia, which resulted in Ms. McIntosh's meeting -- and eventually forgiving -- Ryan Aldridge, the young man who killed her husband, as part of a restorative justice process. Now remarried and using the name Katy Hutchison, she has recounted her experiences before some 400,000 people at schools, prisons and community groups, sometimes alongside Mr. Aldridge, who received a five-year sentence for manslaughter in 2002. 6 A.M. It is Konkani, not Konkanese.

KHAKOO--Dr. Yusuf M.,died August 12, 2010 at home in Bronx, NY, aged 74. One of nine children, he was born in Pemba, in the Zanzibar archipelago of present-day Tanzania. After secondary school, he immigrated to India to study at the prestigious Elphinstone College and Grant Medical College, both in Bombay. There he met Hamida, his wife of 42 years and also a physician, who predeceased him in May 2004. Since the early 1970s, he worked at Harlem Hospital, specializing in the treatment of children with sickle cell disease. He was dedicated to, and deeply loved by, his patients and their families. He was on the faculty of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, educating generations of medical students. Besides his family and Mets baseball, his enduring passions were for things outdoors. He was a skilled fisherman and gardener, an extension of a childhood spent on the hills and shores of Zanzibar. He was a beloved member of the Shia Ithna-Asheri Jamaat of New York, where he served his Islamic community when called upon. He was a devoted father and doting grandfather. He is survived by a daughter and two sons: Yasmin Khakoo and husband Robert Fisher; Aashik Khakoo and wife Jillian Hiris; and Aarif Khakoo and wife Shibani Pati. He will be sorely missed by seven grandchildren: Alex, Anika, Manisha, Wesley, Aliya, Cullin, and Thelonious. He leaves behind a brother, Sherali, of Milton Keynes, UK.

GOLD--Honey, (Annette), on August 20, 2010. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Abe Gold and Ralph Hirschberg. Caring and loving mother of Peggy Noonan Foster and her husband Dennis Foster, cherished son Steven Hirschberg and his wife Rada Salomon, adored grandson Bran Noonan the light of her life and his fiance' Jill Gardiner. Many devoted nieces and nephews and grand-nieces and nephews of her deceased brothers and sisters. As honorary vice president Honey's dedication to N.C.J.W. was all consuming, she held every office except the presidency. She cared for her devoted friends and they for her. Services to be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Tuesday, August 24 at 11am. Contributions can be made in Honey's honor for N.C.J.W., 820 2nd Ave, New York City, 10017 would be appreciated.

For the youngest group of mobile device users, those ages 13 to 17, the largest increase from June 2009 to June 2010 was in the percentage of users who visited a social networking site or a blog. This group and the next oldest, users 18 to 24, have fairly similar tastes and experiences. Together they make up just over 20 percent of all users. Compared with all users, 13- to 24-year-olds are 20 percent more likely to text, and 10 percent more likely to play games or visit social networks on their cellphones. SHELLY FREIERMAN

BAIN--Seymour Milo, on August 19, 2010 at the age of 92. Resident of Scarborough, NY and former long time resident of Hartsdale, NY. Owner of S. Milo Bain Advertising Design Studio, NYC. Survived by wife Roslyn, one niece and three nephews. Services were held on August 22, 2010 at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Family will be receiving friends at the Scarborough residents during the afternoons from August 23 to August 28. John G. Crawford Funeral Director 914-747-2515.

VERONIS--Peter, 87, died peacefully on August 20. He was married for 57 years to Dorothy (Babs) White, who died in 2004, and is survived by his daughter Judith Anne Rodgers, son-in-law Philip Rodgers, step-grandchildren Dina Weitz and Suellen Rodgers, and four siblings, Mary Thompson, George (Kim), John (Lauren) and Reverend Alexander (Pearl) Veronis. In 1941 he joined the U.S. Navy which he served for 10 years, during which time he became Chief Petty Officer on the battleship USS North Carolina and participated in major battles in the Pacific. After his honorable discharge he attended Columbia University from 1951-1954 while working in advertising for the Springfield Newspapers. Subsequently he became an advertising sales executive at Ridder Johns Co. and Look magazine before becoming Vice-President, Advertising Director of Psychology Today magazine and later Saturday Review. In 1973-1980 he served as Publisher of Book Digest magazine. Later, he created the CBS Magazine advertising network. Funeral services will be held 11am Wednesday, preceded by a 10am viewing at Archangels Greek Orthodox Church, 1527 Bedford Street, Stamford, CT. 06905 (1-203-348-4216). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders, Habitat for Humanity or Archangels Greek Orthodox Church.

MARSHALL--Robert H.,passed away peacefully in El Paso, Texas, on August 20, 2010, at the age of 87. During World War II he served as a military intelligence interpreter doing liaison work with French counter-intelligence units as a member of the 6th Armored Division in the combat campaigns in Normandy and Northern France. After the war, he earned his B.A. from Columbia University and his M.A. from Johns Hopkins, and pursued an advanced degree at Harvard. He retired in White Plains in 1988 after having served 35 years as a valued leader at IBM Corporation. He is survived by his brother, Richard T. Marshall of El Paso, and his niece, Abigail Marshall, and nephew, Stanley Marshall, of California. His memory will be treasured by his many friends and former colleagues. A graveside service will be held at 10am Tuesday, August 24, 2010, at Ft. Bliss National Cemetery, El Paso, Texas. Donations in his honor may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, P.O. Box 96011, Washington, D.C. Services entrusted to Martin Funeral Home West, 128 N. Resler Dr., El Paso, TX 79912, MartinFuneralHomeWest.com

FARRELL--Mell W. The family of Mell Farrell mourns his death at age 50, on August 21st, 2010 in East Northport, NY. Beloved husband of Patricia and caring father to William, Patrick, Meghan and Jillian. Dear son of Mell and Janet and cherished brother of Tom. Fond son-in-law of Karen and John Cordes. Co-proprietor of Pierpont Mechanical and known in the New York City construction industry as an innovator in the execution of complex projects involving mechanical systems. Mell's pride and joy was his family and he organized countless family outings including annual trips to football games at the University of Notre Dame where he had a passion for the school's football program. Deeply cherished and loved by his family and many friends. Visiting will be Monday and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport. Funeral mass Wednesday, 11am at St. Francis of Assisi RC Church, Greenlawn. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to PANCAN; www.pancan.org

NEW YORK (AP) -- Harold Dow, the Emmy-winning CBS News correspondent who helped shape the documentary program ''48 Hours'' and covered the kidnapping of Patricia Hearst and the Sept. 11 attacks, died Saturday. He was 62. Mr. Dow died suddenly Saturday morning in New Jersey, a network spokeswoman, Louise Bashi, said. He lived in Upper Saddle River, N.J., but it wasn't immediately clear if he had been at home. The cause of death was not announced.

This has been a summer of upheaval at the top of the leading home and design magazines. In June, Paige Rense, who has led Architectural Digest since the 1970s, said she was stepping down at the end of August. To fill her shoes, Conde Nast, the magazine's publisher, hired Margaret Russell, editor of Elle Decor, Architectural Digest's chief rival.

An article on Friday about the First Niagara Financial Group's pending acquisition of NewAlliance Bancshares misspelled part of the name of the firm of Chris McGratty, a banking analyst who commented on the merger. It is Keefe, Bruyette & Woods -- not Keffe. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the location of First Niagara's headquarters. It is Buffalo, not Lockport, N.Y.

EDGARTOWN, Mass. - Gene Mulak, the golf pro at the Vineyard Golf Club on Martha's Vineyard, does not know how many golf lessons President Obama has taken. But Mulak is certain he was the first to tutor him on his bunker play. And Mulak is certain Obama needed the help. Obama played at the Vineyard Golf Club twice last summer and again last week while on vacation. The club, which is believed to be the only entirely organic golf course in America, also features treacherous, British Isles-style bunkers.

WASHINGTON -- President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan acknowledged Sunday for the first time that he had personally intervened to free a top political aide who had been detained on graft charges by two American-backed Afghan anticorruption units. The aide, Mohammed Zia Saleh, head of administration for Afghanistan's National Security Council, was arrested in late July after investigators wiretapped Mr. Saleh apparently soliciting bribes from a money exchange operation.

Somali insurgents disguised in government military uniforms stormed a Mogadishu hotel on Tuesday and killed at least 30 people, including six lawmakers, Jeffrey Gettleman reported. The insurgents methodically moved room to room, killing hotel guests who tried to bolt their doors shut. The attack laid bare the vulnerability of Somalia's government, even in an area it claims to control.

TORONTO - Amazing was the word Alex Rodriguez used to describe the Yankees' success without him in the lineup. And it is amazing. Before losing, 3-2, Monday night to the Blue Jays, the Yankees had won all 12 games this season in which Rodriguez did not play. So much has to go right for a team to win one game that, one might think, something wouldn't go its way over the course of 12. But nothing did, and here are a few reasons the Yankees were able to thrive in a Rodriguez-less world:

I have started looking for a new apartment. Within 48 hours, I became that clichéd New Yorker, addicted to real estate Web sites and printing floor plans out to rearrange them into my perfect apartment; I even bought a printer on Sunday so that I could print them at home! There are few things that I like more than redesigning spaces on the back on an envelope, creating rooms with little squares that represent sofas and end tables, and imagining scenes of afternoons and evenings with people popping over, and dinners being cooked in a kitchen that was once a closet and second bathroom, and which is now a place where herbs are chopped and corks are pulled from bottles.

The name comes from the ancient kingdom of the Medes.

When I tell people I am going to Rwanda, I usually get the "are you kidding me?" look.  Most people in the West have come to know Rwanda through its bloody civil war; more than 800,000 people were killed there in 1994, marking one of the most infamous genocides of modern history.  Apart from this sad event, however, very little is known about contemporary Rwanda and the people who live within its borders.

A couple of years ago, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration established a "Climate Scene Investigation" strike team tasked with quickly assessing the causes of extreme events -- mega downpours, off-the-chart heat waves and the like. One goal is to gauge any contribution from the global buildup of human-generated greenhouse gases. I'll soon be interviewing Martin Hoerling, the climate scientist who heads this effort, but I wanted to highlight the team's latest product, an incredibly thorough post mortem on the Russian heat wave, posted on August 13. A new reality series ordered by the G4 cable channel may not have the pedigree of the director Kathryn Bigelow or much chance of toppling James Cameron's "Avatar" at major awards shows, but it shares other key details with "The Hurt Locker," Ms. Bigelow's Oscar-winning feature about an American bomb squad in Iraq. The Hollywood Reporter said G4 had committed to 10 episodes of "Bomb Patrol: Afghanistan," which will document a Navy Explosive Ordnance Disposal unit as it trains in the United States and is deployed in the war zone. Neal Tiles, the president of G4, told The Hollywood Reporter that the show provides "a rare opportunity to showcase the work of the courageous men and women on the front lines" and would also connect with the young male viewers already tuning in to G4 programs like "Attack of the Show!" Mr. Tiles said, "Both G4 and the Navy like this for the same reason: It appeals to the tech side of G4's demographic." "Bomb Patrol: Afghanistan" is planned for a spring debut.

When the journal Science published an attention-grabbing study last fall linking chronic fatigue syndrome to a recently discovered retrovirus, many experts remained skeptical -- especially after four other studies found no such association. Now a second research team has reported a link between the fatigue syndrome and the same class of virus, a category known as MRV-related viruses. In a paper published Monday by The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, scientists found gene sequences from several MRV-related viruses in blood cells from 32 out of 37 chronic-fatigue patients but only 3 of 44 healthy ones.

WEEKS--Louis Seabury Jr.,born February 17, 1918, died in Stonington, Connecticut, August 21st. He is survived by his wife Terry, his children Kip (and Chris), Ann (and Arleen), Louis (and Margie), and his grandchildren Sam, Meg, Louis, Neile, and Teddy. He was the son of Isabel Coxe and Louis Seabury Weeks. His sister was the late Ann Weeks Tilney. He is also survived by his brother, Howard of Alstead, New Hampshire. He graduated from Brooks School in 1936, Princeton University in 1940, and Columbia Law School in 1946 where he was a member of St. Anthony Hall. He was a partner in the New York law firm of Beekman and Bogue for 30 years. There will be a memorial service in Calvary Church, Stonington, CT, Saturday, August 28 at 3pm. Please omit flowers.
